editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: CORDERIVS DIALOGVES TRANSLATED Grammatically.
For the more speedy attaining to the knowledge of the Latine tongue, for writing and speaking Latine.
Done chiefly for the good of Schooles, to be used according to the Direction set downe in the Booke called Ludus Literarius, or The Grammar-schoole.
LONDON, Printed by A. Griffin, for Andrew H • bbe at the Signe of the Bell in Saint Pauls Church-yard. 1636.

opener.salute: TO THE RIGHT HONORABLE VVILLIAM, Lord CAVENDISH, Baron of Hardwicke, All grace and Happinesse.

div.p:
RIght Noble Lord, your favourable approbation of my School-indeavouvs, together with your honorable bounty, for the incouraging of me, to the accomplishment of my promise for my Grammaticall
translations, have imboldned me to dedicate this little labour unto your Lordship. And so much the rather, for that I hope, it being used aright, according to the directions given in my booke called Ludus Literarius, or the Grammar-schoole, shall give a full demonstration of whatsoever I have written therein, concerning the commodity of such like translations (so farre as the matter hereof doth extend it selfe) to make the way to the Latine tongue, most easie and full of all pleasant allurement, when once the common grounds of the Accedence are gotten, with a perfect readines in the examples of the Nounes and Verbes, which may soone be effected, by the help in the Posing of the Accedence and Grammar. So as the benefit of these may not only redound unto our common Country-schools,
but happily (and as I unfainedly wish) unto many in all places, who either having had but some little smattering in Latin, or having lost that which they had therein, are desirous to repaire the same. And more specially to our debauched youth, to helpe to retire some of them, to the sweete and pleasant delights, which are to be found in good studies, & the best aut • ors, from their disordered courses, wherein they so generally and wholly runne themselves out of all; mispending their talents, both time and patrimony, to their utter perdition, in all kinde of strange riot, and outragious excesse; without any further consideration, either of the end why they were borne, or wherefore those pre • ious talents of time, wit, and good ability, were cōmitted unto them: or so much as of that dreadfull account,
which they must every one give up for the same: never bethinking thēselves, that the Lord hath not put this price into their hands, to be so consumed in spending dayes, nights, and yeares, yea their whole lives, in drinking, gaming, swearing, revelling, and all manner of outrage, worse then ever did the Heathen; but to be otherwise imployed, even to buy wisedome,Pro. 16.17. as Salomon doth tell them; to the advancing and perpetuall upholding of his true Religion and service, every one for his ability, by himselfe and all others; to have wherewith not onely to maintaine, but also to better their estate, with all those who do depend vpon them. And so generally to the performance of every holy duty, which hee requires at all our hands; yea to live in such imployment, as may most te • d to
the adorning of our holy profession of the glorious Gospell of Iesus Christ, and the comfort of our owne soules, with the good of all others. Thus undoubtedly must our accounts bee made: and to whom more hath beene committed, must more bee looked for at their hands. Wherefore proceed (most worthy Lord) in this your noble care, to further for your part all those good meanes by which the Church of God may ever prosper, and all good learning and vertue (the chiefe pillars and ornaments both of Church and Common-wealth) may flourish more and more. That your selfe, with your noble progeny, may be blessed in the earth, and you (ever ready to give up a happy account of your stuardship) to be taken up into everlasting habitation, to live in blisse eternally: Whereunto I
shall ever strive for you, and to accomplish my service thus entred into for the common good of the present and all succeeding generations. And so in all humble thankfulnesse taking my leave, I commend your Lo▪ with your most vertuous Lady, and all your Noble familie, to his heavenly Grace, to perfect that good work, which he hath begunne, and rest

closer.signed: Your Lo▪ most humbly and thankefully devoted, I. BRINSLEY.

div.p:
THou art to bee admonished (good Reader,) that in this translation of Corderius, I haue referred into the Margents, all the Grammaticall constructions which cannot be uttered in our owne tongue, but by over-harsh phrases; and made references unto them most commonly with an asteriske or little starre. Least whil'st wee seeke to get Grammar and Latine, wee lose purity or propriety in our owne tongue, and bring in barbarisme in steade thereof. And therefore at each Asteriske, the learner is to be admonished, that ever in construing, parsing, or making Latin, out of this English translation, he forthwith cast his eye from the text unto the margent, to the like marke: yet so as that withall, hee ever in the second place, give phrase for phrase; viz. unto our English phrase, to give the like proper Latine
phrase, and so likewise in construing and parsing, or reading the English out of Latine: To the end to learne both Grammar and phrase, propriety and purity in both tongues together: and also for the more ready and full vnderstanding of the matter therein contained. This course I have upon good advice and triall, found most speedy, sure, and profitable. What is already done, with so great paines, and care, in weighing every word and phrase, and fitting them to these purposes, and that, as it were by houres stolne either from my sleepe or necessary recreations, in the midst of my continuall imployment in my calling, (which requireth a whole man,) accept in good part, and what is defective, future editions shall (God willing) supply. Vse it carefully and constantly, according to the directions in the Grammar-schoole: and try whether, by the blessings of th' almighty, it will not performe whatsoever is promised therein concerning it.

For the Coines, so oft mentioned in it, because they are French coines and differing from ours, I have advisd with sundry learned both of the French and English, skilfull
in the French tongue, and haue heere set them downe, according to their severall valuations in our coyne, so neere as we have beene able to judge; and ever in the booke likewise, so neere as I could conveniently. These here being first perfectly gotten, all in the booke will be very plaine.

As, with the French is called un-sould: short it is pronounced, a sou; which in Dutch called a stiiver; in Latine stiverus, or sestertius. And ten Dutch stivers make our E • glish shilling; so that a stiver is more then a penny. Thus As is taken commonly in French; though with the Romans it is taken otherwise. Calep.

Solidus with the French doth commonly signifie the same with As: yet sometimes solidus doth signifie a shilling with th • French, and six sowes make their shilling, as sixe stivers make a shilling in Dutch.
Semis is halfe of As or solidus; the French call semis, deux-liards, two farthings, though we cannot utter it just: for a lard is not just a farthing.
Quadrans is the fourth part of As, in French un-liard, somewhat more then a farthing.
Sextans is the s • xt part of As, in French un-double.
Decusses is ten Ass • s, in French dixsoulds, in Dutch ten stivers, in English a shilling. Though Calepine differ herein.
Denariolus is the twelfth part of As, in French un-denier.
Denarius is a cotne as much as ten denarioli, in French vn-carolus, about our penny, or somewhat more.

These are the principall coines here mentioned: what thou thinkest amisse in these, or any part hereof, or of any of my indeavours, signifie to me in courtesie: so thy love shall both much further and encourage mee to the accomplishing of the worke. Whereunto desiring with all the helpe of thy prayers, unto him whose all my travels, and thoughts are, I commend thee to his Grace, and rest

closer.signed: Thine so farre as his goodnesse shall inable. I. B.

div.head: FOURE BOOKES OF Maturine Corderie. Maturinus Corderius of talke meet for scholars, or scholarlike conferences or communications, Scholasticall Dialogues, for exercising children, or children to-be exercised. to exercise boyes Children by little and little daily, or common speech. in ordinarie talke.
The first Booke.
The first communication, or conference Dialogue.

stage.note: Bernard and Claudius. are the speakers, or the speakers are Bernard, Claudius.
O Bernard be thou safe also.

sp.speaker: CLaudius,
sp.p: God save thee.God speed thee Claudius.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
O Claudius, be thou safe. Godspeed thee too Bernard.
Bernard, God save thee likewise.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Let us play a little.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: O Thou little fond boy. thou foolish [boy] what sayest thou? Thou hast entered in scarsely into the schoole. Thou hast scarcely entered the Schoole,now talke, or talke already. and doest thou already speake of play?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I pray thee be not angry. Be not angry, I pray [thee.]

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I am not angry.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Therefore wh • dost thou cry out so? Why then dost thou exclaime so?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I accuse, or finde fault with. I blame thy foolishnesse.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: may we not play then? Is it not then lawfull to play?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yea we may, but when the time is fit. Yea, it is lawfull, but when time is.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Ou • , thou art wise overmuch, or too wise overwise.

sp.speaker: C.
B.
sp.p: Thou sayest [that which is] equall, reasonable, or right. well; I will also repeat with thee, if thou thinke good. if it I did speake. please thee.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Oh what is this?what this change so sodaine will to it selfe. what meaneth this so soda • ne change▪ diddest thou not speake even now concerning. of play?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I did speake. I spake indeed, but not in earnest.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Why did'st thou counter • eit. dissemble?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That I might confer. talke with thee in few▪ words. a little.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: what doth that profit. What good will that doe?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yea doest thou aske? hast thou never heard [it] of [our] master.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: It doth not run to me, or meet me now. not now come to my minde; [yet] I say, what doth it profit. good doth it to talke?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: for exercising us. To exercise u • . in speaking Latine▪ in the Latine tongue.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Truely thou thin • kest aright, or rightly. well, and I love thee the better for it. I now love thee more.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I have thanke to thee. I thanke thee; goe to, let us repeat our lesson, for [our] Master will bee present in a short space, presently. by and by.
God save you. O master. MAster, God save you.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: My Stephanio, be thou safe. God save thee: from whence com • mest thou so very early. so early?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Out of our chamber.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When hast thou risen. rose thou?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Master, a little before the sixt [houre.] sixe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What sayest thou?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: It is so as I say.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: thou hast risen too early. Thou art over-early; who hath awaked thee. who awaked thee?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: My brother.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hast thou called upon God, or beene at prayer. prayed to God?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I prayed as soone as my brother had Comb'd me, or made me ready. kembd mee.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How i •

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: My knees being bowed. Vpon my knees, and with my hands holden up. my hand, joyned together, I sayd the Lords prayer with thanksgiving. with giving of thanks.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: In what tongue?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: In English. In the English tongue.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: O well done, who sent thee unto mee?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: No man.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: what therfore. whereto camest thou. what then?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I came of mine owne accord.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: O my little sw • et soule. my little heart, how how faire▪ goodly a thing it is to be wise? Is it not time to breake thy fast?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I am not hungry as yet.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What wilt thou then?of breaking thy fast.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I will render▪ repeat our daily thy names nounces, if it please thee. you to heare mee.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: what bu • it should please mee. Wherefore should it not please mee? Therefore doest thou hold them in memory. Doest thou then remember them?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I hold them. I remember them, thanks [be] to God.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Goe to, say. pronounce.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: But you are wont to goe before mee in English, and I doe answer. to answer in Latine.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou admonishe • t [me] well. puttest me well in mind, I had forgot that almost. I had almost forgotten it: answer thou then.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I wait thae thou beginne, or purpose. I expect that you propound.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The head; the crowne. the top of the head; the forepart of the head; the hinder part of the head: now answer in English. The head; the top of the head; the forepart of the head; the hinder part of the head.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: what if thou sayes • them all alon, or by thy selfe. What if that thou now say all alone?all [the names.]

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I shall say [them] easily.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: truely I will heare thee gladly And I will heare thee willingly.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Caput, vertex, Sinciput, occiput. whether or no have I not said well. v Master have I not sayd well?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: the very best. Passing well.the Lord be praised, or let the Lord bee praised

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: eThe Lord God be praised.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: O goodly word O good speech! goe now to aske thy breakefast of the maide, girle.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Master I desire rather. I would rather take [it] of thee. of you, if I shall not be troublesome to you. if it be not troublesome to you.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
O how doe I love thee of, or cōcerning this word. for this speech • goe to, follow
mee, I will give thee something. some good thing, because thou hast done thy duty rightly well • what is this?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: White bread.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What are these things. these?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Dry figs.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: number, o • count them▪ Tell [them.]

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: One, two three, foure, five, sixe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Oh pleasant little head! now breake thy fast. eat thy breakfast all by leisure, or quietly. at thy leisure.
WIlt thou eat thy breakfast. breake thy fast with mee?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I have I have no breakfast not a breakfast.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: What? hast thou not brought thy breakfast. it? eaten my breakfast.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I had broken my fast at home.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Doest thou so alwaies?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Whether doest thou so ever. No; but because not at all. I rose I had risen. very early, it pleased my mother to well i • the morning. vse me so.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: handle. *ver. let it profit thee. Much good doe it thee. Therefore I will &c I then will eat my breakfast alone.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: And I will study in the meane time.
whether art thou ready to the giving a reason, or to render a reason. ARt thou prepar'd to give an account of thy study?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I am prepared as I think as I seemed to my selfe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Repeat therfore, and be of a present minde. Say then, and ma • ke well. take good heed.

sp.speaker: D,
sp.p: We have pronounce, said first this morning time. this morn • ng a verse out of Cato; afterward we have repeated. rendred the interpretation of it in Latine and English: last of all we have handled we two together have handled every part of speech severally. two by two all the parts of speece, with their things belonging • o them. attributes and signification.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Hast thou done
thy duty rightly. well?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I thinke me to have satisfied. that I have satisfied (our) Master, for a great part. most part.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: See that thou lie not; for I will aske him.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Master, as you will; I feare nothing in this matter behalfe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: goe on, proceed. Goe to, let us goe forward: what have you to repeat at noone time of the day. at noone?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: We have to decline the verbe Possum, in Latin & English.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Have ye nothing besides? Nothing besides?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I have taught thee this thing at an other time. this at other times: doest thou not remember it. keepe it in could. memory?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I dare not affirme [it] untill I shall assay, or prove it: try [it].

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Turne or vary it. Decline [it] into. ver. in the first persons, the rest will be most easie to thee.remembrance.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Indicative. I can, I was able, I have beene able, I had beene able I shall be able. The Imperative is wanting. The Optative, God grant I can, would God I could, God grant I have beene able, would God I had beene able. The Subjunctive, that I may, that I might, although I have been able, although I had been able, when I shall be able.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Decline the whole Infinitive Moode.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Present & Preterimperfect tense of the Infinitive Moode. To may or can: Preterperfect and Preterpluperfect tense. To have or had been able. The rest are wanting.this verbe Possum doth.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Why doth this verbe Possum, want the Future tense of the Infinitive Moode? also wherefore doth it want the Participle in Rus?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Because it hath not a Supine.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: for those voices are wont to be formed of the Supine.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Give an example in some whole. perfect verbe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
as Lecturu •
i • made of the supine Lectum. As of the Supine. Lectum is made Lecturus: and of Lecturus,
v. Lecturum esse is made. is made Lecturum esse.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
very well, or well truly. Truely [thou sayst]
well. rightly. But why hast thou pretermitted. omitted the Participle of the present tense. present of the verbe Possum, seeing it is in use,
• otens potentis?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Because (as you have taught us oftentimes) potens is not a participle, although it come of Possum.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What is it therefore. then?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: [It is] a Noune Adjective.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thou hast remembred. Thou remembredst well. God grant thou proceed. goe on so alwaies.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I hope greater things. better things every daily. day, by the grace of God.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
I also doe hope the same thing with thee. Now it remaineth, that thou repeat.
• ay the preterperfect tense with the the tenses comming of it. issue.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I have beene able, I had beene able▪ grant I have been able, grant I shall or will be able, would I had beene able, to have or had beene able.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Say the terminations,

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I, ram, rim, ro, sem, se.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Say the significations.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I may, or can. I am able, to be able.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: These things hitherto: behold, we are called to dinner.
WHen wilt thou dine?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I have dined even now▪ I have dined already.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: at what houre. At what of the clocke?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: At half [houre] after eight.Therefore doe ye.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Do ye then so dine early?some are wont.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: We are wont so almost. usually in summer: but [when dine] yee?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: we dine not. We doe not dine before halfe an houre after ten, sometimes v. from eleven. after eleven

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Wonderfull, not sooner? why no sooner My father is to bee expected,tarryed, or wayted for. whilst he returne from the Court.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Therefore thou. Thou then canst
not be present v. to the hall in the singing, be at the hall. in the Hall at the singing of Psalmes.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I am present very seldome. I am very seldome present·

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: How art thou free. excused?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I am exempted from that duty.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: Who freed thee. exempted thee?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: [Our] Master by the admonition. warning, exhortation. motion of my father.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: whether all the children of the Senators have a priviledge of that sort▪ have then all the Sonne. children of the Senators such a priviledge?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: command. They have, so that their fathers doe whether thy mother cannot. desire it.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: * Could not thy mother give thee [thy] dinner, before the returne of [thy] father from the Senate house?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: truly she can. She could indeed, but my father will have me to tarry for him. will be expected of me.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Wherfore?

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: Because it so pleaseth him. it pleaseth him so.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: Now I must hold my peace; for thou hast stopped the mou • h to me, or shut my mouth. stopped my mouth.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Why art thou so curious an asker of questions?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I am but a childe, and children doe desire alwaies. doe alwaies desire to know something of news. some newes.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I confesse [it] but there is a measure in things:a boy▪ or a lad. as [our] Master doth teach us ofttimes.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Therefore let us goe away, depart, that thou maiest betake the • . goe to dinner.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I pardon me I pray thee, pray thee pardon [me,] if I have offended thee in any thing.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I aske, or request. require the same of thee: I, I say, rather, who could. might offend thee by my bab • ling, or talking. pratling, but in the meane time thinking no evill.
WHere hast thou e • ten taken meat to day?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: At my host, with my host, or at my hosts house. With my host.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: For how much hast thou dined?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: For sixe farthings. quadrants

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p:
what did thy supper coll?. What thy supper? of how much did it stand? how much did it cost?
As much:just so much. but thou for▪ how much? &c. but for how much art thou nourished. tabled. boarded daily?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: For more then thou.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Therefore for how. For how much then?

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: For foure stivers. foure pence and somewhat more.
FRom whence dost commest thou. thou returne?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: From abroad.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Why hadst thou gone forth. wentest thou abroad?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: That I might goe home.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: why thither. whereunto, Whereto?or whereabout.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: To require. fetch my bookes.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Hoe, why hadst thou not brought [them.]

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I had forgotten [them]

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Art thou wont it is even so, or whether so. so to forget [thy] breakefast, or [thy] drinking?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: very seldome. Most seldome.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Indeed it hath bin very great carelesnesse. was a great negligence.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yea, the most great negligence greatest: but what dost thou. wouldest thou doe? we are boyes. children.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: What if [thy] Master knew. should know thy fact. deed.

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: Peradventure I should give punishment, or suffer punishment. be beaten.

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: Sayest thou peradventure? without doubt thou shouldest be beaten. Doth it not shame thee to come into the schoole without bookes?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: not onely it doth shame me It doth not onely shame me, but also irke me: but notwithstanding, I [see] thou do not. pray thee doe not accuse me. complaine of me.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I thinke nothing lesse: but I cannot dissemble, but that I reprehend or rebuke thee. but I must reprehend thee.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I am perswaded in truth, thou dost that friendly. (I in good sooth believe) thou doest it friendly: therefore I consult it of good I take it in good part.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: That is sufficient for me. That is enough for me, let us goe within into the the schoole. Auditory.

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: It is time: now the overseers of ten. decurions exact. doe require an a reason: account of our writing.
Master is it lawfull [to speake] a few words. MAster may I speake a word or two?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Speake freely boldly.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I and my schoole-fellowes have beene ver. fastned. or tied to. set hard to our books, for this whole 3▪ daies, or the whole space of. almost v. release. all these three daies: may it not be lawfull for us? Is it not lawfull to Therefore say thou refresh [our] minde with play a little?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: v. release. say thou then some sentence.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: interpose, or intermingle. Put betweene sometimes joies to thy cares.
That thou maiest interpose, or intermingle. endure every labour. any labour in thy mind.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Say also the English verses. verses in English, if thou remember them. hold them in memory.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: How rightly. well hast thou said all!

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Thanks is to God. be to God.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Something must be. shall be added hereafter.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: but what Maister Master, what?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: which. Who hath given to me. me witand an honest mind and a good mind.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: But who shall teach me those words?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I will write them to thee. for thee, in thy little commentary, or register. note booke, that thou maiest learne them without booke: v. had given. but I pray thee, tell me, who hath taught thee this speech, which thou hast pronounced?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: Campane gave it writ yesterday, and I got it without booke. committed it to memory.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Truly my Daniel I love thee this thy painfulnesse. for this diligence.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Master I give v. thee. you thanks. Therefore doe yee. Doe you then suffer us to play. permit us that wee may play?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yea truely. verely, goe thy way, shew it againe, or tell it. shew it to thy schoole-fellowes.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
I will doe
it

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What wilt thou say to them?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That which thou. you taught me in times past. sometimes.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: But I will heare it of thee first. before.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Oh yee lads, or boyes. children be merry. rejoyce, behold I bring yee a joyfull. pleasant message. I have obtained for you power of playing leave to play.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Oh well done, thou hast remembred well. thou remembredst well, goe even now.
LEt us repeat our daily Nounes, that we may rehearse render them more certainely to our Master.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Thou admonishest [me] well, goe before me [in repeating] yesterdaies Nounes

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Say in Latine, an eye. The right eye.holdest, or keepest. The left eye. Both the eies. Thou thou remembrest well. remembrest [them] well.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Now heare, whether I say well by my selfe. rightly alone.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Goe to, I heare.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: An eye.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Thou oughtest to tell them. number [them] upon thy fingers, as our Master directeth. teacheth.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: what doth that profi? What good will that doe?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: To helpe [our] memory.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: what will this to it selfe. What meaneth this?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Hast thou not heard it▪ so often. very often?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I am forgetfull: what should I doe?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Be thou more diligent to hold, or keepe. retaine those things, which thou hast perceived, or learned. gotten.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Thou dost me a very acceptable turne, that thou admonishest me faithfully.

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: Goe to, returne to the matter.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: An eye, The right eye, The left eye, Both the eyes.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: How perfectly. How well hast thou sayd all!

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Let us repeat also this daies Nounes.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
It very well. pleaseth [me]. But
goe thou before me by againe. course.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A hand, The right hand, The left hand, Both the hands.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It remaineth that thou say so alone.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: A hand, The right hand, The left hand, Both the hands.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Oh if we could say so well, before our Master.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: What hindreth?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Because we feare. we are afraid.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: And notwithstanding he correcteth our faults courteously, or gently. mildely enough.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I know not what this will to it selfe. meaneth, I am alwaies fearefull in the beginning.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: this. That is after a sort naturall to all, as we have heard of our Master.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Now it should be repeated of us, [we] should repeat in Latine and English, but I see our Master comming.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Let us enter in.
SAy in Latine, Let us repeate. say our lessons together.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: This speech how many parts, &c. How many parts hath this sentence. speech?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Three.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: tell or say. Distinguish or each of them. every one by name.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
R petamus is a verbe. Vn •
an Adverb. Praelection • m a Noune.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: shew them. Therefore goe thou, &c. Declare [them] a little more plainely.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Goe thou then before me, as our Master is wont.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Repeto, repet • , repetere, of the third conjugation, as Leg • , legi • , l • gere. The praeterperfect tense repe •• j: Supine, repeti • um. Participles, repetens, repeti • uru • .

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: It is not declined, because it is an Adverb in this place; in English, together.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Praelectionem: praelectio; praelectionis, of the feminine gender, the lesson, or lecture.
LEt us goe to say, or render. repeate together.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What should I repeat? Is it not •• ough that I have repeated alone?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: If thou shalt rehearse. repeate onely once, or twice, that is, litle. too little to learne learne perfectly. without booke.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yea, I have repeated well neere. above ten times.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Indeed that is, &c. That in truth is sufficient.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Therefore what wilt thou any further. any more?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: If thou wilt repeat most certainely before our Master, it is need, to to repeat it before. have repeated with some body.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I knew not that, but I assent willingly unto thee.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Therefore let us doe that which I admonished. advised thee.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: truely.. I in good sooth. In good sooth I doe not refuse, begin.
Dost thou hold thy lesson in memory. remember thy lesson.HAst thou gotten thy lesson without booke?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Almost.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: wilt thou [that] we repeate together?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I desire it earnestly, or specially. Yea, verely I will

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: Begin therefore. thou.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I will doe it willingly: but heare attentively, that thou maiest correct me, if I shall misse in any thing.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Goe to.erre any thing.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: make cost. Bestow quickely.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Now thou hast erred. missed, it was to be begun. thou oughtest to have begun from yesterdaies [lesson]

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p:
Thou admonishest [me] well: Now I will begin. Doe not contend In thy anger. being angry concerning an uncertaine
matter, Anger doth hinder.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Thou missest, or faultest. offendest in the point, or cause. accent, say againe, or • eiterate it. repeate again.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Anger doth hinder the minde, that.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: Distinguish after minde.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Anger doth hinder the minde, that it cannot perceive see the truth make cost speedily. Bestow quickely; when the matter it selfe doth require. For something is to be given.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Thou offendest. missest againe in the point, or pause. accent: repeat.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: For something is to he given when time or occasions matter doth require.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Doest thou not see thee to have. th •• thou hast missed. missed foure times.erred.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I see [it.]

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: And hast thou observed the places?

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: I have observed [them]

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: So thou shalt. wilt take heed to thy selfe more easily.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p:
•• e wr • tch! Wretch that I am! I thought,
• e to remember well, or to keepe them well. that I remembred them well.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: So also it is wont to happen to me, as oft as I have not committed things well to memory. [my] memory is not well confirmed.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: [He is] happy who hath a good memory.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: [It is] a great benefit of God. But the time passeth. goeth away, heare me now.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I heare, pronounce.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Doe not contend being angry concerning an uncertaine matter.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Hoe: our Master is present: hold thy peace, that we may salute him.
IS there nothing that We must repeat. we may repeate to [our] Master?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Nothing, except of the principles. Accidence. Rudiments of Grammar.

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: what?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p:
Looke looke into. upon thy by booke: thou shalt finde notes
upon five lectures which our Master hath appointed. prescribed unto us.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Vpon friday, at the fourth houre. at foure of the clocke.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: But I have not beene. was not present then.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Therefore thou hast deserved punishment. jerkes.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Doest thou judge so, O thou severe judge? I wasbusied. occupied at home, neither was I away without the my masters leave. commandement of [my] Master.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Be it so, but notwithstanding thou should • st have asked. thou oughtest to aske the day after, what was done the day before.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I confesse my offence. fault, but I pray thee, give [me] thy booke, that I may see what we must repeat. what is to be repeated of us.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Take it, and marke thou. signe thou by the same diligence, or labour. note withall those things which are appointed. prescribed unto us of our Master.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I will doe it willingly, neither hereafter shalt thou accuse me of negligence, as I hope.
WHat was done in the auditory, or place where they heare lessons, schoole at at the 3. houre, three of the clock?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: The parts of speech were handled out of [our] lecture.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Nothing more?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: I had told [thee] except thou hadst disturbed, or hindred me. but that thou interruptest me.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I have done erred▪ amisse, proceede.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Afterward our Master told word by word. dictated [to us] a English vulgar. speech in French to be translated. French argument, to be turned to day.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: When to be given up, or shewed. repeated?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: To morrow at noone.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Hast thou made, or translated it now. turned it already?

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: [I have turned it] in some • ort I know not how howsoever.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I pray thee dictate to me the English. vulgar.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p:
Receive it, Take it, make
• ast, for I have to write something something to write.
WHat doest thou?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I repeat by. with my selfe.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: What doest thou repeat?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: This daies appointment, or taske prescript of our Master.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Doest • hou hold it in memory. remember it?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: So I thinke.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p:
Le • vs repeat together: so both. either of us shall say better. pronounce more
• irectly. rightly before our Master.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Therefore begin thou, who hast. that hast provoked me.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Goe to; Attend well. be attentive, least thou suffer me to erre. suffer me not • o erre. misse.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I am more ready to heare, then thou to pronounce. say.
WIlt thou repeate thy lesson with me?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Dost thou hold it? Canst thou say it?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Peradventure not very well▪

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Goe to,where. let us make no • well eno • gh tryall.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Why doe we then a pe • i • l, or attempt. tarry?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Begin expect▪ when thou wilt.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: But it is rather thy part to begin.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Because thou hast provoked, or cause me. invited me.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thou speakest in differently. saiest right, therefore attend.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I am ready. here.

Dost thou nowhold [in memory] remember [those things] which are to be rendred. repeated at three of
the clocke?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I remember them.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I also [doe remember them]

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Therefore let u • talke a little.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: But if the monitour shall come in come betweene. the meane time, he will thinke, us to prattle, or talke, that we prate.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: why? What doest thou feare where nothing is to be feared? If he shall come, he shall not find us in idlenesse. idle, or ill imployed. in any evill matter▪ let him heare our talk if he will

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: Thou speakest best of all very well: let us goe aside some whither into a Corner, least any man. any one hinder us.
IT doth not become [us] to be idle here or to prattle, whilst we looke for master. our Master is looked for.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What saiest thou? doth it not become? yea truly, we may not. it is not lawfull: unlesse we will be beaten.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Therefore, heare tho • me, whilst I rehearse. pronounce my lesson. I afterward will. I wil • heare thee after.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Goe to, pronounce. say.
WHy doest thou not write?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I hav • written now my side: what hast thou done? but thou?

sp.speaker: E▪
sp.p: I goe to write in the Court-yard.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Why so

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Because it is faire abroad. the heaven skie is cleare.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Make hast the time passeth, goeth away; and an a reason. we must presently give an account. account will be required by and by.
WHy dost thou not write?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p:
Because it doth not list me.
I please not. I list not.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: But [our] Maister had commanded.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: I know: but something is to be read before. I must reade some thing before; furthermore, I have nothing to write which I may write now.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Oh if thou wouldest write to me. for me.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I have the Dictates of our master. our Masters notes to be written out set downe.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: What Dictates. notes?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p:
Vpon the Epistles of Cicero.
Tullies Epistles.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: I will write out them. write them out for thee willingly: but expect tarry untill the next of the Holy-daies. the next day. the next holy day.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Therefore I will expect. I will wait. expect then, but I pray thee doe not deceive me.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p:
I will not deceive thee knowing neither, &c. wit
• ing nor willing.
WIlt thou write downe my lesson for me. write me out [my] lesson?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Why hast thou it not? hast thou not it?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Because I was busied. occupied to yesterday. day.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Take my booke and write it out.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Thou art not ignorant me to write. that I write more. very slowly; and thou wilt sooner have written out. write out the whole, then I foure or five little verses.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: seeke thee another writer. Seeke another writer for thee; I cannot give my helpe, or indevour to thee now. I cannot helpe thee now.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I have another businesse. There is another busines for me, and the same very necessary.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I will not urge thee, neither can I in truth, but at least g lend [me] thy booke.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Take it, use it as thou list. pleaseth thee, so that
thou doe not marre it. abuse it.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: There is nothing. no cause, that thou shouldest feare here. for this.

div.head: The 22. Dialogue.
div.stage: Augustine. The Observer, &c. or, the houshold Monitour.

sp.p: SChoole-fellows, is it not lawfull to goe, &c. may we not go to bed

sp.speaker: Ob.
sp.p: Why before the houre?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Because must rise at the third [houre,] three of the clocke.

sp.speaker: Ob.
sp.p: Wherefore?for what thing.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: for the cause of writing. For to write.

sp.speaker: Ob.
sp.p: What hast tho • to write?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Letters to my father.

sp.speaker: Ob.
sp.p: Wh • doest thou not aske leave of [our] Master

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p:
Thou▪ admonishest. advisest [me] well: is he in hi •
little study, or chamber. study?

sp.speaker: Ob.
sp.p: I thinke that [him to be. he] is: goe and see. go • to see.
FRom whence commest thou?

sp.speaker: Pv.
sp.p: I com • from beneath.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: What businesse what busines was to thee. had •• thou beneath?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: I went to make water.

Sit now at the table, & stay.
• arry in the chamber until I shal returne.I had gone.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: What shal I do in th • meane time?

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p:
Learne perfectly thy lesso • against to morrow, that thou maist
• ender. repea • it to me before supper.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Master, now I hav • learned it perfectly.

sp.speaker: Paed.
sp.p: Play therefore. then.
But I have no play-fellowes.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Thou shal find sufficiently many, or many enow. enow in this street, even of thine ow • schoole-fellowes.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p:
I doe nothing care for that, I doe not care fo • that: now I had rather (if it please you) t •
• earne out the Catechisme, against the Lords day.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p:
As it
• steth, or thou •• st. liketh thee.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: If any aske for thee. seeke you, what shall I say unto him?

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Say me to have gone forth. that I am gone forth, but to returne. but that I will returne by and by.
HOe Abraham!

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: a Hoe, or what, or loe here. Anon Master.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Put away. Lay away thy bookes: now thou hast studied enough the whole day: prepare thy selfe, that we may goe to walke.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: would it not be better? Were it not better after supper?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: The exercise of the body is more wholesome before meat.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I remember to heare it. that I have heard it from you.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Let me heare or tell me. Shew [me] the saying of Socrates to that sentence. to the end, or for that opinion. purpose.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When Socrates did walke more with strayning more contentiously. earnestly untill the evening, being asked why he did that, he answeredhim to feede, that he did feede hunger by walking,to provide meat for hunger, or to get a stomack. to the end that. whereby he might suppe better.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Thou remembrest well: who is the authour?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Tully.
Cicero: but Master, whither shall we goe forth. goe?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Without the City.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Shall I change my shooes?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Change [them] least thou sprinkle. marre these new ones with dust: take also [thy] little shadow, least the vehement heat of the sun doe make dusky thy face to thee. doe make thy face dusky.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: doe sunburne or tan thee. I am ready.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Now indeed let us goe forth.I am present now, prepared already.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Shall I call one or another. or other companion out of the street?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p:
Thou dost admonish
me well; for so [our] walking shall be more pleasant: for you shall talke, or reason. Confer speeches. confer betweene your selves by the way: and you shall play together in some place. somwhere in the shadow

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: So also an appetite of meat shall be stird up. an earnest desire, or we shall get a stomack. we shall get an appetite to our meat.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I will goe with a • low pase, softly before: when thou shalt get companions, follow ye me through the gate by the water, or shoare. the water gate.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Will th • u. you then looke for us there?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: yea certainely. [yea] surely.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: What if I s • al • find none?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p:
Neverthelesse follow thou me •
hast thou not heard? dost thou not heare? heardest thou not?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Master I heare. I heard.
OF whom hast thou bought this paper▪

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Of Fatine.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: whether is it good? Is it good?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: [It is] better then of thine. this thy [paper] as my opinion is. as I thinke.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I wonder not. I marvell nothing. not.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Wherefore sayest thou this?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Because peradventure [it is] dearer.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I know not.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: For how much hast thou bought a queare?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: For three halfe pence, or thereabout, but thou for ho • much?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: For a penny and more.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Fo • how much then?therefore.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: for id q; For five farthings.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Truely thou hast not bought it badly, amisse. ill.

sp.speaker: H▪
sp.p: But also. Moreover the Mercer gave me an increase, advantage.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: And what. What, I pray thee?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: A sheet o • blotting paper.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: me unwise. Oh how unwise was • that ha • e forgotten. forgot to aske.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p:
Truely I did not
• ske, but he gaue it me of his owne accord. And (said hee) I giue thee this, that thou that thou come to me againe. visite me againe.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: So they are wont to allure customers. buyers

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: No marvell: everie man seekes his owne profit, or gaine, commoditie.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: But what do we, being unmindfull of this dayes taske?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: our taske is not much. It is [but] little, we have time enough.time enough remaines to us▪
DOst thou not remember me to have given, to lend, or lent thee paper, or that I lent thee paper that I lent thee paper of late?

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: Why should I not remember?what else should I remember. I am not so forgetfull.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: How many sheets were there?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Foure.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Why hast thou not restored them?

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: I expected untill I might have a booke. had [a] booke.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Hadst thou [it] at length?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Onely to day.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: From whence hast thou gotten it?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I asked it of [our] Master.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: In his study. Library.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Wh • t [did] he? hath he given. gave hee it willingly?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: He sent me unto the Vsher, who gave one straightway. [me] a booke refer it before into his booke. presently.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Did he not refer it before into his booke. put it into his booke before?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: He is wont to give nothing but he writeth it in [his booke] before.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I have heard of my Father, that to be the part &c. that that is the propertie of a wise man.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Especially if an account be to be made. given.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But by what signes. tokens durst he give it thee?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I shewed mine owne hand writing in my booke it him written with my owne hand, in my little booke: for as thou knowest wee are wont to doe so.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Therefore thou wilt repay it. wilt thou
restore me that which I lent?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: [I will restore it] straight way after dinnner, doubt not.
ARe those quils or are these quils which thou carriest about to be sold. pens to be sold which thou carryest about?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yea if a buyer shall offer himselfe. come.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Shew [me] Let me see them: ah how soft they are. are they?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Such what ones] [as] have fallen from the wings of our geese: but try them diligently, for some are more strong then other some.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I see enough what manner of ones. what ones they are: how many wilt thou give me for a farthing?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: onely six.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: What saist thou, six? I would rather buy of the Mercers which doe bring [them] hither from Lutece. Paris and Lugdune. Lions.

sp.speaker: M,
sp.p: As if I knew not, for how much they are sold: I have heard of my brother which giveth his diligence. serveth a Scrivener of this City, himselfe to have that he hath bought at Paris for every one a penny. pence a peece.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: It is lived of men. Men live otherwise. after one way at Paris, after another at Geneva: but there is no need of so many words,there is one manner of living at Paris, another at Geneva▪ wilt thou give twelve?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Out. Alas twelve! as if I had stollen them

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I doe not say this, but see whether thou like them thus. whether the condition offer doe please thee.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Wilt that I tell thee. speake in one word?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Say I pray thee, it is pratled enough now we have pratled enough now.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I will give thee nine, so that thou take them one with another mixt as they come. indifferently, of my hand.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: dost tr • fle. Thou triflest, I would not take fi • teene unlesse I might chuse them. without choise, Farewell, I shall finde* enow otherwhere

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: enough of quils. Thou maiest for me; hoe, hoe,quills enow. returne.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Why doest thou call me backe?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Take eight if thou wilt,It is lawfull by me. neither looke for. expect moe from mee.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: reach me. Give mee the whole bunch, that I may choose at mine owne abiterment, or judgement, or as I will. liking▪

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Hold, choose as thou wilt:

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: See now, and number, count. tell them, if thou list.if it list thee.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: There are foure and twenty. twenty foure, the number is manifest, or plaine. evident. But I marvell that thou tookest none out of the pinion. out of the thee to have taken. uttermost part of the wings, for they are stronger.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I know it, but they have a shorter utmost wing. quill: take the price.stalke.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: God turne it well to either of us. God send us both good lucke of it. God prosper it to eyther. both of us.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I wish and pray the same with thee. But when wilt thou bring better quils?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I know not whether I can [bring] better;pennes. but as I hope I shall bring moe withinin. shortly. a short space, when I shall come. goe hence unto to us our house,

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Are there many geese to you. have yee many geese?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thirty and above. more.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Wonderfull! how what a great flocke. great a flocke of geese! where are they fedde?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thou shalt know at another time; It is not lawfull for me to &e I may not to loyter here. stay longer here. Farewell. Franke.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Marius▪ care that thou be in health▪ or looke to thy health. Farewell, Marius.
WIlt thou give me onely pen. but one penne?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: They are not so given to me.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p:
Oh, dost thou deny thing so little to me. me so small a thing? what,
if I should aske some great thing?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: perhaps. Peradventure thou wouldestbeare the repulse. take the deniall. repulse

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: in good sooth In truth in good sooth beleeve it: goe to, I do not aske th • e to give it me. I do not aske it for. as a gift: at least wilt thou lend it me?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I will not. I doe not refuse, so that thou doe not marre it. abuse it.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: I will not abuse it.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Take heed thou move not thy foot from hence stir not a foot from this place.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: I mo • e no whither. I will not stirre any whither.
HAst thou amended. sharpened my penne?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: A good while ago.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: For what manner, or forme. fashion of writing?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: a middle hand For a mean forme.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I had rather thou hadst [fitted it. sharpened it] for to write small. little letters.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: thou oughtest to foretell me. Thou shouldest have told me before.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I had forgotten.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: It skilleth little. It makes little matter: I • hall easily amend. change the point easily; go to, seeke it. fetch [it.]

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: But where hast thou left it?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Vpon the table of the stove. hot-house.

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: In what part?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Where I am wont to study.
HAst thou two or three pens?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: There are but two onely to me. I have but two.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: give me one to lend: Lend me one

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I will not doe it.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p:
Least thou abuse it. marre
it.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou wilt remember this Remember it, it may be thou wilt aske me something and goe without. paradventure thou shalt sometimes aske me somewhat in vaine

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: But Christ commandeth u • to recompence evill with good. evill to be recompensed with good?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: • have not yet learned that. I have not learned that as yet.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Notwithstanding i • behoveth. it is meet that thou learne it, if thou cove • . desire to be a Disciple of Christ.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What doe I desire more?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Therefore learne to imitate thy Master

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I will learne in processe. progresse of time.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: It were better to begin now, whilst it is lawfull by the time. whilest thou hast time.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou urgest me too much: I have not yet fulfilled the eight yeere. I am not yet eight yeers old, as my mother saith.

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: There is alwaies a time of doing well: but in the meane while. time, I pray thee, be not angry to me. at me: for I did jest that I might provoke. invite thee to talke together. with me so long, whilst we are at leisure. idle Behold a pen to thee. Take thee a pen, and thatnot altogether the worst, not the very worst

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I wil restore it straightway unto thee, when I shall have w • itten out, write downe somthing. write out a little.

sp.speaker: I
sp.p:
I will not, that thou
•• store it aga • ne to me▪ give it me againe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What shall I do then?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Whatsoever thou wilt, for i • is given from me to thee for a gift. for I give it thee freely.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I give thee the greatest thanke. very great thanks.
FRō whence dost thou returne so panting and breathing. blowing?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: From the market.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: What dost thou bring from thence?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: A pen-knife.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: what cost it. For how much hast thou bought it?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: For two pence.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Is it good?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: It is out of Germany, as the I know it not at all Mercer cold [me]: see the marke.a chapman.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I know not [the marke]: but thou dealest not wisely enough. very wisely, which trusteth every chapman. Mercer.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: What should I doe?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Thou oughtest to get. take to thee some skilfull man which. one that could a good one for thee. choose thee the best

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I confesse I have donechuse out the best to thee. amisse here; but this doth comfort me, that the Mercer is accounted a good man, erred. as being a professour of the Gospell.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: As if there be none such deceitfull.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I thinke even as of the Evangelicall profession. that there are very many. But let us omit these things: r and rather let us try the penknife it selfe.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: experience will teach us.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Take it,there to be. and try it,but. I pray thee: for I have not tried it. prooved it, but most lightly, and that betweene the buying, or as I was buying it. whilst I bought it.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Wonderfulll who taught. hath taught thee to choose so wisely?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Doest thou aske? hast thou not? doest thou not remember that our master is our master [to be wont] to say. wont to say to us so oft, it to be God. that it is God alone which teacheth good things?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Truely he taught thee the best of all. passing well. excellently well

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I give him thankes from my minde. my heart: and I pray, that he may teach me ever. alwaies teach me to obey his will,

sp.speaker: H
sp.p: I also pray for the same: neither to us onely, but also unto all the godly.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Thou doest, as a good childe. as it becommeth a godly boy. childe: but is it not time that we should goe into the auditory. schoole?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: it is so; take thy bookes, and let us goe together.
HAst thou not a pen-knife?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I pray thee lend [it] me a little.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: When wilt thou restore [it]?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: As soone as I shall neb▪ or amend.sharpen two pennes.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Take it, but by that law. on that condition that thou restore it safe and sound. whole.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I understand it,[to be] taken. as taken with that. of that condition, although thou hadst not added it.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: A word to a wise man. A few things (as is sayd commonly) may serue. doe suffice one understanding to a wiseman. to one that understandeth.
HAst thou bought a pen-knife as thou wouldst of late?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I have not bought one. bought

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: What hindred?hadst said, for thou thou toldest me. saydst to me,thee to be about to buy. that thou wouldest buy one to day.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I sayd so indeed;after it came into my mind. but it came into my minde to me into my minde after to be better that I expect the next mart in this same City.the market; or • aire to be next.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: what wilt thou gaine thereby. What gaine wilt thou make?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Both I shall by it for lesse, and of a better note. marke; I meane▪ have▪ to weet, out of the shops of Germany.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Who h hath given thee that counsell?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Our Ierome.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p:
He
hath done well, for we ought alwayes to give good counsell to our friends.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Therfore only to our friends?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Yea and to [our] enemies, I confesse, because Christ our best Maister commandeth; so.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: would to God we might▪ God grant we keepe the doctrine of him fastned into our memory. his doctrine infixed well in mind wel in memory, that we may follow it perpetually.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: That good spirit grant it, by the by whose onely • nstinct. instinct of which. whom alone our minds are kindled to doe well.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thou prayest well.
hast thou many. HAst thou not many bookes?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Not very many.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: But what books hast thou? [I have] the Rudiments of the Grammer. Accidence, colloquia scholastica. Scholars Dialogues, Terence, Tullies Epistles,Epistles of Tully. with the French translation. interpretation, Cato, a Dictionary, a French Testament, the Psalmes, with a Catechisme,the dictates of our master. besides a paper book to write exercises, or notes which our master gives us. our Maisters dictates: but what bookes hast thou?

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: I have all which thou hast named. numbred, besides Cato, Terence, and the Epistles of Tully. Tullies Epistles; for why should I have bookes which are not read in our forme?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: But I sometime read those bookes, whilest wee are at leasure. idle, that I may alwayes learne some new thing, especially in the Latine tongue, and in honest manners.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
My
Langine thou dost wisely: O wretch that I am. O me wretch I who have never learned what it is to be studious.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Learne therefore: for it is better to learne late then never.
LEnd me thy Virgil for two daies, if thou canst▪ if that may be done with none thy discommodity. without any hinderance to thee?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Truly I cannot.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: When Gerard had received it of me to lend. borrowed it of me in these dayes. of late, he laide it to pawne, or gaged it. he put it to. he laid it to pledge.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Sayest, thou, to pledge?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: It is so, as I say.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: For how much pawned he it?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: For three-pence, as hee saith. 5. O unthankfull man!

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Onely unthankfull?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Yea truly both unthankfull and evill: but whether could he pawne thy thing thee being unconsulted. without thy privity, or thee not being asked counsell of, or not having told thee? without advising with thee?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: He could, thou seest. as thou seest it done.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p:
Notwithstā ding he ought not.touched the ma •
▪ with the needle, o • with the point of the needle.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Thou hast hitte the nayle on the head; but what should I doe?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Dost thou aske? carry him to [our] master.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I had rather suffer that. this injurie, then • o commi • . cause that the wretch should be beaten

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Thou dost well, so that he restore thy Virgill. thine owne.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I hope, he will restore it.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: How. From whence should he restore it?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p:
He saith. himselfe to &c▪
that he is to receive. that he shall receive money of his father shortly.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: What if he do deceive thee.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p:
It may fall out 〈◊〉
▪ It may be; but notwithstanding I will expect
some daies,what he will doe and then. what will be: and then, afterwards I will take counsell.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Nothing is more safe then right counsell.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Thou thou hast remembred. remembrest well: for so our master hath hath told us so oft. often told us: but wilt thou not any other thing?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: that it may be well with thee. [onely] that thou mayst farewell.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: and the best of all to thee. And thou the best of all.
WIlt thou lend me thy Terence?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I in truth will. I wil in truth, so that thou require it of Conrarde to whom I have given it for his use. I have lent it.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: By what signe. token wilt thou that I aske it?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Truly by this [token] because I have the Epistles of him. his Epistles.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: That is enough for me.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: But when wilt thou restore it?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: When I shall have written. write out the textupon. of three or foure lessons.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Therefore make hast, least thou hinder my study.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I will make hast.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: But hoe, thou; take heed thou blot it not: otherwise I shall lend it very hardly at another time▪ hereafter.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Verily I should be unworthy a good turne. or kindnes, a benefit [if I should doe so].
WHat new gilded booke is this, which thou braggest, boastest, or gloriest of makest ostentation of so greatly. highly

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Terence.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Where [was it] printed.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: At Lu • ece. Paris.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Who gave it thee?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I bought it with my money.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Where hadst thou gotten money?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: O foole doest thou aske? Thou askest that foolishly; as if indeed I have stolen it?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Be it far away. Be it farre from me to thinke that, but I did aske that for the cause of my mind. for my minds sake.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Neither have I reproved or found fault with. did I reprehend thy word or saying. speech in good earnest, but we are wont to jest with our familiar friends after that in that manner. manner.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Nothing doth forbid▪ hinder us to jest, so that God be not offended. But goe to, let us returne to our purpose: of whom hast thou bought this Terence?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Of Clement.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: whether or no▪ What of that booke-seller Circumforan • us, one making his market all about. that goeth about from market to market?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: especially. Yea verely.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: How much cost it?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: 12. pence. Ten pence.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No more. Nothing more?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Nothing at all.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Truely the price [is] vile. cheape enough.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Especially seeing it is gilded, and so elegantly. finely framed or made▪ bound up.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Were there not other bookes like?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Two or three.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I pray thee bring me to him.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Let us goe.
whether or no. IS not this booke thine.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Shew it me: I acknowledge it [to be] min • . mine: where hast thou found it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
In our
• orme. schoole.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
I give thee thankes that thou hast gathered it up. taken it
up.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But now thou shouldest be be put in the bill. noted, if I would deale with thee in the highest, or chiefest right. rigor of law extremitie of Law.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Knowest thou no • our our school lawes. scholasticall lawes?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yea those very lawes covet. the lawe • themselves do require that they be guided by equity. ruled by right.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: By what right are our lawes guided?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
By equitie, and by the Iudgement, or discretion. arbitrement of our master,
• o wit. as who hath made those [lawes] privatly for us: furthermore. besides, he is not wont to be so severe in that offended. which is wee doe amisse. don • amisse through negligence or forgetfulness.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I have tried so. proved so oft times by experience: but by what meanes • oever. howsoever thou shalt offend, the cause shall be said. must be shewed before the monitour.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I feare not to shew the cause where there is nothing of danger. no danger.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I hold my peace▪

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: But I pray thee what need is there that the monitour know that? for God is offended nothing. is not offended▪

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Go to: I will hide it, or say nothing. conceale it.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Thou shalt doe well.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But hoe, remember to render like. requite like for like, if peradventure any such fault shall befall me. happen to me.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Thou saiest that which is right. equall and good.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I will remember.
WHy doest thou not restore me [my] booke?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
〈◊〉 for it unto to • orrow day. Expect [it] untill to morrow. I have not used it enough as
〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I will wait expect willingly.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I will thanke thee, or be tha • kfull. I will •• nder thankes to thee God-willing.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
I •• pect no thankes for so very little. small a be
•• fit

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yet it is my part to acknowledge it.
• A west thou my booke?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: What booke 〈◊〉 doest thou seeke?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: The Epi •••• s of Cicero. Tullies Epistles.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: • here hadst thou left it?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: I had forgotten 〈◊〉 in the auditorie. schoole.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: It was thy negligence.

I confess [it]: but in the meane time point out to me.
•• ew [me] if thou know any man to have taken it.that hath • aken it.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Why dost thou not go unto our • aster? for hee is wont, as thou knowest, •• ther to beare [those things] into his little studie. his •• udie, which are left of us, or to give them • o some bodie which may restore them.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p:
Thou admonishest well. how forg •• f • ll am I which remembred not this? Oh me forget
• ll, to whom this had not come. came not into mind.

WIlt thou Enter into great favour from me▪
get favour of me, or do me a very good turne, do me an especial favour?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
I will doe.have done nothing more willingly, if • o be that the matter it se • fe be in my power
but what is it in which I may profit, or benefit thee. pleasure th ••

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: give me to lend. Lend me a shilling. ten pence.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I haue not •• much now, but the greater part.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: H •• much, [hast thou] I pray thee?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I kno • not unles I shall looke into my purse See to thee behold. Se • eight pence halfepenny.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: I will borrow onely seven. I take sev •• alone,leaue thee empty, or rob thee. for I will not empty thee altog •• ther.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: it maketh little matter. It skilleth little, take the who •• if thou wilt.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: I giue thee thanks: I b •• leeue this money to be. will be enough for 〈◊〉 busines, with a little which I my selfe ha ••

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: As it pleaseth thee, or as thou likest. listeth [thee]

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: I am beholden to thee. I love thee 〈◊〉 this so for the benignity or bounty so ready. ready bounty.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
If I can profit or stead thee.
〈◊〉 any other thing, doe not spare.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: I will r •• store the whole (God willing) as soone 〈◊〉 my father shal send unto me▪

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: Be not th ••• very carefull: I haue no need as yet.
CAnst thou not giue me mutually to borrow or lend. lend me a little money. some mone •

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: How much doest thou aske. desire?
I desire five pence if it be commodious to thee. if thou canst conveniently or without thy hurt. if thou canst doe 〈◊〉 commodiously.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: I haue not so man •

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: How many then?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: onely four •

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Very well: give mee those foure.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 will give thee halfe if thou wilt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Wh • not the whole?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Because two are needfull to me. I have n • ed 〈◊〉 two.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Therfore I dray thee give me tw •

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: But they will not be enough. sufficient fo • thee.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I will aske. crave of some other.
• herefore take these two, when wit thou •• store them?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Vpon the day of the Sabbath viz. of the Iewes, Saturday (as I hope) • hen my father shall come to the market.
Therefore be thou mindfull. remember it.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Doe not • eare.
give me to lend.LEnd me two pence.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Now I have it not I have not to give. ready to lend.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What hindreth? for I know thee to have received that thou hast received money in these dayes. of late.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I have received indeed: but bookes are to be bought and other necessaries for me. but I am to buy bookes and other necessaries.

sp.speaker: P·
sp.p: I will not hinder thy commodity,

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: When I shall buy [those things] which are needfull to me. for me, if any thingshall be overplus. remaine I will make thee partaker willingly.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Therefore I will expect; hoping in the meane time: but what ifnothing shall remaine [or be overplus] to thee. thou shalt have no overplus?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I wilt tell thee straightway, that thou doe not expect any longer in vaine.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When wilt thou buy those things which thou hast purpose. decreed?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: To morrow, as I hope, or at the most the day to morrow next, after to morow.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: it hath well. It is well, the time is mo • e short. is very short.
IS whither is. thy father gone away?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: He is gon • away.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: At what a clocke?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: the f •• st hower in the afternoone. At one o • the clocke after noone.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What sayd he t • thee?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: He admonished me in many words▪ I should study diligently.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: God grant. I wish tho • doe so.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I will doe it, God helping.
what money hath he given thee? or gave he thee any money? Hath he given thee any money?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: H • hath given me, as he is wont usually or for most part. as usually he is wont.

sp.speaker: M▪
sp.p: How much?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: It is nothing to thee.

sp.speaker: M▪
sp.p: I confesse it; but notwithstanding, wha • wilt thou doe with that money?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I will buy paper and other things which are use. needfull for me.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What if thou shalt loose it •

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: It shall be borne with an equall mind I will take it patiently.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What if peradventure I shall neede? wilt thou give me mutually lend [me]?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I will lend [thee] and very gladly. indeed: willingly

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I have thanks to thee. I thanke thee.
Hast thou done with my penknife. HAst thou used my penknife enough?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Enough.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Restore it then

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Take it: I give thee thankes▪

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
There is nothing. There is no cause
that thou give [me thankes].

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: But pardon me that I have not restored it of mine owne accord: and sooner.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I am nothing offended concerning that matter: for wee ought not to bee offended, but when we see God to be offended.
LEnd me penknife. thy little knife a little.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Thou askest alwayes something to lend, to borrow something: take it, but to borrow something. thou shouldst buy rather.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I have why doest thou not buy? no money.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Why dost thou not aske?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: not money. Where should I aske?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Of thy father.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: He is not in this City.From whence.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Where then [is he?]

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: He is gone a journey far from home. into a strange countrey.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: To Berne.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: What day?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: now the third day agoe. Now three daies agoe.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: When will he returne. When Is he to returne?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: To morrow as we hope, for so hee said going on hi • iourney. going forth.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: God speed him well.God turne it well.
doth not much bread remain • to thee. HAst thou good store of bread?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: E • ough, thankes be to God.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
give to me to lend. Wilt
thou lend me?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Willingly.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: But peradventure there will it will not suffise thee. not bee sufficient for thee.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Yea, as I hope.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: untill what time, or how long. untill what time▪

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: untill the day of Venus. friday.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: From whence wilt thou have afterwards? From home.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Who shall bring it?will.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I my selfe will goe to aske, or require it. fetch it.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: even upon friday. or the very friday. Vpon friday.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Lend me a pound and a halfe.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Who shall weigh it?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: [Our] the wife of our master. masters wife or the girle.

sp.speaker: S.
