sp.p: Let us goe fetch it out of my arke. chest.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: But goe thou alone: I will exp • ct thee▪ wait for thee in the kitchin.
I Pray thee give me of thy bread.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
I hav • not overmuch. sufficient for my selfe▪ yet •
bestow on thee, or give thee some. impar • [some] to thee, take it.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I give thanks to thee. I give the • thankes.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: It is not. There is no cause that tho • shouldest doe it, for so li • tle a matter. such a little matter▪ But I pray thee tell mee, why hast thou no • brought [bread]?]

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Because there wa • no body at our house who could give me▪

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: But why doest thou not take it?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I da •• not, unlesse my mother doe give me.

sp.speaker: L▪
sp.p: Thou doest well: but heare good counsell

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I listen or hearken. attend, that I may heare: tell me I pray thee. say I pra • thee.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p:
When the fragments, loaving, or scraps. reliques of the table an • taken away dinner being ended. after dinner, aske thy dr • nkin • and lay it up, or hide it. put it up straightway into thy satche▪ So it shall come to passe, thou shalt nev ••
come without meat, void or unprovided. emptie.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: But what doest thou perswade [me] concerning my breakefast?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: That thou aske [it] in the end of supper; and [that] thou doe the same which I said to thee, concerning thy drinking.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I never heard. saw better counsell to bee given.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Therefore make. see that thou remember it▪ and use it when thou wilt.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Truely I will use it oft as need require. shall bee.
GIve mee a piece of bread.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Hast thou not. none?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: If I had, I would not aske.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Why hast thou not brought?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I will tell thee hereafter: but in the meane time, give [mee] I pray thee. For I am very hungry. vehemently hungry.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Take it.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Alasse so little.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yea. Doest thou complaine?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not unworthily. without cause, thou givest [mee] over-sparingly.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: See how little remaineth, I have given almost halfe.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I give thankes to thee. I give thee thankes, thou hast given. thou gavest abundantly▪ but I did jest.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Answer now, why hast thou not brought bread from home?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There was no body which could give it.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: No body?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: none. No body utterly. at all.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What [did thy] mother.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: She had gone away. was away from home.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What [did] the rest?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They all were busie. occupied.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Why didst not thou thy selfe take?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I durst never. I never durst [attempt] any such thing.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: My mother doth forbid perpetually. alwayes, that I touch nothing without her permission. that I touch not any thing without her leave.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: O hard mother.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Truly in thy iudgement, who hast a Indulgent. more more tender. cockering mother.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I doe not say cockering, but surely kinde. liberall.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: How doth shee handle, or deale with thee. use thee?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Most sweetly, and altogether according to my mind, or as I would wish. according to the sentence. determination of my minde.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Peradventure to thy utter destruction.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: God forbid. God the best, and greatest, turne it away.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I in good sooth, or truly I. In good sooth I doe not envie [thee.]

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Therefore why sayst thou that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That I may warne. admonish thee in the meane time, of us to be made worse by licence. that all of us bee made worse by liberty.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Thou doest well, but what doest thou thinke. iudge? Is it not lawfull, to use the goodnesse. kindnesse of [our] parents?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Surely we may. it is lawfull, so that thou do not abuse it.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: How doe we abuse it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Dost thou aske? when as we turne the indulgence. tendernesse of [our] father, or of [our] mother to our hurt. into evill.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Thou sayest well, but how many, or where is any who doth, or who of a thousand. who amongst many doth that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yea verely all, yea almost all. all, except they which are prohibited. or restrained by the Lord. hindered from the Lord God▪

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Who can bee good, but by the grace of God?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Therefore (as we are admonished oftentimes of our master) he is to be 〈◊〉
〈◊〉 unto that hee may make us good,intreated. and help by his spirit.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I rejoyce thee not to have. that thou hast not brought thy breakefast.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Wherefore

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Because I seeme unto my selfe to have profited much by this our our talking together, conscience.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I also seeme to have profited not a little.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That come to passe. is by thy worke. diligence.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yea by the benefit of God, who indeed would so.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: In truth I beleeve it.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Therefore let us acknowledge the goodnesse of him. his goodnesse both heere, and in in the rest. all other things.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That is very equall. meet.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yea it is very greatly. very necessary, if so be, wee avoid the charge or fault. crime of an vnthankefull minde.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Oh most pleasant speech: Immortall thankes be given. [be] to God through I will. Iesus Christ.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: [I wish so.

stage.hi: The first Scholar of the Victors, the Master, [and] the

sp.p: MAster wilt thou give [mee] [my] reward?a little reward, my Praemium.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: for what cause. Wherefore?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: For the cause of For victories sake. Because I have gotten the victory.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Where are thy matches or equalls fellowes?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: they are here. They are present, Hugh and Audax.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hoe Nomen-clator, are these victors this weeke?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: They have the fewest notes of their slips or missings. notes of all.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Therefore they are victors. what other thing doe I seeke. aske of thee? What h reward doe yee require then?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What shall please thee. you.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: By what law, or yet by what right. right at length. then doe I owe it?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: From, or by promise. of promise.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Ye say that which is right or indifferent. equall; for whatsoever is rightly promised. promised rightly, ought to be performed.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: So wee have learned of thee. you.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Behold
a pen for each one of you. severall pens for you to write: and lest you should thinke them to be common. or base. vulgar, they are of the kinde of those pens, which are called commonly pens come out of Holland. Holland pennes.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Master we thanke you. wee give you thankes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But rather give thankes to God, the the g • ver. authour of all good things, which giveth prosperous successes to studies: but goe yee on. proceed yee diligently in the study of learning. letters.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: we will doe our diligence. Wee will doe [our] indeavour as much as that best father shall helpe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: All our things are vaine without his helpe.
CAperone from whence commest thou?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: From home,

sp.speaker: Ob.
sp.p: What bringest thou from thence?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: [My] Bever. drinking.

sp.speaker: Ob.
sp.p: Who had permitted. permitted thee to goe forth?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: [Our] master himselfe.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: How. From whence wilt thou proove that. this?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Let us goe to him that wee may aske [him].

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: But see what thou dost.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I feare nothing h • rein. in this matter.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Art thou so secure?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Hee that saith the truth ought to feare. should feare nothing.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Truly that. Indeed this is a true sentence: but who is to be found which. who among many doth not lie?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I am sure me to lie nothing now. I am certaine that I lie not now.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p:
Thou perswadest me wel neare. Thou perswadest me. Goe thy way, I beleeve thee;
because I have never taken or catched. found thee in a lie.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Thanks is to God. Thankes be to God: whom I pray that he keepe mee sincere, upright, or sound. intire and uncorrupt. pure.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: I wish I would to God. all [men] would pray so from their mind. from their heart. now returne, or betake separate thy selfe▪ returne that thou mayest eat thy drinking▪
WHo are the victors this weeke? Where wast thou when the the reasons. accounts were given?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I was sent for. I had beene sent for of my father, but who are the victors? tell me in good sooth. say of all good fellowship.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: I and Puteanus.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Have you had [your] reward already?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Wee have had it.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: and what I pray thee. What?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Twelve walnuts.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Alasse, what a reward?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Oh foole, therefore doest thou esteeme the reward by the price of the thing?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I see no other thing to bee esteemed heere.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Thou art base minded. base, who doest so g • pe after, or yaune for. gape fo • gaine. b Dost thou not remember the word of our master?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: What word?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: The reward is given not for lucre sake. cause of lucre,hast thou not. but of honour.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Now I remember, as it were through a little cloud, hereafter I shall be more diligent.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: so at length. So thou shalt be wise at length.
OH we are sent away, or have liberty. dismissed to play, hast thou not heard?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Wherefore not, or what else have I heard. Why should I not have heard? when I my selfe have beene present. was present.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Doth it not please [thee] to talke with me a little, and then. afterwards we will play together.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I would rather I had rather to play before.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: But it is hard to cease som play. to breake off play.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Thou sayest the tru • h the very truth. plainly, and I doe finde it. prove it by experience in my selfe.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Therefore because my way or counsell. reason doth please thee, give us some argument to conferre of. talke of.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yea it is thy office. thy part to give, because thou hast. as who hast provoked me.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
Thou sayst [that which is] well or right. equall:
• ehearse or say the names. repeate thou the nounes In Satin, which I will propose. propound to thee in English.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Concerning what matter wilt thou propound [them?]

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Concerning houshold-stuffe.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I will assay. try to answer, so that thou pro • pound no moe. thou doe not propound mo then ten.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I will tell, or count them. number [them] vpon my fingers, lest peradventure I passe the number. I exceed the number therefore heare thou.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I heare. I am here.

sp.speaker: G..
sp.p: A cupbord, a bench, a candlestick, a cauldron, a paire of bellowes, a pillow, a bolster. a linnen cloth, a pot of earth, a flag on of wine,

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Thou hast erred. missed once.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Thou sayedst a linnen cloth, for a sheet.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
I confesse it, I owe
• he victory to thee. thee the victory once.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
now propese. propound againe, that thou mayst
redeeme it if thou canst.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Wilt thou answer concerning meats?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: As it pleaseth thee.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Fresh meat, porke, venison, venison of a wild Boare, sod milke, whey, new cheese, pottage, fish sodden, pickell.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Thou art deceived.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Therefore what is it?

p.note: intinctus is any thing to di • in.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I choose rather condimentum. I will have condimentum.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: But I will not contend.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Who contends? let us consult. aske counsell.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: But let us play before. we will doe that after. that shall bee done the latter, or long after. after.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Go to, let it be, lest we lose let us not lose our occasion of playing.be done.
IT irketh me good while agoe. now of late to use or repeat. to goe vnto so often our scholarlike games.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Therefore what doest thou, or what canst thou doe▪ or wilt. what wouldest thou doe?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Let us goe into our Orchard.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: What shall we doe?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: We will walke, wee will talke together, we will tell or make • ehearsall of, or rehearse. call to remembrance the benefits of God in his works.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Truly no thing [is] more pleasant; but in the meane time we should aske leave. leave is to be asked of our master.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I have gotten leave now. already obtained leave to me. for my selfe, and also for one whom I would have w •• h me, or take. lead forth.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: a • l is well. The matter hath well. is well, let us goe, God guiding us. being our guide.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I pray that hee keepe us.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: I also pray so. pray the same with thee.
HAve yee obtained faculty, or liberty of playing. leave to play?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Wee have obtained it.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Vntill what time?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Even vnto supper. untill supper..

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Who have given verses?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The first orders. [scholars] and the second.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: What did the other classes, or seates. formes?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Every first decu • ion [or governour, or head of the forme. senior of the forme [of the three next formes pronounced one sentence out of the sacred letters. divine. holy Scriptures.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Have you not prayed, as wee are wont?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: [Wee have] prayed, and indeed with our ma • ter. indeed our schoolemaster being present, but where wast thou?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I went home. I had. was gon home, being sent for of my mother.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What then doest thou thinke to doe now?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: To play an houre and a halfe, and afterwards. then to receive my selfe. again. to goe again to betake my selfe againe to [my] study

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Wilt thou that I play with thee. that I be
• play fellow▪ to thee. thy play-fellow?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Why should I not. Why should I not bee willing?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: In what play shall wee exercise our selves?us.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p:
none.
I like no play better. No [play] is more pleasant to me then the hand-ball.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Nor indeed to mee.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Let us goe then to see whether the rest have chosen [their] fellowes. parts: for if we should play alone, there would be l • sse of pleasure. lesse pleasure.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: In truth let us goe to see.
WIlt thou come with me?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Whither hastest thou. makest thou hast?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: To the p • ole, pond, or meere. lake.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Why thither. Whereto?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: To wash [my] feet.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Goe indeed: now there is no need to me of washing. I have no neede to wash.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: But in the meane time wee will talke a little.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Indeed I will not talke now.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: But it is profitable to talke. talking is profitable, onely concerning. of honest matters.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: But the exercise of [my] body is more profitable to mee unto. for [my health].

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What if I shall tary with thee?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Thou shalt doe wisely, and we will play together, at the hand-ball. with the hand-ball.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: God turne it well God speed us well: I tarry.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I will go together with thee to wash another time (to wit) when we shall have more leisure. when there shall be a longer space of time.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Therfore let vs gird. make our selves ready▪ or fit our selves. prepare our selves to play.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: There shall be no stay in me. There is no delay in me.
WHy hast thou not played with us to day?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: There was not any s • ace of playing to mee. I had not any leisure to play.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: What businesse hadst thou?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
I had not
finished that which was enjoyned me▪ my taske.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: What taske?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I had halfe a copy to write. Halfe an example remained to be written through of me.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Hast thou done or perfected. it? finished it?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I have finished it.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: I praise thy diligence, thou shalt play idly. quietly at other times.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: When God shall or will, or shall see good. shall bee pleased.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Thou sayest rightly. well; for nothing can be done without the will of him. without his will.

div.head: The 58. Dialogue.
div.stage: The first boy, the Master, the second boy, and the third.

sp.p: GOd save you master.

sp.speaker: Prae.
sp.p: Let health, or prosperity, be to yo • from Christ. Christ save you also.
Amen.

sp.speaker: Prae.
sp.p: Have yee repeated now?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Yea master.

sp.speaker: Prae.
sp.p: Who hath taught you?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: The Subdoctor.

sp.speaker: Prae.
sp.p: What will you now?that it may be lawfull to us by your leave.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: That you would give us leave to play a little.

sp.speaker: Prae.
sp.p: It is not time to play. of playing.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: we doe not aske for all. require to all. for all, but onely for us little ones.

sp.speaker: Prae.
sp.p: But it raineth, as you see.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: We will play in the gallerie.

sp.speaker: Prae.
sp.p: with. At what play?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: For pinnes or walnuts:

sp.speaker: Prae.
sp.p: What will you give me?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: We will repeat names. nounes

sp.speaker: Prae.
sp.p: How many will every one say. will you say every one?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Two

sp.speaker: Prae.
sp.p: Say ye then.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Paper, inke, I have said.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: A booke, a little booke. I have said.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: A cherry, nuts, we have said.

sp.speaker: Prae.
sp.p: How good pleasant, faire. fine feat, or Prety boyes, or dwarfes. little men are yee! play untill supper.
O master we give you thanks.
WHere is thy father now? I thinke him to be. that he is at L • gd •• e. Lions.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: What doth he there?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: exercise merchandise. he buyeth and selleth there. He traffickes.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Since whence From what time?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: From the very beginning of the faire. mart.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I wonder excedingly, marvell greatly, how he dare tarry there so many dayes, sith the plague or sickne •
pestilence is so sore. so great through the whole city.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: It is not to be so wondred at.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Doth it so seeme to thee?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: So truly: for he hath beene in greater danger at other times, but the Lord God hathever preserved him. kept him alwaies.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I verely beleeve it, and he wil keep him as yet. still: but when will he returne?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I know not: we expect him in houres, or continually. every houre.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: God bring him backe.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I pray so.
Concerning what matter. FOr what cause art thou so li • ted up with joy. joyfull?

sp.speaker: D·
sp.p: My father hath come. is come even now.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: What maketh it matter to me, or what have I to doe with that? What concerneth it me?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yea very much because he hath gotten us. he hath obtained to us leave off playing. leave to play.
Sayest thou so?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
See the boyes
playing now in the court yard.leave of playing.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Verely▪ let others play,in the yard. I would rather. I had rather study then play.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Nor I lesse. I also no lesse. And I no lesse, but in time 〈◊〉 for as it is in the proverbe. All things have [their] time. From whence. Whereupon also our Cato doth admonish us rightly.well.

lg.l: beare out. That thou mayst indure

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Those things which thou sayst, are true, I confesse. But in the meane time, let mee alone, that I may study in good earnest.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It is lawfull that thou study. Thou mayest study by me for mee, I hinder thee nothing. I doe not hinder: but I will use this occasion.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Vse it in truth. indeed.

div.head: The 61. Dialogue.
div.stage: The callers of the names. A certaine boy of the company. Also another.

sp.p: HOe boyes, hoe, hoe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p:
What. Why doest thou
• ry out so? cry out so oft?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: You must desist. leave off from play.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Oh, vaine, or fond. foolish [boy] the fourth houre. foure of the clocke is not yet exact. fully past.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p:
Yea [it is] almost halfe an
houre after the fourth hou • e. foure.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Why hast thou not given a token. a signe?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: the belrope is broken. Because the rope of the little bell is broken.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Cry againe, but lift up thy voice.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p:
Hoe boyes,
• eceive or betake your selves. returne yee all [into the schoole] make haste, I say, our master presseth on, or commeth nee • e. is neere.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Cease. Give over to cry: All runne.
What. WHy art thou so merry. jocund?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Because my father is come.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Sayest thou so? From whence came hee?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: From Paris.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: When came hee?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Even now.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Hast thou • aluted him now. already?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I have saluted him when hee descended. lighted. alight from his horse.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: What didst thou further. more unto him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I pulled off his spurres and bootes.dr • w off.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: I marvell thee not to have taried. that thou tarriedst not at home for his comming.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Neither would he had permitted, neither I would. would, especially now when our lesson is to bee heard.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Thou consultest well to thee. Thou providest well for thy selfe. for thy selfe, which hast a reason, regard of the time: but what [doth] thy father? is he in health? is hee well?

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: [Hee is] rightly, or he is in good health. well, by the good nesse of God.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: In sooth I do • rejoyce very much for benefit. thine owne, and for thy cause. his cause,the cause of him. that he hath returned safe out of a farre countrey. strange countrey.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p:
Thou doest as it
becommeth a friend: but we will talke together to morrow in moe words. See [our] master who now entreth into the schoole. auditorie.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Let us goe to heare our lesson.
IT pittieth mee of thee.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: That thou dost ma • , or spoile. abuse thy pen so miserably.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: How doe I • buse it?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Because thou used. handlest it the worst of all. very ill in amending. scraping.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is not my fault, doe not e •• e any thing. bee not deceived.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: of whom is the fault. Whose fault is it then?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Of my penknife, whose edge is blunt. dull▪

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The penknife▪ is not in the fault but thou thy selfe.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Why sayst thou
• hat. thi •
▪

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Because thou oughtest either to whe • . to sh ••
pen thy penknife, or to aske to borrow another somewhere else:it • hould be denied to me. at least for the preseat businesse.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I dare not aske.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What fearest thou?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Least I should be denyed

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: behold my penknife to thee. Take my penknife.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I thanke thee. I give [thee] thankes.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Vse it how much thou. as much as thou wilt, but rightly. well.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I will not abuse it knowing. witting.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Neither be thou not shame •••• d, over bashfulls or modest. be thou hereafter so shamfa •• in asking.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I am of such • nature. My nature is so, I am won • to give more willingly, then to aske.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
I would to God there were many like thee: but notwithstanding, he that giveth a benefit willingly▪ may also aske freely: but I
hold thee backe. detaine thee overlong. overmuch. finish. perfect that which thou hadst begunne.
Why Peter doth not come.WHy doth not Peter come into the schoole?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: He is he is busie. occupied. busied▪

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: In what businesse?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: In heaping▪ or laying up wood in order. piling up wood.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: How knowest thou?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: It was. It is told me.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Of whom By whom?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Of. By his father.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Where sawest thou him?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Hee met mee when I came.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: See that thou lie not, for I will aske of him, if peradventure he meete me by the▪ in the streets.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Thou shalt finde it so, as I say.
WHy wast thou absent. away to day in the morning?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I was occupied. busie.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: In what busines?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: In writing le • ters to my mother.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: What neede hadst thou. was there to write to her s

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Because shee had written to me.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Thou then hast. Therefore thou hast written backe.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Thou speakest fitly. properly.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: From whence had she sent. sent she letters unto thee?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: From the countrey, to wit, from our towne, or village. farme-house.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: When went shee into the countrey?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: in the former daie • , or this other day, or of late. But a few dayes ago.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: What doth she at the countrey. in the countrey?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: she looketh to. She careth for our countrey matters. busines.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: What especially?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: She prepareth those things which are needfull against. unto the next grape gathering. vintage.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: She doth wisely.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: How. From whence couldest thou prove this?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: For a diligent preparation is to be added. used in all things.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Who hath taught thee thal this?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: A certaine Scstoole master gave or read it to me dictated it to me out of Cicero. Tully.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: On what. by what occasion?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: When he admonished [me] that I would prepare my selfe diligently to rehearse. repeat the weekes worke the day after. the day following.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Truely hee did warne or advise. admonish rightly. well.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: But let vs returne to the purpose: have ye not a bailiffe which may care for. l • oketh to your busines at the countrey?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Yea, we have also a shee bailiffe, a dairy maid. a housekeeper, and men servants, and maids or women s • ruants. girls.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Therefore what need the diligence of your mother. What need is there then rude countrey dwellers. of thy. your mothers labour?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Because she knoweth better to provide, or take order for. or foresee. looke to all things, then these • vnskilfull countrey folkes.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Nothing more?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Suffer me to tell out my tale. to end my purpose.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I did thinke thee to have done. that thou hadst finished, goe on.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Yea (as I have heard of my father) the chiefe care of a master is required in administring or governing, disposing aright, and guiding ordering pe • uliar goods, or substance. his houshold busines. Therefore thy father ought rather to to be himselfe. be at the v • llage. farme house now.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: He cannot.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: What prohibiteth. hindreth him?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Because he is wholly busied. occupied in his a • t and science. greater fruit. trade.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p:
Hee f reapeth * more commodity by that, as my opinion is of that as
I thinke.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Who doth doubt?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Therfore thence it commeth it is done. it commeth to passe thereupon, that he leaveth all the care of his houshold busines to his wife.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: it is so altogether. It is even so.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: But when is thy mother when will she returne? to returne?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: Scarsly before the grape gathering. vintage finished.perfect, ended.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: what dost thou? What thou, wilt thou not goe to the vintage, or grape gathering. to get the vintage?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I shall be sent for in a short space. shortly of. by my mother, as I hope. But I pray thee what doe we thinke vpon? now all doe runne to the schoole. auditorie.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: it is well. The matter hath well. is well. let us runne also, lest we be the last▪
HAst thou heard the clock?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It hath sounded. It sounded long agoe. of late.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: hast thou numbred the houre. Hast thou told what a clock it is?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I have numbred. I have told.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: What houre is it? a clocke is it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Almost the first and a halfe halfe an houre after one.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Therefore lecture time. the time of lecture is at hand: make. see that thou be ready prepared.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Behold. See, me ready prepared, or that I am ready. I am ready when I have eat, or as soone as when I shall haue eate my drinking. beauer.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Why wast thou not present with vs the noone time. at noone?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I went forth I had gone forth with the good will. good leave of [our] master.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: But in the meane time I hinder thee. I am an impediment to thee.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Thou hinderest me not. doest nothing hinder [mee]: truly I have not lost bit, gobbet, or mouthfull.
• morsell by thy by thy disturbance, by speaking to me. interruption of me.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: It is well: goe on. proceed, but make hast.
HAst thou done thine duty. office?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: In what thing?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: In repeating thy lesson.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I have repeated nothing as yet.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: What eause hath beene. was there?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I did expect whilest my match, or fellow, or adversary. mate did returne.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Whither hath he gone. whither. went he?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Home.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: * Whereto?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: To fetch. aske [his] drinking.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: What if it shall be late before he come. if he shall returne more late. later?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I know not: it may be done, or come to passe. be.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: In the meane time wilt thou repeate with me?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Verely I doe not refuse.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: therefore let. Let us goe aside. goe then a part, lest any one be troublesome to us.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Indeed thou admonishest well: no man can study in so great stir, tumult, or clamour. a noyse and cry of walkers.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: See. Behold there a place removed farthest off. most remote where none are walking.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Let us goe thither.
WHither doest thou hast. make hast?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: I goe to supper: what doest thou▪ what thou?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I have supped now. already.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: At what a clocke▪ fift houre.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: At five as we are wont almost or most usuall. commonly.
What wilt thou doe now?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I will repeate somewhat. some of those things, which we have to repeate to morrow day. to morrow.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: I have learned o • my schoolemaster that it is not good to study, or that we must not study, that we are not to study so soone after meat.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I have learned this also, but I will not con▪ or learne by heart. learne without booke now.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Therefore what wilt thou doe?

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: I will reade and reade over [my] lesson peecemeale, or peece by peece.by parts, sundry times, or divers t • mes▪ sometimes as it were for my minds sake.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: So it shall be done, it will come to passe by little and little, that may learne I shal learne without booke a good part of [my] lesson, without care, irkesomenesse, without wearinesse, without griefe. trouble.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: I doe not understand these sufficiently. well understand these things, and certainely thou seemest to me to be wise above thine age.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It is not a thing so difficult. so difficult a thing, and I could teach thee, but that thou didst make hast. but that thou makest haste to supper.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Thou putst me in minde, admonishest me in time concerning my supper: I will goe hence. I therefore betake my selfe home, for the cause of it. thereof. Farewell.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: God leade thee. guide thee and bring thee backe.

div.head: A little preface which was set before. prefixed to the seven next Dialogues.
div.p:
LEast children may learne. should learne to do evilly by doing nothing, especially corrupting themselves by course one corrupting another or each corrupting others. corrupting
by course. one another by idle talke, and by shrewd lewd, evill, wicked. naughty and fond talking together. foolish speeches together, they are to be stirred up. incited by all meanes that in the sch • ole whil'st whilest they w • it, or • a • y for. expect the comming in or ingresse entrance of [their] master into the schooles they accustome themselves, in the meane time two together▪ or three together. two and two, or three and three, to repeat together, that which shall be appointed. prescribed by their maister. by him. This pleasant exercise shal profit them very much, and shall bee able to a • ert or keepe them, turne them away. turne them in the mean while. in the meane time from idlensse, malapert toying, or ri • al • ry▪ or wantonnesse. Lasciviousnesse, and many other evil things with which God is offended. But because repetitions of that • ort. such like repititions are not wont to bee handled without childlike or childi • h talking together. talking of the children together; and the boyes. children themselves vnlesse they they have beene shall be instituted, or taught. instructed, do speak no other things then. other way but without any eloquence, corruptly, or rudely. barbarously: therfore that they may learne by little and little, to speake latine betweene. among themselves, we have propounded here some briefe formes. short formes concerning this manner of speaking together, ne • erthelesse: or notwithstanding But it shall relie vpon, or be. consist in the diligence of the master, that he make plaine, or interpret. expoūd these same communic • tions▪ conferences. dialogues sometimes to his scholars, and that he teach how they ought to exercise themselves both at home, and in the schoole, in these things and others of that kinde (which he may be able to set downe. which hee himselfe may deliver) and that he exhort them in like manner to that thing. thereunto. So it shall be done. it shall come to passe, in the progress • of time, that hee shall have them bo • h more prompt. ready alwayes and more cheerefull to repeat those things timely in good time▪ ma • urely • ip • ly, readile. quickely which hee
hath. shall appoint. prescribe: hereupon also hee shall he shall obtaine, or it will follow. attaine, that he may execute his office. function of teaching, with lesse labour and griefe.

sp.p: WIlt thou [that] we repeat together?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That which is prescribed unto us.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I will indeed. I will verely: but what kinde of repeating shal we use? Let us heare us. our selues by course.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: So our master doth warme. admonish us oftentimes,rightly.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Hee admonisheth well, but we obey badly, evilly. ill.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Whether shall begin?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I, if it please thee so.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: It pleaseth me chiefly, or passing well. Yes verely it pleaseth me, therfore begin

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: the nounes of the second declension are declined in latine with or after. by these examples; Magister, Puer, Dominus, Lanius, Antonius, regnum.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What. Which (nounes) are to be declined to day?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Indeed Lanius is yesterdaies [noune,] and Antonius to daies [noune]

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Why doe we reapeat that daily. euery day, which wee said. rendred the day before.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Because our master commandeth so.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I know enough. well enough▪ but why doth he command?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: to our memo • y to be confirmed. To confirme [our] memorie.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Go to, decline Lanius.

sp.speaker: G▪
sp.p: hujus Lanij, &c. even so vnto the end. vnto the end.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Turne it into english. Lanius, Lanij, masculine
gender, a butcher.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Decline Antonius

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Singulariter nominativo. Hic Antonius.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: huic Antonio, &c. unto the end.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Turne it into english.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Antonius, Antonij of the masculine gender is the name of a man in english Anthony.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Wherfore sayest thou the name of a man? thou art not a man as yet.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I confesse it, but there are other Anthonies which are men.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: God grant thou mayst escape, or prove. sometime. become a man * at length.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I shall become [a man] by the helpe of God. God helping.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Attend now that thou mayst here me by course. againe.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I heare thee. I am here: speake boldly.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: The nounes of the second declension.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Give over. cease, or end. leave off, our master is present.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I heare him coughing, let us cease, Iest hee thinke us to prattle. that we prattle.
OVr Master will be here. present by and by, let us repeate.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: what need is there to me. What need have I of repeating to repeat, I have repeated alone enough, I remember all. I hold all in memorie.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: What then? by how much thou shalt repeat more often. have oftner, thou wilt hold it so much better.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Thou admonishest well, I thankes to thee. I thanke thee.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Begin, the time goeth away.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: [Nounes of the fourth. Of the fourth declension.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
Daniel thou
• rr • st. missest, (wee) must begin of yesterdayes example.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
I have
said false. missed I confesse.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Therefore now say rightly.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Singulariter nominative. hoc Sedilè.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: hujus Sedilis, &c. even vnto. vnto the end. The nounes of the fourth declension are declined after. by this ensample. Nominative singular, hic Sensus.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Let these things suffice hitherto. These things hitherto: I heare [our] master.
FRancis what dost thou? the our master is at hand. our master is comming. comming of our [master is at hand.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: truly, or may this be true. Indeed is he at hand? It is not yet halfe an houre after the second houre. two.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Notwithstanding wee ought not to abuse the time so in the in the mean time. meane while, let us repeat.stand by me.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: It I will not hinder it, shall not stay thro ugh mee, for I am prepa • ed. ready.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Therfore begin.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I pray you expect ye a little for me. I am of your of your ten, or decury. company.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Make hast.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: let every one of us say. Let us every one say his case in order, as our master doth teach us sometimes.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: There is enough of words. we have saide enough. There is enough sayd, attend yee.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: What other things doe we?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p:
The nounes of the third declension are declined in latine by these examples. A father, a light, a rocke, • harvest, a part, a a place to sit on, a seat, or bench. seate, a a subsidie, or rent, tole, pension, custome, or taxe, tribute, a embowed, or fretted, or a plaine beame in a roofe.
• aulted roofe in a chamber.

sp.p: Nominatve • ingulas, haec • upes.

Nom. plur. hae rupes.

Gabriel thou 〈◊〉
erred. missed, correct [thy] errour.

sp.p: Rupes, rup •• se ••• . gender ▪ a rocke: put in a in an oration, or sentence. speach 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: It is not in our booke.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: But our mast •• hath taught [it.]

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: A high rocke.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 speakest after the maner of the countrey. thy country fashion, breath it on • . aspir ••• [the word] high, valiantly. lustily.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: A high rocke

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Nom. sing. haec mess •• .

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: E. huic messi, &c. unto the end of th •• noune: and afterwards. then they goe on to speak ••• gether thus.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: both of you have erred. You have missed both

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I have missed I confesse.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: And I. And I also but whether shall be overcomed, set. conquered?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Our master shall iudge.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Thou sayest that which is right. equall.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: whether will ye. Will yee that we say againe, to to help, or strengthen. confirme [our] memorie?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: What else?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: What if our master come betweene. come in the meane time?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Whatthen?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: He will praise vs with a full mouth. fully. highly.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: But the order is to be changed.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: there is.. It is no doubtfull things. doubt: beginne Francis.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: The nounes of the third declension, &c▪
WIlt thou repeat with me?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Why so quickly?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p:
Lest the monitor catch u •
find us pratling, or idle.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Go to, let us repeate, but whether shall beginne?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I, because I am victor.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Therefore say.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Prudens a noune adjective, is declined so by genders. into genders: hic prudens, mas. gender, haec prudens, foem. gender, hoc prudens, neuter gender. The same noune is declined so into cases. No. singular. hic, haec, & hoc prudens.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Accusative prudentem & prudens, and unto. and so unto end.
WHy art thou idle.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I am not [idle] altogether. at all.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: What doest thou then?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
I devise, or meditat •
thinke of repeating my lesson.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I also doe that. the same, let us repeat together.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Let it be done. part • . Be it so: but Let it be so. what course shall wee hold?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p:
What way shall. we take? Play thou the part of the master,Do • tho •
I [will play the part] of the scholar.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
The condition
pleaseth me greatly. very well.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: But 〈◊〉 not thou more sharpe or severe to me, more austere toward me.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 not feare, thou thou hast knowne. knowest me sufficiently▪

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I know thee.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Decline Lego in the in • finitive moode.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: The present tense an • preterimperfect tense of the infinitiv • mood, Legere. Preterperfect and preterplu • perfect tense, Legisse.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Proceede. Goe on.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Goe to,let. suffer [thee]: hast thou breathe • enough?

sp.speaker: L▪
sp.p: Enough,

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: Goe forward. Proceed now.

sp.speaker: L
sp.p: The future tense of the infinitive moode, Lectum esse. Gerunds Legendi &c. unto th • end.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I I am glad. rejoyce thee to have done. that thou hast done thy office aright. well.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I also doe congratulate. rejoyce to me. fo • mine owne cause: But the praise. thankes is to God.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thou sayest rightly: God grant from thy heart.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Certainely from my minde▪ my heart.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It is well: let us cease, I perceive our masters comming. the comming of [our] master.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: See. Behold him▪ he is present.
viz. every one his • ense.HOe boyes we are five here, let us repeat this daies verbe as we are wont before our master.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: No man as my opinion is. (as I thinke) will contradict, or say against it. gainesay it.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Who should gainsay it? the matter of us all is done. the matter concerneth us all.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Then Nicholas begin, as because thou sittest first, or highest who sittest first.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p:
The present
tense of the Optative and the Subjunctive moode.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Audiam, audias, audiat, audiamus, audiatis, audiant Preterperfect tense, Audirem, audires, audiret, audiremus, audiretis, audirent: Preterperfect tense, Audiverim, audiveris, audiverit, audiverimus, &c. They goe forward in this order, unto the end of the verbe.
THis day we have beene▪ occupied▪ or we have kept holiday. hath beene kept [as] holyday of us, and we have a played enough now.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: enough, I thinke.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Will ye therefore that we confer concerning our studies, for the cause of our minde. for our minde sake.

sp.speaker: T
sp.p: Surely thou shalt doe me an acceptable thing, a good turne. acceptable turne.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: And the most acceptable to me.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: But what shall wee handle?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Let us try or prove. assay to decline some verbe Latine and English together.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Begin then because thou hast provoked us.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I will doe it sith that it pleaseth you so.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Let us heare. The present tence of the Indicative moode. Doc • o I teach, doces thou teachest. docet he teacheth. Pl. docemus we teach, docetis yee teach, docent they teach.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Preterimperfect tense.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Docebam I did teach, docebas thou didst teach, docebat hee did teach. Pl. docebamus we did teach, dobatis ye did teach, docebant they did teach.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Preterperfect tense.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p:
Docui I haue taugh •
docuisti thou hast taught, docuit hee hat • taught. Pl docuimus we have taught, docuis ••
yee have taught, docuerunt vel docuere the • have taught.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Otherwise in english▪ I hav • taught, thou hast taught, hee hath taught▪ we have taught, ye have taught, they have taught.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Preterpluperfect tense.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Docuir • m I had taught, docueras thou hadst taught &c. So they goe on, even as they think good. as it pleaseth.

div.trailer: The end of the first Booke.

div.head: THE SECOND BOOKE of scholars talke, o • conferences: scholarlike talke, or conference. Scholasticall Dialogues.

sp.p: WHat dost thou reade?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Letters.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: From whence?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: From my father.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: When receivedst thou them?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yesterday, • t evening.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Who brought [them?]

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: • know not delivered.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Doest thou not know? who It was not lawfull to looke. gave them thee?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: A certaine girle from the host, or victualer. Innekeeper.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: From • hence are they given. dated?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: From Paris • beleeve.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: What day?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: occupied. I could not • ooke into them as yet.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
to wit or because. Verely I inter
• upted thee.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
it maketh no matter, It skilleth little, I am not 〈◊〉
occupied. busied.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
Go to reade through. reade over thy letter. epi
•• le, I will study in the meane time.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I also will doe the same thing by and by.
how goe your matters at Lions, or Lugdune. IN what state are your Lions matters▪

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I know not, wee have heard. heare nothing now of late.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: hath your. thy brother written nothing?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Hee hath sent nothing of letters. no letters after two moneths. this two moneths that my father hath seene.which.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: perhaps. Peradventure he is sicke.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: No truly for the carriers doe often bring us commendations from him.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: do shew us often salvations in his words. I am glad to heare that he is well. I love him I heare willingly him to be well. dearely because he was a most sweet schoolefellow unto me. he was my most sweet schoolefellow.greatly.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: He (as I thinke. as my opinion is) loves thee by course. again,

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Verely I have no doubt of that: but the houre calleth us,Truly that is no doubt to me. let us goe into the schoole. auditory.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Let us make hast, now the the roule or table of the names of the scholars is called, or read. catalogue is recited.

div.head: The 3. Dialogue.

sp.p:
OH yee boyes cease your speech. give over or to prattle words in your masters absence. to prattle, (your master being absent) words by which that chiefe father is hurt. offended. handle yee. speake yee. intreat yee rather concerning your
studies and honest matters.

div.p: Learne utter. to speake fit speeches and fit words.

Learne also to say over. to roule over often between you such things as y • u are to rep • at among your selves things to be repeated: for the doctor. teacher cannot bee present alwayes amongst the scholars▪ with the children.
Learne to follow the sure footst • ps. steps of good [men.]
I pray [God] take ye 〈◊〉 [lest] I pray [God] yee take heed that flattering idlenesse to the deceive you [not.pleasing.]
Behold I fo • wa ne you that it doe not delight you. admonish you before: let it not delight you to abuse the time: l • st you be bear. le • t sore stripes beguil • you not light upon [your] backe.
Behold againe, I the presse. monitour doe for warne you. give it▪ to me for a fault, or impute the fault. doe tell you before:
If any one shall bee beaten, let him not the master of your manners. lay the blame to me.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Cease to speake moe things. any more, none of us. no man refuseth to obey.
That • est father is a admonisher. monitour to us:
And the sonne of that father to whom t • e name is Iesus whose name is Iesus:
And the renewing spirit of the holy Ghost. spirit which renewing us, doth nourish us within.

sp.speaker: Ob.
sp.p: Whom had I hoped. could I have hoped so prepared. ready to answer me?
What boy doth speake as an Angell. doth send angelicall. angellick sounds from [his] mouth?
Oh thou most learned of our forme, how may I remember thee. how may I speake of thee. whom may I call thee?
For thou utterest a divine verse. a divine verse doth flow * from thy mouth.

I am not so happy that I can poure out
verses to thee from thy mouth, of the [present] time, of the sudd • n without premeditation. ex tempore.
But I had studied before. premeditated those things which I spake even now.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
if thou hadst thought on them before. If thou hadst premeditated [them] how doest thou poure so plainely verses flowi • g from the Muses.
Castalian liquors. y Castalius is a fountaine dedicated to the Muses in the hill Parnassus. streames, what new fury is this?

sp.speaker: Ob.
sp.p: For thy verses have moved me with so great flames, such a poericall spirit or fury. affections.
That now I seeme to my selfe to be able to move. I thinke I could move the wilde beasts.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: But why doest thou lift me up. extoll me being undeserving. unworthy, with so great praises?
The chiefest glory is to be given to to God alone, or onely. one God alone.
And I would to God eloquent speech. eloquence and space. leisure might be given. granted to vs.
And that he would untie, or open. unloose our mouths into his praise:
But because the time is present, that wee pray with voice and with heart, or spirit. minde:
And the Doctor doth command it, I cease o speake moe things. any more.
What dost thou.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I write.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: What thou write?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Sentences.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: What [sentences?]

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Out of the new Testament.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Thou doest well: from whence hast thou had them?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
The usher. under master
hath dictated. dictated them to us.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Yesterday.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: At what a clocke?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: at the noone time. At noone

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: In the court.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Who were present?

sp.speaker: X.
sp.p: All our houshold [scholars] besides the first and the second.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Where were they?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: In the common hall.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: What did they?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: They did dispute.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Farewell and goe proceed, hold on. out to write.
OH yee boyes, what doe yee here? You seeme to mee to prattle. prate, and to to doe trifles. trifle. A certaine boy. Thou art long, or much. far deceived, for wee repeat together.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Concerning what matter?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Of the anomale, or out of rule. lame verbs that which is to bee repeated at the third houre. three of the clocke.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Yee doe well.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Wilt thou heare our conference. talke?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p:
Yea, goe yee on, I move. I intend. I am about a greater worke: I will stretch out, or se •
lay snares for Pies and Iack-dawes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou shalt finde many in the court at the sunne.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: There is sport for me. There is a prey prepared for my net.

Ah ha. A Ha! loe. behold now you are catched, doe yee not confesse it? A certain • boy. surely, or truely. Certainly we confesse it freely. ingenuously, but wee did not speake no evill. evill words. I pray thee, my Nicholas that thou doe not unto us. thou wilt not note us.

sp.speaker: Ob.
sp.p: What did you prattle? I heard, I know not what, concerning a breakfast.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That is it, we speake concerning our morning breakfas • ; because [our] servant had not given it us in time.

sp.speaker: Ob.
sp.p: I doe thinke that to have beene it. that it wa • that, that that was it, neither indeed is it any so great an evill any very great evill, except that. but for that they are idle words.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But we did speak in Latine.

sp.speaker: Ob
sp.p: I heard it, but it was not a place of talking: For (as you know) this very little time from drinking. after drinking, ought to be very precious unto you, sith it is dedicated to study: to wit, that every one prepare himselfe diligently to those things. to be repeated. to repeat those things to the masters which they have fore-appointed. appointed before. prescribed: doe I not truly. say the truth?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Cert • inely thou saist the truth, we had ought to reade. wee should have read together out of the Testamēt, what things it shal behove us, to we should repeat by and by: but I pray thee pardon me ô most sweete Nicholas, hereafter wee will be more wise, and we will doe our duty diligently.

sp.speaker: Ob.
sp.p:
If ye shall doe so, our master will
love you as his little entralls, or bowells. sweet-hearts: doe you not see how hee loveth good children and studious? neither doth hee onely love them, but also praise [them] and affect them with rewards. bestow rewards upon them • doe. reward [them].

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: We know these things: we prove them by experience daily.

sp.speaker: Ob.
sp.p: Therefore remember ye, and the things promised, or what have promised. fulfill your promises.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Wilt thou then hold thy peace. conceale th • s fact?

sp.speaker: Ob.
sp.p: I will conceale it, but of that condition take heed to fall. that yee fall not backe. that ye beware of falling back.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: We will take heed Christ favouring. or helping. by the helpe of Christ.
WHere is thy brother?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: He hath gone. He went home even now.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: why thither. Whereto?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: to fetch us. To fetch meat for us.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: what need is to you. What need have you now of meat?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: for our. Against [our] drinking.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Have you not in your arke. chest?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: not. No.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: why so not? Why not?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Because my mother is not wont to give us meat,give us meat. except for the present time.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Verely, because shee knoweth you to be. that you are gluttons.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How are we gluttons?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: because peradventure you devour at one eating together. meale that which hath bin given for three [meales.] three.gluttons who have no measure.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hold thy peace, I will tell [my] brother thee to call us. that thou callest us gluttons.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p:
Hold thy peace: I will tell [our] master thy brother to doe. that thy brother doth nothing
else no other thing then. but runne up and downe.run out

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But hee is not wont to goe for • h without the good leave of our master. our masters good leave.

sp.speaker: B.N.
sp.p: But he deceiveth our master.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How doth hee deceive him?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: For it is not the minde of our master, that he goe forth thrice daily.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Suffer him to come, thou shalt see what he can answer to our master.
Hath thy brother come. IS thy brother is h • e. thy brother come from Lions?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Hee came now yesterday before noone.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Brought he thee nothing of letters to thee. no letters?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: nothing. None

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Therefore what did he tell. report?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: That all were well. All things prosperous.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What doth he tell, shew. report especially concerning thy father?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Hee saith him to want, [or be • reed from] the ague. that hee is now delivered from [his] ague altogether by the goodnesse of God, and that hee waxeth well againe, by little and little.benefit.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: In truth I rejoyce, and pray God, that he may recover his old, ancient, or wonted. former health in a short [time]: but why hath hee written nothing unto you. thee, as he is wont?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: My brother denieth him to be able to write. sayeth that he was not able to w • i • e. that bee could not write.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: for what thing. Wherfore?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Because hee was not confirmed. strong enough as yet.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
There is no marvell, sith that hee hath beene sicke so long, so grievously; but hath hee sent nothing
to thee?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Yea [hee hath sent] money.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Oh! no messenger welcommer. message is more pleasant.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: They say so.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But thou answerest so, as if thou hearest. heardst a fable.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: But I heare a worse thing.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: what I pray you. What?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: A me • re or ve • y lie. A starke lie.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Doe I lie? have I lyed?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I doe not say thee to have lyed. thou hast lied, but thou hast sayd that which is false. [that] thou hast spoken falsly.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I doe not understand what thou sayest.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I will doe my diligence. indeavour that thou mayest understand.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I beseech thee. I pray thee.

sp.speaker: L,
sp.p: If no message bee more pleasant then of money brought unto us, what then is the Gospell of Christ? what is a more pleasant message? who is a more pleasant messenger then of the grace of God, which Christ hath brought us by the Gospell?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I confesse nothing to be more pleasant, then the Gospell to them onely who doe beleeve it, and doe imbrace it from their minde. heart

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: In good sooth I understand so I meane so

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But I did speak of things belonging to this world. humane and earthly things, but thou hast gone • p ascended by and by. straightway into heaven.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: So good Preachers are wont.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I did not thinke thee to bee a divine so acu • e. so sharpe o • learned a divine or • ipe. so acute a divine.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I have said nothing, but that which is is worneth edb • re. common and put in the mid • est. usuall amongst all men.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I would to God it were so usuall and common amongst all. vulgar and thorowly w • r • e or used. commonly received, that all would beleeve in Christ.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: All will never beleeve.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What prohi • iteth or forbid • eth. hindreth?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Because many are called, but few are elected chosen: as Christ himself witnesseth.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But that I hold not thee longer, canst thou helpe me? canst thou cause that I may talke with thy brother i • few [words.] a word or two?come together.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I can scarsely.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What so. Why so?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: For hee hath very many commandements from our father, looking to which. in which to be ca • red for. in the care wherof, hee is wholly occupyed.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Will hee not sup at you. at home, at your house?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 opinion is. I think • hee will sup. will.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Therefore I will goe about supper time.u • der, [or about.] the h • u • e of supper.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p:
Come I pray [thee] and thou shalt sup with us,
• nder one and the s • me labour. under the same diligence. labour.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I doe not refuse.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: In the meane time farewell, but see thou shalt remember. see thou remember to be present at time. in time.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: At what a clocke?At what houre.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: • efore sixe

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
It is an houre most fi • , or the fittest houre. most commodious for me.
• efore the sixt.
O Angeline I pray thee stitch [or joyne] together. sow together. stitch together this paper for me.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: What doest thou aske me? it is not my trade. art.

sp.speaker: V▪
sp.p: And yet thou doest joy ne together to other. sow together of times for others.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: How many sheetes hast thou?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Eight, but they are folded together already, only it remaineth to sow them to a parchment, set a parchment on them. n • o a parchmēt

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: What wilt thou give, if I shall sow [them] for thee?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: I have nothing which I can give for: I have no money.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Seeke thee then another workeman,there is no money to me, for I will not doe it gratis, [or for nothing]

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: My Angeline art thou so honest [and] wilt thou denie me so little a thing?good.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Doest thou kno • what the proverbe hath. meaneth?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p:
What
proverbe doest thou say. meane?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: hand rubbeth a hand. One good turne deserveth another. one hand lookes for rubbeth another.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: what wi • l this to it selfe. What meaneth this?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Give something if thou wilt receive something

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: If I had any thing, surely. certainely I would give it willingly.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Give mee thy drinking.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: My drinking; ah me w • eth. ah wretch that I am! what should I eat? I had rather give [my] cap, if I durst.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thy drinking is a small matter.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: But I am vehemently hungry.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: What cause is there?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Because I have eaten nothing at dinner, but a piece of bread,dined nothing. and three or foure walnuts.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Hoe, what was hath beene. the cause?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Because my mother was away from home

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Therfore who gave thee [thy] drinking?

sp.speaker: V
sp.p: She her selfe.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But thou saidst her to have beene away. that she was absent. away.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: It is true, for shee was away at time of dinner. at dinner time, neither returned she but a little before drinking

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Hast thou eaten nothing at home before thou camest into the schoole?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Because I feared, that I should not be present. not to be present in time.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The sound of the chappell bell. little bell ought to▪ might admonish thee sufficiently.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: But we heare seldome in. from our houses.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: what so. Why so?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Because they are farre off. distance over farre from his schoole.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Are all things true, which thou shewest unto me. tellest mee?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: In good sooth (Angeline) [they are] true.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Goe to give mee thy paper,a most fine. I will make thee an elegant little booke: in the meane while, eat thou thy drinking.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: I will aske of my mother a sextans is the sixt part of a penny, as quadrans is the fourth in french vn duble. sextance [or the sixt part of a penny] which I will give thee.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Take
heed thou aske [not] I will have nothing▪ but rather I will give to thee, if thou needest, shouldest neede. d • ddest need.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: I give thankes to thee. thee thanks.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Did •• thou not thinke that I did aske. that I asked of thee thy drinking in ea • nest?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p:
Truely I did think •
• o.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But I spake in jest.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: did speake. Wherefore▪

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That I might hea • e thee a little to talk • in latine; why. for I rejoyce that thou learne •• well: for how much hast thou bought thi • paper?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: I gave a penny with a half. three halfepence for the booke.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thou hast not bought it amisse, ill, i • is good, but thou hast not folded it. together. folded it rightly. well▪ hast thou parchment?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: See.

sp.speaker: A,
sp.p: Behold to thee, take thee. The matter is well; the matter hath well. I will dispatch it sooner the • thou it is well. couldest will eat. eate [thy] drinking.eat up.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: My Angeline I will have to thee. I will give thee very great thanks

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Thou speakest honestly, but my son remember. remember [my] sonne that thou live alwayes in the feare of the Lord, that thou obey thy mother diligently, that thou be often, ordinarily. frequent in the schoole, diligent in study, be not conversant. that thou bee no companion. that thou keepe no company with lewd. wicked and carelesse. dissolute [boyes]: to conclude doe well to whom. to whomsoever thou canst. thou shalt bee able, as thou seest mee to have done to thee, that I have done. hast thou understood •
understandest thou?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: the best of all. Very well.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: make. See then that thou remember it oft-times.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: I will doe it God willing.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Eat now quietly. at thy pleasure.
WHat what thy mother hath given thee. hath [thy] mother given thee unto. against thy drinking?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: See.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It is flesh, but what flesh?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Biefe flesh. Biefe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Whe • ther fresh or salt?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It is biefe salted. salt biefe. poudred.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Whether fat or leane?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Oh foolish boy. foole doest thou not see [it] to bee leane? that it is leane.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Hadst thou not rather * that it were, it to be. veale or calves flesh. mutton?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: both. Either is good: but venison of a kid, kids flesh. kid, especially roasted, is most savorie to me of every kind of meat: or pleaseth me best of any kinde of meat. tasteth best to mee, of any kinde.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Hoe thou fine little delicate. dainty boy, hast thou now so cunning a tast. * so learned a mouth?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I speake as I thinke, for we may not lie. wee must not lie.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Lies 〈◊〉 let them be far away. lying. Lies be farre away from us. for we are the sonnes of God, and brethren of Christ, who is the truth itselfe, as he doth witnesse, speaking concerning of himselfe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: But to the matter: I also doe eat swines [flesh] willingly. I can also eat porke very well being having taken a little salt. sprinkled with a little salt, & boyled well.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: O the wonderfull marvelous kindnesse grace of God, who giveth to us so many so • ts. kindes of victual • s, or food. meats, and good [kinds]. so good.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: How many poore poore doest thou thinke folkes to be. there are in this city, which doe live onely with barly bread neither yet unto the saturity, their bellies full. full?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I doe not doubt many to be. that there are many, especially in so great a scarsity. dea • th of victualls.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
There
• ore how great thanks owe we. ought wee to give to to doe, or are we to give.
God in so great abundance. plenty of good thing • what praises to say utter to him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Therefore let us publish, • eport, shew abroad. extoll his benefits magnitically. so • emnely, or greatly. highly every where, and in the meane time let us pray that wee may have mer • ie upon the poverty, or poore estate. want of poore or poore [servants.] his poore ones.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I wish that h • throughly stir up, • et. affect our hearts with the spirit to that thing. thereunto.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: So I pray. I pray so.
What WHy doest thou laugh?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I know not.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Knowest thou not? I say to to thee it to be. [it is] a great signe of foolishnesse.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Callest thou me • oole then?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No truly; but I tell thee that it is a signe or token. an argum • nt of foolishne • when as any man laugheth and doth not know why he laugheth. a cause of [his] laughing.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What is foolishnesse?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: If thou reade over. roule over thy Cato diligently, thou shalt finde that which thou seekest.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I have not now my Cato, and I will doe another thing.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: What businesse hast thou?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: to learne some I have thing something to learne out of the Rudiments of Grammer. Accedence.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Oh thou little foole, and doest thou talke in the meane time?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Tell mee (I pray thee) [a sentence] concerning foolishnes in Cato.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
It is the chiefest wisedome, to saine counterfait, or dissemble. make a shew of foolishnesse in place. in fit place;
whe • he • , or no • &c. hast thou not learned these things?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yea, but I did not remember.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When thou shalt bee at home looke upon. looke unto thy booke.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Oh how great thanks d • e I give to thee! I will propound this question to some one. to some body, cannot. which will not be able to answer me, and so hee will be conquered, or • et. overcome.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: oh boy hold. Hold thy peace (boy,) hold thy peace, and study lest thou bee beaten.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I doe not care much, I hold my lesson almost. I can almost say my lesson.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Vnlesse thou hold thy peace, I will tell the observer. monitour, who will note thee straightway.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Ta • ry, tarry, I will say nothing more. no more.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But remember that which I sayd unto thee.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That thou doe not laugh at any time without cause.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: But it is no ill to laugh. To laugh is not an evill thing. it is not e • ill to laugh.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I doe not say that.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What therefore. then?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is a foolish thing to laugh without a cause.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I understand it now.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: call it oft to mind. Remember it often.
whether hast thou any newes? WHat newes hast thou?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I have received newes from my brother, which dwelleth at Lions.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: When receivedst thou them?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yesterday under night. at night. a little before night.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Who brought th • m?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The fisher.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: And for what. what understood • thou by of those letters?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: that all things are well.All things • be well there, which doth appertaine to the Gospell. as much as concerneth th • Gospell.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Dost thou publish, or shew true things. report the truth

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: wayt, expect. Tar • y, and I will from dinner. shew thee the le •• ters themselves congratulate or rejoyce for. after dinner.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: True there is cause that wee should verely. rejoyce wit • our brethren.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: * Yea verily, and that we give the greatest thankes to our God.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Truely wee ought to doe that at every time. at all times but now especially when wee heare tho •• things which doe appertaine chiefely the glory of him. to his glory.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: God grant wee may hav • alwayes this thing in memory.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Wilt thou then impart, or acquaint me with. communicate thy letters with mee▪

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: As I have promised.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Therefore, after dinner.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yea doest thou doubt.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: In th • meane while farewell.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Cleophilus farewell, and God keepe, or preserve thee. God save thee.
whether is. Is thy brother at home?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Why doest thou aske this?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: My father would talke with him.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Hee is not in this city▪

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Where then?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: He is gone from home. farre from home

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Now three dayes agoe.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Whither hath he gone, or went he. is he gone?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: To Paris.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Which way is hee to make his journey?take his iourney, travell.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: By Lions.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: whether went hee a footman or horseman. Went hee on foot, or • n horse-backe?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: He went on his horse. in horse. He rid.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: When wil he come home againe. When • s hee to returne?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I know not.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: But what terme. time his father hath appointed. hath his father set him. appointed him?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Hee hath commanded. commanded that he should • e here at the twentieth day of this moneth
God leade him forth. guide him, and bring him safe backe. backe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I pray so.
when art thou to. when goest thou home. WHen wilt thou goe home?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: To morrow, God helping or assisting. by the helpe of God.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Who commanded?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: [My] father.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: But when bad he. commanded he?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: he hath written this other weeke. He writ to me hast thou received letters? the last weeke.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What day All to be. receivedst thou letters?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Vpon friday.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What did [thy] Letters containe besides?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: to be in health, rightly. That all were very well, the beginning of the grape gathering. vintage about to be, very presently. to bee the next dayes.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Oh happy. fortunate boy, who makest hast hastest to to gather in the grapes the vintage.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Wilt thou that I speake to my father that he may send for thee?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What an acceptable thing a good turne. a pleasure shouldest thou doe me? but I am afraid that hee will not▪

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yea, he will rejoyce both for our familiarity, conjunction or joyning together. friendship, and also because we shall both exercise our selves in talking together in Latine, and we shall conferre together in the meane while. sometimes concerning our studies.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
oh, I wholly leape for joy. Oh how doe I leape for joy!
my little heart, I pray thee of fellowship of all love. as ever thou wi •• doe mee a good turne care for that thing. bee carefull for 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Thou shalt see it. well perceive it: in the mean • time let us pray to God, that hee may tur •• our words, admonishest. deeds, and counsells to the glor • of hi • name.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Thou advisest well, and surely it is needfull, or profitable to doe so. expedient so to doe.
LAmbert stop, or make to stand, thy going goe not too fast. stay thy pase a little, whither makest thou hast? hastest thou?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: the right [way] home. straight home.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: wh • t thithe • ? Whereto?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: My mother desireth to talke with mee will talke, in a few [words,] or a word or two. a little.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Knowest thou not wherefore?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I know not unl • sse by chance. peradventure sh • may care winter garments to be made. that winter garments be made. That thing. that she may provide to make mee some winter apparell.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: like to be true. That is very like to be true. like to bee so, for now winter is instant, is at hand.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Now the frosts a • e seene. appeare, and ice also in some pl • ces.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I saw in these dayes. of late. within these few dayes in the market, certaine mountaine dwellers. men, fellowes inhabiting in the mountaines. dwelling in the mountaines, who reported that great wore of snow fell this last weeke,stor • , or violence of snowes to have fallen the former we • ke. when in the meane time we saw here onely sm • ll. drizling raynes. raine.

sp.speaker: L.
