sp.p: I also heard the same thing. the same at our house of countrey [men] which had brought. which brought us wheat?wheat to us but I am inforced. compelled to to breake off abruptly. breake off my speech, lest I offend my mother. lest my mother be angry lest I offend my mother. with me.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
But ho thou (my [good] Lambert) bring mee some grapes f • om
home, for you have had a most ample vintage hath bin to you you have great store of grapes. a most plentiful vintage

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I will bring (as I hope) fully enow. abundantly for us both for both of us, except if peradventure. peradventure my mother be any thing angry with me. bee angry to me. with me.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: God turne away that. God forbid.
WHither goest thou so swiftly. so fast. speedily?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: To the Barbar.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I also [will goe] with thee.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Hast thou asked leave?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I have not asked, but wayt for or expect me. tarie for me so long as, or in the meane time. so long, whilest I goe to aske.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Make haste then.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I will return by and by▪ I have returned, or come backe. I am returned, let us go presently.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: With what countenance hath entertained thee. did our master receive thee?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Truely with a merry, or cheerfull, or cheerefully, pleasant countenance

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: He had received or entertained received me also with the same like.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: He is not wont to bee angry with us, unles we go unto him unseasonably. out of season.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: what one Who among many [can be found, which] doth. will not take that grievously.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Also. Even we who are children are very often angry at our schoolfellowes,are angry at more often. when they disturbe, or trouble interrupt our studies: how little soever, how small soever they bee: but now let us give over. cease; I see in very good time. very fitly the barbar before the shop.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Ah well. Well done, there are therefore. then none expecting. tarrying •
waiting: so it shal come to passe that we may stay not long, or the lesse. lesse while.
WHither goest thou away. goest thou now alone?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Thou beginnest luckily beginnest alwaies something of verses with a verse.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is an easie matter to begin a verse; not in like manner. [but] it is not so, to leade it forth, or finish it. to make it out: but tel [me] whither go'st thou now

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: The right way to the port. Straight to the haven.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: What busines hast thou in the haven?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I goe to see, what nourishment, or meate, or provision. whether any victuals bee brought mee.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Wilt thou me to be a companion to thee. that I shall be thy companion?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yea, (I will) thee to be also, that thou be, or I would have thee f a guide also if it seeme [good] to thee so.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I have never learned to be a guide, but I have done I have plaid the fellow. companion many times.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: It appertaineth nothing to the matter to talke here in moe words. here to use many words, let us goe together.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Indeed let us go, we may talke more at large in walking by, or in the banke. on the bank of the lake, if the ship be not yet beaten to, or brought to land. be not as yet come to the haven. arrived.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What if [it be] arrived already? yet we may walke long enough, whilest the ship is &c. it is unladen.

stage.hi: The caller of the names: the Boy.

sp.p: WHere is Peter?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: He is gone. He went forth of doors. abroad.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: He hath gone. He is gone into the countrey.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: With [his] father.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Who came to call for [him?]

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The servant of (his) father. [His] fathers servant.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: When is about to returne. he to returne into the Citie?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: At the eight. About eight daies hence. Eight daies hence, as he hath said. as he said.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Of whom required. asked he leave of going forth. to goe forth?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Of the usher, undermaster.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Why not rather of the head master. schoolemaster?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: He had. he was gone forth to his, &c. about his businesse.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: I have enough.
WHither ascendest thou? goest thou?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Into our chamber.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: what thither? Whereto?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: To fetch [my] case for writing, my pensheath, orpenner or pencase. pen and inkehorne.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Bring me my girdle by one and the same worke. under the same labour.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Where is it?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Upon my arke chest.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: I will bring it: but expect me. waite for me here.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I wil stir no whither I moue. I will not stir any whither.
HOe, Gerarde?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: What wilt thou?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Thou art sent for. called for.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Who cals me?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Thy brother.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Hee lookes for thee without the doores. before the doores.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Doest thou know certainly that it is my brother?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: What but I should know. Why should I not know? I I have seene him. saw him and speake unto him.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Truely I goe to see. I will goe to see what the matter is. what it is.
DOest thou not know. us to be prohibited that we are forbidden that we speake not to speake submissively, softly or with a low voyce. low among our selves?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: what else should I know How should I but know it, when as our master doth so oft treat upon, or repeate to us oft inculcate. beate upon the causes of that thing. thereof unto us?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why then didst thou contrary even now?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Because Isaias. I 〈◊〉 had began. begun to speake to mee so.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: What then? thou oughtest to admonish him; not to imitate [him.]

sp.speaker: V
sp.p: I ought, but then I thought not of it. came not to me to minde. it came not into my mind.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
But in the mean
time thou art to be noted.

sp.speaker: V
sp.p: not at all. No verily, except. unlesse thou wilt be more severe than our master himselfe

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: tell me why? Tell me the cause.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Because our master doth forbid any one to be. that any one should be noted, who shall acknowledge his delictum is taken properly for a faule in omitting that which we should do. offence. fault of his own accord, so that it be not such a fact as is forbidden by the word of God.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Is it not commanded of God, that we obey our parents?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: That is the fift cōmandement of the precept. decalogue.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But (as we heare in our Catechisme) that commandement doth ten commandements. extend it self more largely: lye open. for it doth comprehendeth under the name. containeth. comprehend masters, and magistrates, and to conclude al [men] to whō God himself hath subiected. made us subject, under the name of parents.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Truely I. In very deed I do not deny those things, which you shew, or say. thou affirmest, to be true: but I had rather to confult with. aske counsell of our master, than dispute with thee: otherwise thou wouldest induce. bring me. or draw me. lead me into a great evill, which is the vice. which fault of contention is forbidden much more fault of contention, much more forbidden of our master.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou saist [that which is] equall. right: thou sayest well. therefore remember to put our master in minde, when he shall exact. strictly require an reasons. account of us.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Doe not thinke that I wil forget, that I shall forget. especially when as the matter concerneth my selfe. mine owne matter is done. is in hand.
FRom whence commest thou?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: out of the market. From the market.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: What newes hearest thou there?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: whether nothing. Nothing?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: [Nothing] at all.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: It is marvell that thou hast heard. that thou heardest nothing concerning war or concerning other matters of England. English matters,

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I am not wont to aske questions. to aske of those [things] which doe not belong to me. appertaine nothing. nothing appertaine to mee.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Be it so, but neverthelesse thou art wont to heare something, at least in thy iourney, or passage to and fro. in thy passage.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: let me not lie. That I may not lye, I understood. heard somewhat in may passage.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I bese • ch thee. I pray thee tell [me.].

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Now there is no space of shewing, or telling. to tell.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I must make haste another way.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: (It is) nothing to thee. Nothing to thee.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: When wilt thou then visit us againe, that wee may heare this thing of thee?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: from dinner, if it shall be lawfull by our leisure. After dinner, if we can tend, if we may have leisure.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I will love thee. Of all love make see that we may tend that wee may.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I will give my diligence. doe my indeavour: but thou detainest mee longer. over long, farewell.
FRom whence commest thou?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: From the market.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Who had sent. sent thee thither?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: [My] mother.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: What diddest thou. hast thou done in the market?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I have bought, I bought peares.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Doest thou not know it to be forbidden to us. that we are forbidden to buy any fruits?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Who knoweth not? for it was spoken openly in the hall.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: How durst thou then buy peares?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: My mother had given. gave me the sixt part of a penny. a sextance that I should buy peares for me. buy me [peares] against my drinking: what evill have I done, if I have obeyed my mother?
WHere hast thou been in these dayes. of late?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: At the country. In the countrey.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: In what place?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: In our At our farme house.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: What didst thou there?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I ministred to, or helped my father. served my father.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: But what [did] he?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: digged about, or delved about. dressed our vines.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: When returnedst thou from thence?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Only
yesterday.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: What [did] [thy] father?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: he hath returned. He returned together with mee.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Well done, but wither goest thou now?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Streight. The right [way] home.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: But when wilt thou seeke againe. goe againe to the schoole?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To morrow God helping. by Gods assistance, or at most, the day after. Therefore in the meane time farewell.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: And my Francis fare thou well.
when will Blasius returne. WHen is Blasius to returne?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I know not certainly, peradventure to morrow, but wherefore dost thou aske that thing? that?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Because he hath taken away the the bill of the nameés. catalogue with him, and our master will be angry, if there be no man. none who can call it. recite it.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: commit this charge. Leave that care to mee: I have an example. a copie of the of the bill, or table. Catalogue.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Therefore wiílt &c. thou then recite it?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I will recite it.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Thou shalt do well, and our Blasius will requite, or give thee thankes. give thee thankes, if there shall be any occasion. if any occasion shall offer it selfe.
what house, or homesteed is to thee WHat where is thy abode or where dwellest thou. dwelling place hast thou?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: [My] fathers house.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: From whence commest thou now?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: From home.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Where hast thou dined?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: At home.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Where wilt thou sup?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: At your house, as I hope.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: How knowest thou?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Thy father himselfe hath invited me to day.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Where hast thou seene him. sawest thou him?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: At the house of Varro. At Varroes house.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: What businesse was to thee. haddest thou there?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: My father sent me to shew somthing to carry a message. to doe a certaine errand.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I would know also where thou art about to lye. thou wilt lie?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: At the house of (my) brother. At [my] brothers house.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: What businesse hast thou with thy brother?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: He told our. said to our sister, himselfe to will to speake with me. that he would speake with me, when I could tend, or he could be at leisure. at leisure.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: In what house doth he dwel?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: In a certain (house) hired. hired house.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Hoe, hath he no proper house. no house of his owne?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: He hath indeed, but hee he placeth, or renteth it. doth let it to certaine inmates. tenants.take.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Doth he then let his own house [and] hire another mans (house.) another mans?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: truly. Verily, as thou hearest of mee

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: of how great price. For how much doth he let it?

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: eighteen Italian nobles, or pieces of gold. crownes which they call now Pistolets

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Why doth he not dwell in it, or in that house. inhabit it rather?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p:
Because it is
not situated, or seated. sited in a commodious place, in a place sufficiently commodious, or (as I may so speake) fit for buying and selling. marchandize.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: But for how much doth hee hire that which is another mans. that strange house?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: more by farre.. For farre more.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Therefore for how much?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: twenty and five. For five and twenty [Italian crownes]

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: It is a deare habitation. doest thou? dwelling.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: [It is] most deare, but what * what speakest thou, or what meanest thou, or what matter makes that? wouldest thou doe? the commodity of the place doth make that. cause it.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Goe to (that we may make some end. end at length) I pray thee tell me say, dost thou know where thou shalt. wilt be to morrow?

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: I wil return home, that I may betake my selfe. I may go from thence into the schoole. to the school, if so be that the Lord shall suffer permit.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Why dost thou adde, if the Lord shall permit?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Because in truth, we could not goe from our house. so much as from home, except by the permission of God.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I have heard that often of our master.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Therfore why diddest thou aske?

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: Because it is never spoken too much, which shall be wel spoken. that which is well said, can never be said too often: especially where men speake. where it is done. the speech is concerning divine matters.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: We have learnd that also of our master.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: (it is) true. True, it is good. but it is profitable to repeate such things often, to our memory to be exercised. to exercise our memory.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: See whither thy first inte • rogation. question hath brought us by little and little.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I desired. I would onely jest with thee, in few words. in a word or two.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Go to: because we have exercised our minde now. we have now exercised our mindes sufficiently, wilt thou also exercise thy body, for the cause of thy health. for thy healths sake?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: What and I will? or why may I not be willing? Why should I not?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p:
Therefore let us goe to play at hand ball. with the handball, for I know thee to be. that thou art delighted with
that play.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Truely I am delighted, but now I have not a ball.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Behold one to thee: or Here is one for thee. Here take it. take thee one, follow me

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I follow thee gladly. willingly: guide. leade me well.
How long, or until what time WHen dost thou expect the returne of thy father?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: untill the eight day hence. at the eight day hence, &c. Eight dayes hence.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: How knowest thou the day?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: My father himselfe writ. hath written to me.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: His comming will make thee rich. in rich thee, as I hope.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I shall be more rich, then Croesus ▪ if he shall come well moneyed.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Thou then wilt restore me [that which I lent. that which was] lent.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: There is no cause that thou shouldest doubt, there is not (any thing) (that) thou doubt. but if there shall be need to thee of any more. if thou shalt need any more, I wil not onely restore that which was lent, but also I will be thankefull. I will requite thankes.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I will give thee money to lend againe. I will lend thee money againe.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I hope there shall be no need to me. I shal have nothing need. no need.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: But thou knowest not what may fall out.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: The time is most short.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I speake it not to that end. for that because I would guesse or w • sh evill, forspeake, or speak unl • ckily bode evill to thee.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: What soever men doe bode, God ruleth all. God holdeth the the helme. stearne.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: But why doe we not hast to get our selves, what do we linger to betake our selves into the auditorie, schoole?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Thou admonishest seasonably. fitly.
when hast thou returned?WHen returnedst thou from home?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I returne onely [now.]

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Where is [thy] brother

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: He hath • arried. tarried at home.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Wherefore did hee tarry?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: That he might dine with my mother.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But why hast thou not tarried? why didst not thou stay? why didst not thou tarry also?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I had dined already. even now with my father.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Who served you?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: a girle, maide, or handmaid. [Our] girle.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What [did] [thy] mother? where was shee?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: At home also, but busied.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: In what thing?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: In receiving wheat which was. which had been brought us.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When wilt thou returne home?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: a When I shall be sent for when my father shall send for me by [my] father.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What day shall this thing shall be. that be?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Peradventure at four daies hence foure daies hence.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why goe you so oft to and fro.Why goe ye together so oft?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: [Our] parents will so. will have it so.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What do ye at home?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: That which we are commanded of our parents.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But in the meane while, doth perish to you your time of studies you lose your time. is lost.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: it doth not perish at all. it is not lost at all.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: As oft as our father is notoccupied necessary. necessarily busied, he doth exercise us at all houres: in the morning, before and after dinner, before supper, from supper. after supper, long enough. very long; last of all also, before wee goe to bed.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
In what things
doth hee exercise you?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Hee doth require strictly. exact of us these things especially, which we have learned in the schoole the whole weeke. all the weeke: he looketh upon our Theames. looketh into our Theames, and doth aske us concerning those things: oft he doth give us. he oft gives us some thing to be described, or set downe written downe, sometime in Latine, sometime English: sometime also he doth propound unto us a short sentence in our owne tongue, or that which every bondslave, or country fellow can speake. in our country speech. in our mother tongue which we may turne into Latine: sometimes contrarily he doth command to render, or give againe. repeat some thing in Latine. some Latine [sentence] in English: last of all, before meate, and after, we reade alwaies somthing out of the English Bibles. Bible, and that before all the family. the whole family being present.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Doth he aske nothing concerning the Catechisme?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: He doth that every Dominicall day, unlesse. every Lords day, except peradventure he be absent from home.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou shewest, or reportest to me wonderfull things. tellest [me] y marvelous things, if they be true. if so be, that they bee true.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yea they are long or many more farre moe then which I have told thee; for I I forgot. have forgotten the civility of manners, concerning which hee is wont also to admonish us in the table▪ at the table.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why doth your father spend. take so much labour in teaching you?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: That hee may so understand, whether we play our diligence. lose our labour in the schoole and abuse our time.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The diligence of the man is marvelous, and so his prudence. wisdome. O how are ye bound to the heavenly father, whohath given to you hath given you such a father in the earth?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: He graunt that we never forget this and the rest of his benefits. other his benefits.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
This with
is good and godlycare. see that. be carefull that thou have it not onely in thy mouth, but more, also in thy heart. I have thankes to thee. minde.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I thanke thee that thou dost admonish me, so faithfully.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: We owe the duty of admonishing well. of good admonition to all, but chiefly. especially to our brethren.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: therfore whether onely. Onely then to our brethren?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I call those brethren here especially which are joyned unto us by faith in Christ.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thou judgest rightly, but I goe I will go to see whether [my] brother hath returned, is returned from home at length: for he is more then enough ready, over ready to to cease to be • dle, or to play the truant. loyter.
DOest thou write in good earnest, or dost thou trifle, doest thou play the foole?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: in good sooth I in truth. In truth I do write in earnest, for why should I abuse the time? But wherfore doest thou aske that?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Because I have seene sometime when thou diddest write. writtest well.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Sometimes I write better.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: How then is it done? commeth it to passe that thou writest so badly now?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The helps of writing well are wanting to me. I want the helpes of faire writing.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What I pray thee?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Good paper, good inke, a good penne: for this my paper (as thou seest) doth flow thorow. sinke miserably, my inke is waterish and somewhat white. whitish,
my pen soft and ill made.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Why hast thou not provided al these things ripely, or seasonably. in time?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: money was wanting to me, and also is wanting. I wanted money, and now also doe want.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thou hast fallen into that vulgar. common proverb: All things are wanting to him, to whom money is wanting.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: So it is done. it fareth with mee.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: But when doest thou hope thee to receive. that thou shalt receive money?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: My father will send to mee in the next market. the next mart, or hee himselfe will come,

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I will helpe thee in the meane time.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: If so be thou canst do that, thou shalt affect me with a great benefit, or good turne. doe me a great kindenesse.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I will lend thee these sixe pence. Take mu • ually, or to love. Take these sixe pence to prepare paper, and to buy other things.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How truely is that spoken; A sure friend is seen in an uncertaine matter. in a doubtfull matter: but what inforceth. moveth thee. causeth thee that thou dealest so bountifully to me to deale so bountifully with me, of thine own accord?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: That love of God which (as Paul saith) is shed abroad in our hearts.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The power. force of the divine spirit. of the spirit of God, which is the author of that charity, wonderfull. is marvellous: but in the meane time it is to be thought to me, how I may requite thanks to thee. I must thinke how I may be thankfull to thee.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It is a small matter: omit this cogitation, lest it hinder thee that thou cannot be quiet. cannot sleepe on whether eare thou wilt, onely restore that lent give it me againe. restore that which I lent thee, when it shall be commodious to thee when thou canst commodiously.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I will restore it (as I hope) within a few daies, or within a day almost. shortly.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Let us goe to prayer lest we be noted.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Adde one thing if it please thee.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Lest we be sent to day not having supped, or without our suppers. supperlesse to bed.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Ha, ha he.
AT what houre hast thou • isen? what a clocke rose thou to day? A little before the fift (houre) before five.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Who awaked thee?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: No man.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: whether have the rest risen now? Are the rest risen already?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Not as yet.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Hast thou not gone. Wentest thou not to raise them up?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I went not.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: for what thing. Wherefore?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I know not, except because I did not thinke. but that I thought that that that matter did not appertaine to me. it did not belong to me.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: whether do they not raise thee up, &c. Do they not stir thee up somtime?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Yea very often.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Therefore thou oughtest to doe likewise.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I confesse I have owne. I ought.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Therfore remember, that thou doe it hereafter.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I shall remember God helping.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: but thou. But what hast thou done from that time thou hast risen? But what didst thou from the time that thou rose out of bed?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: First I prayed upon my knees unto [my] knees being bowed, I prayed unto my heavenly father, in the name of his sonne Iesus Christ our Lord. his sonne our Lord Iesus Christ.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Well done: what after?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Afterward I adorned me. I made my self handsome and cared for my body meanely. decently, as becommeth a Christian, last of all I betook my selfe to [my] daily studies.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: If thou shalt goe on to doe so, thou maist not doubt, but that God can doubt not but that God will helpe or further. promote thy studies.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p:
Hee hath helped mee alwaies as yet, such is his goodnesse. which is his bountie, neither will he utterly leave me. forsake me, as I
hope.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Thou speakest rightly. well: neither will he mak • vaine. frustrate thy hope.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I haue learned out of Cato the former yeare. the last yeare; Keepe hope, onely hope doth leave a man no not in death. doth not leave a man in death.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Thou hast thou done well that thou hast remembred it. retained it▪ for it is an egregious. excellent sentence, and worthy. beseeming a Christian

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: But the author of that booke was not a Christian.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: He was not, the thing is certain, it is a cleer case. it is a certaine truth.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: From whence then hath hee fetched. taken so many faire. fine, or excellent, goodly sentences?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Out of the heathen Philosophers chiefly, for even they being illuminated. enlightned by the divine spirit. by the spirit of God, have uttered very many things, which are agreeable to the word of God, which thing thou also shalt be able to see somtime. at length, if thou shalt prosecute. follow thy booke. follow the studie of letters. learning.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I wil follow it (as I hope) so that God himselfe. God give, grant my father a longer. a long life.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Pray earnestly. diligently, and from thy heart, that it may bee so. it may happen. fall out.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I pray for that every day▪ daily oftentimes.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: The Lord God give thee perseverance in every good work.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I pray the same for thee, which thou wishest to mee, and I give thee thanks that thou hast admonished mee so brotherly.
WHere are thy walnuts?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Concerning. Of what walnuts dost thou speak?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Which thou hast received. thou receivedst to day of a praemium. for a reward.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Doest thou aske where they are, as if truly. indeed I ought to keepe them to thee. for thee?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I do not understand so. I doe not meane so, but I aske what thou hast done.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I have eaten [them] in my drinking. at my drinking.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: O wretch, hast thou eaten them? Wherefore didst thou not keep them rather to play?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I had rather eat them, than lose them.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Thou couldest not lose but twelve.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I confesse it.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: If so bee that lot had suffered. hap had served, or chance. luck had served, thou might gaine. mightest have gained two hundred or peradventure mo.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: The event of play is doubtfull, as it is said commonly.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What then? we ought to be prepared every where unto. for either part. for both parts, and to to consult of good. take in good part, whatsoever shall fall out. shall happen to us.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I know that, but I am not very skilfull in that kinde of playing. of play.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Goe thy way: thou wilt never make a matter, or get gaine or substance, or bee rich. thrive.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: No man thriveth, but God willing. by the will of God: neither I would bee made rich of play. doe I desire to bee inriched by play.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Therefore (as I see) I must seek another play-fellow. another play-fellow is to bee sought to mee. for of mee.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Truly I hinder nothing. I doe not hinder [thee,] but tarry a little.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What wilt thou?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What doest thou call lot. chance of which. luck, whereof thou madest mention. concerning which thou hast here made mention to mee.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: the very fortune. Fortune it selfe.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: But what is fortune?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The opinion of Fooles.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What doe fooles think concerning fortune?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Now it is not vacant to mee. I cannot tend. I cannot now bee at leasure to answer thee concerning this, but see the annotation of our master upon Cato.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Vpon what place?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Vpon that litle verse;
sp.q: Fortune doth favour. cocker evill men, that it may hurt them.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: As I see, thou art not ignorant what fortune is.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I know sufficiently. well enough that fortune is nothing. fortune to bee nothing.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Why then saiedst thou, If so bee that chance, or lot he carried. luck had served?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: it fell out from mee. It overslipped mee to speake so, after the manner of Ethnicks. heathens, for the bookes of them. their books (as our master teacheth often) are full with ungodly doctrine of that sort. of such like impious doctrine.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: It is no maruell; to wit. for because. for that they have not had the true knowledge of God.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: But heare my Barrase if thou wilt dispute any more, seek other disputers for thee. seeke thee other to dispute with thee. disputers, for now I must play in good earnest: notwithstanding I will admonish thee againe before.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
O what an acceptab •• thing▪
a pleasure. a good turne shalt thou doe mee?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: whether or no saidest thou not? Spakest thou not these words, The the chance. event of play is doubtfull?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I confesse that I said so, but fortified it. fensed it before.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
How understandest thou this thin •
this?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
For I have added. I added these
three words. As it is said commonly.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: O crafty little boy, thou hast stopped • he mouth to mee. thou hast stopped my mouth: but these things let •• em bee spoken. but let these things bee spoken without hatred or ill will between us.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: God knoweth both our mindes. the minde of both of us.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: For hee alone is the searcher of the hearts, but what wilt thou doe? what then? wilt thou wax drousie here • lone in idlenesse. lye idle here alone?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I devise with what play I may exercise mee. my selfe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: As if indeed it is to bee thought of any longer. Goe to, follow me, I will give thee to end. I will lend thee walnuts.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Thou now speakest friendly, but when shall I restore them?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
never; because the • recians had no Ca
• ends, as the Romans • ad. At the Greeke Calends, if thou canst not sooner.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: O pleasant head! let us go.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: What wilt thou?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Let us repeat our lesson together.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: There is no leasure • o mee. I cannot • end. I have no leasure.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: What businesse hast thou?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I will write.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: What doest thou prepare to write?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: our Masters dictates, or notes. The Dictates of [our] master.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: why writest them • or? Why hast thou not written them yesterday?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: when. At what time should I I had. have written them?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: when it was played [of you] When ye played.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: But I would not lose occasion of playing. of play.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p:
Ah slow
• ack slow [fellow] thou musest, or • hinkest of. meditatest no other thing than playes. but play: are there not 3 hours free
upon the dayes o • Mercury, and the Sabb • th, viz. Jewes Sabboth, Saturday. on wednesdayes and saturdayes?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Truly they are free, but destined. destinated, deputed, given. appointed, assigned to play.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Yea they are dedicated partly to pastimes, or sports. play, or to some honest remission recreation, partly to studie. to the studie belonging to learning. of learning.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I confesse it onely to them who will be continuall at. die at their studies. bookes.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Couldest thou not withdraw or spare. detract yesterday an houre and a halfe from thy play, or at least one onely houre?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Studie thou as much as thou wilt, but I will play as long as it shall be lawfull. I may.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Truly it shall bee lawful by mee. thou maiest for mee, but in the mean time thou wilt goe forward, or pro • fit smally, thou wilt doe little good. thou wilt proceed little in at thy booke. learning.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Do I not satisfie [my] master?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: after some manner. So and so.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: O studious young man, therefore thou, &c. O studious youth! thou wilt then bee more severe than our master himselfe: omit mee at least. let mee alone at length: doe thine owne businesse, I [will do] mine.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Go to, as it listeth. pleaseth thee.
WHen wilt thou repeat, or seeke the schoole againe. go again into the school?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I know not.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Why dost thou not admonish [thy,] &c speake to thy father. put thy father in minde concerning this matter?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: What, dost thou think mee to care. that I care?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Very little, as I beleeve.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Verily thou saist the truth.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p:
It is a an evident signe.
sufficient token, thee not to love. that thou doest not • e learning. that thou lovest not thy booke.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
I • e knowledge e
• ough. I know [how] to read, to write, to speak Latine, at least meanly: what need is to mee it. what need • e I of. what need I so much knowledge? I know moe • ings. more than three Popish Priests.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: O wretched. miserable young man! dost thou contemn dost thou so contemne a thing unestimable?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
Why doest thou exclaime so? whereupon unvaluable mat
•• r. doe I seeme to thee a wretch, [so] wretched?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: O friend I have one thee no injurie. no injurie is risen. done to thee from mee. by mee; for what I said to thee is not railing. a reproach: thou maist • ot take it in, &c. take it not in the evill part; but I pittie thee. I have pittie of thee, because thou contemnest that which doth bring forth get. breed felicitie.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Game, riches, and pleasure, do do bring forth. breed felicitie.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Yea these things have beene a destruction to many [men,] although riches are the gift of God, neither doe they hurt, except them who doe abuse [them:] but verily there is. no possession is more precious to man, than vertue, and the knowledge of honest things.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Thou then wilt preach, as I see.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I would thou hadst heard godly sermons. divine sermons diligently.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Hoe, thou beatest upon • e, or anoyest mee. thou troublest me: wilt thou any thing?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: That God may give thee a good minde.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Peradventure • here is more need of • hat to thee than to me. Thou peradventure hast more need of that than I. That peradventure is more needfull to thee than to mee, farewell.
I Marvell what thou wilt to thy selfe. what thou meanest, thou art almost alway idle. thou art idle almost alway, or doest prattle, trifle. or play the foole.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What wilt thou have mee to doe. that I doe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That thou studie diligently.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Why doest thou admonish mee of that thing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: For my love toward thee, and thine owne profit.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Thou admonishest in vaine.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: What so? Why so?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Because my minde is not to mee in letters. I have no minde to my booke.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Therefore what wouldest thou? What wouldest thou then?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Learne some trade, or science. Art apt for. fit for my wit.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Hast thou thought what Art now. already may like thee especially?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: now long agoe. A good while agoe.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Why then doest thou not admonish, or put thy father in minde of it, speake to thy father?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I durst never.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I durst never.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I am afraid lest hee shoul • bee angry at mee. that he may be angry at me.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Aske [thy] master that hee may tell him.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yea I pray thee (my Antony) tell thou my master. thou thy selfe tell my master in my behalfe or for me. in my words, name, for shamefas • nesse. I cannot for bashfulnesse. bashfulnesse doth hinder mee: wilt thou doe what, [that] which I desire?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Surely I will do • it, and that most willingly, • or it doth irke mee greatly, to see thee so slack, or carelesse. so remisse.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: O what good turne. an acceptable thing. what a kindnesse shalt thou doe mee!

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But our master will call thee.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
What then? The
occasion offred will make mee bold to my minde to bee • pened freely. to open my minde freely.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thou judgest rightly. well.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
make. see thou that. See therefore Thou shalt remem
• er. thou remember thy promise, afterward report back to •• ee, or tell mee. shew mee againe what he shall answer thee.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Otherwise I should not bee a messenger for thee. bee an unprofitable messenger for thee.
Frisius God save • hee. GOd save thee Frisius.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Michael be thou safe • lso. God save thee also, what a clock is it?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thou shalt heare, by and by, the sound of halfe an hou • e. the halfe houre after the fi •• houre. after five.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: it hath well.It is well: wee shall be present early enough.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
I rejoyce mee • o have met thee. that I have met thee, that we going may 〈◊〉
that going wee may talke together in Latine so long.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Truly that is a profitable and pleasant exercise.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: How oft I fall into. As oft as I fall upon any of these loose, or carelesse. di •• olute knaves, I would rather to meet with 〈◊〉 Cocheman. have found a carter: for it is not lawfull for mee. I cannot meditate any thing in the way for them. by them, I so hate their manners. their manners are so odious to me.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: It is no marvel, for they are almost. for the most part such, that neither they will, &c. that they will neither speake any thing of good. any good, neither can endure to heare.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What doest thou with them to whom there is no care. who have no care, but that. except that they may fulfill their lusts?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p:
They brag, or talke of. cracke of no other things except. but
their delicate dishes. junkets and meere bezeling. only drinkings together tipling houses, or little • nnes. in secret ale-houses.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yea they laugh at us fully. with full cheeks, because wee speake Latine by the streets, or as wee goe thorow the streets. in the streets: but that is the worst of all they suffer themselves no where to. &c. that they will not indure to be admonished. suffer themselves to bee admonished no where. at all.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: utterly. to wit Doubtlesse, because (as the Prophet saith) the feare of God is not before eyes of them. their eyes.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: If thou shalt begin to admonish [them] friendly any thing. to admonish them of any thing friendly, thou shalt heare straightway, O Preacher, hold thy peace, thou doest annoy me, or fillest my head full of noyse. thou troublest mee: if so bee that thou shalt say, I will carrie thee to our schoole-master. [our] master, or to the monitor, oh say they what care I for that? thou darest not. I care wel much; thou durst not: for if thou shouldest accuse mee, I would bee meet with thee. thou shouldest not beare it. carry it away unpunished, without punishment, quit. scot-free.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Yea verily they will beat thee forthwith, or straightway. presently if there shall be. if they can finde a place remote from arbitrators or Iudgers. where they may do it secretly. witnesses.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: In good • ooth when a certaine [boy] one of them had found. found mee of late, in a certaine a hid place, in a place remote. secret corner, hee dashed to me. hee gave mee two huge blowes. very great buffets on both cheeks, and run away presently. upon either cheek, and fled away forthwith.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I pray thee what [didst] thou in the meane time?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: why dost thou ask. What doest thou aske that? it hath been. it was so sudden, that I could scarcely behold. see the man.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: But how have we come. are wee come so quickly, and sensim sive sensu. without any wearinesse unto the schoole?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: it falleth out so usually. It is wont to come in use almost so to talkers together. to fall our usually so, to them who talk together.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Goe to, let us enter without any trouble, disquiet, or disturb, noyse and stir,by little and litle, without any feeling. lest we offend them who study. the students.
FRom whence doest thou bring that little coat?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: From home.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What wilt thou do?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I will put it on.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: There is no time to change it. no time of changing now.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When then?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: To morrow in the morning, so soone as thou shalt rise, &c. when thou shalt rise out of thy bed.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thou doest admonish. advisest well, I will wait. I will expect.
OH, I have heard thy • i • ter to have beene married. that thy • ister is married.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Thou hast heard the truth.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Who is the husband of her. her husband.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A certain citizen of Lugdune. Lions begotten, or borne, or descended. bred of honest parents.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Is hee rich?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Hee is accounted so: but notwithstanding my father doth esteeme far more of these things. doth account these things long or much of more value. of far more value, first because hee is a well nurtured. mannered young man: afterward; or furthermore moreover, because hee is not onely most learned, but also most most loving. studious of good learning. of good letters; to
conclude, because he is a true worshipper of God, and a chiefe professor. observer of Christian religion.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Thou tellest mee
• greg •
ous. titles. notable commendations of the young man. O thy sister happy. happie is thy sister. O happie sister of thine which hath gotten such a husband by the benefit goodnesse of God!

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Truly thou hast called her. thou maist call her happie not unjustly. not withou • cause, if so be that shee acknowledge so. shee can so acknowledge that blessing. good thing perpetually, that shee can remember alwaies, it to become. that it is come from the goodnesse of God, and give him immortall thanks for the same. give to the same. him immortall thanks for it.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I beleeve her to do it. I beleeve that shee will doe it.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Truly I hope so, for shee hath been so taught. she hath been instructed so alwaies. shee hath beene alwayes so instructed of her parents in the Christian religion. doctrine: but domesticall businesses doe recall me now. do now call mee backe to another place. otherwhither, therefore my Anthonie, farewell.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thou also (O most sweet Daniel,) farewell.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: whether wilt tho • any thing. Wilt thou any thing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That thou say. doe very many salutations, or commendations. hearty salutation to all thy friends, in my name; especially to thy father, and to thy mother,mee to congratulate, or rejoyce together for, or wish all happinesse to▪ and to the new married wife her selfe, and and shew that I doe. shew how I doe congratulate that luck • e marriage to her.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Truly I will doe that thing. that, and indeed most willingly.
I have not seene thee. I Saw thee not to day at the sermon. in the assembly, what will that to it selfe. what meaneth that?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I know not what it will to it selfe. what it meaneth, yet I was present. I was there.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Shew mee what thou dost remember. what things thou hast committed to memorie.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: It is not thy [office] to require strictly. to exact a reason. an account of me.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Truly I doe not exact an account: but I doe aske that, that wee may confer together, for the cause of our memorie. for our memories sake.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I rather chuse to remember. I will rather remember now alone: Thou shalt heare mee (if thou wilt) when our master shall examine us. aske us questions before dinner.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Wkat evill should it bee, if wee should confer now betweene our selves, concerning that matter?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I confesse, it should bee no evill, but now it doth not list mee. I list not.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Therfore thy will. lust doth governe. rule thee.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Omit mee. Let me alone: why dost thou trouble mee? why art thou troublesome to mee?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Truly I let thee alone, but heare one word: It doth not become a boy to bee so froward, wayward, te • ty, hard to please. peevish.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Whether doth it become a boy to bee so troublesome?
WHat hast thou done with my ruler. my rule?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I left it in the upper gallerie.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Why hast thou left it? leftest thou it?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I forgot it.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: [It is] not done rightly. well done, but thou art wont so usually, if any thing bee lent. have been lent thee.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: It irketh me of my negligence.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: It is not enough to to grieve. be sorrie, except thou wilt change thy manners.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I will pray God that hee will change mee. that he will change manners for mee. change [my manners].

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: If thou bee wise: otherwise. else no man will • end to thee hereafter.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: have thanke to thee. I give thee thankes. I thanke [thee] that thou hast warned. admonished mee so friendly.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Goe now to fetch my rule, for there is need of it to mee. I have need of it to rule my booke. to draw lines in my paper.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I goe now.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Bring it to mee into the chamber.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Thou shalt have it by and by.
WHy dost thou laugh being alone. all alone?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What [doth it concern] thy [matter.] thee?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Because peradventure thou laughest at mee.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Whence is that suspition risen to thee? From whence doest thou suspect that▪

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Because thou art bad, nought. evill.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Truly wee all are evill, but I am not worse than thee. than thou: doth then no man laugh unlesse he •
mock some body. laugh at some one?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: I doe not understand so. mean • so: but hee who laugheth alone (as I have heard often) either is a foole, or thinketh some ill.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I know not of whom. whose sentence this is, but of whom soever. whose soever it is, it is not true perpetually: notwithstanding I take thy admonition in good part, and I warne thee againe, that thou take heed to be suspicious. how thou art suspicious, for death is most ready to selfe upon fearfull and suspicious men. most apt to fearefull men and suspicious, as it is in our morall verse.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: I remember it, yet I consult of good, or esteeme of a good value, or esteeme much of. I take thy admonition in good part. I take in good part thy admonition.
FRom whence commest thou?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: From home.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: What is done. do they at your house.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: it is nothing to thee, or it maketh no matter to thee. It skilleth nothing thy matter. It concerneth thee nothing.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: I confesse it, but we are wont for most part, almost. usually to aske our familiars so, (even as we aske, how doe yee:) how goeth all with you, or how fare your matters. how stand your matters?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It doth not become to bee too busie in asking. to aske over much of another mans matter.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: I hold my peace, but tho • seemest to mee to be wise too much. to be over-wise for thy age▪

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I call nothing mine owne, I have heard that often.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: I also have heard it not once.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Therefore why dost thou not use it?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Because it doth not come alwayes into my minde.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yea because thou art a busie demander. a busie asker of questions, which thing is reproved not unjustly, is given for a fault. blamed not without cause.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: have thanke to thee. I thanke thee, because thou doest admonish me so friendly: hereafter God willing, I will take heed to bee fond, or foolish. of playing the foole.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: So thou shalt wax wise at length. by little and little.
you, or oh Sirrah▪ HOe thou, [our] master is present.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: looke backe. Look to him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: that thou mayest put off to him. That thou mayest open thy head. uncover thy head to him and [that thou maist] salute him comming.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It becommeth to do so, but I did think another thing.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Hold thy peace.
FRom whence commest thou?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: From abroad.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why hadst thou gone. wentest thou forth?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: To make water.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: of what sort is the face of the heaven. How looketh it. How is the skie?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Cloudie.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The frost is so thawed. resolved, that the snowes begin to melt altogether. snow begins wholly to melt.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Doth it not raine also?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I have perceived something to drop downe, to mizzle. to distill from above.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Peradventure in the descending. passage from the eves. dropping of the house.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yea I know out of the clouds. from the clouds: if so that thou doe not beleeve it, thou thy selfe see. see thy selfe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: As if I may not beleeve thee in such a very little matter.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Why then didst thou seeme to doubt?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That I might talke with thee in mo • words. have more talke with thee.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: whither doth that appertaine. To what end serveth that?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: To exercise [our] Latin tongue. Latine tongue.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: But in the meane time wee speake often idle words, from which Christ hath commanded to abstaine altogether.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou errest in the whole way. Thou missest, or mistakest. art wholly deceived in the understanding of the commandement.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Why sayest thou that?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Because it is not an idle speech which is referred to any institution. for teaching sake. instruction, especially when it is done. wee speake concerning. it is concerning good and honest matters, what ones the workes of God are. of which sort are the works of God in naturall things.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Thou
seemest to mee judge. to thinke rightly, therefore I easily assent unto thee.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: but let these things bee spoken. But these things hitherto, we must goe in hand with another businesse. another businesse is instant to us. is at hand.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Go to; let us cease. leave off.
DOest thou know what a clocke it is?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I know not the certaine. certainly, but I see the time of supper to bee at hand. it to be supper time.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: [O] O wretch that I am. me wretch! I have forgotten to go to my mother as shee had. which had commanded mee.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Run, run, thou wilt come in very good time. very fitly, that thou maiest sup at home.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: thou warnest [me] well, I goe to aske leave.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Behold him. Behold the usher.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: hee is welcome. He is present the best of all. in very good time.
WHat saiest thou Of. concerning the penknife, which I had bought for thee. I bought thee now the third day. now three days ago, is it good enough. a good one?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p:
Yea truly it is a very good one. the best. a passing good one (e me wretch!O wretch that I am.)
it hath beene away a little, but I have lost it. I had almost lost it. it wanted but a little but that I had lost it.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Hoe, what sayest thou? How hath that happened. how came that to passe. how fell that out?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: When I came backe. returned from abroad it had fallen. it fell from mee in the street.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: From whence had • t fallen out? fell it?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Out of my sheath, which I had left open carelesly. unwisely.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: How recoveredst thou it? gottest thou it againe?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I had fixed, or fastned to. I set up a siquis, or note. a little paper straightway to the. on the boards. leaves of the gate [and] a certaine boy of the sixt forme brought it mee after dinner.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I would all were so faithfull, who finde things lost.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Truly there are few who doe restore, if so be that it be a thing of any value, or price of any worth.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: And yet that is commanded, by name. namely, in the. by the Word of God.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: What else? For it is a kind of theft, if any man keepe back. retaine another mans goods, or things. anothers goods, being found, so that he can know to whom it is to bee restored.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: But most men thinke that they may lawfully keepe. themselves to possesse rightly. by right, whatsoever lost thing they shall finde.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Truly they are fouly deceived. they doe erre most grievously.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: But that wee may returne to our speech begun. former speech, what gavest thou. what hast thou given to the boy who found thy penknife?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I gave him a little peece of • ilver. a sextant and some. a few walnuts. I praised him moreover, and I advised him in few words. in a word or two the same thing to be done alwayes. to do so alwaies.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Thou hast done. didst well, for so he will restore more willingly at other times, if he shall finde any thing: but what if thou hadst lost it?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I had taken it with an equall minde, and I had bought another to mee. I would have taken it patiently, and have bought mee another.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Hast thou taken it with so patient a minde. Wouldest thou have taken it so patiently?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Verily not without some griefe.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p:
Therefore not patiently. with a patient minde, but
I will urge thee more strictly. straitly.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: We are not Divines.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: little Grammarian or smattering Grammarians. Young Grammarians.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: And indeed unskilfull.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: We ought to pray to God more deligently by so much. so much more diligently, that hee may deliver us by his Gospell, from the darknesses. darknesse of ignorance in which both wee have beene conversant. lived and as yet are conversant, o • doe remaine. do live.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: That verily we shall doe. Verily we shall do that if we obey the holy admonitions which wee heare dayly of our master, and of the Preachers the Ministers of of the divine Word. Gods Word.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: See how much the losing of my penknife hath gained. profited us.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I rejoyce for thy cause, or with thee. I congratulate thee double for that matter; first because I have bought it well for thee, and then because thou hast recovered it. got it againe being lost.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: have thanks to thee. I give thee thankes O my Rouland.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: But praise and giving of thanks. thanksgiving bee to our heavenly father.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Amen.
I doe not thinke thou art. THou seemest not to me, too much or very much busie, or occupied. very busie.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: mea •• ly, or in a meane, 〈◊〉 so. Reasonably.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What if thou sharpen. make me two or three pens?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: bee enough for thee. It may suffice thee, if I shall sharpen. make one for the present: whether are they new. are they new?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Indeed they are new, but prepare thy selfe, till they be sharpened: for now I have smoothed them, I have cut
off the end, or taile- the top [and] I have plucked off the plumes. feathers.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Shew them; truly they are very good. the best. notable and most apt to write. fit for writing.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: from whence • ast thou knowne his? How knowest thou this?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Because they are of a ample. large. big stalk. quil, strong and bright. shining; for the soft, and which have a shorter quill are • ittle fit. nothing • eet. are nothing fit to write • ithall. for the use of writing.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I rejoyce me • o have bought them • rofitably. I am glad that I bought [them] well.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: not • ithout matter. Not without cause: but for • ow much price. for how much?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I have given two quadrants, or • wo farthings. a halfepenie for these three.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Thou then hast bought every one of them for two deneeres a peece.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
The matter doth • peare. is very •• are. is apparent: It is a sorry price. vile, or base. a small price for one • ho goeth from mar
• et to market, or • ho makes his market • ery where. the goodnesse of the thing.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Of whom boughtest thou them?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Of a certaine pedler.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
every • n, or quill. Each severall [quill,] and indeed lesse • od. not so good, are sold for for, q. c. one
• bble. sextants with. amongst the Mercers of this towne.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: And notwithstanding they dare say sometime to and, or be of more; at they stand them more. that they cost them more at Lions.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
That is commonly the custome of of Mer
• ants, them who buy 〈◊〉 sell. Mercers, for they gain nothing unlesse they lye very great
••
exceedingly, as Tully saith.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: But go to, that I may not stay thee any longer, let us doe that which is instant, 〈◊〉 to be done, or •• refully, or well. which we have in hand.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
I shall dispatch it quickly: looke upon mee heedfully, that thou mayest learne
• ometime. at length.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
I look with [mine] eye, intent, wholly bent there
•• . earnestly fixt, but there was • ed to mee of. but I had need of a little longer space.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Therefore I •• ll doe it. it shall be done in [my] chamber, if thou wilt visit me at any time.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: At what time?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
After the sending • ay of the scholers. breaking up, or •• ving the schoole. dismissing of the school, that is to say, at the ninth houre belonging to the morning. nine of the clocke in the
morning, or at foure in the afternoon. Now thou hast two pens fitted rightly for hand. use, except I be deceived: thou shalt keepe this third to thee. for thy selfe untouched untill another time.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Take it thee if it please thee.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: But keepe it to thy selfe, many enough. I have enow brought mee from home. enow are brought to mee from home.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I give to thee as great thankes as I can. all possible thankes: farewell.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: God keepe thee safe. in safetie: but hoe thou mayes • not spare for. doe not spare my labour at any time.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thou also use agai • or by course. in like manner, both mee and my things if thou shalt need. if there shall bee any need: farewell, againe.
FRom whence diddest thou come. cam'st thou even now?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Out of the kitchin.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: what hadst thou gone thither? Why wentest thou thither?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That I might warme me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou (I beleeve) art. I beleeve, thou art more willingly in the kitchen than in the schoole; whether or no? [is it] not so?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: No marvell, a fire is not. there is not a fire in the schoole, as in the kitchin.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Goe thy way, thou art wise.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I would I were so wise in divine things, as in the care of my body.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: make [or see] th •• be wise. Bee carefull to get wisdome.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: By studie, care, labour, diligence.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I doe not spare labour. I spare no labour, diligence.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Thou doest well, but wee must expect a time, in continuance, or proceeding whereof. progresse whereof all thing are done in
the meane while God is to be prayed • nto. we must pray to God continually.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Thou admonishest. advisest well, God grant. I wish he may promote our studies to the glorie of his name.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
He will do it, if we pro
• eed, or goe for
• ard. hold on to serve him • arefully. to worship him diligently.
O Capusius, what doest thou think. muse with thy selfe?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I would goe home •• llingly. willingly goe home.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Whereto?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: That I might recreate my selfe a little with my mother in these dayes, or • ese few dayes. at this time.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: stands against it. what aileth thee. what hindreth that thou mayest lesse. that thou mayest not goe?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: My master will not permit.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: he provides, consults better. He is more carefull for thee than thou thy selfe thinkest.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
For in the mean while thou wouldest lose much time, and it would grieve thee, when thou
• houldest had re
•• rned. hadst returned: do I not say true?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Indeed it is so.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Therefore tarry▪ if thou be wise.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
I will obey thy counsell, because it seemeth
• ight. good unto me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
I would not give thee evil counsell
• nowing, or wit
• g. wittingly: and I pray God [that] that which I perswade thee. perswade
•• y have prospe
•• us successe. may succeed prosperously unto thee.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
I hope
• o bee so. it will be so, God willing.
HOw much money hast thou?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: a penny with a halfe penny. Three h • lfe pence: but thou. but [how much hast] thou?

sp.speaker: M▪
sp.p: Not so much.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: How much then?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: but one bare penny or one single penny. One onely penny.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: wilt thou give mee mutually lend it me?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I there is need to me have need of it my selfe.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: For what purpose. use?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: To buy paper.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I will give it you againe to day. I will restore it to thee to day.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It hath beene to be added, God helping. to have put to. Thou shouldst have put to, by the helpe of God.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: So our master teacheth out of the Word of God, but I cannot accustome [my selfe].

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: make, or be carefull. See that thou doe accustome thy selfe.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: How shall that bee done, or come to passe. bee?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: If thou thinke often us to hang so on God. that we so depend upon God, that we can do nothing without his aid.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Thou givest mee good counsell.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: of what sort, or what manner I would, or wish. Such as I desire to bee given me.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: But that we may returne to the purpose, w • thou give to lend. wilt thou lend [me] this pennie.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
I marvell thee to aske mutu •
ly. that thou doest aske to borrow, who hast more money. more than I.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
There is a certaine scholar, passing by. who useth to passe this way, which sheweth often, or offere •
profers a sale-booke, or a booke set on sale. a booke to bee sold.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I did desire to buy it, because he doth shew, or pro • . offer it cheaper than our stationer booke-sellers.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Take it, but I pray thee how wilt thou restore it so quickly?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I will goe home from supper. after supper, that I may aske [it] of my mother.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What if shee will not give [it]?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: shee will stay [or • ause] nothing. Shee will make no delay when I shall shew [her] the booke.
HOw How many yeeres • ast thou? old art thou?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Thirteene as I have received. heard of my mother: but how old art •• ou? but thou?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I indeed have 〈◊〉 so many yeares. Intruth I am not so old.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: How old then?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
one yeare is wan
•• ng. I want one yeare of thee.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: There are then •• elve years. Thou then art twelve yeares old.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
The reason is in rea
•• nesse. plaine.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p:
But what •• are doth thy bro
•• er, or doth he goe 〈◊〉 ? But how old is thy brother?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: He goeth on the 〈◊〉 yeare.Five yeares old.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: What sayest thou? doth hee speake Latine now • atinly. already?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Why dost thou marvell? we have alwayes a Schoolmaster at home, both learned and diligent, hee doth teach us ever to speake b Latine; he uttereth nothing English. in English, unlesse for the cause • declaring some
•• ing. unlesse to make something plain: moreover wee dare not speake to my father except in Latine.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Therefore doe yee never speake in English?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Onely with my mother, and at a certaine houre, when shee commands us to bee called unto her.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: what is done with 〈◊〉 familie. What do ye with the family?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: There is seldome • eech to us. We have seldome speech with the familie, and indeed onely in their passage, and yet the servants themselves doe speake to us in Latine.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: doe they speake Latine? What [do] the maids?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: If at any time need requireth, that we speake to them, we use the the tongue that every bond-slave speaketh. vulgar tongue, as we are wont with my mother her selfe.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: O yee are happy. O happy yee who are taught so diligently.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thanks be to God, by whose gift we have a father who cares for us to bee instructed so accurately. hath a eare to have us so diligently instructed.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Certainly the praise and honour of that thing. thereof, is due to our owne onely heavenly Father. to our heavenly Father alone: but what doe we now? I heare the the catalogues [or bils] to be recited. roules caIled.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Therefore let us make haste.
Ludovicke. LEwes, what. why art thou sad?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I am sick.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: what of disease. What disease is it?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I know not.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: But yet is it a sore disease? is it a grievous disease?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Not very grievous, thanks be to God.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: what doth ake unto you? What doth paine thee?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: [My] head.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: whether or no all your head. What, all [thy] head?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: not truly. No certainly.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: What part then?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I know not the name.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Is it the top of the head. the crowne?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: It is not.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: What then? whether [is it] the former part. forepart of the head, or the hinder part of the head?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: [It is] this forepart.

sp.speaker: S▪
sp.p: Therefore it is Synciput.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: What shall I doe then?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p:
Rest, thou wilt bee very
well straight way. by and by:sound, well. for so I have heard of my mother, there to be no more prese •• a remedie, that there is no more present a remedie for the paine, or to the headache. griefes of the head than quietnesse. rest.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: But the diseases of the head are divers.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: And peradventure there are divers remedies. peradventure the remedies are divers: but what is more easie than to trie that which I have shewed thee. I said unto thee?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Truly as I hope it sh • ll not hurt to make an experience. to trie: but where shall I r • st?

sp.speaker: S▪
sp.p: At you • house in [thy] bed.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: My mother will not let mee. will not suffer.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Yea if thou shalt say, that thou art sicke.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: But shee will thinke that I doe dissembl • . that • dissemble.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: it may be done. It may bee, but what doest thou doubt to make a danger. to make a triall.

sp.speaker: L
sp.p: [It is] good counsell.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Vse it if thou wilt.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Verily, I will doe it.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Yea certainly if thou bee wise

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: But one thing • emaines.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: thou art to get leav •• . Leave is to be obteined. gotten of [our] schoole master. master.

sp.speaker: S▪
sp.p: G • e to him, and aske.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: What if hee will not give [leave?]

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: he will grant most easily. Yea most easily.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: How knowest thou that?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Because he is credulous enough to us. ready enough to give credit to us, except [to them] who have deceived him sometimes. who have sometimes deceived him.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I never wittingly deceived him, or that I know. I never deceived him witting.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Therefore goe confidently. boldly.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Now I goe

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: But hoe thinke well. meditate before, what thou art about to say. what thou • ilt say, le • t peradventure thou stammer. sticke in speaking.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Thou advisest. admonishest well, I will not come unprepared.

div.head: The 52. Dialogue.

sp.p: O Timothy, thou commest to me being wished. or thou commest as I would wish. thou art present as I would wish; did seeke [one.] I sought [a companion] that would strive with mee, but all run to the strift of play: but what sayest thou?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: What desire I rather, than to strive. contend with thee, quietly. peaceably concerning our studies?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But what shall we trie in. what argument. matter of scholarlike contention. of contending dost thou require? whether in repeating. of repeating the Epistles o • Tully. Tullies Epistles?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I desire rather or concerning the repeating of Cato. out of Cato

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p:
Because some lessons doe remaine to mee. there remaine some lessons of Cicero▪
Tully to bee learned without booke. learned perfectly of mee: for thou knowest mee to have been sick almost two weekes. that I was sicke almost a fortnight.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I doe remember it: therefore wilt thou [that] wee say repeat Cato's second booke of Cato. the scond booke of morall disticks?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: It is too long for this houre.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Because it is to be played to us a little. wee are to play somewhile, that wee may exercise our bodie for health to bee preserved. to preserve our health.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Let us then say the third booke, which is most short.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: But I will [have] a Judge.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Solomon is at hand who doth follow mee for that purpose.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: therefore Solomon wilt thou. Solomon will you? wilt thou then heare us?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: What are yee about to say?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
The third
booke of morall disticks.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Will yee not say by by course, or one course after another. courses one after another?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: to wit. Verily, either of us his owne disticke

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: But O boyes you may not erre. (doe not decei • e your selves) I will not heare you as a Judge.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Lest peradventure either one, or other. one of the friends bee offended by my judgement. sentence.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: In what then wilt thou bee a helper unto us?and then refer them, or it

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I will note diligently in a little paper, how oft either doth misse. the slips of either: afterward yee shall refer them to [our] master.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: what shall bee done, or what then? What will I be then?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Hee will. He shall adjudge the victo • y and the praemium. the reward to whether it shall seeme fi • . it shal be thought [right].

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Thou then shalt bee onely a witnesse for us. our witnesse.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I meane so: indeed I alone like the course passing well. the reason seemeth to mee very good.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is approved also very greatly of me, or I like it well. very much of mee.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: But one thing remaineth.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: will you also your stickings to bee noted? Will ye have also your stammerings noted, besides your manifest missings. slips.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: So the lawes of our master upon. concerning this matter doe will. require

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Give me the booke into [my] hand, that I may marke. observe more certainly.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: • old my booke. Hold mine.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: shall I not begin? Shall I begin?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is meet. equall, because I have provoked thee. thou hast beene provoked of. by me.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Solomon heare (I beseech thee) diligently.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: But take heed, that thou say negligently. thou say not negligently.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: O Reader whosoever [thou art, which] doest desire to understand this little booke written in verse. to know this verse.

div.p:
Thou shalt beare away. beare [in minde] these precepts which are most w • lcome, happy, or pleasant. most
• o life. profitable to good living.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: instruct, or adorne with instructions. Furnish thy mind with precepts, neither cease, or bee not weary to learne. and cease not to learne.
For the life without learning is a picture: a man without learning is like a dead man. an image of death.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Thou shalt beare away, or get much commoditie. reap many commodities: but if thou shalt despise this this booke. verse.
thou thy selfe despise. Thou shalt not [neglect] me the Author of the booke. the writer, but thou shalt be the loser. thou shalt neglect thy selfe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When thou livest well. rightly, care not for the words of evill men:
It is not of our arbitrement. in our power, &c.
So they proceed even untill the end of the third booke.
O Macarde, I I am glad for thy returne. congratulate returne to thee. thy returne, when returnedst thou from the countrey?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yester-day, after the noone. after noone.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What [did thy] mother?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: As she had led. taken me with her, so she brought me back.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Came shee not in, or on horse. on horse-back?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yes indeed, and truly abmling. and on an ambling horse.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But What didst thou? thou?

sp.speaker: M.
