sp.p: What dost thou aske? I was to her from her feet, or a foot-boy. I did run on foot by her.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Was not the labour of the journey wearisome, or grievous. troublesome to thee?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: No way hath been. was hard to mee [my] returne into the Citie was so pleasant: what doest thou aske? I would ot come as a horseman. on horse-backe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: how far is your village distant from hence▪ How far hence is your farme?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Foure miles, and those not very long.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But now enough concerning [thy] returne: let us now doe another thing: hast thou not remembred thy promise? hast thou been mindfull of thy promise? art thou returned? or hast thou returned emptie?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I hav • brought how much of grapes? as many grapes as I could.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Therefore how much, what store? how many?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: a hand-basket. A little basket.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Alas a little basket, Therefore for thee alone. for thee the • alone?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yea for us two.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What so very little store? s • little [a basket] for two?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I could no • beare any more for the weaknesse. strength of my weake body. of my little bodie. If so be that I had beene strong▪ I would had. have borne as much as an Asse can beare. the burthen of an Asse; for my mother did permit mee easily. suffered mee willingly.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: O that I had beene present. How would I me to have beene present. that I had been present?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I and my mother have desired thee exceedingly. much: but bee of a good minde. of good cheere, shee left a • ervant at the country. in the countrie, which will come loden with a most ample. a very great basket, then shee will give thee sufficiently, or largely. plentifully.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Aha, my Macard, now thou speakest things wished. as I wish.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Let us goe home to us. to our house, thou shalt see our little basket. basket full as yet. stil as I hope.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: O pleasant head! for I desired also. I also desire to go to salute your mother most deare unto mee▪ your most deare Mother.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Intruth thou shalt doe a thing most acceptable to her. her a very great kindnesse.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Therefore let us • oe. Let us go then.
WHat doest thou study, or thinke on. muse on here alone?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I deplore, or lament. bewaile my miserie.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: what miserie is it. What •• serie doth affect thee. trouble thee?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Alas (me wretch) behold &c Ho (wretch that I am) see wee have changed our seat, or classis. forme, neither is there any money to mee. and I have no money from whence to buy. wherewith I may buy mee bookes.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Doth not thy father give thee?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: Truly. Intruth he giveth [mee] sometimes, but over sparingly.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Hee is then miserable. covetous.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: It doth not follow.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: What then doth hinder [him,] that he doth not affoord. minister money to thee. allow thee money?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Povertie; besides. moreover, when I aske, hee doth marvell need to bee to us. that we have need of so many books.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: nothing marvellous. No marvell, especially sith he • is poore; but in the meane time bee of a good mind, or courage. bee of good cheere, neither doe thou. and doe not trouble not thy selfe. afflict thee. thy selfe, I pray thee, I will doe my indeavour that my father may helpe thee: for hee giveth bountifully. hee giveth willingly to the poore, especially to those whom hee hath knowne. hee knoweth to love their books. to bee studious of good letters. of good learning.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: O mee happy. O happie I, if God shall helpe me by thy diligence.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I hope he will helpe: thou in the mean time bese • ch him diligently
• hat hee may make the minde of my father affected toward • thee. that he may incline my fathers minde towar • s thee.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Thou admonishest mee rightly. advisest mee well: for (as I have heard oft times out of the holy assemblies. of the holy Sermons)
it is God alone, who doth governe and direct the hearts of men.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The matter hath so. is even so.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: my Anthony farewell. Farewell my Anthonie, who hast restored courage, or heart unto mee. thou hast revived mee.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thou also Bernard, farewell: but tell mee, I pray thee, how much money is needfull to thee. thou hast need of?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: If I had two tenpences. vid. supra. two shillings, there would be abundantly to mee in the present. I should have plentifully, for the present.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Hold thy peace, thou shalt (as I hope) perceive the divine helpe to morrow, as I hope. see to morrow the helpe of God.
WHither goest thou now?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Into the hot-houses. stove.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: what thither? Whereto?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Is this to bee asked? doest thou not feele the cold?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Who is to bee found? Who is there which doth not feele it now, sith it is so sharpe. bitter? But I chuse rather to warm. I will rather warme mee in the kitchin.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: but. Yea but [our] master hath forbidden it.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I am not ignorant [of it] but I will aske leave.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Why wilt thou not bee warmed. warme thy selfe in the hot-house?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The vapors▪ fumes of the oven. furnace doe do annoy my head t • me. trouble my head, which I have bad enough. is otherwise weake enough: whereupon it comes to passe, that I labour easily of my head. I am soone troubled with the head-ake.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p:
I have also been so sometime: but I have accustomed my selfe by little and little, to beare, or abide the •• conveniences. endure the
discommodities of the hot-house.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: And I (as I hope) shall accustome my selfe: but it is better that to bee done. to doe that in the afternoone-houres, or houres of the afternoone. afternoone-times, what that so great a heat shall wax small againe, or • lake. abate.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: But now time is not. there is no time to play the Philosopher here any longer, now my teeth doe chatter to mee. doe hack in my head with cold. doe chatter with cold.
WHat trees are there in your garden. orchard?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Wee have an orchard in the subburbs of the Citie. neer the city▪ in which a • e pot-herbs which we eat daily; there are furthermore. besides two orchards in our grounds, planted. set with divers trees.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: What he • rbs to bee eaten. pot-herbs are in your garden. orchard?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p:
My mother can answer better concerning this thing.this, for she
• s conversant. is there oftentimes either for to sow. for the cause. upon the occasion of sowing, or of weeding, or of gathering something

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: But neverthelesse. yet tell me some names of pot-hearbs. hearbs.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: It would profit little or smally availe. do thee little good to rehearse the names unto thee unlesse thou sawest the things themselves: but let us goe therefore to the orchard it selfe to see the hearbs. unto the thing present.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Canst thou? Mayest thou goe when thou liftest, or it listeth thee. it pleaseth thee?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I may indeed, my mother permitting. giving me leave.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p:
Of all good fellowship get leave. Of all love cause that she may let thee goe. give thee leave: but of that
condition, that thou take me as a companion to thee. take me with thee for thy companion.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: That shall be done most readily. easily: onely tarry for me. expect me here: I will returne by and by. straightway.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: What if she be not at home?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Yet I will signifie, or report to thee. bring thee word againe hither.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: God direct. God turne it well. God speed thee.
I have received to day. I Have this day received money from my father, if peradventure there be any need to thee. if perhaps thou have any need.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I have no need now: but notwithstanding I have the greatest thankes to thee. I give thee most heartie thankes, that thou in thy liberalitie, thou dost offer mee freely a kindnesse of thine owne liberalitie. offerest me a kindnesse of thine owne accord: For how oft doth any one that? where is one of a thousand that will doe that?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I beleeve there to be very few. that there are very few, yet thou hast provoked mee not once by thy benefits. kindenesse.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Those have been so small, that they are not worth rehearsing.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: it is not a small benefit, which commeth from the best will. It is no small kindnesse which is done of speciall good will.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I wish that wee could so weigh the bounties, mercies, gracious kindnesse, or goodnesse, 〈◊〉 gifts. benefits of God towards us, as we are wont to esteeme the kindnesses of men.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: God grant. Hee grant that wee may exercise us. our selves in that meditation. cogitation both more often, and more diligently. That indeed is necessary, if wee will prove by experience his bountie more oft. have more oft experience of his bountie.
WHat dost thou?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I write.

sp.speaker: F▪
sp.p: What dost thou write?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I Write downe, or coppie out. write out the rea • dings, notes, or expo • sitions, of our master. our Masters dictates.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: What [dictates]?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yesterdayes.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: What, wast thou not present?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yea, I was present, but I could not attaine to. write so fast as our master spake. follow our Master speaking, or reading to us. dictating.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: What hindred thee?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Because I sate not handsomely. commodiously enough.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Thou thou hast come. camest then more late. too late.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That is it.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: teach mee. Give me thy note-booke. commentarie, I my selfe will write to thee. for thee.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: what gaine shall I make? What shall I gain by that?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I shall write them sooner than thou, afte • wee will play. we will after play together as our master hath gran • ed: give mee (I say) thy little booke.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Truly I would doe it willingly, but I dare not.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: What doest thou feare?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: The edict the prohibition, o • expresse commandemen • . expresse charge of our Master.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: What statute. expresse charge dost thou shew me? doest thou tell me of?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Doest thou not know him to have. that hee hath forbidden lest any man. that no man write to another. for another without his leave. permission.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p:
I doe rem • mber it well. remember that well, but
• rom whence? how shall hee know this?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Doest thou aske? when our master shall r • quire a straight account. exact an reason. account of our writing
• or the cause of ame • ding. that hee may amend it, I shal • be catched then. then I shall bee catched, for hee knoweth my writing. my hand: b • sides. moreover, we must
it is to bee deceived [of us] neither deceive, neither must [wee] lie.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Wee are forbidden both of them by the Word of God.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: wha • shall I. What then should I answer to our master, when hee shall deny mee to have written. denie that I writ those things?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I hope the matter will not goe forth, or fall out so. come to that.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I will not adventure. undergoe so great a perill. danger because tho • hopest well. for thy hope.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Ah thou art too fearfull: thou wilt never get any gaine. doe [any] thing. gaine ought.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: But peradventure thou [art] more bold

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Write thou therefore how much thou, &c. as much as thou wilt: I betake my selfe to play.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I pray thee, goe thy way: I had written out one page, but that thou interrupted, or troubled mee. if that thou hadst not interrupted mee.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: But in the meane time we get some good. wee profit somewhat, whilest we talke in Latine.
Hath, or doth thy father? &c. IS thy father come to this dais mar • . market?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: hee talked w • th me. He came to me to day early in the morning. in the morning, when as y • t I rose. when as I was • ising out of my bed.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Askedst thou nothing of him?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Yea, money.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: And he hath numbred it? did he deliver it [thee?]

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: in presence. Presently.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: How much I beseech thee. I pray thee▪

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Two shillings. Twentie pence.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: O strange! twentie pence? how is it done? how comes it to passe, that he dare commit so much money to thee?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Because
he knoweth mee to be a thrifty dispenser, or wary disposer. a good husband; sith that I give him ever. I alwayes render him an account, even unto a farthing.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: But peradventure thou hast got it, with much adoe. thou obtainedst it hardly.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Yea most easily, and so. and indeed with thankes.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: O milde parent. O courteous, kinde. gentle father!

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Indeed most gentle.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: But that we may come to the matter, what wilt thou doe with this. that money?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I will buy bookes and other necessaries. things necessary for me.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Canst thou give mutually some to mee. lend mee some?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I can, if so that thou needest.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Vnlesse I needed I would not aske.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How much wilt thou have. receive of mee?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: five pence. Fippence.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Take it.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: O heart freindly indeed. friendly heart indeed!

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hee is not a true friend, who doth not helpe his friend in time, if notwithstanding. if so be that hee have from whence. whereof he may helpe him.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: A true friend (as it is in the proverbe) is knowne, or tryed. is seene in a doubtfull matter.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When wilt thou restore that borrowed, or lent. repay it?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: As soone as my father shall come into this citie.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When doest thou hope him to come. that he will come?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
At the next mar •
In the next market, to wit, at the eighth day of October.
AT what a clock hast thou awaked▪ didst thou awake this morning. to day in the morning.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Before day: I
know not at what houre. at what a clocke.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Who awaked thee?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
The weekely raiser up of the • cholars. caller came with his lanterne, hee knoc
• ed, or beat upon the • oore of my chamber earnestly. hee knocked earnestly at my chamber doore, one opened [it] the with his voice lifted up. Caller lighted our candle, hee called upon us with his voice lifted up. with a loud voice: all awaked.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Tel mee. Shew mee in order thou didst. what thou hast done from that time, untill thy breakfast ended. untill after thy breakfast: yee boyes attend diligently, with eares and mindes, that ye may learne to imitate this your schoole fellow.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
I a waking. awaked, rose out of my bed, I put on my coat with my stomacher. doublet, I sat on the bench. low seat, I tooke my slops. breeches and my nether-stocks. stockings, I put on my shooes. I put on [my] shooes, I tyed my breeches to my stomacher. doublet with points, I tyed my stockings with my hose-garter. garter upon my legs, I girded. girt mee with my girdle, I comb'd my head diligently, I fitted my cap to my head. I put on my little cap. my cap, I put on my gowne: afterward having gone forth. going forth of my chamber, I went downe beneath, I made water in the court at the wall, I tooke cold water out of the bucket,I washed together, or rinsed. I washed my hands and my face, I all to washed, or washed cleane. I washed my mouth and teeth, I wiped my hands and my face wi • h a towell, in the mean time a signe. we are called to prayer. warning is given to prayer with the little bel. with the lesser bell, it is come together. we come together into the private hall, we pray together, wee take our breakfast from the from the cooke, or boy in the kitchin. kitchin servant in order, we eat our breakfast. we breake our fast in the triclinium a dining-chamber with three beds to rest on after meat. dining-chamber, sitting and quiet without dinne▪ without noyse. stirre, I admonish them friendly whom I heare pratling foolishly. fondly, or speaking idle words. idlely, or also
behaving themselves wantonly. playing the wantons; I carryed up the •• names.
• gave up unto observer. monitor [the names of them] who obey not [my] admonition, that hee might no • e them.

sp.speaker: Paed.
sp.p: did none rule over you, or look to you. Was none set over you, whilest you did breake your fast?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: the third master. Yea the Vsher.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: What did hee in the meane time?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: Hee walked in the midst of the hall through the midst of the Hall, holding a booke in his hands, and also. in like manner admonishing the monitor, that hee would note the •• l • ers, or pratlers. them that pratled fondly.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: may no word bee spoken then? Is it not then lawfull to utter any word at that time?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: Yea, it is lawfull, but they onely. at least are wont to bee noted, who doe talke long and in many words, fondly and without any good, or profit. any fruit: But it is lawfull to all to handle or use. all may use pleasant speeches among themselves, of good and honest things, so that neverthelesse it be done modestly, without clamor. cry or contention.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Thou hast satisfied mee hitherto, thou shalt shew the other things. tell the rest after dinner, except some businesse shall happen, or come between. shall fall out in the meane time: let us goe now into the Hall to dinner, that we be not in delay. le • t [our] master stay for us.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I heard the signe, or bell. warning to bee given even now.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: It is given very fitly.
WHere didst thou end. endedst thou thy narration before dinner?

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p:
O master when
I would put an end to. have made an end of my breakefast, thou diddest interrupt mee, or trouble mee. you troubled me.

sp.speaker: Paedago.
sp.p: Goe on therefore to shew the rest in order.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p:
Whilst wee made an end of eating our breakfast of breaking our fast, the signe af • er. the latter publike signe. warning is given: every one takes his] booke, wee goe into the common hall, rolles, or bils. the catalogues of every forme are recited. called according to the manner. after the custome: they who are present, doe answer to their name, I also answered, they who are absent. the absents are noted in the catalogues by the callers of the names. Nomenclators themselves: the calling of the rolles. bils being ended, the head master doth ascend. the schoolemaster doth goe up into the his pue, or seat. pulpit, that he may pray; hee doth command us to be attentive and then hee prayeth. doth pray publikely: when hee hath prayed, Get you. Betake ye (quoth he) your selves every one into his owne forme, or seat. auditorie: all come together. meet together, I also come with my schoolefellowes, I sit in my place, the master doth inquire of the absents, afterward hee sitteth in his seat. chaire, and commandeth the writing of the author to bee pronounced; wee pronounce by threes. three and three distinctly, or plainly. with a cleare voice, as we are wont daily: Then hee com▪mandeth that we give. render the interpretation, some of the more ignorant.
• uder doe read one by one, other s of us doe repeat by threes. three and three, and that by heart. without booke, besides him which goeth before us in order reading, or saying, or observing. [repeating] the very words of the author: At length [our] master doth require. exact the English the meaning of the words. signification of the words, the more learned scholars, whom hee give commandement namely. doth command by name,
doe answer: I also being commanded by him doe answer:they are commended. they doe commend [those] who have answered well, of which number. of the number of whom I (which that I may speake without boasting. bee it spoken without bragging) was one: afterwards he commandeth the severall parts of speech to bee handled in order, according to the Grammaticall reason, or manner, or rule. to the reason of Grammar: last of all, hee doth prescribe openly, what is to be repeated after dinner? the eighth houre being heard: or when it hath strucke eight of the clocke. eight of the clocke being heard, hee commandeth prayer, which being ended, hee admonisheth that we doe our office diligently, at length hee doth make us to bee sent away. dismisse us: he looking on us. as he looketh on us we goe forth in order, and without noyse, and wee depart being joyfull, or cheerfull. merrie. Master have I satisfied you?

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Yea most fully. most abundantly.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: Doth it please you, that about supper time, I doe the same of the rest of the actions. concerning the other actions of this day?

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: There shall bee no need, for I have heard thee sufficiently elsewhere. enough at other times concerning those things, which are done in afternoone houres. the houres of the afternoone.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: will you not any thing. Will you any thing besides?

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Is it not time of going. to goe into the common hall to the singing of the Psalmes?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: It is time.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Goe then.
O Charles come hither. art thou art thou there Charls. there?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: Master I am present. here.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: What doe thy two schoole-fellows?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: the sub-doctor teacheth them still. they are taught as yet of the sub-doctor.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: But thou. But hast thou said, or repeated. pronounced now. already the thy lesson, or the text, or words of thy lesson. context of thy lesson, against to morrow morning?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: I have pronounced it.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Whether well enough. And hast thou done it well?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: enough. Very well thankes bee to God.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Who heard thee?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: The head master. Schoole-master.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: it hath well. It is well, but there is one thing. there is a thing that I will admonish thee of.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: I desire earnestly to heare what that thing is. that.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: It is to bee thought of thee oftentimes. Thou must think very often, how much thou owest to God the giver of all good things, who hath given thee both wit and memorie so happy, or good wit and remembrance. both wit and such an happie memorie.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: What doe I not owe unto him, who hath given mee all things. hath given mee all things?

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: repeat, or rehearse some chiefe benefits of him. Tell some of his chiefe benefits, even as I have taught thee sometimes.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p:
that our heavenly father. That heavenly Father hath given my body a soule, life, good minde, parents being good, wealthy, well disposed. good parents, rich, noble, well affected towards me, and who do not only afford. minister copiously, or abundantly. plentifully unto mee all things necessarie to this life, but also (which is the greatest feare. far the greatest) doe care. doe [provide] that I may bee instituted, or trai
• ed up. instructed
so diligently in good letters. good learning and the best. good manners, that nothing can bee requ • red besides. is to bee required further.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Thou hast spoken all these things very truly. truly; but thou hast pretermitted one thing, which is a singular benefit of God, doest thou know what it is?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: let me bethinke my selfe. Suffer mee to thinke a little upon it.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: take thee time enough. Thinke quietly. at thy leasure.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: Now I remember: but for the greatnesse of the matter I know not in what words how to expresse it. I can expresse it.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: but shew mee. Neverthelesse tell me in what manner thou canst.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: I thinke seriously, or I am studying of it. I thinke againe and againe.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Say at length.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: The benefits of who is best and grea test. the best and greatest God towards mee, are not to bee numbred. innumerable, in bodie, in minde, in outward matters. in externall things: but none greater. but none can neither can be spoken nor thought of. either bee uttered or thought greater, than that hee hath given mee freely. given freely his onely begotten sonne to mee, who hath redeemed me most miserable sinner and a bond-slave. and captive under the tyrannie of Satan, and being ordained, or appointed. destinated to eternall death▪ and that by his owne death, the most cruell of all, and most reproachfull. chiefly ignominious. most ignominious.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Thou hast spoken aptly enough. very fitly, and almost in how many. in so many words, as I otherwhere had, &c. as I had taught thee at other times: whether or no? But hath God performed. granted this so great a benefit to thee onely. to thee alone?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: not at all. No truly.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: To whom besides?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: To all as many as, or ho • many soever. whosoever shall beleeve the Gospell faithfully and truly.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Goe to, bring forth. cite the place out of the Gospell of Iohn to that your purpose. to that end.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p:
God so loved the world, that hee gave his onely begotten son, that whosoever. every one who
beleeveth in him may not perish, but have. should not perish, but have eternall life: for God sent not his sonne into the world that he should condemne the world, but that the world might. may be saved by him. through him: He that beleeveth in him is not condemned, but that beleeveth not. hee that doth not beleeve is condemned now. alreadie, because he hath not beleeved in the name of the onely begotten sonne of God: And is the condemnation. this is, &c.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Hitherto enough. this may suffice • hereof. And these thus farre: but of whom are. whose words are these?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: Of Christ hims • lfe, speaking of himselfe.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Whom doth he speake unto?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: he speaketh to Nichodemas who had come. came unto him by night.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Christ himselfe our onely Saviour grant that thou mayest grow. mayest profit more and more in his knowledge. in the knowledge of him.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: I hope hee will doe it.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Therefore proceed merrily. goe on cheerefully, as thou hast begun, which God cause to succeed. prosper to the glorie of his owne name.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: I pray so too.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Let us goe to supper.

thou dost study ne
• er.THou never studiest: when wilt thou be learned. a scholar?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That shall be done, or •• all come to passe. will be in processe of time. progresse of time, God-helping. by the helpe of God.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Thou sayest right well. well, yet in the meane
time it is to bee laboured of thee. thou must labour.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: But I am not a a tiller of the ground, plow-boy plowman.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yea doest thou make a jest. laugh? as if it bee all one to labour and to plow. as if to labour, were the same thing that it is to plow.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I know it not to bee the same thing. that it is not the same.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Therfore why answeredst thou so? is not that to laugh?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: And it is no evill to laugh. to laugh is not an evill thing. not evill, sith it is naturall to all men.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Dost thou goe forward to speake trif • es. goe on to trifle?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That which I have said is true, and [to speake] the truth is not to trifle: why doest thou reprehend mee without cause. undeservedly?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I finde fault w • th thee justly. I reprove thee by right, or rightly. justly.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: By what right?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Because thou art not ignorant [this word, &c. that this word] ridere to laugh, to bee. is usuall for irridere [to mocke] and neverthelesse thou takest it so. thou takest it so, as if I spake of laughing.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: If I maintaine. defend my cause, what evill doe I?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: therefore proceedest thou. Doest thou then goe on to bee froward, or obstinate. stubborne? Indeed thou shalt be noted in good earnest. in earnest.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: My Martine, I pray thee be not offended against mee. angry at me.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I am not angry, but I doe my office. dutie.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: But heare I pray thee.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What should I heare. What shall I heare? thy trifles?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Heare I say, I will lye nothing. I will not lye.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: speake briefly: there is businesse to me otherwhere. I have businesse elsewhere.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: First of all I was not idle, when thou hast admonished. when thou admonishedst me, I was not idle.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What therefore. What then? if thou didst nothing, whether or no. wast thou not idle?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I was not, if I might have said. I may speake without offence. I may speake, by your leave.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: How can this be. that be?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I will tell thee, although thou knowest it better than I. thou thy selfe understandest this better than I: I did nothing, as it might have beene thought I did. as it did appeare, but notwithstanding I did thinke of some good.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: shew me how. Declare that unto mee.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
When thou makest verses, thou studiest, or thinkest. doest
meditate long ofttimes, as if thou wert idle, although thou art never lesse idle.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thou art too acute, or sharpe. too wise for thy yeares. over wittie for that age. thy age: although thou thinkest, thou wast not idle thou wast not idle in regard of thy selfe to thy selfe, (as thou sayest) neverthelesse they who saw thee, can judge otherwise.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: But I was alone.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: True; but some might come betweene the meane while. might have come in the meane time: finally To conclude, dost thou not confesse. thou doest not confesse thy fault.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: If there was any fault, it hath beene. it was in that, because I seemed to thee at the first sight to bee in idlenesse. to bee idle, when I was not in very truth. indeed.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I desire nothing in that. I passe not for that. I am satisfied for that, but what doest thou answer concerning [thy] mocking?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: Certainly I said nothing with an intent to mocke. with a minde. purpose of mocking. to mocke.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: With what [purpose] then?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Beleeve me, I spake merrily. I did jest.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: To what end?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That I might learne something by talking in a few words. by talking a little.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I am not he who can teach thee much. of whom. by whom thou canst be taught many things.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yea, I have learned oft times much good with thee. of thee.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: what wilt thou gather thereof. What wilt thou conclude at length?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That thou pardon me, sith that. when as thou seest, I have done nothing amisse, or not trespassed, so farre as I know. I have not any thing offended with an evill minde, that in truth I know.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Goe to, I pardon thee, because thou seemest to me to be honest, innocent. sincere and open. plaine, neither have knowne. have I seene thee. knowne thee as yet to bee a lyer.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: O most sweet Martine I give thankes to thee. I give thee thanks.
But dost thou go away. DOst thou then go into the country?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: I am compelled to go, for that I am sent for. to wit, being sent for of my father.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: art thou never about to returne? Wilt thou never returne?

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: No, I hope.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: when goest thou? wilt thou, &c. When art thou to go?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: To morrow day. To morrow, as I thinke.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: wilt thou? Dost thou then leave me so?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: I must needs. It is necessary so.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: me wretch! wretch that I am! where and when shall I finde such a friend? a fellow to studie with. such a companion in my studies;

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Doe not grieve, bee of good heart, or courage. cheare, God will give thee a better fellow. [companion.]

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Truly I know he can. hee can I know, but I can hardly looke for it. I can scarcely hope for it.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: I pray thee, doe not trouble thy selfe so greatly. afflict thy selfe so much: for neither. for our good will shall not decay. our friendship shall not die by this separation of our bodies, but rather it shall grow more, and being absent in bodie we shall be present in minde: what the letters, which shall passe betweene us, what power will they be of. the Epistles, which wee shall send to and fro, how great force doest thou hope them to be about to have. that they will have? what? that by that desire one of another. mutuall longing our love shall be made more pleasant.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: All things which thou sayest are like to bee true. very likely: but in the meane time my griefe is not mitigated, or lessened. asswaged.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Ah, cease from weeping. represse [thy] teares.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: I cannot for griefe.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p:
saiest thou so indeed? Dost thou even so? dost thou thinke me to be touched. to grieve lesse. that I am touched with lesse griefe? but what wouldest thou doe? what meanest thou? wee
must obey the divine will. the will of God. Now I pray thee gather up thy spirits. recover thy selfe, and rather prepare thy selfe to sup chearefully. merrily, we will talke together in moe [words.] more fully, after supper.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: O how sorrowfull a divorce. O what a heavy parting [is this?]
Hast thou not remembred our master to admonish us so often. REmembrest thou not that [our master is wont to admonish us so often, of flying naughty company. lewd companions?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Truly I remember it well.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Notwithstanding thou usest his admonitions in other places, or at other times. otherwhile carelesly negligently enough.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Wherein doe I seeme to thee to neglect these admonitions. them?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I will tell thee, so that thou attend, or mark. that thou heare attentively.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Speak I pray thee, I will heare most attentively.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Wilt thou never beware, or be warned. take heed to thy selfe of that deceiver, or cousener. impostor?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Why may I take heed. should I take heed?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Lest thou be marred, or spoiled. corrupted by the contagion of him. by his infection. contagion, for thou knowest him very bad. thou hast knowne [him] to be the worst. a very lewd fellow.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: But I doe not follow him willingly. of mine owne accord, he commeth to me on every side. every where.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: to wit. Verily because he knoweth thee to have that thou maiest give him, and to give him, &c. that thou hast something to give him, and that thou art wont to give him freely, or frankly. willingly and often.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: What then doest thou counsell me to doe. perswade me to doe?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
speake thus to him. Say
once and in good earnest, and as it were with an angry minde: O friend, what wilt thou? why doest thou follow me every where? all doe complaine. cry out thee to be the worst. that thou art a very naughty boy, and therefore. for that they will not be thy companions: O therefore let me alone hereafter, I pray thee, lest I be beaten openly with rods, for thy sake.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: What if hee shall reply againe. if hee will answer ought of the contrary part. any thing against [it]?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Have no more talke with him, break off the speech to him. Break off his speech, and receive, or betake. get thy selfe away quickly. speedily.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: I give thankes to thee. I give thee thanks, that thou hast admonished me so faithfully.
WIlt thou remain in that blindnesse, or doltishnesse. this ignorance?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: God turne it away. God forbid.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: What wilt thou do then?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I pray thee tell me what to doe. give me counsell upon. in this thing. concerning this matter.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: First of all call upon God often. pray to God most often, and heartily. from thy heart, and afterward. then be alwayes attentive, that is to say, heare diligently, whatsoever is read. taught, whether thy Master say. speake, or whether thy schoole-fellowes repeat any thing, last of all love charitie diligently. nourish love carefully.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: By what meanes?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Neither hurt no man. any man▪ neither offend [any,] envy no man, I have no man in hatred. I hate no man, but contrarily love all [men.] all, as brethren, and doe well to all, as much as thou canst.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p:
What
shall those. these things further me to the increase. profit of [my] studies?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Very much.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: For so God will illuminate thy will. will inlighten thy wit, increase thy memorie, and the rest of the gifts, or induments. the other gifts of [thy] mind; finally. to conclude, hee will so promote thy studies, that thou mayest make daily greater progresses in that thing. therein.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Truly thou dost give me the best. very excellent counsell, I would to God. I wish that I may bee able to use it perpetually to the glorie of God himselfe, and sometime to requite thankes to thee. at length to requite like, or to render thankes. to requite thee.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I do not wish, that thou render any thankes to mee after that manner, but that thou oftentimes praise God. praise God very oft. very oft praise God, and that thou alwayes pursue, or prosecute alwaies. follow honest studies, and so thou mayest come at length to the knowledge of of excellent and rare learning. Divine learning.
WHat hast thou done by these, &c. these fifteene daies?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I have ministred to. attended on my mother, who was grievously sick.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Sayest thou so?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: In truth it is so.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: with what disease did shee labour? Of what disease Is shee? was she sick?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: with a, &c. Of a tertian fever. Ague.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: * Hath she waxed well againe. recovered?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thanks be to God shee begins to recover by little and little.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Who helped her, or was her physician. cured her?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
The chiefe
of Physicians.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Who is he?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: God himselfe.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I doubt nothing concerning this thing. not thereof, but by whose diligence, or meanes. helpe?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: by the helpe of master Sarrafine. Master Sarrafines.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: He is accounted of of excellent skill, or amongst the chiefe. the chiefest name in the profession of Physick.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: His egregious. excellent cures do prove that thing. that dayly.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: What remedies did he use in curing thy mother?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Medicines.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I understand that sufficiently, yea thee holding thy peace. though thou hold thy peace. But tell mee plainly what have beene. what were those medicines?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Suffer me to remember somewhat. a little.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I suffer thee, speake. say at length what things thou remembrest.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: There come only two names to my minde. Two names onely do run to mee. come to my minde, Glysters and potions.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: what doe those confer, or help. What good doe those?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: O fond fellow. O foole, thou askest so, as if I have. I had applyed my selfe, or given my diligence. given my selfe to Physick. Therefore if thou covet. desire to know any more, aske thou thy selfe rather of them who professe Physicke. who doe professe those things, that is to say, of Physicians and Apothecaries.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I pray thee be not angry with mee. at me.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Why art thou so busie in asking. so curious?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: That I may be always learning. alwayes learne something.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: But see. take heed in the meane time, that thou be not called a busie bodie or a medler in other folks matters. a busie asker of questions.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Neverthelesse heare asker of questions.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Neverthelesse heare thou in • ike manner. also a few things. a few words.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Speake.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: How long hath thy mother beene sicke?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Almost two weeks. a fortnight.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: in the mean while • here was, &c. Where was thy father in the meane time?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: hee had gone. He went to Lyons to the faire. Mart.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: but thou. when hast thou returned? But at what houre. time returnedst thou into the schoole?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: To day in the morning.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Hast thou excused thy selfe. given. made [thy] excuse to the master?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I have given it. made it.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: What did he answer thee?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Well done quoth he; but where wast thou?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I had gone. I went into the Countrey with my my fathers brother. Vncle yesterday.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Goe to, let us see what we shall render, or say. repeat at the second houre. at two of the clocke, for I am now in a manner. after a certaine manner. after a sort a new scholar.
WIlt thou come to make water?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I have made water quietly enough. at my leasure. Let us go together, I pray thee, that we may talk a little.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: O foolish lad. O fond boy hold thy peace, unlesse thou wilt be accused, or noted. complained of: It is not time to of talking. talk. Shouldest thou not make water it was eaten the breakfast of thee. when thou breakest thy fast?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I ought to doe it. I should, but I forgot.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Goe then alone, with thy masters good leave. with the good leave of [thy] Master, neither be thou. and be not so forgetfull hereafter.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I will obey thee, and I will remember it.
O Gassine what thinkest thou? I pray thee take heed to thy selfe.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: What should I take • eed of. What shal I take heed of to my self?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Lest thou fal
into a disease.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: of what, &c. Vpon what cause?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: of over much excesse. Vpon too much intemperance of play.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: from whence, how? Whereof doth the danger appeare?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Because thou art thou doest wholly smoak with heat. altogether. all of a smoake with heat, thou art wholly of a water. all wet with sweat.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Thou warnest mee well and fitly. admonishest me well, and in time. In truth I, did not thinke so. perceive it.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: desist, or leave off. Give over if thou wilt hearken to mee. if thou hearest mee

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Truly I heare willingly, and I yeeld my manner, or obedience. I doe obey thee, for who can refuse so wholesome. faithfull counsell?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Wipe thy face with a a napkin. handkerchiefe, and array thee. put on thy clothes quickly, lest thou take, or draw upon thee. get a sudden cold.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I give thanks to thee. I thanke thee, for I am almost. ready to fall into diseases. very subject to diseases.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What is the cause?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: The infirmitie of my health, for thou seest of how feeble a bodie, or constitution. of how weake a bodie I am.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thou oughtest to take heed to thy selfe more by so much. so much the more.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I know this well, and both my father and my mother doth admonish mee most often. both my parents doe give mee warning very often. But what doest thou? we are prone by nature to our destruction.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: O my Gassine it is not to be • served. wee must not serve pleasure, but we must provide for health by temperance.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Every man knoweth Catoes verse. The verse of Cato to that end. to that sentence. purpose is in readinesse.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I know it. I remember it, but of these things at other times: now thou art cl • thed enough. sufficiently arrayed, there is no cause that thou shouldst thou tarrie, or linger. stay here any longer.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: O Malagnode most friendly adviser. admonisher, farewell.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Wilt thou that I lead, or conduct. bring thee home?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
I have no need of leading, I have my selfe well. I am well, by the
benefit. goodnesse of God.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: My Gassine, care that • hou be in health. looke to thy health.

div.head: The 70. Dialogue.

sp.p:
I Marvell very greatly, or ex
• eedingly. greatly why thou hast not • eene. wast not present to day in the morning.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
what. Why doest thou marvell so much? this is • o newes. there is no newes here. Many are ab
• ent. are away daily, yea at every hour. almost every houre.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: But the victorie was to thee. was in in thy power. thy hands.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What care I? Such a victorie, as a certaine man. one said well, is nothing else • han. no other thing but a short glory.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: But in the meane time. while, modest young men are set on, or kindled. inflamed more hereby to their studies; neither yet doe they swell with vaine glory, but they refer to the glorie. honour of God, whatsoever praise shall come thence. thereupon.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: certainly. Surely, that doth happen. fall out seldome, for there are moe who doe abuse their victories, to their private glorie, than who have a a reason, or respect. regard of the divine honor. of the honour of God.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Thou speakest that which is like to be true.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yea [which is] most true.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: But I would that thou tell. have thee to tell me, why thou wast absent. why thou wast away.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I have writ. I wrote letters to [my] father.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: In whose name?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: [in the name of] Of my mother.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Did shee her selfe dictate to thee, or indite for thee. tell thee what to write?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
What should I had written, unlesse shee
had indited to mee. told me?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: What did the letters containe?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: It would be over long. long to tell thee.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: At least tell the argument, or summe. matter of them.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: It was divers and manifold, and. but I pray thee, what hast thou to doe? what doth it skill thee. concerne thee to know?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Why then doest thou aske so greedily. earnestly?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: for the cause of my mind. For my minds sake, as we are almost, or most of us. for most part curious of hearing some newes.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Thou doest no other thing. nothing but prattle, omit me. let me alone.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Heare in few words. Harken a little.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Goe to, I harken, speake what thou wilt.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I long. I desire to know where thy father is.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: As if indeed thou knowest not.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: from whence. How should I know?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: seeing that. Sith that he is most knowne. best knowne to thee, and and seeing we are neighbours, I had not thought thee to bee. that thou wast ignorant.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Speake at length I pray thee.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: He is at Lugdune. at Lions.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: When went he?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Foure dayes hence. agoe.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: What doth he there?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: He doth exercise merchandize, buy and sell. traffique.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: When is he about. will he returne?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: The mart being ended. At the end of the mart.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: At what time will it be ended?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Aske the merchants, it concerneth not mee. it is not my office. part to care for such things.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Therefore what doest thou care for?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That I feare God, and obey, or may obey. obey my parents, I may learne. learne good arts with godlinesse. pietie.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Verily thou speakest worthily, with a majestie, or stately. magnifically. But tell me in good earnest. in earnest, canst thou doe so great matters?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Doe I take, or challenge. affirme this to my selfe? but I rather confesse, not so much as to begin, or to begin 〈◊〉 to be in my power. that indeed it is not in my power to begin.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: what shall become of thee. What then shall be done concerning thee?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: God himselfe will worke in me by his spirit.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p:
Thou thinkest the best of all. passing
well, I did require nothing else of thee.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
The thanke is to God, to whom I do refer as recei
• ed. I doe acknowledge whatsoever good thing is in mee.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Thou [sayest] this rightly. well, and I indeed doe praise thee, lest I should seeme to thee, [to doe] nothing else. no other thing but to prattle.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: When I said that, in truth but jest. I did jest.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I tooke it so: proceed. goe on to learne and to bee wise, as thou hast begun.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Hee that hath given mee faith, the same (as I hope) will give mee. grant perseverance.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Thou hopest well, and I doe hope the same as thou. with thee; therefore let us goe on to live most lovingly, or jointly. friendly, betweene our selves, as we have done as yet. hitherto.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: In truth it shall not • e hindred by mee. it shall not stand by • ee. there shall be no want in me, except. unlesse I shall be left destitute wholly. altogether destitute of the divine helpe. of Gods grace. the helpe of God.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: God forbid. God himselfe turne away that: but dost thou heare the clocke?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: How have we ended. finished our speech in very fit time. in the fit time!

div.trailer:
The two Dialogues which did so follow. which follow, are translated.
referred. removed according to the • dvice. by the counsell of the Author unto the end of this second booke.

sp.p: FRom whence dost thou come?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: • rom abroad. From without.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: why hadst thou gone forth? What wentest thou forth?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: That I might buy paper.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Hast thou bought?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I have bought.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: How much hast thou bought?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: A quier.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: For how much?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: For penny farthing.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Of what shape, or sort. sort?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Of the lesse sort.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Shew it.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: See whether it bee good.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Truly it is good: for what purpose? unto what use hast thou bought it?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thou askest foolishly. fondly: what is the use of paper. papers, but to write?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Yea [there is] another [use.]

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What, tell [mee.]

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: to lap up wares in. To roule up wares.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I did meane it, of Scholars paper, not of course paper, to wrap wares, for I am not a Mercer.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p:
Wee use paper also to drie
• hat which is newly written. our new writing.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I know it sufficiently. very well; but that is drinking. blotting paper.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: And yet it is paper.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Bee it so.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Therefore there are many uses. the use of paper is frequent. manifold, even in the schoole.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I am compelled to confesse it.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I will also tell thee another use, and indeed most common in the schoole.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I dare not speake without some words of reverence. a preface of honour.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
What need is there to
use a preface of honour betweene us? for words doe not stinke. smell ill.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Therefore I speake, sith thou wilt so.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Speake freely.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: to use in the privie, or house of office. To wipe the buttocks in the privie.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: faire papers. Cleane papers are not carried thither, but already written, and those good for nothing. unprofitable.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: What then? yet they are papers.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: But I speake of cleane and new paper.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: But in the meane time, thou art conquered. overcome.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Be it so indeed: it doth not repent me of this our little conference. disputation.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: But now it is departed. they depart from play.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: And therefore let us goe. let us depart from [this] place.
HAst thou good inke?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Why askest thou this?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: That thou mayest give mee a little.
Hast thou not none then?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Yea, but I cannot write with it.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What aileth. hindreth?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Because it is too thick.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Doest thou not know to make i • thin, to mix it, or to • llay it. how to mingle it?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I have no water.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Allay it with wine.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Much lesse.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What if thou shouldest allay it with vinegar?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p:
Thereupon the paper perflueret, would sinke, or run thorow.
pro •• ueret, would run abroad, or the ink would. would leake.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: How knowest thou?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I heard it of a certaine Master, which taught me to write.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
But I heard another thing,
more marveilous.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Tell it mee of all love. Of all good-fellowship, shew it me.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What wilt thou give me?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: A good pin.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Heare then what I have learned of a certain schoole-master of mine. Ink which is made thin with vinegar is hardly put out.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: It may be, but in the mean time give me a little for the present occasion. [my] present use.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Hold thy ink horne well open, I will poure to thee. thee some.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Behold, poure in; fie, out. Ah! how thin is it!

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Peradventure because there is not gum enough.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: But how bad coloured!

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Vse it, if thou wilt, of what sort soever it is, for I have not any better. no better.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: What shall I doe then?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Hoe foolish [boy] canst thou not stir, or temper it well. mingle it well, with thy pen?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I have mixed it enough: what might I doe besides?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Poure [it] again into my horne.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p:
move, or reach it neerer.
• ring it neerer. Hold it neerer: is there not enough?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Thrust together. Presse the lit • le linnen, or thy wool. linnen cloth with [thy] pen.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I have pressed it so that it is almost dry, what will it be at length?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: it will be good. Good ink, or surely meane. indifferent.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: The rule of mediocrity is good; as we have learned of our Master. But whether can any good thing be made of two evils?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: When I shall mingle it. temper it, and shall poure to thee againe. poure thee againe, thou shalt see an experiment.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I vehemently desire. I even burne with a desire of seeing. to see this thing.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Reach now thine ink-horne. Behold. Take it, poure in.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Oh, it is enough now: what meane • . is this lavish spending? thou hast given mee more than thou hast kept. reteined for thy s • lfe.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Mingle it together againe, againe and againe. over and over.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p:
A Cooke could never poure together, temper. mingle his pottage,
and sauce better.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Now at length make a triall.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Dictate mee some sentence. Dictate to mee some sentence, that in the meane time I may learne somewhat.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Experience (as it is said commonly) is the the teacher. mistresse of things, hast thou [it?]

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Sooner than the word. than thou spakest.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: To wit. Because. Verily, thou heldest it. knew it long since

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Who could bee ignorant of. could be ignorant of that, which is so common, usuall. vulgar?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Now let us see.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: The matter will appeare better, when the writing shall bee dried well.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What wilt thou expect? it is dry now more than enough. it is now over dryed.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Oh see how black it is?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Have I not spoken truly?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Because. Verily, thou hadst sometimes made triall.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Therefore it will appeare. bee evident, that experience is the mistresse of things.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Moreover we have experience hereupon, that a good temper may be made. that a good temper may bee made by the mixture of things.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Now thou beginnest to play the Philosopher more deeply. more profoundly, therefore I depart.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: O long speech of nothing!

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I doe not repent it. It repenteth me nothing. not, for we were otherwise. almost drowsie. asleep with sluggish idlenesse.

div.trailer: The end of the second Booke.

div.head: THE THIRD BOOKE OF scholar-like communications, or conferences. SCHOlasticall Dialogues. To which, Dialogs of the master with the scholars are in. IN WHICH THERE are contained Dialogues of the Master with the Scholars.
An Admonition.
div.p: These [Dialogues] shall be read so. are to bee so read of scholars. children, that of two reading together. reading one may doe. may play the Scholar, the other [may play] the master. the Master.

div.head: The first conference, or speech. Dialogue.
div.stage: One of the Scholars, the Master.

sp.p: master be thou safe. GOD blesse, or speed. save you Master.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Be thou safe by Iesus Christ, or God save thee thorow Iesus Christ. Jesus Christ blesse thee. Have all risen? Are all risen?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: All besides the little [scholars.] the little ones.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: whether is any sicke? Is any one sick?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: No one. None, thanks [be] to God.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What is done? What do they?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Some
array, or attire themselves, or get themselves ready. put on their apparell, others study lustily, diligently, or ch • erefu • ly hard now. already.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Is the usher present. come?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Even now. A good while agoe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: get you then t • pra • er. Go then to pray, and commend your selvs diligently to the Lord God, by. thorow Jesu • Christ our mediatour who maketh request for us interces • our, and then goe on. proceed in your studies till the houre of breakf • st. untill breakfast time.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Mast • r
• e are wont so. so we are wont.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I beleeve so. I beleeve it indeed, because yee are almost. commonly slee • y and negligent, therefore I put you in minde the more often. admonish you oftner.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: O most courteous master we have thanks to you. We thanke you most courteous Master: whether will you any other thing. will you any thing besides. else?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: bid my man. Speake to my servant that he bring my gowne to mee. that he bring me my gowne.
Hast thou not beene to day? WAst thou present to day at the holy assembly, or congregation. at the sermon?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I was there. I was present.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Who are witnesses?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Many of [my schoolfellows, which have seene me. saw me can witnesse.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But some are to be brought forth. shall be produced.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I will produce [them] when you shall bid, or when you will. command.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: who had the assembly, or who made the sermon? Who preached?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: D. N.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: At what houre. a clock began he?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: At the seventh houre. At seven of the clock.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: out of what place. From whence tooke he his theame. text?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Out of the Epistle of Paul to the Romanes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: from what Chapter, or in what Chapter? [Out of] what Chapter?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: [Out of] the eighth [Chapter]

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Thou hast answered well hitherto,
now let us see what may follow. followeth. and what hast thou committed to memorie, or what dost thou remember? Hast thou committed any thing to memorie?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Nothing which I can report, say, or relate. rehearse.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: whether nothing. What, nothing? thinke [with thy selfe] a little, and see that thou be. thou be not troubled, but be cheerfull and call thy wits together. be of good minde. audacitie.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Truly, or certainly. Surely Master I can remember nothing.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Indeed canst thou not remember a word? Not a word indeed!

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Nothing at all.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Hoe thou kna • e worthy to be breeched. thou lewd knave! Therefore what hast thou profited? what good hast thou done then?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I know not, unlesse that peradventure I was kept from naughtinesse, doing bad, or ill tricks. I abstained from evils in the mean time. Indeed that is something, if so bee that it could bee. it could have been, that thou couldest bee kept from. thou couldest have abstained from evill altogether.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I forbare. abstained as much as I could.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Cause [it] to be so. Bee it so. Grant that it is so, neverthelesse. yet thou hast not obeyed, or done Gods will. satisfied God, sith it is written; decline from, or shun evill. Eschew evill and do good: But tell me (I pray thee) for what cause thou wentest. wentest thou thither chiefly. especially?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That I might learne something.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why hast thou not done. didst thou it not?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I could not.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: O vile fellow. knave couldest thou not? yea thou nilledst. thou wouldest not, or surely. certainly thou caredst not.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I am compelled to confesse [it.]

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What compelleth thee?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: My conscience, which doth accuse me with God. before God.

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: Thou sayest well, I wish thou spakest. I would to God [thou spakest] from thy minde. heart.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: In truth, I speak from my heart.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It may be, but goe to; hath there beene. what cause was there, why thou remembrest nothing. why thou committedst nothing to memorie?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: My negligence, for I did not heare diligently.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What didst thou then?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I slept e • tsoones, or ever now and then. ever and anon.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
That is thy manner. Thou art wont so: but what didst thou in the other time. in the rest
of the time?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I had a thousand toyes in my head.I thought of a thousand follies, as boyes are wont.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Art thou so childish. so very a child that thou couldest not bee attentive. oughtest not to be attentive, at the hearing of Gods word· to heare the word of God?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: If I did marke. If I could be attentive I could carry something away. I could profit somewhat.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Therefore what. What hast thou then deserved?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: [I have deserved] stripes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Truly. Indeed thou hast deserved [them] and that most abundantly. largely.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I confesse [it] freely. ingenuously.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I thinke, [thou confessest] from the teeth outward. even onely in word.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yea certainly from [my] minde. heart.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: it may bee. Peradventure [so] but in the meane time prepare thy selfe to stripes to be received, or to receive stripes. to be breeched.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Ah Master, pardon [me] I pray [you]: I confesse I have offended; but of no naughtines, evill purpose, or peevishnesse▪ ill minde.

sp.speaker: P.
D.
P.
sp.p: What wilt thou do then. If I shall pardon thee?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I will doe my office. dutie hereafter, as I hope.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: There was to bee added God helping. Thou shouldest have added (by Gods grace. by the helpe of God,) but thou carest for that a little. but a little.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yea Master God helping. willing, I will doe hereafter. performe my offi • e. dutie hereafter.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Goe to, I forgive. pardon thy fault to thy. for thy teares: and I pardon thee of that law. condition, that thou shalt remember. remember [thy] promise.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: O most courteous Master I give [you] • hanks. I thanke you.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I will love thee dearly. Thou shalt be in the greatest favour. in speciall favour with mee, if thou wilt doe as thou sayest. [who is] best. keepe [thy] promises.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: God s the best and the greatest inable mee. grant that I may.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I pray he grant it. I beseech him to grant it.
MAster, there is no man who may teach. none to teach in the sixt forme.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: what a matter is that, or what is that? What a thing is this? where is master Philip?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Hee is holden w • th sicknesse. Hee is sicke in his bed.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How knowest thou?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: A certaine one of his houshold-scholars shewed it. One of the scholars of the same house with him, told [me.]

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Tell my Vsher.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: He is not in his little studie. studie.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How knowest thou?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: For I beat upon the little doore. knocked at the doore thrice. three or foure times.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Tell the doctor of the first forme, that he may send some one of his forme. of his [fellows]

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What if he will not send?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: oh foole, get thee gone. Goe thy way, foole: dost thou thinke that hee is s •• impudent. him to bee so impudent that he can refuse. dare resist? Go thy way, make haste.
MAster.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Ho, what is it?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: There are certaine who would come together with talk with you.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Where are they?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: They looke for you. expect you in the street.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
I will goe to [them] now, or anon. even
now.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: But they urge, or are instant. are in haste.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Run before, and bring them in into, &c. send them into the court, I will follow. I follow thee: wait, or tarry. expect yee in the meane while with silence. I will be present. I will be here by and by, that I may send you away to supper.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Oh how pleasant a word! Oh what a good speech!
MAster, what shall we render. repeat to morrow in the morning?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I shewed you openly to day. To day in the morning I told [you] openly before the breaking up, or leaving off. dismission of the schoole.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: But master, I was not present.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Therefore aske. Aske [thy] school-fellowes: for if all one by one. every one should aske me concerning matters spoken openly of me, or by mee. of which I have spoken openly. spoken of me openly, I pray thee, when would there be an end? therefore make [tha • ] thou bee. take heed thou bee more wise hereafter.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I will care for it for my strength, viz. with all my might, or to my uttermost power. I will looke to it as much as ever I can.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But where wast thou?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: went forth. I had gone forth.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What hadst thou gone forth. Why wentest thou forth?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: That I might looke to some businesse, concerning which my father had written to me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Of whom askedst thou leave?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Of the under-master. Vsher.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why not rather of me?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Because you were occupied▪ busie.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What did I?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: You spake unto. talked with honourable personages. viz. worthy men. men of chiefe note, who were come. who had come to talke with you in the court.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Goe thy way: I rem ember now. now I remember.
HOe Martin.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Anon master, I am present, or here sir, or I am ready at hand I am here.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Call hither to mee. Call me hither the five publike Monitours, whom I choosed. I have chosen yesterday for this moneth: knowest thou not?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: The best, or passing well. Very well, for I my selfe was present.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I thinke they are every one of them are. every one [of them] in their auditorie, or forme. place, make hast.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I will come againe. I will returne againe very quickly. O Master wee we all are present. are all here,command what you will. What pleaseth it you to command as an Emperour. command?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
It was enough to bid, for I am neither a great commander. Emperour no • Magistrate. I bade you to be sent for. that you should be called for. sent for hither: that I might put you in minde. admonish you of your dutie: harken then with attentively, or diligently. attentive eares and mindes: you are not ignorant with how great feare of the Lord I have chosen. choosed you openly yesterday in our common hall: wee began with prayer. wee began of sacred prayer. with sacred prayers, our admonition followed, and [our] exhortation to all the schoole. to all the scholasticall company. the companie of scholars, concerning the feare of the Lord, and concerning manners, which may beseem • . become painfull youth • , or student s. studious [scholars] being conversant dayly in the schoole, and afterwards. then I choosed you five, not without the approbation. testimony of the
best youths, whom I thought fit to this. for this function: last of all, it is come. we came to the second prayer. latter prayer with giving of thanks: therefore doe not thinke. yee may not think that that action. that action, in which the name of the Lord hath been invocated. was called upon so studiously. earnestly, to have been a toy, or foolery. a sport, or a jest, and although function. this office seeme both base. vile and abject at, or with. among the unskilfull or proud. arrogant, notwithstanding. yet beleeve ye your ministerie, or • nction to be. that this your office is both honourable and holy: if so be that, you shall thinke otherwise, it cannot bee, that you can execute, or discharge our dutie well. doe your function well: therefore I exhort you as earnestly. as much as I can, and I doe intreat witnessing • nto you. heartily beseech you through Iesus Christ. by Jesus Christ that you adde all dili
• ence. you performe diligence, with the feare and reverence of God, in all those things, which you shall understand to appertain, or belong. pertaine to your office: therefore let there be away all • avour. let all partiality be far away from you, hatred, thanke, reward, or • espect. favour, study of revenging and the like things. the like, which carry men amisse. overthwart, and doe corrupt sound. sincere judgement: fear ye not the threats of lewd boyes. of the wicked, who are wont to terrifie young youths of a faint heart. little. base minde, from executing their function. from doing their [office]: for what power have they over you? feare ye him rather, who is your Lord, who hath power of life and death. I say, let his feare be alwayes before your eyes. The feare of him so great a prince let it be alwayes con
• ersant to you. let the feare of him so great a Prince, be alwayes before your eyes. You shall run into the, or bee hated of. incurre (I know) the hatred of some wicked and dissolute [boyes]: but let the love and dearenesse of your owne heavenly father. your heavenly father alone may be, or ought to be. bee of more [value, or moment. weight]
to you. with you, than all the en • ities. ill will of all people. of all men. Bee yee alwayes mindfull of that word, wherewith. whereby our Saviour and chiefe Master did exhort his owne disciples unto constancie. If (quoth hee) the world hate you, know that it hath had me in hatred. hated me also before: Therefore make yee, or esteem of all threatnings. esteeme yee as a flocke of wooll, all threatnings of knaves, offendings, or grudgings. offences, enmities, in respect of Iesus Christ. for Christ himselfe, so that you may serve faithfully to the. for the glorie of God. These things are. These are the things concerning which I have thought that you were to be admonished, or warned of. you to bee now admonished. good to admonish you now for the shortnesse of the time, besides those things which you heard yesterday in the common hall. hall. The first Monitour. O most courteous Master, we give you the greatest. most humble thankes: and wee pray Christ that hee may alwayes increase his gifts unto you. in you. Also we earnestly desire you. desire of you that you would give us your admonition. exhortation written thorowly, or out. written, if it bee not troublesome to you: whereby wee reading it over sometimes, amongst our selves may remember it the better. may fasten it more firmely to memorie. in memorie.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I will doe that presently, or forthwith. the very first time. first of all, sith that you it is an honest request. you require indeed. indeed require a most honest matter. thing. The First Monitour. Wee desire. wish also to have of you (if it please you) a little a little briefe. commentarie written, concerning the chiefe heads of our dutie. office: that wee may bee more certaine, what is especially to be chiefly observed. to bee observed to us. of us in this matter. behalfe.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p:
Thou admonishest concerning this in the fittest season. in very fit time, and so I had a good while ago • . now of late in my minde: but one thing, or other. one thing of another. after another
hath hindred mee daily. Therefore I will give [you] such a little note, to write, as conteineth. which may containe whatsoever shall appertaine. belong unto the offices. duties of the publique Monitours. And you shall write forth, or write downe. write that out of my first example, or • atterne. first draught, which I will keepe therefore. to that end, that I may deliver it also to other Monitours that • hall be hereafter. to bee hereafter. Now returne ye every one into his owne auditorie, or place. forme.

sp.speaker: Ob.
sp.p: Master we go the right • way.] straight forth. straight thither.
Master is it not lawfull that I, &c. I pray you master give mee and my cousin leave, &c. MAster may not I and my cousin Germane, or Vncles son. my cousin goe home?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: what thither? Whereto?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: To the marriage of my sisters daughter. cousin germane.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When is shee about to marry. to be married?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: To morrow.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why will ye go so quickly?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: That wee may change our apparell, or raiment. garments.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is lawfull that ye goe by mee, or I grant you leave. Yee may goe for mee, yet of this condition, that yee returne hither to bed to morrow.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: What if my Vncle will have us to tarry. will that wee tarry for. tarry repotia, the feast, the latter wedding day. the latter wedding day?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I know sufficiently. certainly that he will not detaine or hold you. stay you, so that you tell him by what law. upon what condition I have dismissed, or sent you away. let you goe.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: We will confesse. tell the truth.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Goe your way, and take yee heed. beware of all disorder, or excesse. intemperance, and see that your light shine. cause that your light may shine before all [men] whereupon, or that. whereby that
our heavenly father may be glorified.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Indeed we trust. we hope it to be, or that i • will be so. that it will so come to passe, by his helpe. he helping us in all things.
MAster is it lawfull for 〈◊〉 to goe forth? may I goe forth?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What cause of go • ing forth is to thee. What cause hast thou to go forth?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: That I may seeke some one of [our] country men in the market.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: what is that needfull? whereto. What need is there of that?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I will command him. speake to him, that he admonish mine. that hee put my friends in minde of bread either to be brought, or sent t • me: or of bringing, o • sending me bread. either to bring or send me some bread.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Where bread doth faile, there all things are saleable, or to bee set a sale to buy bread. to bee sold.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: That is a usuall, or vulgar. common proverbe amongst us▪ with us.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Yea very usuall. very common every where, bread is so necessary to the life of mortall [men.] But to the matter, wilt thou go forth now?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Master if it please you, lest I lose this occasion, or opport •• nitie. the occasion of my businesse.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Go thy way, and make haste to returne befo • e dinner.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p:
Truly. Indeed I will give my diligence, or do my be ••
will doe [my] indevour.
Is it not lawfull for • e to goe forth? MAy I not goe forth together with my brother?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: whereto, or what • eed is there? What cause is there?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That my mother may buy us shooes for us, or to 〈◊〉 . shooes: and then that wee may goe unto the Barbar.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: why thither? Whereto?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: To pole us. To cut [our] haires. haire.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What need have you now. is there now?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That we may goe to see. visit my Vncle to morrow, if the Lord shall permit.

sp.speaker: P.
