sp.p: Goe and returne quickly to your studie. But ho • , boyes, bring a certificate 〈◊〉 mee. bring mee a testimonie from your mother, against to morrow day. to morrow, or bring a witnesse.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I will care for. look to that diligently, by the helpe of God. God assisting [me.] Master will you have any thing?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
That yee commend mee kind
• y to your mother. salute your mother
• fficiously. dutifully in my words. from mee. in my name.

MAster is it not lawfull fo •
• s, or to us? may we not go to the barbar?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why thither? Whereto?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That wee may be poled. may pole our haire.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
ye would wish to go • orth. Yee would go forth willingly. gladly goe
forth six times daily. every day, but expect ye. tarry unto to morrow day. to morrow, that ye may goe together with the rest.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But there will be a great company, or croud. a throng in the Barbers shop, because of the market. for the market.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What then? yee will have time enough. leasure enough to wait. Get you. Betake your selfe to [your] studie.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Master, as it listeth, or liketh you. pleaseth [you.]
MAster my father hath sent • or mee. I am sent for of. by my father.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: In the Inne.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When came he?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: He came even now.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Who shewed. told thee so quickly?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: He sent a servant unto me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: He tarrieth for mee standing before the doores. looks for me before the doores.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why hast thou not sent in him. brought him in?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Hee would not enter in. come in.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Because he saith, he is in haste. he is urged by haste. in haste.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Call him, that I may talke with him in few [words.] a little. a word or two, and afterwards. then goe thy way: but be care thou. carefull that thou be present. be here the very first. very quickly.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I will goe. I goe to call [him.]
WHere is Martin?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Hee went to the market.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Whereto?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: To buy (as he sayd) a girdle.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hee should not have gone forth unbidden, or without my leave Hee ought not to goe forth without my commandement: but this [is] nothing to thee: who shall give you • your] drinking?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Hee said himselfe to returne at the second houre. that he would come againe at two of the clocke, that he may gi • e us [our drinking] might give it us.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What if he deceive [you?]

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: That thing. That is not his manner. custome.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: unlesse. Except he shall bee present at the houre appointed. houre admonish my wife. put [my] wife in minde concerning. of your drinking: for [shee] hath another key of the store-house, or store-cellar. butterie.
I Marvell greatly from whence thou commest now. now commest?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Master I returne from home.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why hadst thou gone. wentest thou home?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: To fetch. aske [my] drinking.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Wherefore hadst thou not brought it. For what cause
broughtest thou not it?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: My mother was about busines. was busied. busie.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What then? oughtest thou to goe forth without my commandement?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I confesse I ought not.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Therefore what hast thou deserved?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: To be breeched. To receive jerks. stripes: but I pray you master pardon me. master, I pray you pardon mee.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why hast thou not asked leave of going forth? askedst thou not leave to goe forth?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Because I was afraid of troubling you. I durst not trouble you.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What did I?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: You held a certaine little booke and you did. read something.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It may be so, but neverthelesse yee interrupt me. notwithstanding ye trouble me oftentimes, for a lighter matter: now therefore prepare thy selfe to be beaten.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I pray you master spare mee. O master spare mee, I pray you.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Suffer [me] that I may thinke. bethinke my selfe somewhat. a little before: goe to, I spare [thee,] both because thou confessest it freely. ingenuously, also for that thou seemest to mee sufficiently painfull. studious enough.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Most courteous master I give [you] the greatest thanks. most humble thanks.
MAster there remaineth no paper to me, or paper remaineth not to me. I have no paper left to write: whether will you. will you give [me] a book?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Vnto what use?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Partly to dialogues, or conferences. fo • dialogues, pa • tly to write copies. for examples.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hast thou set them downe. put them into thy booke?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I have put them in.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: let m • see. Shew [me.]

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Master behold to you. see.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What [is] that? thou hast written downe. put downe eighteene sheets. xviij. wilt thou then have of the greater paper. greater?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: If it please you.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Aske of [my] servant: and that he may not doubt. lest he doubt shew him thy booke, that hee may refer, or write downe. put the same into his owne booke. his [booke.]

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I heare [you.]

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Heare also, beware. take heed thou dost not mispend, or mar. abuse thy paper, lest thy father be angry at thee. with thee grievously.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: God grant I may use [it] well.
MAster may I go forth?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Wherefore? For what cause?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: That I may buy knives for the Table. tableknives.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Where are [the knives] which thou haddest?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I left [them] at home.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What? Why so?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Because they were already dull and unprofitable. become dull and good for nothing.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hast thou money to buy other knives. others?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: My mother gave me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Who shall bee [thy] helpe thee. helper to buy [them?]

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Go verily: and take heed lest [deceipt] be put upon you, or lest it be deceived unto you. lest you be cosened, circumvented, or over-reached. deceived.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Wee will take heed. beware God helping. by Gods helpe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Indeed hee helpeth all [men;] but them especially, who refer all things to the honour of him. his honour.
MAster is it lawf • ll [for me] to speake a few words unto you. may I speak unto you a word or two?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Speake.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Wee two determined. propounded (if you should thinke fit. if it might seeme [good] so unto you) to go walke without doores. abroad whilst the rest play.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Whither will ye goe forth?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Into the neerest places neer unto the Citie walls, or under the citie walls. suburbs.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But what will you doe walking?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: We will handle some speech, or conference. Dialogue.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But of good and honest matters.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: This fairenesse of the time, and so faire. goodly a shew. face of the earth will give, or afford. offer unto us some honest argument. fit matter to talke of.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: matter of lauding God is never wanting. There is never wanting matter of praising God, onely to his true worshippers.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Never truly, or indeed. in very deed: but that we may returne to the purpose, Master, doe you permit. will you suffer us to walke out of the Citie. to goe forth without the citie?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I would never suffer you but that. I would never permit [you] but that your perpetuall trustinesse. fidelitie had beene. hath beene thorowly knowne unto me▪ and [your] true love of learning had beene tried. of learning: especially sith that lewd youths have deceived me often after this manner, or herein. in this kinde: therefore goe yee forth, and then returne in due time, or due season. quickly to supper.
MAster, is it lawfull to goe abroad? may I go forth?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Whither dost thou covet to goe forth? wouldest thou go?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: To the botcher, or mender of old clothes. tailor.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Whereto?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: To fetch [my] breeches, ho • e for the thighes. overstocks.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Are they done. made ready?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: They are I thinke.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou sayest well, I gesse, or suppose. I think: because the matter is uncertaine.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: But hee had promised mee against this day.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What if hee deceive thee. deceive?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: It will bee no marvell.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Now also thou hast spoken truly, for craf • smen. artificers seldome doe fulfill their promise. performe fidelitie performe their promise against the promised time.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: neverthelesse I will goe. Notwithstanding Master I go to see, if you permit me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I hinder thee nothing. I hinder thee not.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Master will you any thing?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Yea that thou make haste: lest thou be wanting to thy lesson. lest thou come too short to take thy lesson, or lest thou cannot s • y. to thy lesson.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: you give mee good counsell. You admonish [mee] well: I goe my way.
Is it lawfull to goe • orth? MAy • go abroad?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Whither.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Home.

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: Ho, to goe so oft home. to gad home so oft?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
My mother had commanded. commanded that I and my
brother should come unto her. goe to her to day.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: whereto, or to what end? for cause of what matter? For what matter?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
That our maid. girle might
• earch, or picke [our] garments to us looke our clothes,.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: what is this? What [is] that? Are there lice to you? Are you lousie? have you lice?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: And indeed many. Yea indeed wee have many. many.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why have yee not admonished my wife, or put my wi • e in m • nde of it. told my wife [of it?]

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: wee have not beene bold. We durst not.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: As tho she is so very difficult, or straight toward you, or hard to be pleased. hard. Shee hath a girle especially for that cause, that shee may see that you bee kept • cleanly. looke to your cleanlines of all. the cleannesse of you all: neither yee are. are ye ignorant of it, but ye rejoyce. are glad to have an occasion given you to see your mother: tarry therefore; I will take order to morrow, that [your] clothes an occasion of visiting your mother, to bee given. be thorowly looked.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: But [my] mother will chide us.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I my selfe will quiet, or content her. pacifie her, rest you, or be still. be ye quiet.
MAster, is it lawfull for me? may I go home to morrow?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: whither? Whereto?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: To require. To fetch bread.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: doth there remaine no bread to thee. Hast thou no bread left?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: There remaineth indeed but, &c. I have some indeed, but very little.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What [doth] [thy] brother? will he goe, &c. is he to goe with thee?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: My father hath command so. bidden [him.]

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When spakest thou with him? mettest thou with him?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: On thursday when he had come. came into this citie.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Where sawest thou him?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: At the market.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Doest thou not speake untruly. lye?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I doe not lye.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: whence. How wilt thou prove [this?]

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p:
There are of my
schoole-fellowes who were present.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Who at length. I pray thee?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Blase and Audax are present. are here.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Boyes, is it true?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: [It is] It is true altogether. very true.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How know yee?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: Wee saw his father and we heard the very words.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: If it be so, I permit that thou goe. I give thee leave to goe home with [thy] brother.we pray the same.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Master farewell.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The Lord God God be with you, preserve you. keepe you.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Wee wish you the same heartily. from our minde. heart.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But hoe, when will you be come hither againe. here againe?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: To morrow at evening, God willing. God assisting.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Care, or be carefull of. See that thou be mindfull of. remember [thy] promise.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I will bee carefull.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Even. Verily, as thou art wont.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Yea, I will bee more carefull. I hope better: whether will you any thing? will you any thing?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That you commend me to your parents. that you shew salutation [or health] to [your] parents in my words [or in my name.] That you doe my commendations to your parents.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I will doe it willingly: Master, farewell againe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: yee also farewell. Fare yee well also: and walke with a slow pase, not too fast. softly because of the • eat. for the heat of the Sun.

sp.speaker: T
sp.p: We are wont to doe so.
what will it to it selfe? WHat meaneth it, that thou hast been absent. been away this whole weeke? I was to stay at home. It behooved mee to stay, &c. I was of necessity to tarry at home.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Wherfore?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: That I might bee present to my mother. That I might be with my mother who was sick.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What office service didst thou performe unto her?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: I did read more often to her. I read to her very often.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What didst thou read?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p:
Somthing
out of the sacred letters. holy Scripture.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That [is] a holy and laudable ministerie. seruice, I wish all would study so in the word. so study the Word of God! But what? didst thou nothing besides?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: As oft as there was need. it was needfull, I did minister to her. served her with [our] maid-servant. girle.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: whether are these things true altogether. Are all these things true?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: I have witnesse, or evidence. testimonie.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: let me see it. Bring it forth.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: See. Behold.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Who writ it?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Our servant in the name of my mother. for my mother.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I acknowledge his writing. hand, because thou hast oft brought a writing, or his hand. [it] mee from him.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Is it lawfull therefore May I then returne unto my forme, or place. seat?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: what else should be lawfull? or why should it not be lawfull? Why shouldest thou not, sith thou hast satisfied me?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Master, I give thankes [to you.] I give you thanks.
MAster, is it not lawfull for me to, &c. may I go forth?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: What need hast thou to goe forth? What cause is to thee of going. hast thou to go forth?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I must goe to the market.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Whereto?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: That I may buy leather.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: For what purpose. use?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p:
To the▪
for soling. For the soles of my shooes.Why thither?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Who shall helpe thee in the buying?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: A certain townesman to whom my father hath commanded, or given this in charge. committed this.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: thou hadst ought, or shouldest. Thou shouldest to goe unto. have come to mee with the rest who have gone forth to, &c. went to the market.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I was busied.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: In what matter?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: In writing letters to my father.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: When wilt thou give. send those letters. them?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: To day, if I shall finde any our countrymen. any of our country-men in the market.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Goe thy way, and thou shalt bee mindfull. remember to be present at the wonted. accustomed houre.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I will remember.
MAster, I had gone forth. I went forth by your leave. permission at the first houre. at one of the clocke: now I returne.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hast thou cared for, or looked to. dispatched thy businesse?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I have dispatched it, I thanke God. thankes [be] to God.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Well done, what a clocke is it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: the second houre is at hand. It is almost two.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Call my servant to me. Call me [my] servant, afterwards. and then go to [thy] drinking with the rest.
MAster, will you give me mutually, or to lend a little money. lend me some money?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: what need is to thee of money? What need hast thou of money?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: That I may pay. satisfie Sylvius.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How much doest thou owe him?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: a penny with a half. Three halfe-pence.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: By what name. For what cause?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Because he writ. he hath written some Dialogues to mee. for mee.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Shew [them.]

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: See, if it please [you.]

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Goe to [my] Vsher, bid him. tell [him] that hee
may give [thee] so much as, or how much. as much as thou desirest.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Master I give thanks to you. I give [you] thankes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is not. there is no cause of thanks. There is no [cause] that you give mee [thankes,] but refer it, or set it downe in thy booke. put it into thy booke.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: But I have referred it now. set it downe in my booke already.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Well done, shew it to the under-master, Vsher. Vsher himselfe.
MAster, is it lawfull? may I goe to [my] gardian, or governour. Tutor?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: whereto? What cause mooveth thee?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Hee had commanded, or bidden. commanded that I should meet with him, or come unto him. talke with him to day if it might bee lawfull • by my leasure. if I could tend.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When o commanded he?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: now the third day agoe. Now three dayes agoe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Where hast thou seen. sawest thou him?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: In the court, which is of the region. over against the temple. Church.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But take heed thou lie not. see thou doe not lye.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: let a lie be far from me. Farre be it from mee to lye: if thou wilt, I will give. bring witnesses of my schoole-fellowes, which were present with me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Who are they?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Daniel and Corberius.
Corderius: wilt thou that I send for them. go to call them?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Tarry, I will talke with them. But tell me. tell [mee] what need hath thy Tutor of thy helpe? what doth [thy] governour. Tutor need thy diligence, or labour. helpe?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: to set downe. To write out some thing.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: therefore at what houre. At what a clocke then wilt thou goe unto him?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Now, if it please you.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When wilt thou come hither againe. returne hither?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: As soone as he shall send mee away, or let me goe. dismisse me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Now goe
thy way, and commend mee heartily to him. say unto him very much salutation from mee. doe my hearty commendations to him.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I will doe it willingly.
MAster, my father biddeth, or desireth you. inviteth you to dinner, if it please you.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Is hee alone?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I thinke [hee is] alone, except for our houshold hee hath no guests. besides the people of our owne house. our houshold.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Excuse me to him, for I am bidden. I was invited otherwise, or to another place. other-where already. even now. Notwithstanding give him thanks in my name or word. from me.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Will you any thing else. any other thing?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Nothing but that thou returne timely, or betimes, earely. quickly to the schoole.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: [I will returne] quickly, God assisting, or helping. by the help of God.
MAster, is it lawfull? may I have leave to go forth?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: First to the botcher. tailour, and then. afterwards to the barbar.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why to the tailour?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: That I may care for my stockings to be mended. get my stockings amended.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Are they rended. torne?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
[They are]
so torne, that I can scarce put them on.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why to the Barbar?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: That I may shew him an ulcer which is risen to me in these dayes. a boyle which I have risen now lately. of late in my thigh.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Vncover it that I may see it.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: See [it.] seeing it pleaseth you so

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is a sore, or boyle, called a Cats-haire. a fellon.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: so ghesled. I did conjecture so.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When thou hast opened it to the barbar, desire of him that he adde to thee. request him, to give thee an salve. emplaster, good for • boile. fit for an ulcer.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I will doe that which you counsell. as you advise.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But is there any who will goe forth with thee?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yea, Iohn Fluvian.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What busines hath hee?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: [Hee] also will goe to the barbar.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Go yee then together and returne in like manner together. likewise.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Will you any thing besides. else?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That you hasten your return. returne quickly, left you lose your drinking.be punished by your drinking, or by the losse of your drinking.
MAster, is it lawfull for. may wee have leave to goe forth?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Are ye many who will goe. desire to go?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Almost all.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What will this to it selfe? What meaneth this?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: There is a market to day, thereupon it commeth to passe. thence it is that almost every one will buy himselfe. buy something for himselfe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Now I am busier, than that I can know the cause of going forth of every one. examine the reason. inquire into the cause of every ones going forth: goe therefore to the usher, or teacher under the usher. sub-doctor, who may know. take notice, and himselfe may
goe with you, or • ad you forth. most • ourteous master wee • hanke you. conduct you, if he be at leasure.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Wee thanke you most courteous Master.
HAst thou then talked with. met with Peter to day?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: yes even to day. To day.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: In the temple. Church.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: At what a clocke?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: At eight in the morning.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: hast thou not asked • im, &c. Askedst thou him not when he will come to the schoole againe?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I asked [him.]

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What [said] hee?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I know not quoth he.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: he is to goe to the • choole againe, or to returne to it. Thou shouldest have Thou oughtest to exhort him. exhorted him to returne speedily.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I did it, perswade him. and indeed largely, or in a long speech. in many words. at large.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou didst well: but what doth hee answer? answered hee?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: himselfe to be kept backe as yet by [his] father, to gather fruits. That he was stayed still by [his] father to gather [his] fruits.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What if thou write to his father himselfe concerning our scholasticall state. the state of our schoole? for peradventure he will be mooved, that he may send backe. to send backe [his] sonne the sooner.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p:
If it shall
• seeme so. seeme good so unto you, I will doe it and that diligently. carefully.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Therefore doe [it] also the first time, or very quickly. the very first time: but heare, write at large. most fully: afterwards shew mee thy letters, before thou give them. deliver them to bee conveyed, or sent away. carried.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Master, I will doe it diligently. carefully.
MAster, is it lawfull for m • to goe forth? may I go forth by your leave?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Whither must thou goe?

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: To the Barbar.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Is there no other businesse to thee. Hast thou no other businesse?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I will goe. To goe from the Barbar to buy points, from thence to goe. to get me to the coblar. Shoo-maker.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: why wilt thou go? Why to the Shoo maker?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That he may knit to, or tye a shooe latcher. put a latcher to one of my shooes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When wilt thou dispatch all these things?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: within an houres space. Within the space of an houre, as I hope.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Peradventure there will be many expecting. waiting in the Barbars shop.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It may be: but if I shall see, to be tarried. that I must tarry longer there, I will stay, or tarry. expect untill the day of the Sabboth. Saturday.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Is there another who will goe forth?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Pontanus saith, himselfe to be willing to buy paper. that he will buy paper.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Doest thou know need to bee to him that he hath need?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I know [it.]

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Goe yee therefore together: either of you 〈◊〉 him care for diligently. both of you care diligently for your owne businesse, neither • aye •
〈◊〉 backe • , or 〈◊〉 . and be not loyterers.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: We will take heed, God willing. helping.
MAy Is it lawfull to goe forth? I have leave to goe forth?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: To the botcher, or mender of clothes. tailour.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why thither? Whereto?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: That he may measure out a coat to bee made for mee. That he may take measure of me for a coat.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: what matter is there to thee? What stuffe hast thou to make it on?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Blacke cloth.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Where is it?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: In my arke. cheft.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But who is a tailour to thee? Who is thy tailour?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Is hee a skilfull artificer. workman?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I have heard so, and he is knowen of my father, who commanded that I should goe unto him. mee to goe to him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Where dwelleth he?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: In the s • reet of the hospitall, or almeshouse. In the hospitall street.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Is it not very far? see that thou wander not. runne not up and downe.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I will take heed.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: They who never deceive, do obtain leave of me easily. They easily obtaine leave of mee who never deceive [me.]

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: GOD turne • t away. forbid that I deceive ever. ever deceive you.
MAster, is it lawfull [to • peake] a few words. may I speake a word or two?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Speake what thou wilt.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p:
When sometimes you say to some of us, where is follis. where
is the paire of bellowes. the bellowes? or give mee the bellowes. it is not plaine. it doth not appeare whether follis be of the Masculine, or Feminine Gender.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I confesse it doth not appeare: what then?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Therefore how? How therefore can wee know?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why have you never asked me concerning this. of this?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: We aske so many things so often, that wee are afraid, lest we should be troublesome to you.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: As if indeed I ever beare this before me. make shew of this: contrarily, I love you so much more, by how much you aske me more often. as you aske the ofter: for what do I more desire than that I may see you sometimes. at length I may see you both notable [boyes] and the best and most learned. most learned?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Most courteous master we have the greatest thanks. we give you very hearty thankes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I and yee. I my selfe and yee owe that thankes to our God, who alone hath given a good will to both of us of his gentlenesse. alone of his goodnesse hath given a good will to both of us.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Hee grant, that we use alwayes this benefit rightly. may alwayes use this benefit well to the glory of him. to his owne glorie: But tell [us] I pray you, of what gender is Follis?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Of the masculine.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: But I rather would had said. would have said it to be. that it is of the feminine Gender.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Because [this word] pellis, is of the feminine Gender. Pellis is such a one, which is put. set downe for an example, in our rudiments [of the, Latine tongue,] or the introduction. Accidence.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou diddest conjecture, or judge. ghesse at that, not without cause: for [words] ending in is, what a word. of which sort this word Pellis is, are feminines of the greatest part. for the most part.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Not all therefore?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: There is scarcely. scarce any rule so generall which wanteth an exception: therefore Follis is contained under. doth fall under an exception, because it is the Masculine [gender.] So some other; as ignis, piscis, axis.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p:
But from whence.
how may I know them easily. know them?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou shalt know them easily. easily know them, when thou shalt come to the rules of Grammar: But in the meane time marke diligently. observe those the scholars speaking Latine. attentively who speake Latine, and accommodate. apply thy selfe diligently to imitate them. to the imitation of them.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: But Master this is farre to. that is long to.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: worthy, or famous. Very goodly buildings are not made except. but in long time.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Experience teacheth us that. But my father would see mee to be a scholar. learned in a yeares space.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: And I would see it in a dayes space. in the space of one day: But what meanest thou? doest thou? wee must expect a time in all things. time is to be expected in all things. Thy father because he hath not learned letters. because he hath no learning, knoweth not the worth, or price of learning. what learning is worth, nor with how great labours it is gotten.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: You say the true, or that which is true. truth: but what may I answer unto him, when hee wonders at mee, or chides mee. complaines against me concerning the long time. of the space of [so] long time in getting letters. learning?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I will teach thee, betweene supping, or as wee sit at supper. whilst we are at supper: now goe to play with the rest, that I may goe, or get mee. betake my selfe into. unto [my] studie.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Master, I pardon mee I pray you. pray you pardon mee, I have troubled you. interrupted you.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou hast hindred me nothing. not interrupted me: for I was not busied: Moreover, if it had beene troublesome to me to heare thee, was I not able. could I not have rejected, or put thee off. deferred thee unto another time?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: you were able [to doe.] You might have done that at your pleasure, or by your owne authoritie. by your owne right.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Therefore goe thy way.
MAster, God save you.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou commest luckily, or happily. in due time: what dost thou report. what newes bringest thou?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: My father beseecheth you. intreateth you that we may goe together for the cause of our minde, or recreation. for [our] recreation into his orchard in the under the city wals. suburbs.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The cleernesse. fairenesse of the weather doth invite us to that thing. thereunto: and now we are unoccupied. keeping holyday: but what shall we see there which is pleasant. pleasant to the sight, or view, or worth the seeing. to be beholden?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Divers and faire trees with their fruits, also a marvellous varietie of herbes and flowers.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Nothing is more pleasant than those things, at this time.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: That is. Such is the goodnesse. bountie of God towards us.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How indeed ought wee to prosecute. to extoll him with dayly. continuall prayses!

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: But I am afraid lest we bee in delay [or a hindrance] to my father. lest we cause my father to stay.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Tarry, or wait. Expect so long, whilest I change my gowne, that I may be fit to walke. now I am ready. I am already prepared, ready. prepared, now let us go: But is [your] father at home?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: He tarrieth for us. He expecteth us without, or at the doores. before the doores.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The matter hath it selfe well. is well: see that thou salute him comelily, seemelily, reverently. decently.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: We have bin admonished often concerning this matter, you teaching us. by your instruction.
my father doth say very much salutation unto you. MY father doth heartily commend him. commendeth him very heartily unto you.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Sayest thou [so?] when returned he out of the countrey. from the country?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Onely yesterday.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How doth he?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: very well. the best of all. Passing well.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: but where is thy mother? But thy mother, where is shee?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: She is In France. in England as yet.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Where in England?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: At Chichester. Orl • ance. Cicester.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What heare you concerning her?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: to be indued with good health. that she is in good health, through the benefit, or mercy. goodnesse of God.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The Lord God ke • pe her safe. preserv • her.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I pray so too.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Say againe very much salutation to thy father in my words. Recommend me very heartily to thy father.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I will doe it diligently. carefully.
MAster, is it lawfull. may intreat. I have a few [words?]

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: say. Speake freely.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Why doe we not say, hic arbor, aswell as wee say. like as hic labor? In like manner, why doe we not utter, or bring forth. pronounce the Genitive case, arboris, the last syllable save one. the last save one long,
as almost. usually. commonly in other Nounes of the same termination?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Because custome, or the manner. use of speaking hath approved it otherwise, for neither the analogie hath, &c. for the the manner of speaking proportionably to the common rules of Grammar. analogie hath not place every where: but where the analoige. it failes, the use of these [men.] their manner is to be followed, who have spoken rightly. well and purely: for very Latine it selfe doth consist. stand more in use, or in practice than our reason. by use and authority, than by reason.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Give therefore authority for arbor for the manner of the increase, or accent and Gender. concerning the Noune arbor.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Arboris exes • e truncus, in Virgil Doest thou not see here manifestly both the Gender and the quantitie, or increase. the Accent?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Master, I see it. I see it. But are there not others, of the same accent?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: First of all, all Greeke [Nounes] as Castor, Castoris, so Hector, Nestor, and like [Nounes.] also. In like manner these two of the Neuter Gender, aequor, aequoris, marmor, marmoris There are also certaine Adjectives, as memor, memoris, and immemor compounded of it: the compounds of decus, &c. are such. such also are the compounds of Decus, and Corpus, as indecor, indecoris, tricorpor, tricorporis. But thou shalt. mayest finde out easily of thy selfe. by thy selfe, these things noted at. by the Grammarians. amongst the Grammarians, for this thy age doth require every day. daily greater diligence. it commeth hither that thou wilt hold in firmer memory these same things. Moreover, thou wilt hold these things more firmely in memorie, which thou shalt finde out by, &c. which thou hast found out, by thine owne labour and diligence.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Most courteous Master, I give thankes. to you. I give you thankes, that you doe not onely teach mee so courteously. teach mee, but also admonish [mee] with so great courtesie.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Thou doest well: but in the meane time I will thee to remember. I would have thee to remember to refer onely to God, as being received of him whatsoever, &c. to ascribe onely to God, whatsoever
good thing commeth to thee from my labour: for we labour in vaine in teaching, unlesse the favour of God shall come to our labours. God shall blesse our labours. Thou knowest that of the Apostle, Neither he that planteth is any thing, neither he that watereth, but God that giveth the increase.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Truly wee should bee more heavy, blockish, or dull. senslesse than lead, if we should not know these. bee ignorant of these things, which you inculcate. beat upon so oft to us, and so diligently.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It behooveth you both to remember, and also to record [them] more diligently by so much. so much more carefully. But now it is time, that thou refer. betake thy selfe, to thy dayly taske, but in the meane time do hide my selfe. and I will shut up my selfe in the meane time, into my in my studie. studie.
SAy in Latine, a booke.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Of what Gender [is] Liber?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Of the Masculine [Gender.]

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How knowest thou?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: of the use. By the use and custome of right speaking. of speaking well.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Shew the use.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: For we speaking dayly, say thus; The book of whom. Whose booke is this? Cujus est hic liber? In like manner we say oftentimes, My booke, Liber meus; thy booke, Liber tuus; A good book, Liber bonus, and the like [words.] like.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Thou hast answered well; but
who taught thee the manner. use of speaking?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Master, you your selfe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Doest thou then know all the use of the Latine tongue?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: If I held it. knew it perfectly. knew, I would not be a scholar.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: It may be a master. A master peradventure.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Goe thy way:then. I am content with thy answer.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Truly I rejoyce. I am glad.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Give thanks to God who hath given thee wit, and a good minde.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: God grant I may acknowledge alwayes his benefits towards me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: God grant. I pray that he may accompany thy studies with his favour. that hee may blesse thy studies.
what will this to it selfe? what meaneth this?

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: That you pray well for me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Remember thou therefore also to pray well to all from thy minde, heart. for all men, from thy heart, and especially for thy school-fellowes.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Master I will remember.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: thou shouldest had added; God willing. God helping, was to have beene added.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: I con • esse I forgat. I forgat, I confesse.
DAniel, attend that thou maist learne to turn Latine words, or sayings. Latin well into English.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Master I attend.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But diligently.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yea most diligently and from my minde. heart. Thou doest well.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Therefore
• ske mee. propound to mee Latine [words] as you are wont [to propound] unto me sometimes.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What is needfull?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To a hen,

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: She.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Be.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou hast construed. turned well. Now answer to all the parts by themselves, or one by one. to every part of this speech word by word. by name.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I will answer as far forth as I shall be able▪ as much as I can, you shall goe, &c. so that you goe before mee.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It is a Noune.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Noune.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Verbe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Noune.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Conjunction in this place.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Pronoune.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Verbe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Noune▪

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Goe to, let us say againe, that thou maiest understand every thing. all things a little more fully.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What shall I answer now?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Shew shortly the declining of every part, as I am wont to teach you.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Goe then before me as you have begun.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Quid, cujus. a ou • of rule. lame Noune Substantive.

p.hi: Hoc opus, operis; ut onus, oneris.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Daniel thou art deceived.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: what Why so?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Because opus is an Adjective here.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Hoe an Adjective! how is it declined?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is not declined. undeclined.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: mee wretch. Wrech that I am! I had never heard that.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That I know was to bee added. [This] hath beene. was to be added, that I know, or that I remember

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Because peradventure thou hadst heard [it,] but thou haddest remembred. remembredst badly.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It may be, but (I pray you) goe on to teach mee: what doth this Noune signifie in English?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is not wont to be turned in English. into English, except joined with this verbe Sun, es.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Give an example.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou hast examples daily in [thy] mouth.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: now they doe not run to mee, or meet mee They do not now come to my minde.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Art thou not wont to say, and to heare of thy schoolefellowes; there is need to me. I have need of paper, inke, money,
and the like [things.] like?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I confesse I say it oftentimes, and I heare it oft, but I marke but a little. little.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Therefore marke now, and commit to memorie▪ I have need of money to buy bookes: or so, I want • oney; or I have to doe with.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: also. Give likewise another example, I pray you.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou hast need of roddes that thy slouthfulnes may be driven out. driven away.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Master, I in t • uth doe confesse [it:] but God (as I hope) will have pittie, or bee mercifull. have mercy on mee.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: God hath pittie of all, who call upon him holily. But we have spoken now many things enow. sufficiently concerning the Noune Opus, which doth appertaine. as much as doth • elong to you: I returne to the rest Est.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Sum, es, ess • , a unperfect, out of rule. lame Verbe.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: It is not de • lined, because it is a Conjunction: In English, That, to the end that, fo • that.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Ille of the Masculine Gender, illa of the Feminine [Gender,] illud of the Neuter.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Decline it in the Feminine [Gender.]

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It is. It was spoken of now. before.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Bonus, A Noune Adjective of the Masculine Gender, bona of the Feminine, bonum of the Neuter

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Confer. Compare it to the Example.

p.hi: Iustus, justa, justum; Bonus, bona, bonum.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Now aske yee mutually. one another, that ye may handle all things more fully.
MAster.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What wilt thou?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Is it lawfull? May I have leave to goe home?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why before the houre. time?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: My father commanded that I should goe away. go now.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: what needeth thy diligence, or helpe? What need hath hee of thee?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Hee will send me unto [our] towne, or village. farme-house.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: what thither? Whereto?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: To fetch grapes, and or together. with the same diligence. labour, to doe an arrand to our Bayly. to shew something to our Bayliffe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What if thou deceive me?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I will bring a certificate. testimonie, as I am wont.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When wilt thou come againe. returne?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: At the first houre. At one of the clocke, as I hope.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How [canst thou] come so soone? How so soone?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Our village. farme-house is not far from hence. hence.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Goe thy way. Go indeed.
MAster,will you heare? doth it please you to hear my excuse?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When hast thou beene. wast thou away?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yesterday.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: At what houre? At what a clocke?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: At the first houre. one of the clock.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What was the cause?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I have bee • e. I was sent for.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: from whom. By whom?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
By my
father.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: who shewed it thee Who told thee?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Our servant.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why camest thou not came he rot to mee?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Because hee said himselfe to be urged by haste. that he was in haste.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Are there witnesse • to thee? Hast thou witnesses?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Master, they are here.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Goe thy way, sit in thy place, I will aske them concerning it. examine them in the meane while.
WHy camest thou no sooner?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I waited for. I did expect [my] brother.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: He abode, or staid behinde. tarried behinde in the market.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why broughtest thou him not? hast thou not brought him?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: He would buy. desired to buy inke.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Yea peares, apples, or some other fruits.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I know not, notwithstanding. yet he said that. so.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Sith you are brethren, why have you not inke in common. common inke at home in a viall, cup with a hollow belly. pot?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: [My] brother will have nothing common with me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: he will. Will • e then [have] all things proper to himselfe?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: yea very so That is it.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: admonish me. Put me in minde when he commeth. when he shall come, I will teach him what brotherhood is.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Master, I will doe it.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Goe thy way into thy place.
is it lawfull, &c. MAy I be permitted to bee away at two of the clocke?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What businesse hast thou?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: My father hath some occasion to use mee. needeth my diligence. helpe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: In what matter?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That I may write something to him. for him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But in the mean time, thou wil • not render. repeat [those thing▪] which are prescribed unto you appointed you.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I have learned perfectly, or without booke them • ow. l • arned them already.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Well done.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Doth it please you to heare me?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I will heare [thee] to morrow, when I may by my • eisure. when I can attend. tend.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Master, doe you permit then, that I may be absent. may be away?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Goe to, • permit it: but so, that thou bring to morrow a day. to morrow, a a certificate, or • ote. testimonie written.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I bring alwayes to you. I bring you alwayes a note. a writing either from my father, or from our servant, in my fathers name, • r for my father. in the na • e of my father.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thy father doth well: for there are many who feed me with lyes: Now go • thy way▪ and say salutation to •• y father in my • ords. commend mee to thy father.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Master, I will doe it.

HO •
Caperone.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Oh, or here. Anon master.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: what? Why weeps thy brother? doth thy brother weep?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
He is
sicke.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How knowest thou?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: It appeareth sufficiently.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: By what signe?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Because he hath vomited.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What troubleth, or paineth him, or where i • he sicke? grieveth him?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: [His] head and stomacke, as hee saith.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why why tooke he not himself home? wen • he not home?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: He durst not.got himselfe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But thou, durst thou not? But durst not thou admonish me, or put me in minde of it. tell me of it? Go to, thou thy selfe lead him even until home. home, and shew diligently. carefully to [his] mother, how he hath himselfe. how hee is: make haste, why doest thou lo • ter? lead him with a slow pace, leasurely. softly.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Master, I will lead [him.]
HOe, Tiliak, follow me into my chamber, [there is a matter] that I will admonish thee of asunder, or severally. I have matter to admonish thee of privately.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Master I am pres • nt. here.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Wilt thou never come betimes. earely to the schoole?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I cannot come sooner.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou sayest that ever. this alwayes: what hindreth [thee?]

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: There is none. no bodie at our house who may awake, &c. to awake mee.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: No body?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: No bodie at all.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Have yee not a gi • le?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: We have indeed, but she hath no regard. shee careth not to stir me up. to raise me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Yea thou (as I thinke) dost not care to rise, doe I not say true? what? why doest thou hold thy peace? Answer something now at length.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: me cative. Wretch that I am, what shall I doe?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
There is nothing. no cause that thou feare. that
thou shouldest feare, confesse the truth.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: What if I shall confesse it?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why? Hoe, beleeve mee I will pardon thee.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Ah, it shameth [mee]

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I pray thee, let it not shame [thee] to confesse the truth, otherwise thou shalt be beaten: goest thou on to hold thy peace? Hoe Monitour, goe to see unto his mother and aske. goe to his mother to see and aske.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Master, I pray [you] [see] you doe not send. doe not send, I will tell you all the matter, I will retaine, or conceale. hold backe nothing

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Goe to, take a good heart. bee of a good cheare. good courage.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Indeed it is so, as you have said.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That. This is not enough, I will heare all things asunder. severally. Shew me plainly how the matter hath it selfe. standeth.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: When the girle commeth to get me up. to stir me up, first I answer nothing, as if I sleep • in earnest, and then, if shee call upon me more earnestly. urge me more, I lift up my head very hardly, grievously, or with much adoe. heavily: I sit in my bed, I seeme to put on my doublet. I cast my doublet to my shoulders. upon my shoulders, as being about to arise straightway.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How goodlily, or well. finely doest thou tell [it!] As God loveth mee. So God love me, I love thee more now than ever I have done. I did. Goe on. Proceed.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: As soone as the girle is gone out of the chamber, then I bend backe my head. I lie downe. bow my head backe upon the pillow, and put downe my fee • .

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Also doest thou? Doest thou also sleepe againe?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I indeed sleepe againe well and pleasingly. quietly.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How long?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Vntill our maid. girle come the second time.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When shee returneth, what saith shee to thee?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: [She] exclaimeth, [shee] cryeth out, [shee] wood, or in a rage. is madde.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What words doth [shee] use?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p:
Hoe knave (quoth [ • hee]) when wilt thou be in the schoole? I will tell thy Master,
that he may
• erk thee. beat thee well: thou wilt never rise, unlesse thou shalt be raised, or roused up. stirred up twise or thrise.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: wilt thou? Doest thou promise in good faith, or truth, or sinceritie. sooth thee to doe thy dutie. that thou wilt doe thy dutie hereafter?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: If ever I shall fall backe I shew, [or plead] no cause, but will be beaten. I will intreat no more pardon, but will bee content to bee beaten openly with roddes, and that most sharply, severely, or cruelly. bitterly.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Indeed thou promisest very well, but how wilt thou performe [thy] promises?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Through the helpe of God. The Lord God helping [mee.]

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: By what reason, o • way. meanes wilt thou bow him. move him?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: By faith, and by dayly. continuall prayers.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Otherwise thou canst obtaine nothing.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I verily beleeve it. Intruth I doe beleeve it.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is not enough to beleeve it, unlesse thou care. bee carefull to effect it diligently.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I will looke to it to my uttermost power. with all my power, and I will thinke on. meditate that one thing day and night.dayes and nights.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou speakest the best of all. passing well, whilest that. so that yet thou proceed to be mindfull.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p:
How can I forget? The Preachers doe never cease to put us in minde of that. to admonish of that; you • lso master, doe exhort us almost dayly un
• o it, and you doe well, because we are all very negligent. But I chiefly. the chiefe of all.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Therefore give thy diligence. doe thy indeavour, that thou first of all change these manners the first of all. manners, and remember especially s to be alwayes a true, a lover of truth, or to speake the truth. speaker of truth.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: God grant that I never lye.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Oh how happy shouldest thou be!

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I shall be happy enough presently, if onely you shall absolve, or acquit mee, forgive mee, let mee goe. set me free.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
I will doe what I have promised thee; but of that law▪ condition that thou remember thy promise, and that
thou performe in very deed, or in truth. indeed, like as now thou hast received. undertaken to mee

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: what then? Therefore what lacketh. remaineth, that I may goe away quit. free?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Yea something remaineth, tarry and heare even now. presently.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Master how long? as long as you will.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Amongst the rest. other things it is meet [that] thou shake off that sluggishnesse, which is wont to detaine thee. hold thee in thy bed, for it doth not become student. a studious youth to bee sleepy and idle, or slothfull. sluggish, but to bee cheerefull and raised, or got up, vigilant. soone awaked, as thou seest some of [thy] schoole-fellowes. Doest thou not hold in memorie. remember the divine precept of Peter the Apostle?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Bee yee sober (quoth hee) and watch.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: O how oft had I heard it, but ah griefe. alas, I never used it.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: See that thou use it studiously. carefully hereafter: neither that onely, but other precepts of living well, which thou hast heard so oft, which thing indeed if thou shalt diligently doe performe, thou shalt consult, or advise. provide well for thy selfe, first of all. especially thou shalt bee well pleasing. pleasant to thy parents, also to me, and to thy schoole-fellowes, and to conclude (that which is the chiefe) thou shalt bee deare to God who will promote thy studies every day more, to the glory of his name.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: O how much benefit? How great fruit doe I perceive by this your admonition!

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Truly, I rejoyce vehemently. exceedingly both for thine owne cause. sake, and the sake of thy schoole-f • llowes.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: What if you make knowen to them. shew them my sorrow for my • ault. repentance?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Indeed I will make it knowen. I indeed will shew it the very first time. presently, that they may learne by [thy] example,
that nothing is mor • pleasing nothing to bee more acceptable to God, than to acknowledge [our] fault, and to amend. to returne to good fruit, or thrift. to amendment. Sonne farewell, and be present at the third houre. at three of the clock in the schoole. auditorie.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Most loving Master, I give most hearty thanks, or most great thanks. you very great thanks.

div.trailer: The end of the third Booke.

div.head: THE FOURTH Booke of Scholasticall Dialogues; Containing more grave by a little. somewhat more grave matters, especially in manners and in Christian doctrine.

sp.p: SAmuel, I pray give mee thy diligence, or lend me thy helpe. thee helpe me a little.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: What is that. it?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I know not what hath fallen to mee into, &c. fallen into my eie, which hath me very evilly. troubleth me very sore. very ill.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Into whether eye hath it fallen?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Into [my] right [eye.]

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Wilt thou [that] I looke into it?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I will love thee. Of all love looke into it.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Open thy eye. [it] as wide. as much as thou canst, and hold it immoveable.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I cannot hold it from winking. twinkling.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p:
Tarrie, I my
selfe will hold it with my left hand.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: And what, doest thou see? Doest thou see any thing?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I see some little thing.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I pray thee plucke it forth I pray thee. pull it forth, if thou canst.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: But, I have plucked it forth already.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: O well done, what is it?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: thou thy selfe see. See thou thy selfe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is a small part. a mote of dust.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: And in truth so very little, that it can scarce be seen.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: See how much griefe so very small. so little a thing can bring to the eyes.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Truly [it is] no marvell: for none of the outward members is said to be more tender than the eye. Thereupon also it commeth to passe, that we may trie, prove. find by experience, that nothing is, &c. nothing to bee more deare unto us.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: God doth approve this, when speaking concerning. of his love towards us, in Zachary, in the second chapter, hee speaketh thus: Hee that toucheth you, toucheth the apple of mine eye.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: O the excelling. immeasurable goodnesse of God, who hath us so deare. who loveth us so dearly▪

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Is not my eye red unto mee? Is not mine eye very red?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: A little. Somewhat, for because. to wit, because thou hast rubbed it.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Doest thou not beleeve it to grieve mee as yet. that it paineth mee still?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: why should I not beleeve it? How can I but beleeve it, who have felt such griefe. have had experience of such trouble so oft?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Experience is the mistresse of things.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: So it is said commonly.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What price. reward shall I give this Physician for [his] labour?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: how much? So much as we have covenanted for.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The conclusion is short, therefore nothing. nothing therefore: but neverthelesse I have thanke to thee. I thanke thee, and I wish there may be given a place of requiting. I may have an occasion to requite thee.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: But rather God forbid.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Thou hast corrected me well: I had spoken. I spake unwisely, but without
deceipt. guile.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: So I toooke it, but in the meane time we may • est. it is lawfull to jest, especially that we may exercise us. our selvs in the Latin tongue.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The Lord God grant, that all our studies may be referred to the glorie of his name. to his glorie.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: He grant [it] I beseech [him.]
BEhold, I restore thee that lent. that which thou lentest mee, and I give thee the greatest thankes. very hearty thanks.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: There is not, that thou give, &c. There is no cause that thou shouldest give me [thanks:] but hadst thou used it sufficiently?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thou hast granted [me] the use of it long enough, such is thy humanitie. which is thy courtesie.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I pray thee spare not my things. any thing that I have, as oft as need shall bee.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I will not spare, when. sith thou commandest so.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Thou shalt doe mee a very acceptable turne.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I give thee most hearty thanks, thou also use our [things,] if there shall bee. thou shalt have any need.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: There is not. There is no cause that thou shouldest warne, or admonish. wish me, I am impudent. bold enough of mine owne free-will, or of mine owne selfe. accord.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yea thou [art] over bashfull.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Be it so: neverthelesse thou shalt. wilt perceive it sometimes.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I wish▪
will. desire so, farewell.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: The Lord God preserve thee.
WHy ought we carefully to heare, &c. ought we to heare the Gospel diligently?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: That we may learne to worship God after his will, or from his will. according to his will.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Dost thou answer mee no other thing?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What should I answer? for I know nothing besides.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: whether or no also. And not also, that we may live soberly and justly?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I pray thee make plaine unto mee. declare unto mee those two Adverbs.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Soberly, that is to say, continently: Justly, that is to say, in justice, to wit, that we give to every one his owne: So it commeth to pa •• e, that Soberly appertaineth to the private life of every one, and justly to love. to charitie which we owe to our neighbour.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: But my Paul hear [mee:] whether or no. doth not the worship of GOD comprehend. containe all these things?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Quintane thou thinkest well: but I would try by experience, whether thou diddest understand thy answer rightly. aright.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Thou hast done well: for nothing can be said over much, concerning the sincere understanding of the Word of God. And truly I would deale with thee willingly more at large. in moe words, concerning this matter: but the houre it selfe doth admonish us that we depart.

THy brother either doth prattle alwayes at the Sermon. alwayes in the Sermon either doth prattle, or play the foole, or doth incite, or stir up some one to evill. provoke some one: whereupon it commeth to passe, that he is to be noted ofttimes, and then that he be beaten.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What wilt thou [that] I doe?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Why doest thou not warne. admonish [him] oft?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I never leave off to admonish him.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Goe on I pray thee. I pray thee, proceed.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: There is no cause, that thou pray mee: I will never Give over. cease untill (God willing) he shall reforme himselfe of some part. in some sort.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: So thou shalt use the Precepts of Cato, when thou admonishest any man: thou knowest the rest.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: But my Nicholas, I pray thee, that thou shew it unto me. let mee know it, as oft as thou shalt put him in the roule. note him.

sp.speaker: O▪
sp.p: There would never be an end, his name is so oft in my little Commentaries. bills.roules.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: At least make mee more certaine. certifie mee once, when first he shall doe a fault. as soone as he hath committed [a fault] for which he may bee accused, or complained of. is to be noted; then I will tell my father, whose words he feares more than stripes.

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: That is no small token. little argument of great hope. of a good towardlinesse.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: In truth I hope so. Therefore wilt thou doe what I desire?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Indeed I [will do it] and that willingly.
WHat counsell didst thou handle. speech hadst thou even now with our master?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Aske him if thou desire to know.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why doest thou hide it from me?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: That thou doe not utter it. thou make it not [knowne] openly.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Beleeve me, I doe not aske thee therfore, that I may utter it: for what good should it doe me?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Why then doest thou aske so covetously, or desirously. earnestly?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Verily that I may rejoyce stilly, in secret. in silence with my selfe, if thou shalt heare any good.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Doest thou come so prepared, that thou mayest wrest from mee that, which is committed in trust. committed to me alone, and that from [our] master?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thinke [that to bee] spoken to a deafe and a dumbe [man] which thou shalt speak to mee.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Shall I commit my backe unto thy trust, or credit. fidelitie?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Truly thou mayest doe it, and indeed without danger.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thou shalt. canst never speake so fitly, or cunningly. commodiously, that thou canst perswade mee that.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I will give my faith. fidelitie, me to hold my peace. that I will hold my peace.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I will not utter it, or tell • ee. disclose it although thou shalt sweare most holily, three or foure times. Therefore cease to aske.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hoe, where is that our friendship?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Knowest thou not that sentence of the Wiseman?
Thou shalt tell no man [that] which thou wilt have to be secret.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I have heard it somtimes; but that seemeth to be spoken to no man, which is spoken to a friend: for a friend is as another selfe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: whosoever. He who wil know of thee, will say same things. the same to thee, and also another who [will know] of him: and so it will come to the ears of al [men] Therefore if thou wilt have me hereafter to be friendly. thy friend, make me dismissed, or let me alone. dismisse me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I am not a commander. an Emperour, that I may. should send thee away. dismisse thee.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Proceedest thou to be troublesome?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I had rather goe my way then to exhibite, or bring trouble. to be troublesome to thee▪
WHen wilt thou goe away. goe home?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: I know not, when it shall be thought good, or when God seeth it good. seeme [good] to God: for that doth depend of his will, not mine.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What if thy father send for thee?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Then I shall understand, God to will so. that it is the will of God. that God will have it so, and therefore I will obey [him.]

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What if God shall will one thing, and thy father another. if [the will] of God shall be one, the wil of thy father another?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: It is not my part to dispute concerning this: but as I trust, my father will not send for me without good cause. rashly.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
I also doe not thinke otherwise: but I desired to talke thus farre. thus long
with thee.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: I am glad this our speech not to have beene. I rejoyce that this your speech hath not beene vaine, or idle. fabulous.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I would to God, such like speeches were more common. more frequent in the schools.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Then shall they be so, when God himselfe shall indue. affect the mindes of children with his feare. with the fear of himselfe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Therefore let us beseech him, that that may in a short space. shortly be, or happen. come to passe.
WIth what money hast thou bought this booke?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: With what money, what, thinkest thou, except but with mine owne?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I wonder. marvell from whence thou hast had it.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: What doest thou marvell? whether. Ought I to render a reason. to give thee an account?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Doe I require earnestly, or strictly. exact [an account?]

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Thou seemest to exact.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I doe not exact, I say: but we are wont to talk so friendly. familiarly, and freely between our selves, that wee may alwayes learn together somewhat. something in Latine.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I confesse, that it doth conferre, or further. helpe us very much, to the faculty of getting the Latin tongue. of speaking Latine. But there is none. no man so soft, or gentle. milde, but he will be somewhat. a little angry sometime.now and then.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It is as thou sayest; but, the anger of of boyes. children is short.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: But, for that which thou askedst concerning [my] money, I had received it. I received it of my father.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: When had he come? came he?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p:
Eight
dayes agoe. hence.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I marvell that I have not seene. I saw him not.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: There is not [any cause] that thou marvell. that thou shouldest marvell.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p:
Because he stayed. tarryed here scarce an hour and a halfe: for when he had descended, or come downe. lighted from his horse, and spoken to me in few word •
▪ a word or tw o, let us ascend.goe up (quoth he) into thy chamber, that I may talke together. talke with thee more freely.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: But before thou speake of. tell [me] other matters, I desire. I would know why he came so unlooked for▪ what his comming so unthought of, would to itselfe. meant.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: it is done. He had heard by a certain false rumour (as chanced, or happened. it fel out) me to be sicke. that I was sicke.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: what [did] he, when hee found thee being in health. well, beyond his expectation besides [his] hope?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: He was affected with ioy. He rejoyced marvellously.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Who can doubt [of it?]

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Moreover, he gave the greatest thankes. very hearty thanks to our most gracious God. to God the best and the greatest.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I heare these things willingly, goe on I pray thee.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Then he asketh me concerning my health; we pray together, giving of thankes: at length he asketh [me] if any thing be needfull unto me if I need any thing. what I lacke I say. I answer, father there is need. I have need of something. What dost thou need, quoth he? I say. I tell him, I lacke (quoth I). [I need] a book of a shilling. ten pence [price.] Thē he taketh, or fetcheth. draweth a ten pence out of his bagge. purse: he gives it to me into my hand, and farewell being said. bidding me farewell having bidden me farewell, he went to his horse, or tooke horse. he light upon his horse, and went his way.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Why gave he thee more then thou didst aske. hadst requested?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p:
Thou askest this foolishly. fondly: To wit. verily hee was so ioyfull glad because he had found mein good health. very well besides, or above his hope. beyond [his] hope, that if I had asked him even a crowne of gold.a crown, he had given it meas readily. as
easily.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: O how much dost thou owe to that chiefe father, who hath given thee so good a father!

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Indeed it cannot bee thought, how much I owe: for albeit. although he had given me an evill [father] yet I ought not a little. I should have ought no little unto him. But why doe we loyter, delay. defer to goe to heare the lesson?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Now the third houre. It is now almost three of the clocke. three of the clocke is at hand.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: All things are prepared to me. I have prepared all things.To me also.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: They are also prepared to me. And I also.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Therefore let us goe into the auditorie, or place where we heare lessons. schoole.
WHere thy brother greatest by birth. is thy eldest brother now?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: He is gone into war-fare. to warre.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: What sayest thou? into war-fare. to warre!

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: The ma • ter is so. It is even so.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: So therefore he &c. So he hath left his book. hath then bidden farewel to letters. to learning.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Satie • y, or fulnes, or wearines of learning had catched him long agoe. He began to be weary of learning a good while agoe.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: I know not, but because he would live more freely. more at his pleasure.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: How did [his] father let him goe. permit him?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: What? canst thou thinke him to have given him leave. that he did permit him? [my] father being away, or from home. absent, my mother being against it, he went on his iourney. he went.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: O miserable young man!

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Yea truely most miserable.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: What will he doe?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p:
[He will doe] that, which others who follow that kind of life, to wit,
he will spoyle, he will snatch, or ravine. take by violence, he will play with a Dye. play at dice, he will drinke, give himselfe to whordome. he will follow harlots. whores.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Is this the life of souldiers?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Altogether.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: from whence. How knowest thou that?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: I heard it of late, of [my] father, when we supped.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: To what end did he tell, or shew. speake of such things?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: He taught us, nothing to be. that nothing was more certaine then to feare God, who keepeth little ones, and leadeth in them. leadeth them in by little & little into the right way.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Also our master himselfe doth admonish us oftentimes, concerning those matters.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: We ought to be so much more carefull by so much more. carefull, that we love our parents & Masters most dearely,that we have our parents deare, and (our) masters. whose labour, or helpe. diligence God doth use for our institution. instruction.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: God grant we may performe to both of them [that] which he doth command in his law.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: He graunt so.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I pray he grant so. I beseech him to graunt so.
I Heare that thy thy brother to have come backe now. brother is already returned come backe out of Germany.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: It is so.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Hath he returned alone. Returned he all alone?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: not at all. No verily.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: therefore who. Who then returned with him?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: A certaine citizen of this Town, who had dwelt there almost the space of • wo yeares. two yeares.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p:
Wherefore
had gone. went [thy] brother?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: He was. had beene sent thither of by my father, that hee might learne to speake after the Germaine manner. Germaine-like, or the Germaine tongue, Dutch.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: For what cause then hath he not beene. was he not there longer?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: He could not longer. now foregoe. forbeare the sight. desire of his mother.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: O very tender. tender yong man! what yeare doth he, or doth he goe on. how many years old is he?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: the seaventeenth (yeare) Seaventeene, if my mother remember well, aright, of whom I have heard that oftentimes.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Goe to, what countenance did his father give him. with what countenance was his comming accepted of [his, or thy] father?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Dost thou aske? My father did not indure to looke upon him: moreover, neither having vouchsafed him vouchsafing him salutation, nor speaking to, he commanded him to get him out, &c. to go out of [his] sight.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: What besides. moreover?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: But that my mother had made intercession with teares. Had not my mother made intreatie with teares, he commanded the apparitour. sargeant. officer to be sent for, who might cast the miserable (young man.) wretch into prison.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: But he could not without the commandement. authority of the Magistrate.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: I know not, nevertheles he was about it, or attempted it. yet he indevoured it.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: what fell out after. What was done after? did he lye at your house?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: not at all. No truely.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Where then?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: (At the house) of my sister. knowest thou the man, or husband of my sister▪ Knowest thou my sisters husband?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I know him as well as. Even as [my] fingers.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: He was sent thither by [my] mother, whilest my fathers anger waxed coole againe, or slaked. was asswaged.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: What fell out at length?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: [My] mother dealt with our kinsfolks & friends, that they might appease my angry father, my fathers anger. would mitigate. appease [my] father being angry.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: So then thy brother was received into favour, or reconciled. returned into favour with thy father.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p:
That was [matter of no great labour. a matter] of no great businesse: for now it began to irke. to repent [my] father that hee
had beene so burning with anger. so very angry, Because and that he had received entertained his sonne so so heavily, or dealt so hardly with his sonne. hardly.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Verily, time. the day had asswaged mitigated his griefe.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Notwithstanding he received him, of that law. condition that he should promise hi • selfe to. that he would returne into Germany straightway after the vintage.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: See how folish. fond this affection is towards our mothers.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: But the mothers thēselves are in the cause. fault: for why doe they love us so greatly, or foolishly. tenderly?

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: It is a difficult thing to compell, or inforce. restrain nature.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Dost thou remember. not remember the verse out of Horace to this purpose?hold.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Although thou drive away nature as with a forke, or staffe. with a forke, it wil returne incontinently.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: But what [is] this? whilest we talke, it is ceased, or lingred from play. wee have neglected our play. wee have lost our play.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: we shall get no hurt thereby. No evill shall happen to us thereby. Let us meet together. goe together now to [our] disputations.
VVHere hast thou bin to day after dinner?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: in the orchard of our master. In our masters orchard.

sp.speaker: C.
