sp.p: what hadst thou gone. Whereto wentest thou thither?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: He had sent. sent me thither to fetch herbs.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: what herbs hast thou gathered at length? And what hearbs hast thou gathered?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I can scarsly tell. number all.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
At least what meet, or run to, what thou dost remember. come
to [thy] memory?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: But why doest thou aske that?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: That in the meane time wee may remember certaine. some names of things which we being little ones learned, or when we were children. we learned being little ones.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: It is a faire exercise; especially when we have any thing of leisure doth remaine, or abound. any leisure. Heare then: I have gathered Garlike, wilde thyme. running Bettony, Leekes, Onions, Cresles, Cumine, Fennell, Thyme, Marjoram, Hyssop, nose smart. Parsley, Sage, Savory.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: [Those] are smalage. smelling. sweet hearbs which thou hast reckoned up. numbred as yet.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I had I purposed so. determined so for [the cause of my memory. my] memory sake.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Goe on as yet. Proceed further.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Indeed a few remaine, as bettes. Beete, Succorie, Lectuce, sowre dockes. Sorrell, Rocket, Colewort, Purslane, moe hearbs. moe doe not meet me. come to [my] remembrance. minde.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: How couldest thou remember so many?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: [My] Master had given me gave me a note, or scrole. a catalogue written.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: And hadst thou. knewest thou [them] all?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I had knowen them. knew them: otherwise I would had. I had asked him.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: But I have not known knew them not all, although I had learned the names.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I also will shew thee moe, when it shall be lawfull for us. we may go into the orchard. garden.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Hast thou brought much. store?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: [I have brought] a full basket, or hamper. a basketfull.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: But how much of every one?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Thou art too inquisitive. over curious what meanest thou? wilt thou? I have brought [so much] of every one, how much. as hath beene. was needful.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Although I be thought over curious. I seeme to thee curious, neverthelesse I desire that thou answere me this. I would have thee to answer me this: dost thou know for what use our Master did care. cause so many kindes of herbs. potherbes to be gotten. prepared?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p:
Partly that the pottage might be wel seasoned, partly that
a a Iussel, a pudding or meate made with herbes and other things chopped together gallimawfrie might bee made of of potherbes. herbes.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: How well consult. provided hee for us!

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: the best of all. Passing well: but yet. neverthelesse that was not the chiefe cause.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Therefore what was the chiefe cause? What then?read ever.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p:
Hast thou ever read Virgils Moretam is a kind of pudding made of milke, cheese, and herbs. the Moretum of Virgil, Virgils poeme, called Moretum.
moretum?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Indeed I have read the verse, but I have never eaten of the pudding, nor seene it that I know.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: But I hope thou shalt see [it:] for our master hath taught [his] wife to make it, and she hath made it by the prescript of him. according to his direction. by his prescript.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: whether shall there be set before us. Shall wee have some good thing put to us. provided against Supper?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: At least fatte pottage made of flesh. of fleshmeate well seasoned, the best flesh. notable flesh, and a gallimaw frey [made] of pot herbs. herbs.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: from whence. How knowest thou these things?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I saw all things in the kitchen, when I had been bidden. was commanded to helpe, especially in washing, purging, or clensing diligently. picking my herbs.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: what the moretum? What must what the pudding made of milke, cheese and herbs do? the Moretum [do:] shall we not at least taste of it?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Yea there shall be given, we shall have some given us, for that is made which is enough. there is so much made, as is enough for all.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I like these better. These things do • avour more. are more pleasant. savory to me especially in summer, then flesh themselves, very flesh, or any flesh flesh it selfe, or little fishes. or the finest fish.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Truely, I could wish flesh to be kept untill winter, that we might eate of potherbs throughout summer. hearbs and fruits in the whole summer. all the summer.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: But (as I have heard) these things doe lesse nourish.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I also have heard it sometimes. have sometimes heard it; but what need is there to students. what need have to scholars studying. students of so much nourishment. meate?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
There is no need of so much I confesse. Not so much I confesse: notwithstanding if our parents should see us pale and leane, they would straightway
assigne, or lay straight way. impute the fault thereof. of that matter, to our master: is it not so?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: There is no doubt, but what meanest thou? parents almost. almost [all] parents (especially mothers) make too much of us. doe cocker us over much.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Indeed thou speakest true things. thou sayest the truth: but thou in the mean time art glad of, or canst be content with. dost enjoy willingly the tendernesse. cockering. kindenesse of thy mother.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: As if indeed thou lesse. thou dost not.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Let me not lie. That I may not lye, I likewise finde experience of I also finde by experience oft times, in my selfe [that thing. that] which I impute to thee, or blame thee for. ascribe to thee.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Wee cannot change the affections of parents towards us but by our vices. faults: onely let us take heed of abusing their tendernesse. beware to abuse. of abusing their kindnesse; but especially let us prayse that our most bountifull father, who hath given us such parents. such progenitors.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I heare these things willingly, but the time. houre calleth us away.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Goe to, let us put to. make an end.
FRom whence comest thou? dost thou return?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Out of the market.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What hast thou bought?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Flesh.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Of what sort, or of what kinde? What [flesh?]

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: flesh of the calfe, or calves flesh. Veale.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Shew it. Let me see it, I pray thee, it is almost a newes, or new thing. a novelty at this time.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: looke on it See.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I take it to be good. It seemeth to me to be good.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Thou art not
deceived I thinke.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: How many pounds are there?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The butchers will not sell veale by weight. weigh Veale.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: For the newnesse. noveltie [of it.]

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: See the craft, to wit. verily every man selleth the most dearely. as deare as he can.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: thou hast touched the matter with the point, or in the point. Thou hast hit the nayle on the head.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: How much doest thou thinke [that it wayeth. it] to waigh?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Two pounds, and more by a little. somewhat more.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: For how much hast thou bought it?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Goe to; ghesse. divine

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I am not a foreteller, or a ghesser of things to come, a wizard. a diviner.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: But many do divine, who notwithstanding are not wizards. diviners.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It may be done. be, but by certaine coniectures; otherwise foretelling, or sorcery. divining is forbidden in the divine letters. holy Scriptures.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Therfore ghesse. divine from. by conjecture.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thou hast bought the whole for two pence.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: [I have bought it] of lesse price by a little. for somwhat lesse.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: For how much then?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Try againe

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: For twenty deniers.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I will not have thee to be written or molested about nothing. troubled any longer concerning nothing.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: of all love tell me. Therefore tell [me] of good fellowship.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: All this cost me sixe farthings. three halfe pence.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Truely, thou hadst good fortune. fortune favoured thee well.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What fortune dost thou speake of. dost thou tell me [of?]

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: we use to speake so. This is the [usuall] custome. manner of speaking.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Custome (as it is said) is a very vile tyrant. the worst tyrant. But I would to God we could make so much of love good customes so studiously, or with such desire. earnestly, as we hould. retaine the bad customes. evill perversly. obstinately.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Then all things should have themselves better. should goe better.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Therefore let us leave that fortune to Ethnickes. Heathens & wicked men: fortune is nothing, it is God alone who doth blesse, or prosper us. favour us; he alone. onely is our helper and protectour.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Indeed I know
that certainly, I beleeve it faithfully, and confesse it truely, but what doest. meanest thou? the tongue slippeth oft times, when the minde thinketh no euill, or no harme. the minde thinking no evil: It behooved thee to have remembred that. Thou shouldest have remembred that; Let not [thy] tongue run before [thy] minde. wit.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Surely wee have learned this, out of the sayings of the seven wise men: but things of such sort so goodlily spoken. such excellent, or worthy. goodly sayings doe not alwayes come to minde, although we have comm • tted them to memory.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Therfore the memory. it is to be exercised so much the more, that it may minister enough to us. afford us matter sufficient when need is.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I shall learne. I will learn to be wiser at other times, by this thy admonition.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: But I heare warning. the signe to be given, let us give over. cease.
wast thou in the market to day?HAst thou beene to day in the market?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I have beene [there.]

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: After the sacred assembly. holy Sermon.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: What hast thou bought for us?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: almost nothing. Nothing almost.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: But what?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Butter.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: For how much?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: For a farthing.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: hast thou bought so little. So little?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I durst not buy any more. more.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: What fearedst thou? diddest thou feare?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Lest it should not bee good.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: (It is) done wisely. Thou hast dealt very wisely. wisely enough.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Master, why say you that?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p:
Because I had rather that thou shouldest be. have thee to be over timerous. too fearefull then
too bolde, in this matter. But hast thou brought nothing besides. else?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Nothing

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Hoe! what nothing?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Nothing at all.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Alas. Out, how pinchingly. sparingly hast thou provided meate. made provision of meate for us?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: What other thing might I have. could I had bought?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: As if thou knowest not, with what meates I love. what meats I am wont to be delighted.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I know you to love. that you love cheese somewhat soft, and peares, and other new fruits.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Thou sayest well, therefore why boughtest thou not. why diddest thou not buy [some]?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: The very cheese alone. The cheese it selfe was too deare. over-deare for our little money. small deale of money.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: What were the fruits? What the fruits?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Some were not ripe enough; I doubted concerning others, whether they were good.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: O miser, wretch. O foole, couldest thou not taste?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: But those women will doe not suffer to taste, unlesse you affirme. will not let men taste. not let you taste any thing, unlesse you promise.you affirme to be about to buy. that you will buy.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: [It is] no marvell, for many would taste onely for the cause of their minde. their minde sake. Be thou therfore more wise at other times.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: If thou shalt see any fair fruit, buy therefore be thou. a little for somewhat. a deniere, that thou mayest make a perill. a tryall.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: What then moreover. besides?a little penny.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: If it have a good taste, or relish, or savour well to thee If thou like it well, then buy more; if lesse. not, leave it, and betake thy selfe else where to buy. goe other-where.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: This is a good caveat, or advise. caution.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Therefore remember, that thou use it hereafter. after.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: • As I hope I shall. I (as I hope) shall remember it diligently. carefully, will you any thing besides?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: That thou looke to. care for [those things] which are of thy office. which belong to concerne thy office, and then [that] thou apply [thy] letters, or thy booke. learning.
hast thou beene present. WAst thou present at morning prayer?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I have beene. I was present, but where wast thou?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I went to [my] father to the Inne.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: what thither. Whereto?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Hee commanded [me] yester evening. yesterday at evening, that I should meete with him. talke with him well early. very early.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How durst thou goe forth well early. so early, & that our Master unconsulted, or una ked. without asking leave of our master?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: now yesterday I had gotten leave. I had obtained. gottē leave even yesterday, before it is gone. we went to bed. But tell me what he said, or admonished of. what hee gave warning of openly, after prayer.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I have heard (quoth he) there to be some. that there are some amongst you, who talke in English very often. oft times, and in the meane time, none of you doth shew. tell me any thing; which is an argument of the consent of [you] all in the same offence. fault.a signe, or token. This was the summe of [his] accusation, and then he spake many things to the same sentence, or end. purpose which I could not remember.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: But at length. I pray thee what was [his] conclusion?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Wherefore (quoth he) I admonish you, that you one exhort another, and &c. Prolepsis implicita. that another. one [of you] exhort another diligently, to speake Latin, and that you give up. bring unto me the first of all. very quickly the names of them who will not obey; that I may adde a remedy to this evill.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Therefore shall it be lawfull to utter no English word. May we not therefore utter no word in English. any word in English?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: He doth not understand the matter so, as much as I could gather of his words: for (as thou knowest) he is not so sharpe a censurer, or so very strict. so very severe an exactour, that he doth punish straightway, if any word slip from any. escape any by chance between talking. as they are talking together.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: He hath said openly sometimes (as I remember) that his decree, or order. edict appertaineth to those only who when they know [to speake] in Latin. Latine, yet alwaies seeke dennes, lurking, or hiding places. holes, that they may talke in English, and that concerning frivolous and vaine. of most fond matters.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: That is. frowardnesse. Such is the stubbornnesse of some. certaine, that they had rather be beaten most often. very often for resisting. disobeying the honestest commandements. most honest precepts, then to be commended. praised, and also to be loved for obeying.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Thou remembrest us to heare oft. that we have heard, (this sentence.) of our master himselfe; We indevour, or labour. strive to the thing forbidden. to [that which is] forbidden.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I doe remember [it,] and it is it is so very true. most true: neverthelesse they who sincerely imbrace, or receive. who imbrace willingly the doctrine of Christ, doe not offend of purpose nor of naughtinesse, or ungraciousnesse. peevishnesse.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: That The true feare of the Lord doth performe this that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Therefore such do carefully labour. indeavour to beware, or avoid diligently. to take heed as much as it is lawfull by the weakenesse, or imbecility. they can, for the infirmity of nature, that they neither doe nor speake, or thinke any thing. doe, speake, or think nothing knowing wittingly whereby God may be offended, even the least of all. yea never so little.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
Therefore let us also study to beware of that same thing, let us studie. indevour to live well, and to obey the will of our God, not onely that we may not be beaten. least we be beaten, but more [also] that we may
may be pleasing to. please that our best father.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: So it shall be done. it shall come to passe, that we may be truely children, not of darkenes • e, but of light.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: But [we will speake] concerning these things at other times. elsewhere, more largely. in moe [words,] now let us receive our selves. betake our selves to our disputations.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Behold the bell doth ring for us. the signe, or token. bell doth call [us.]
REturnest thou now onely, but now. now at length from the market?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: what (sayest thou) at length? Why, at length? there is so great a crowd, presse, or thrusting. a throng at the butcherie. shambles that I could hardly come to it. scarce come neere.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: What flesh hast thou brought us against to morrow?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: oxe flesh and weathers flesh. Beefe and mutton.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Is there great store of flesh in the market?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Indeed so great, that I marvell (them) to be so deare. that it is so deare.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: [It is] nothing rare. no marvell: as there is great store of fl • sh. much flesh, so there are many who eat flesh daily: but what kindes of flesh sawest thou especially?chiefly

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I saw beefe, veale, mutton, or flesh of the ewe. ewe mutton, weather mutton, swines flesh. porke, kidde, lambe.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Nothing else?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: What wouldest thou more over. besides?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Was there then nothing of venison flesh of the wilde beast. no venison?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I cannot relat • . report all things together, yea I saw also venison.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Of what kinde. sort?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p:
Stags flesh. Venison of the stag and Boares flesh. venison
of the wild-boare: Oh how fat is the Venison. flesh of the wild-boare!

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: O how fond art thou!

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Because thou art deceived in the names of things: for that which in a swine living about the house, or a tame swine. about home, is called lard, or su • t. fat, that in the wild swine (that is to say in the boar) is called brawn, and it is the most hard in that kinde.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Truely. Indeed I doe not remember that I have heard that. this.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Now thou hast heard it, command it, or remember it. commit it to memory, if thou wilt.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: But thou doctour, from whence hast thou learned this?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Venison is a thing most usuall, or common. frequent at our house.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: from whence is there such store to you. From whence are you so stored▪ have you such plenty?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: My father hath a warren. a parke of many wilde beasts at the countrey. in the countrey, from which sometimes whole boars are brought into the Citie. What a one is that parke?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The place is almost. It is a place almost of a foure-square fashion. fouresquare, most ample. large, hedged about, or invironed. compas • ed about on every side, with most high walls, beset with many & most tall. high trees, amongst which are shrubs most thicke. very thicke shrubs or bushes. shrubs.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: what trees? What kinde of trees are there? whether, trees planted, or nourished in the citie, or about the city. belonging to the citie, or to the wood. such as grow commonly about the cities, or wilde?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: [They are] almost all belonging to the wood. wilde; but amongst these. in these are especially oakes & beeches, with the fruit, or acornes. mast of which. whereof the harts. stagges, boares, [and] buckes and does. does doe feed on. are fed.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Oh how great thankes doe yee owe of due, or worthily. deservedly owe to God, who hath given unto you so great abundance of all things?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p:
We are not unmindefull of his benefits: for my father doth erogate. bestow very many good things, alme •
▪ very much goods unto. upon the poor, which
notwithstanding I will to be. would have to be spoken to thee alone.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Because he will not. will not have such things to be published abroad. preached of. spoken of.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: [Hee is] to be praysed much more, because he followeth truely the precept of Christ, whose words are written in Matthew. When thou doest (quoth hee) [thy] almes, and what things doe follow.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: In what chapter?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: In the sixt chapter. sixt, unles my memory faile. deceive me.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But these things hitherto: for we have talked together sufficiently, and now it is met (of the scholars.) the scholars are come together, to dispute.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Therefore let us goe.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Follow mee, if thou wilt rather. or if thou hadst rather, goe before [mee.]

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I will doe neither, but we will goe together.
Hast thou then returned, &c. ANd art thou returned onely to day from the town, or village. farme-house?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I came backe. To day only, and that a little before dinner.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: But thou haddest said, saydest that thou wouldest be there onely two daies.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I hoped so to come to passe. that it would be so, and my father so promised.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Therfore what letted thee. hindred [thee] that thou camest not backe. returnedst not sooner?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
My mother kept me backe. detained mee, although I besought her even
wit h teares, that she would send me away. dismisse mee.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: But why hath she. did she stay thee so long?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: That I might accompany her. attend upon her in [her] returne.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: And what diddest thou in the meane time?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I gathered fruits with our husbandmen. our countrey fellowes.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: What fruits?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: As if the harvest fruits and [our] lateward [fruits] thou knewest not. are not knowne. unknown unto thee, Peares, Apples, Walnuts, Chesnuts.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: pleasant exercise!

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It is not onely pleasant, but also commodious. fruitfull.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: But this was an evill. But [there is] this evill, that in the meane time the fruit. benefit of five or sixe lessons is perished to thee. that thou hast lost the fruit of five or six lessons. is lost.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I hope it is not lost at all. altogether; I will be carefull for my strength. as much as ever I can that I may recover [them] in some sort. in some part.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: What wilt thou doe?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I will write them out. write it downe the most diligently I shall be able. as diligently as I can.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: What then after?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I will learne without booke the very oration, word. speech of the Author.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: But thou ca • st not. wilt not sufficiently understand the sentence. sense. meaning.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The very exposition▪ interpretation of our master will direct me. helpe me, that I may get, attaine the meaning. sense of a great part. for the most part.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Neither yet will that be enough.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thou if it please thee, shalt be present. come to me by thy leisure. when thou canst tend. at [thy] leisure, that we may conferre together.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Indeed I will doe it willingly.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: But truely that will not serve. that indeed will not be sufficient.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I can do no more. I have not what. that I can doe any more.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: How much better had it bin, to have heard the lively voyce of [our] master▪

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
Truely it had been much better; but sith it fell out otherwise. sith that happened not unto mee, neither is it done. come to passe by my negligence▪
negligence. fault, I have no iust cause. nothing to accuse. I may accuse my selfe of, in this part, or herein. behalfe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thou sayest rightly. well: therefore see that thou have a good minde. that thou be cheerefull: for as for that. in that, that I have disputed. reasoned with thee in moe words. so largely concerning this matter, I have not done it for that cause to cause thee. to that end, that I would bring thee into distrust of recovering that which thou hast lost. despaire: butall this is come. all that is proceeded from my singular • ove towards thee.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I doubt not of that. That is no doubt unto me: whereupon it commeth to passe, that I give thee the greater thankes.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p:
But behold the
• ance bell. little bell calleth us to supper.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: A fit messenger.
God save thee Peter.PEter. God save thee.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: O Iohn thou art come luck • ly. hast come in very fit time: art thou in good health? art thou well?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Passing well thanks be to God, but how doest thou?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Truely very wel by the goodnesse of God: but when camest thou? returnedst thou from home?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: now the third day hence. Now three daies agoe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It hath well. It is well, thou art come. hast come fitly.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: To wit. Truely or for. Because I knew the time of the vacation to be instant. to be at hand. quietly.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Doth it please thee that we talke a little at leisure. now at our leisure?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p:
Especially. Yea verily, so that wee may bee sundred separated from thiscompany making a noyse. clamorous company
of players.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou admonishest. advisest well: let us depart asunder into that roome, or place of hearing lectures. that auditory which is open.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: How fitly doe we sit here! Goe to, we may speake. let us speake freely.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Have you got your vintage. Are your vintages finished?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Altogether.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How much time have you put. bestowed. spent in the whole worke?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: About fifteene daies.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hast thou then been present. And wast thou present alwaies?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I omitted no day.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What didst thou?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I very often gathered. gathered grapes very oft.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou oughtest to adde somewhat with the verbe. to the verbe Collige • am.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: What, I pray thee?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: What need was there [to adde that?] No man can doubt concerning this. of this, for who doth gather good fruits and ripe, but he will eate even. he eateth also of the best?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: In truth thou sayest right. speakest well: hoe, I praise thy answer.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Didst thou thinke now to have stopped [my] mouth?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Indeed I thought not that. so.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I did not expect so ready and so wise an answer.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: There is no cause that thou marvell. that thou shouldest marvell: for as it is in the Proverb, oft times even the very gardiner, a seller of pot hearbs, or roots. pot-hearb-seller hath spoken fit words. fitly.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: To whom dost thou owe this Proverb?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: To master Iulian, for he doth dictate now and then. sometimes such Proverbs and notable, goodly, fine. pretty sentences out of good authors.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hee provideth or consulteth. adviseth passing well for you: but at what time. hours is he wont to doe that?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Sometimes, otherwhile. Now and then after supper, but more oft when we have nothing to repeat in the auditory, or in our place. schoole.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
I would to God, all would do so, so that they were not a hindrance to the daily exercises
in the. of the schoole.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Thou hast well put to. adjoyned that exception, by the Adverbe so that. Dummodo [so that:] for there are certaine masters who teach little children. under-masters who do so load their children, with their dictates, and private lessons. readings, that they cannot satisfie. doe that which they ought, or are inioyned. performe [their duty] in the schoole.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thence it commeth to passe that the head-masters themselves, doe complaine sometimes of such ushers. under-masters: But whither are we gone? what doe we? Let us returne to our instituted, or appointed. determined speech.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: it pleaseth me. It liketh me well.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hast thou beene all this time. alwayes occupied, or busied. imployed in gathering grapes?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: That worke is ended, or shut. finished in a few dayes, because that. for that so great a number of workfolks is wont to be placed, or set unto it. imployed about it.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What is done then. after?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: The grapes are trodden, the wine is drawne out of greater pipes, or tuns. vessels [and] is powred by the same labour, or diligence. withall, into hogs-heads: afterwards the grapes themselves, not yet sufficiently pressed out are put under the presse in the fat. are put again into the wine-presse: last of all, the graines and husks of the grapes, or mother of the vine. kernels of the grapes are carried out & cast away.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But thou didst not care for, or oversee. looke to these things.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Yea I looked to them of some part. somewhat, for I was present in doing all things, especially that I might call on the work-folks. stir up their diligence, or incourage them, care for, or looke to. solicite the workes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou wast then unto them, as an overseer, a ruler and as a master of the worke.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: yea was I indeed a master? Yea I was indeed a master & a governour. overseer of the works, for my father had set me over them. preferred me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
How didst thou reioyce in this mastership. office incouraging. How goodly a thing was it to see thee with thy gravity, commanding some, incouraging. exhorting others,
and to conclude chiding, or reproving others. blaming others.

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: Truely, if thou hadst then seen mee, thou wouldest had said that I had been another, than a scholar in the schoole.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou wast not idle as I see. As I see thou wast not idle.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Yea [I] as a good father of a houshold. governour of a family added oft times. did oft times put [my] hands to the worke, that I might pricke forward, incourage. stirre up the workfolks themselves, by my example.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: [Thy] father (as appeareth) had preferred thee to this office not without cause.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: to wit, for that. Verily because he hadproved by experience. tryed my diligence in other matters.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Yet let bragging be away from thy word, or speech. be it spoken without boasting. bragging.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I understand so: but I speake so freely, because [I talke] with my familiar friend.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But let us proceed. How great store of wine is there to you? What plenty. store of wine have you?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: meane. Indifferent: of what sort. as it is said to bee almost every where this yeere; although we have reddish, or somwhat red. claret wine abundantly. plentifully, [yet] white wine. white not in like manner. so. But whatsoever it is we are content, and we doe receive it, from the hand of the Lord, with thankesgiving. with giving of thanks.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How many hogs heads have you filled?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: more, or lesse then forty, or about forty, or forty, or thereabout. we have filled forty more, or lesse. Forty, more or lesse, but some of the hogsheads some are greater than others.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Wonderfull! dost thou not thinke it? doth it not seeme to thee a great increase.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Enough indeed, but not for the reason. in respect of the former yeare.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What makes it matter. skilleth it? By how much the quantity is lesse▪ The lesse quātity there is, it shall also be sold for more by so much. the more it will be sold for.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: It is wont to fall out so almost. commonly. But doe I not seeme to thee to have shewed enough. doest thou not thinke that I have spoken sufficiently concerning the vintages? what dost thou desire besides. moreover?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Because we abound so with leisure. we may tend so well,
I will. I desire to heare also something of thee, concerning the fruits of trees; for it is, as it were, another vintage. Have yee not many, or great store of fruit. many?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: [We have them] in full boorded floores, or chambers full. lofts, which is. such is the bounty of God.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When are they. were they gathered?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: [Our] houshold. family did gather them at what time. when we made wine·

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What kindes of such like fruits are to you? have you?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Apples, peares, chestnuts, walnuts: but there is much, or many sorts. great variety of apples and peares.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What quinces? have ye not them also?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Yea we have, but those are contained under the kinde of apples; wherupon they are called by another name, quince peares. quince-apples.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: And what thou comming againe hither hast brought? hast thou brought now returning hither?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Nothing but a hand-basket of chosen. choyse grapes: due there shall be brought to me apples, peares, &c. but apples, peares, chestnuts, shall be brought mee in full sackes. by sackfuls every weeke hereafter.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: In the meane time, give me I pray thee, some of thy grapes.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Let us goe into my chamber, there I will give thee.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: in truth I am prepared. I indeed am ready, let us goe.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: There also wee will talke of repeating the last dialogue against monday, for as I thinke our master will looke for that. exact that especially.
I Heard thy father to have come to day. that thy father came to the place of exercise. schoole to day.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Thou heardest the truth.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: why. For what cause came hee?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That he might number. pay money to my master, for my nourishments. table, or boord. dyet, [and] withal that he might speake to him earnestly for me. commend me unto him.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Had he never commended thee?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yea most often.very often.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: what will • e to himselfe. What meaneth he by this so frequent. often commendation?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: he doth pro • ecute me with true love. He loveth me unfainedly.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Therefore he covets me to be instructed diligently. Hee therefore desires that I should be diligently taught.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: What if he cōmend thee▪ that thou maist be beaten more often. the oftner?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Peradventure that is the cause: but what then? he doth not therfore lesse love me. love me the lesse.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: How. From whence dost thou gather this?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Because correction is as necessary for a childe as nourishment. meate.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Truely. Indeed thou saiest truth, but few doe judge so, for there is no one. none but he had rather have bread then a rod.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That is naturall to al: who doth deny it? but notwithstanding punishment. correction is to be born patiently, especiallyif it be iust, or worthy. just.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p:
This sentence is had. is in Ca • o of good manners. the little booke appertaining to manners. Remember to suffer patiently, what things thou sufferest by due desert. deservedly. But what
if the correction be unjust?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That neverthelesse is. That also is to be suffered neverthelesse.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: For whose cause?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: for Christs sake. For Iesus Christ who suffered a most unjust death, and that most bitter, for our sinnes.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: I would to God, that would. might come into the minde, to us. into [our] minde, as oft as we suffer any thing.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Our Master doth put us in minde of that often. doth oft of that. oft admonish us of that, as oft as occasion doth offer it selfe: but a fable. it is as a tale. a tale is told [in vaine] to them who are deafe. to deafe [men] as it is in the Proverbe.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Therefore let us give our diligence. doe our indevour, that we may be more diligent hereafter.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: God grant so.
WHy wast thou not present at the sermon to day. this daies Sermon?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I was busie in writing Letters.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Couldest thou not put off. deferre thy businesse?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: The hasting. haste of the carrier did inforce me. did urge [me.]

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: But our master teacheth us, all things to be set after. that al things are to be set after the businesse of God.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Indeed he teacheth. He teacheth [it] indeed; neither is that doubtfull to me. doe I doubt of that: but we are never so perfect, but we we put after God oft times to these earthly things. oft times set God after these earthly things.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: That thing is a fault. That is evill.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p:
Truely it is the wo • st. [it is] very evill: but we are alwayes carnall. men, except God shall
• hange us by his spirit. But I pray thee tell [me] was there a frequent were there many in the auditory. auditory?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Not very great, were there many in the auditory. according to the ancient manner.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: from whence is that thing. How commeth that to passe?as it is wont.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Art thou ignorant the people to be occupied now in (their vintages. Knowest thou not that the people are now busie in gathering their grapes?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I am not ignorant of it: but cannot men bestow one onely houre in Gods service. in divine matters?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
It is not my duty, or office. [part] to render thee a reason of this. to give thee an account hereof, onely this I say: It is a dishones • y. shame to for a teacher when the fault which he is blamed for, or when he is guilty of the same fault which he reproveth. a fault reproo
• eth himselfe.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Wonderfull! how great a blow hast thou dashed to me. given me! farewell▪ I will not reply a word. adde a word more.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Be thou wiser therefore at other times.
THou then (as I heare) art to depart to morrow?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: To morrow, if the Lord shall permit.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Hoe, wherefore so quickly?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: My father doth constraine. urge me.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yea thou inforcest, or compellest. urgest [thy] father.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Thinkest thou so. Doth it seeme so to thee? How can I urge my father?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: By daily. continuall sending of Letters.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I writ onely once, our scholasticall vacation, or the breaking up of our schoole to be at hand. that the breaking up of our schoole was neere.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: When sendest thou?didst thou send Letters?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: The other. former weeke.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What day?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Upon The day of Venus. friday.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What wilt thou doe at home?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: The vintage is at hand, theother fruits. fruits of trees are to be gathered in the meane time.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thou mightst tarry untill. expect the day of dimission. the breaking up.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I know not when it will be.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I hope it to be. that it will be at the end of the next weeke.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: But this isis not set, or put. doth not consist. not at our arbitrement. pleasure, or appointment. determination.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: No nor indeed [in the determination] of our Master.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Of whom therefore?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Of God onely, who doth governe the counsels of men by his owne nod. appointment.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: But Satan doth seeme to governe sometimes.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: As much as God himselfe doth permit. But let us leave these things to wiser [men.]

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: It is more safe; for the Proverbe doth admonish: The shoo maker let him not meddle. Let not the shoo-maker meddle beyond his panto • les. slipper.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: We have oft times heard that of our master.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: The very same our master. He hath taught us also not once. more than once, that sentence of Paul; Doe not savour, or understand. meddle with the searching of a thing too high. too high matters: but feare.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: He useth that also oft. He hath that also oft in [his] mouth: Thou shalt not seeke out too deepe matters for thee. Seeke not out too deepe matters.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: But doest thou not heare a signe to be given. that we are called to supper?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thesance-bell. little bell doth beate my eares as yet. sound still in my eares.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Let us goe into the hall, lest wee be away. be wanting to prayer. at prayer. I will take my leave of thee. salute thee, to morrow before [my] going away. departing.
IN what kind of play hast thou exercised thy selfe to day?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: In play of walnuts. for walnuts.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hast thou gained any thing?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yea, I have lost.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Fortune then hath beene adverse, or crosse. against thee.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I know not what fortune: onely I know, it to have fallen out. that it fell out by mine owne fault: but God so willing, or pleasing. disposing.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Wherefore would God that thing. have it so?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: That hereby I may learn to beare more grievous things when they shall happen. fall out.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: As if God care for, or regard. regardeth the pastimes, or games of boyes. sports of children.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Verily he doth regard [them:] moreover nothing is done. comes to passe in the nature of things, without the divine providence. the providence of God.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: what dost thou play the Philosopher even so? Dost thou thus play the Philosopher? And who, or who I pray thee. who taught thee those things?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Hast not thou thy selfe heard them so oft. very oft of our Preacher?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It may be that I have heard them; but what meanest thou? what dost thou? I have but aweake memory. my memory • s flowing, or slippery to me. weake.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Verily because thou dost not exercise it.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How is it to be exercised?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
First by diligent attention; that is, by turning our selves. marking diligently those things which we hear 〈◊〉 reade, and then by repeating the same things oft times: to conclude, by teaching
others the same things which we have learned.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: those. These things are beaten upon very often by our Master; but (woe is me wretch. me wretch!) how retchlesse. carelesse is that my negligence!

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: So we are all, except that spirit of God do stirre us up.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Therefore what shall I do?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: My Pe • rine awake: goe to God. aspire unto God with [thy] whole minde. heart, and with whole power. all thy strength: pray unto him daily, ordinarily, or very often. continually, and with a godly affection. devoutly: be vigilant: flye the wicked, be conversant with good men, or honest scholars. with the good; also effect, or make. cause by thy most courteous manners. behaviour, that thou mayest make the good to be thy friends. them familiar unto thee.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: what benefit shall I reape. What shall I get at length. thereby?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Doest thou aske? If thou shalt accustome thy selfe to these manners, the Lord God will have pitty▪ mercy on thee in his gentlenesse, clemency. goodnesse, and thou shalt perceive thy minde to be changed. changed in a short time.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Oh how fit. seasonable this meeting hath beene. hath this meeting beene unto me! I pray thee. I intreat thee, my Crote • an that we may talke together more often.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: It shall not stand by me, as oft as it shall be lawfull to us both by our leisure. There shall be no hindrance in me, as oft as we may attend. we may be at leisure.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I give [thee] very hearty thanks. most hearty thankes.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: There is not a cause. [no cause] that thou give mee thankes, let us betake our selves. get us into the schoole, or place of hearing. auditory.
WHy didst thou sprinckle, or strew. scatter pease here?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: After dinner.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I did it for [the cause of my minde. my] minde sake.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But whence hadst thou those pease?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
I had taken. I took them out o •
a little shell, or vessell. a little trey where they were layed up, that they might be sodden to morrow.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: oughtest thou to doe evill? Shouldest thou have done evill for [thy] pleasure, or cause of thy minde. mind sake?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I did not thinke it to be an evill thing. evill.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Is it not evill to tread bread with thy feet. under thy feet?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I would not doe that.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Why wouldest thou not?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Because bread is most needfull. especially necessary for us.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: And God hath created. God hath created both pease themselves, and other things which are eaten, for our use.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I am not ignorant of • hat: moreover I love pease well, or I can eate • ease well. I eat pease willingly. gladly, if they be well sodden and seasoned.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Furthermore, wouldest thou abuse thine owne things?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: no not at all. No in no wise.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: By so much. So much lesse oughtest thou [to abuse] other folkes goods, or matters. things.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I understand well enough. sufficiently.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Therefore thou hast not done well.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I confesse, [I have done] not rightly. well; yet not with an evill minde.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Therefore why? Why then hast thou done it?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: fondnesse. Foolishnesse stirred me up thereunto. unto it.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
What hast thou deserved
thereupon?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Stripes.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thou sayest rightly. well, but (I thinke) (thou speakest not) from thy not from thy minde. heart.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yea certainely, I pray thee (see) thou doe not accuse me, or complaine of me. doe not accuse me.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Sith thou doest confesse it, of thine owne free will accord, I will not accuse thee: for our master hath said very often himselfe to will so. that he would have it so.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What hath he said?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That wee should bring up no mans name, or complaine of none. bring up no man to him, for such lighter matters, so that he shal, &c. who onely shall acknowledge his fault willingly.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Therefore my Aegidius. Alexander, I shall owe thi. benefit to thee. be beholding to thee for this kindenesse.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I would have thee to owe me nothing under this name. for this cause, but pray to God. intreat God with me, that he may deliver us from evill.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: We pray daily. every day in the schoole foure, or five times each day. foure or five times openly.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Moreover [(it is prayed) of us, wee pray] privately, as oft as meate is taken. wee take meate, as oft as it is gone to bed wee goe to bed, as oft as wee it is risen. rise from lying downe. from bed: are not these sufficient?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Besides those. these, our Master doth admonish [us] oft, that every one depart, or separate himselfe. goe at some times. now and then for himselfe. by himselfe some whither into a secret place, for the cause of praying. to the end to pray for himselfe. to pray: doest thou not remember it?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I remember it well;hast thou not remembred it? but (as thou knowest) it seemeth to be a difficult thing, for children to accustome themselves. that children should accustome [themselves] to secret prayers.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: And yet it shall bee very good to accustome [them] by little and little.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: That our God will stirre us up and accustome us to that thing. thereunto in processe. progresse of time.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
we are to hope so. It is to be hoped to be so. that it will be so, if yet. if so that we proceed diligently. profit well both in
the reading and also in the hearing of his word.
what. What cause was there? HOw is it that thouart come backe. hast returned so quickly to day frō thy uncle,any longer. especially sith there was a banket, hath been a feast?ta • ried.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: What should I have done there longer?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Thou shouldst had expected the supper, that thou mightest eat of that which was left of dinner.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I had eaten enough the reliques▪ at dinner. Furthermore [my] uncle commanded that I should bring my master home, whom I had in dinner. fetched forth to the banket. feast.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: What did thy companion, or kinsman. brother [brought. thy] cousin germane? wherfore returned not he unto the schoole with you?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: He is thy uneles sonne. kept. stayed behinde by [his] mother, retained, or holden backe. a day or two for a day or two.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Wherfore?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: for one, or another day. That he may have his cloths repaired amended.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Such is the care of women. But goe to, that garments may be amended to him. because we are now idle. at leisure, I pray thee that tel me something concerning the banket. feast.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: What shew or relate to me wouldest thou know concerning the feast concerning it?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: First, who doest • hou covet▪ or desire to know? were the guests, and then how dainty and have been strangers. magnificall, or ve • y rich. sumptuous the ba • ket. feast [was.]

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
These were the chiefe guests, the foure Syndici: officers having charg to deale in the affaires of the cō
• onwealth with any for
• aine Prince Syndicks, the costly Lieutenant of the Citie,under governor, or depu • y. and other two
men of principall condition. of chiefe note, of the number of the Senators.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Knowest thou [them?]

sp.speaker: C▪
sp.p: [Indeed I know them] of the face, or countenance by face: but I know not their names.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: [Were there] none besides?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: there were two of the familiar friends of my uncle Also two of my uncles speciall acquaintance.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: which in number.In what place did our master sit?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I marked. observed not in what number, or ranke, or order he sat.place he was: but he was almost in the middest of the table of the contrary part of my uncle. over against my uncle.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: But thou But where sattest thou?
Alasse. Hoe foole, who askest that! Should I little man, or dwarfe. poore boy, or little childe base fellow, feast with so great men? This was honorable. honour enough to me, that I served.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Were there no women?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: None besides the wife of my uncle. but my uncles wife, who indeed sate in the utmost table. at the lowest end of the table.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Why so did she sit so low, or so far off. so remote?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: So shee her selfe would, that she might rise eftsoones. ever now and then, morefitly. commodiously, for the order of the ministery, or to see the service well performed. service.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: What [did] [her] sonne?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Hee sate by [his] mother.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: I hav • (heard enough▪) I am satisfied concerning the guests: now I expect to heare thee concerning. concerning the feast.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Thou imposest upon me a burden very great. weighty and hard. difficult, especially for [my] memory: but sith that (as thou saydest) we have gotten a little more. somewhat more leisure this afternoone, I indeed will give my diligence. do my indevour, that I may fulfill thy desire of some sort. in some part.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Thou shalt doe me thing very acceptable to. a very good turne. a very kinde favour.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yet of that condition, that thou mayest requite like for like when thou shalt have fit opportunity. if at any time occasion shall be given.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: There is nothing. no cause that that thou doubt. thou shouldest doubt concerning this matter. Begin.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
But I will
sit in the meane while, because the narration. it is a long discourse.

sp.speaker: V▪
sp.p: Let us goe under the gallery, that we may talke more commodiously under the shadow. in the shadow.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Heare even now.Hearken then.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Because (as thou sayest) the narration. discourse is long, tell me first, at whathoures. a clocke it was sit downe (of them) they sate downe?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Almost at tenne.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: when rose they? At what a clocke was it risen. did they rise?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: A little before noone.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Did they all commodiously. handsomly. sit conveniently?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Most conveniently.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Now goe to the matter.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Heare therefore the firstthe preludes, or preambles. flourishes, or things going before the feast, or the first service preparatives of the table.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Begin. Set [them]▪ downe when thou wilt.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: First of all, there are.were set upon the table cracknels baked. little thinne wafers made with honey, of the bakers work, with a pleasant wine brued with spices. hypocrasse.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: The best. A notable beginning indeed, and most apt to get their mindes, or affections. fit to gaine their good liking.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Omit I pray thee, these interruptions; lest memory be troubled to me. lest [my] memory be hindred. be troubled.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: I will not interrupt [thee] hereafter, unlesse if it shal be needfull to aske of. to require any thing.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: •• lt • d gammons, or pestiles of porke. Gammons of of bacon salted. bacon followed, chitterlings dryed in the smoke hanged in the smoake, u sausiges, oxe-tongues, hardned also with salt & smoake. And these were to stirre up an appetite, and to sharpen. to make them taste their drinke. to provoke thirst.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: As if indeed it could not be sharpned enough. provoked sufficiently, by the heat and fervency of the Sun.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: learned banketters. Cunning feasters are wont to doe so.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: I heare these things gladly: especially, sith that thou expressest all, in proper and significant words. proceed further. Goe onmoreover. still.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
There were set between in the same manner. order, sallets of cabbage, lectuce; intrailes, 〈◊〉 garvage. giblets of birds fryed,
mixed meate. galley-mawfreyes of veale, with whole yolkes of egges. And these things hitherto of • he entrances. preparatives; which was the first messe.service.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Is it drunke nothing in the meane while? Drank they not in the meane time?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: A question unworthy, or unbeseeming, or unfit. unmeet for a man; for who wold spare wine here? scarce three, and those indeed most lust • e, or strong. of the most able amongst us, did suffice. were sufficient to fill drinke. to poure out drinke. But I will deale. speake afterwards concerning drinke: suffer me to dispatch the meate.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Goe to: I permit, or give thee leave. suffer [thee.]

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: In the second course.service there were these for most part. al these things: pasties.fleshpies, chickens boyled with lectuce, biefe, wethers mut • on. mutton, veale, new. fresh swines flesh. porke, poudred [porke] pottage of flesh. flesh pottage seasoned most pleasantly with yolkes of egges,sweetly. saffron and ve • iuyce of unripe grapes, or fruit not ripe.verjuyce; also some brothes [made] of pot hearbs. hearbs.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Here I ghesse. imagine (it) to have been ta • ked mo • e then eaten. they talked more than they ate: to wit be cause. for that rost [meates] were looked for.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: They had scarcely touched the meates on the table. table, when weare were commanded to take away. those. those things. Therefore I come to the third service. course, wherein these rost [meates] were served up. set on the table, chickens, pigeons,yong geese crammed fat goslings, and pigs, also conies, shoulders of mutton; last of all, venison of two kindes,incrusted by the bakers worke. baked in a crust, or in paste baked.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: What besides?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: What? Hoe! (I have almost omitted) [there were] two partridges cast betweene with a leve rate. with a leverat a leverate (or young hare) betweene two partriches. set betweene them, green beans fryed, and pease sodden in the husks, or cod • . with the shales.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: [what nothing of fish.Was there] no fish?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
Thou putst me in minde admonishest in time: There was a huge trout.a marvellous great trout which had was bin
divided into foure parts, besides the tayle: also a very great pickerell. pike divided into foure parts, after the same manner: I passe over the menowes, pinkes, or gogions. little fishes, and of the middle sort, partly boyled, partly rosted.broiled or fried, also c • ay fishes of the river. fresh water crabs, all in great number: But these morefor shew, then need to.for ostentation thentouched.for necessitie: for there was almost nothing touched.tasted of them.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Thou seemest to me to have omitted one thing.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Were there no sauces to dip in. sauces?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yea there were added almost to every d • sh. messe sharpe sauces to dip insauces of a mostpr • ty, or delica • e.fine tast, which the cook himselfe had fitted. prepared with marvellous cunning, or most artificially. skill.citrons, or lemmons. Neither indeed have there beene. were there wanting capersout of oyle.in oyle and vineger, orenges, pickled olives with their pickle, rose-vineger, the juyce of sorell. green-sauce.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: O how many and how great incitements, stirring▪ up, instigations, provocations of the throate, or gullet to gluttony [were there!]

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Adde also hindrances. impediments of body and minde.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: But I pray thee, what was the last act of the fable, or play. Comoedie?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
At length,no one. when nowany did eate neither not any one did eate either flesh or fish, my uncle cōmands the banketting dishes. junkets to be set on the table, in which. ā mong which these were chiefe; most fat, delicate. very fat new cheese, also old [cheese] manifold. of many sorts, tarts, little cakes. wafers, rice boyled in milke and well sugered, ripe peaches, figges, cherries,grapes dried in the sunne. raisins of the sunne, dates, banketting dishes used towards bedtime. junkets for the evening, things conserved. condite of many kindes, and other things which now doe not meete m • . come to my minde. To conclude, there was such affluence. store, or plenty. abundance of all meats,
that the table it self could scarseuphold, or beare them, contain them.hold thē ▪ what. But doest thou aske? the round plates. round trenchers, and the fouresquare. square trenchers are. were changed foure times. foure or five times: we carried backe for the most part, the grosser and harder, or courser. meaner meates whole into the Kitchen▪ so very few did touch [them] for the store of more delicates.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: what so great abundance and variety of meate doth profit.What good doth so great abundance and diversitie of meates?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: To oppresse, or over-loade. over-charge the stomacke, and to breed very many diseases. But what doest. meanest thou?so it is lived of men. after this manner.thus men livealmost. for most part, now-adayes.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: They who make feasts to such men,concerning plentie, concerning preparation, concerning splendor and daintinesse. doe seeme to strive about store who shall have most variety. for abundance, the finest preparing. preparation, sumptuousnesse, or statelinesse. pompe and daintinesse.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: And yet notwithstanding (as I have heard) there areapparant. to be seene. extant certaine lawesconcerning too great charge. for moderating the expences at feasts.against over-great sumptuousnesse in feasts, amongst the lawes of this citie.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Lawes have no place, or are of no force at feasts. Lawes are silent amongst feasts; that we may writhe incidently, (or beside the purpose) somewhat out of Tully. by the way, we may turne somewhat out of Tully to our purpose.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Doest thou thinke all the guests to be. that all the guests were delighted with thatoutragiousnesse of costsstrange excesse of expence?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: I doe not thinke so, unlesse peradventure they be devourers of their own substance, or gulligu •• . ding-thrifts, or prodigall, incontinent. riotous, or worshippers of their bellies, such as Apicius the Romane was, being famous for gluttony. Apician belly-Gods, as I may so say. But whence is it? what isin the cause.the cause?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Doest thou aske? Not onely the foolishnesse, or vanitie, or folly folly, but also the contagiousnesse. madnesse of banketters.feasters.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p:
The greatest part
of men istossedtroubled with the same disease, as Horace saith.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: But let us omit this busie iudging. censure, according to the proverbe: Let not the shoo-maker, &c. Therefore let vs come againe. returne to [our] purpose: what wine? what sort of wine was set to.was set on the table?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: If thou askest concerning colour, [there was] white, black lyon▪ tauny, or browne.deep yellow shining like gold,bloudied.sanguine, andsundry, or manifold.many kindes of wine of every colour: If [thou aske] concerning goodnesse, all in a manner were. all [the wines] werealmost. for the most part most generous, noble, or excellent. of the best kinde. very delicate: but they first of all, or above all. especially commended that kinde of wine out of Burgundy, which iscalled commonly Aubosium. commonly calledmalue • ie.Malmesie.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: From whence wasthis drawne.that fetched?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Out of the wine cellar of my uncle.mine uncles wine-cellar.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Hath he much of the like. of the same sort?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: [He hath] two hogsheads, or tuns. pipes wine o • Helvetiaof claret-wine, he hath two also. two also of most pure white-wine.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: What was the end of dinner?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
When [my] uncle saw all the guests wel • neere tired. almost weary with eating, drinking, and talking together: then he commands. commanded wine to be poured out to every onefilled out, given. heinviteth.invited all to the last drinking. draught. After this. Hereupon all thingsare.were taken away in order: more large. very large hād-towels ofthe finest flaxe are.most fine linnen were spred upon the tables:odoriferous or sweet smelling waters. sweet water is.was given, to wash [their] hands lightly. I and my cosin germanmy uncles sonne doesay grace, or prayse God.give thanks to God according to the manner: and my uncle himselfedoth thanke,doth give [thanks] to the whole assembly, with a cleere, or shrill. loud voyce: At length the first, or chiefe of the Syndicks. first Syndicke doth give publique [thankes] to the maker of the feast. feast-maker, in a speech curious enough. a very
curious speech in the name of the guests, and withall he chideth him. blameth him, that he hath made the feast. feasted with so magnificent and sumptuous provision. preparation: Yea (quoth my uncle) pardon me, I pray you, that I have not handled received, entertained you magnifically enough. sufficiently enough for your dignity: These things being spoken, or after they had spoken thus. These speeches being ended, all of them doe rise. rose from the table: a great part fare well being said. having taken leave, doth depart anon. straightway: the rest doe stay. tarry standing and talking together in the hall.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: What [did] you in the meane time, who had ministred. served at the Table?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: We betooke our selves. went to dinner into the kitchen, we cared for our body there quietly and according to the sentence of our minde we looked to our selves there at our leisure, and according to our minde.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Where was [your, or the master. our] Master in the meane time?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: My uncle had called him by himselfe. aside to talke together. to talke with him.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: I beleeve, that hee might commend thee and his sonne unto him of better note. (or care of you.)to take better notice of you.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: That is like to be true.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Thou knowst not what so great a cause the • e was of the feast. cause there was of so great a feast?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: What concernes it, or skils it my matter concerneth it me to know?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: It then concerneth mee lesse by so much. so much lesse.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Thou gatherest rightly. well, and I did so expect.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: But I am no logician. not a Logician.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: naturall logick is to thee. Thou hast naturall reason Logick.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: the countreymen also, &c. Even the countrey-men have the same.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: But goe to; tell mee in earnest, have I not handled, or received thee magnifically, or stately. intertained thee sumptuously?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: I had never bin present. I was never at such a feast.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I reioyce it to be satisfied to thy stomack. I am glad, that thy appetite is so well satisfied.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Thanke. Thankes be to God who hath given us so pleasant a rest, or leisure. vacation.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Let us arise at length, for I doe heare that the boyes depart, or are going away. the boyes depart from play.

O Tityrus, who liest along. sittest downe under the shade. covert of the spreading. broad mulbery tree, Art thou, or shalt thou be. Wilt thou be here alone, so merry and so idle, or retchlesse carelesse?

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: O Melibeus, GOD hath given us these idlenesses, or quietnesses, vacations, leisures▪ this rest.
That great God who hath made al things for our use, giving the proper meate. their owne food to a •• living creatures.
Who hath built. made the sea who [hath made] the earth, and the heaven, which covereth all things, that chiefe workman. that workman of all things, who is counted the chiefe.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Leave offto utter all in verse to versi • ie. to speake verses▪ I have forgot all poetry. now the Muses have left me.
My minde is otherwhere, I desire to strive for a drinking, or bever. with a drinking.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: But neverthelesse thou maiest sit downe with me under this shade:
For here (as thou seest) is place ample enough, or sufficient. roome enough to us. for us both.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Therefore let us omit verses, and let us betake [our selves] to our drinkings.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: it shall not stand by me. There shall be no stay in me; goe to, let us search ourbagges, or budgets, or scrips. satchels: untie, or unfold. open thine.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p:
wayte. Expect a little, tell mefirst. before what thou
hast against thy drinking?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Bread.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: As if indeed a drinking is wont to be without bread.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Verily poore men have no not so much as bread alwayes. not alwayes bread.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Thou admonishest in due season. time, our reliques, or leavings. scraps shall be put into their little almes tubb. basket.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What if there shall bee nothing of scraps. no scraps?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: There will be bread left. There will bread at least will remaine. at least bread be left, and this will be enough. But tell me at length I pray thee, hast thou any meate?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Yea dost thou doubt? My mother would never commit. admit that she should let me goe. send me to the schoole without some meate.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Therefore tell, &c. Tell me then what is it?

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: coniecture or ghesse. Divine.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I am not a Prophet, neither desire I to. will I weare. spend this houre. time of [our] drinking in trifles.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: at least thou shalt. Thou shalt at least make a tryal, what thou canst doe by ghessing, or how thou canst ghesse. how thou canst prevaile by conjectures, concerning which matter we have heard something already in the Rhetorick.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: There is either cheese, &c. Either cheese, or flesh is remaining, or the remainder. left of thy dinner.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Neither.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Tell me of all good fellowship, that we may gird. frame, or see. prepare our selves to the worke.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
That I may not writhe▪
vex. trouble thee any longer, they aretimely, or rathe ripe.soone ripe peares.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Sayest thou [so?] [It is] a new thing. a novelty, I saw none. I had not seene [any] yet this yeare.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: See now.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How ripe are they are. they?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why doest thou not adde also, how good?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But I have not felt of them. tasted of [them] as yet.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou reprovest me. reprehendest me wittily. sharply enough. Take and taste.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: marvellous. Wonderfull, how soft (are they) mellow? Of how pleasant a taste how good a iuyce. a taste▪

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Are we not bound to give iustly. Ought wee not justly to give the greatest. most hearty thanks to our God, so gratious. bountifull a father, who doth
give us being unworthy, so many good things,and so, or of so sundry sorts. so divers?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Truely he is most unthankfull, who doth no • so. doth it not.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Goe on still. Goe to, let us eate his good things, with reioycing ioy, and thanksgiving. giving of thanks.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I am a hungry already, a a good while since. good while a goe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But hast thou no meate?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: See, a grosse, or thicke gobbet. great peece of old cheese.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Let us eate peares first, wee will shut up our stomacks with cheese.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: But let us make hast lest peradventure the time. hour oppresse, or hinder. prevent us.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Surely I see neither of us to stay.to loyter: that which appertaines to me. as for me, I cannot eate faster. sooner.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: yet notwithstanding. Neverthelesse thou mayest not eate so greedily▪ devoure so, after the manner of swine. hogs: Art thou not any thing ashamed? doth it [not] shame thee anything?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Because thou saydst to be hasted of us. that we must make hast.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I sayed, let us make haste wisely. Maturemu • , but not let us hasten rashly. Festinemus.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I doe not make a difference so curiously. scrupulously, between these words.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Yet our masterw • l that we speake. will have us to speake properly, as much asit shall be lawfull. we canby the. according to our capacity, or understanding for the capacity of our wit, forwe learne together. we learn also to write wel by speaking well.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Contrarily, we use al • o, or we are inured or acquainted we also accustome our selves to speake wel by writing carefully. diligently.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: These two are conioyned. joyned together between themselves. But hoe, let us eat (I say) quietly, or taking us leisure. leisurely, we have time enough.to our bever.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Is not this whole houre free for [our] drinking?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Indeed [it is] free to day: but neverthelesse let us give over. cease, lest we want bread.[our] bread faile us,and there be nothing left to. and nothing be left for the poore.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Therefore let us goe to the pit. well, that we may potemus. drinke somewhat. a little. Hoe, thou doest abuse alwayes. alwaies abuse the propriety
of words, this is to sucke in. sooke in, not to drinke.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: In truth I have thanke to thee. I thanke thee that spareth me not. I got. I have gotten these first vices. faults of a naughtyinstitution. teaching at the fi • st entrance in the beginning.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Therefore Quintilian said most truly:These. these things which are worse do, &c. These same things do sticke more stifly, which are wo • se: hast thou remembred. Dost thou remember?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I remember: but in the meane time helpe me, that we may draw water out of the pit. well.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: strive, or indevour. Labour more strongly.lustily, thou suffrest me to toyle overmuch.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou wilt drinke so much more pleasantly.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Thou shalt drinke more pleasantly by so much Wee have drunken enough, let usIt is drunken (of us) goe into the hall,receive or betake our selves. lest we be away at prayer and thanksgiving.giving of thanks.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Goe thou before, whilst I goe aside to the wall. thither to make water.
I marvell at greatly. Wonder greatly at thy negligence.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: In what thing at length. I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: That thou doest not looke to. care for thy selfe more diligently.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Truely In truth peradventure I doe looke • o. care for my selfe overmuch. I eate, drink, sleep sufficiently,such is Gods goodnesse towards me. which is the bounty of God towards me: moreover. furthermore I combe [my] hayre, I wash [my] hands, face, teeth,
eyes, and (I doe) these. these in the morning especially: moreover when time requireth. serveth, I exercise [my] body, I relea • e. recreate [my] minde, and play with the rest: what wilt thou more?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Let us leave those. omit these things, those are not the things which I finde fault with. reprehend in thee.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What therefore. then?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Looke about thy clothes from the heele to the crowne,garments, rayment, or apparell. thou shalt finde nothing whole, all things are out of order, or slovenish.torn and worne threed-bare. Truly those things become not at all.doe not at all become your descent, or kindred stocke, if at least thou diddest respect, or look to. regard to have thy clothing. apparel to be amended, or to be renewed. repaired any way.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou speakest indeed whatsoever it pleaseth [thee:] if so be that thou haddest thy parents removed as far away as mine. so farre of, peradventure thou wouldest not bee more elegant, fine, trim, or handsome. so tricke.neat. If money did suffice unto me. If I had store of mony, I would not suffer my selfe to be so altogether. so very ragged.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Neither yet thereforedost thou want. art thou free from carelesnesse. negligence: for why dost thou not require. aske (to receive) me mutually. to borrow other-where?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: from whence. Where should I aske?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: If [thou canst] not otherwhere, certainly thou mightst of [our] master.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What if he would not give. lend me?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: He doth deny to none of his scholars of his house, or boorders. houshold scholars, if so be that he see need to be to them. that they have need.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I am not ignorant of thereof. that: but I a • so shamfaced that I dare not aske I am more bashful, then I dare aske of him.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: This is a rude. clownish shamfacednesse. bashfulnesse.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Neverthelesse I had rather be bashful than impudent.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Shamefacednesse as one said. Bashfulnesse (as a certaine one said) is a good signe in a young man, but a meane is to be added. kept every where.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I amof that wit. of such a nature. disposition, that I am alwayes afraid to offend any one.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I praise [thy] nature. disposition, but there is a measure in things: for that feare of of • ending, ought to take.to have place in filthy things. dishonest, or certainely in things unbeseeming.uncomely things, but I see no such thing here: It is an usuall thing in the societie of men, that some need the helpe of others. Who then shall give it. blame me for it. impute it to me for a fault, if I shall aske any thing of friends either to lend or to borrow?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: No man can finde fault, or reprove it. will reprehend [it,] unlesse peradventure thou a man will. wilt abuse such like things.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: But thou (asmuch. as farre as I am perswaded of thee. as I know thee) wouldest not. wilt not abuse [them.]

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: away with that abuse. Fie upon that abuse.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Therefore what hindreth now, that thou mayest not require especially of a most easie. kinde, or gentle. courteous man, & most loving of thee. most carefull for thee, or who much tendreth thee, most loving towards thee, as doth appeare?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Goe to, I will aske; but by a little epistle, which I will commit to thee. give thee, that thou maiest give, or restore. deliver.

sp.speaker: L.
