sp.p: In truth I will deliver it most willingly, and I will commend thee to him diligently, or carefully. earnestly.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Verily I shall not be a little beholden to • hee. shall give thee no small thanke, that thou hast esteemed me so. made such reckoning of me, that thou wouldest exhort. incourage me to this confidence. boldnesse.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Now it remaineth, that thou write the little epistle. the epistle, which thou mentionest. speakest of, [and] (that) thou commit. commit the rest unto me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: God speed. turne. prosper that well which we have undertaken. begun.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Doe not doubt, the matter will succeed well enough. prosperously.
THou knowest notewhat hath come into my minde what thoughts I have had. of late.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What [is] that,in these days. I pray thee?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I I thinke. purpose to set my selfe to the schoole. to betake my selfe to the schoole.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What unto the schoole? for the cause of dwelling. To the end I may inhabite. to dwell there?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not that I should dwell [there] as an inmate, or tenant.inhabitant, but that I may diet. live with you my Master.at my Masters table.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Oh I would to God, thou saydest.spakest this, from thy minde heart and as thou thinkest.truely!

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Thou oughtest to know. understand sufficiently by our mutuall acquaintance and friendship, me (to have beene) wont, neither to faine, not dissemble nothing with thee. that I have not been wont either to faine, or to dissemble at all. any thing with thee.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I have knowne fully, &c. I plainely understand this now. already, long agoe: but assoone as I heard that word. but that word being heard of thee, [my] affection snatched me. caried me violently into passionate crying out. exclamation, I did so wholly forget. I was so altogether forgetfull of my selfe.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I take thyit no otherwise. word otherwise: but to the matter. My father indeed doth not inforce, or urge me. compell mee: but I see sufficiently by [his] countenance and by his words, b that that thing to please him chiefly. that doth please him especially.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p:
Verily this is the cause this is that, [that] thy father being a most wise man, knoweth,liberall wi •• . that ingenuous dispositions are, &c. ingenuous dispositions to will. to be unwilling to be compelled, [but] to bee
led.perswaded easily: But yet • do not doubt, that to be done. but that, that is by the guidance, or direction. instinct of the divine power.spirit of God: but what doest thou judge?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I am of the same sentence. opinion; especially sith that I also hang incline to that part incline thereunto, of mine owne selfe. of [mine own] accord.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: [It is] a great reason, or token. argument, that counsell to be of God.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I have thought so I have beleeved it: for they who are compelled th • re unto of. to that matter by their parents, doe almost. for most part seekemeanes to escape devices.shifts, by which they may sh • ft • ff avoid, or escape.withdraw themselves from under authority, or command. government.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p:
I (that I may confesse itfrankly.ingenuously) have so many times proved or found by experience. had experience of it in my selfe: to wit before I began to be a scholar. I entred into the schoole: for what doest thou thinke? I did heare of these bond slaves, drudges▪
taken captives by Sathan. slaves of Satan, so many evill reports, both concerning [our] master, and also concerning thediscipline.government, that I might seeme to my selfe, to goe. to enter more truely into a prison, or intoa mill wherein to grinde as horses do·a mill then into a schoole: If so be that thou also hadst falneupon any such a knave. into any such a plague, there is no doubt, but he would have earnestly indevoured with hands and feet with all his power to terrifie, or feare thee.to fright thee away frō this so holy a purpose.revealed it, or laid it open.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I had. have made it knowne to none as yet.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: That thou speakest it to me.That which thou sayest to me, is not tomake manifest, or publish.make knowne to all.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I know [this] sufficiently: but that phrase. that [word] fell from me. overscaped me before I was aware, out of Terence. Now let us proceed to the rest.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What remaineth but that thou beseech. pray to God, and goe on with dexterity, or lustily. proceed diligently in [thy] sentence. purpose?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
Thou shalt heare, concerning
the daily victuall, food, dyet, or meat. provision at your table, concerning the familiaritie of the master. head-master and usher. under-master in hearing the repeating of the lectures, of the facilitie. mildenesse. curtesie of our master. the maister in the very living together. dyeting together, concerning that pleasant strife of studies after supper: of the freedome of talking together. libertie of speaking together of honest [matters] at meet opportunity. at our leisure, of the free reprehension betweene your selves; concerning all these (I say) thou hast told me many things • now. spoken to me sufficiently, at other times: all which things in truth do greatly please [me:] Yet nothing doth seeme to me, [to be] more profitable, then that continuall. perpetuall exercise of speaking Latine: for what greater benefit, or commoditie. fruit is there of our studies? what more honest? what more pleasant? especially when one doth reproove. reprehend another freely, without hatred or envie.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What, that they who are overcome in that contention. in the first of those things, are punished onely by shame, the victors also. but the victors are graced with a reward, or have a reward bestowed upon them. are rewarded.

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: To conclude, all your exercises do delight me marvellously, even in the very hearing.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How much more wouldest thou say that, if thou sawest these things, if thou wert present when they are done!

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: I (God-willing) will be present.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: would to God. I will [it may be] shortly, or every day, now within these few dayes.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Truely I hope so, yet I have onely one doubt. one doubt remaineth unto me,scruple. from which thou canst free me. thou shalt deliver me easily if thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p:
I will doe it in good faith. in truth. unfainedly if I can: but in the meane time, see that you doe not seeke a knot in a bulrush, as we
have seene before in Terence. Goe to: what scruple.doubt is that at length. I pray thee?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: your scholasticall discipline is suspected unto me. I suspect your schoole government. discipline in the schoole, not that I would leave off. cease from my enterprise for that cause. for that; but that I may come more cheerefully and pleasantly, when I shall heare of that matter.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Unlesse thou wert hee, who (as I know) doest neither thinke me vaine nor a lyer, I in truth had rather hold my peace concerning this altogether, then report those things unto thee, which I thinke.

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: Why so I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Because it is a difficult thing to make those things like to be true. to seeme like to bee true, although [they be] otherwise most true; sith that the vulgar sort.the common • ort of men. of people doth speake and judge all the worst things. evill that may be concerning these.

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: To what end (I pray thee) doth the common • ort so? [doth it] that?

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: For our schoole-government. discipline is so ill spoken of. doth heare so very evilly among those simple people. ideots, thorow the lies of wicked men, that it is a marvell any one to be. that any one is willing to dwell. abide in our schoole, although (which is the worke of God) the worse we heare. the worse other speak of us the moe by so much. so much the moe come together. come unto us.

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: [There is] no need of so long a colourable, or cunning entrance into the minde of the hearer. an insinuation: tell mee all things plainely: [take heed] thou feare not, thou shalt not scarre me. terrifie me. I perceive. I have perceived all things andaccomplisht them.dispatched [them] before with my selfe in my minde.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p:
Therefore turne thy minde to the matter. attend, I will speake. utter most shortly whatsoever I shall thinke to be of weight▪ shall seeme to be of any moment. First of all,I would that thou perswade thy selfe that our master to be. I would have thee to perswade thy selfe of that, that our
Master is much more gentle, or m • lde. courteous to us, then hee appeareth openly in the schoole: forhe l • veth, or carrieth himselfe.he is conversant so familiarly amongst us, as a wise father is wont [to be] amongst [his] children. Why then (wilt thou say) is he so severe openly? I answer, because without such severity (as I have heard of himselfe, whensometime.of a time he reported it. he made report of it to a certaine familiar friend) so great a scholasticall company.a company of scholars and indued with so divers manners. of so divers dispositions, neither could. could neither be kept in. kept under, nor contained in obedience. in their duties, for every one [would live] after his owne manner. fashion, each would live by his owne arbitrement. as he thought good. according to his owne pleasure.

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: Moreover I marvell with my selfe most often. very often, that there is. so great reverence to be in the whole schoole. thorow all the schoole, so great silence, and to conclude, so great modesty.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Thou wouldest marvell much more, if thou hadst seene ever. ever seen schooles in the village. the countrey schoole.

sp.speaker: C
sp.p:
I have seene them sometime and marked them well▪ considered [them] diligently. There is more silence in our schoole of six hundreth, then of forty boyes, yea of thirtie, in these common schooles, or meaner. triviall schooles. But goe on, I pray thee, I am afraid,
〈◊〉 lest 〈◊〉 be. that thou art an oratour of Asia. an Asian oratour: for now thy speech beginneth as it were, to to go▪ further from the purpose. erre. rove further off from the marke.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: but, Yea even thouthou thy selfe interruptest [me.]

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: I have said nothing from the purpose,troublest 〈◊〉 . but now pursue; or goe thorow the whole prosecute the rest. •

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p:
Wilt thou that I tell thee in summe, briefly. summarily? This private government of your house. domesticall discipline, although it may seeme odious to a few wicked
ones, yet it doth please very greatly. very greatly please the good and studious, for the benefit. commodity [of it:] for if the matter. state. government were retchlesse. dissolute, what could be safe to us.we have safe against the violence, or iniuries. assaults of wanton and malepart. saucy boies? what quiet, or safetie [could be to us.] rest could we have? what tranquillitie. quietnes of [our] studies [could there be] Therefore the discipline it selfe is a refuge to the true lovers of studies.sound lovers of learning, and as it were a bulwarke, or strong hold. fortresse,even as. no otherwise, then a haven to marriners in a tempest. To conclude, whosoever is would be quiet, a lover of peace. peaceable amongst us, and prepared alwayes to doe well, is most safe from correction, or severity. from the discipline. Neither indeed doth our Master that, that he may draw us by beating. blowes and by stripes unto the study studies. of good letters. of learning, but he doth indeavour to induce vs, leade us, or perswade us. draw us on by these things especially; by honest and liberall, or courteous. good handling, or dealing. usage, by good will,civilitie, or kindnesse. humanitie, gentlenesse, or easinesse of manners. mildnesse of behaviour, by benefits, to conclude by the love of vertue and ofstudies. learning: wherupon it comes to passe, that the greater part of us is so disposed. affected, that it studieth, or a greater part studieth. wee study to obey him heartily from the heart, taketh heed, or avoideth. bewareth to offend him, loveth, honoreth. observeth, [and] reverenceth [him] as a father.

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: Otherwise you should not doe the office.performe the dutie of scholars.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p:
But there are sundry knaves worthy to be beatē, who neither feare God nor stripes:worthy stripes, or to be beaten each houre. who also hate the studies of learningworse then a toad.worse then a dog & a snake, that I may use the words of Horace: severe correction discipline is added. used sometime (I say) to such, to wit, for very necessitie. because necessity
doth compell.

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: I have enough: for now I see whither. to what end the severity of your schoole discipline doth look, appertaine. doth tend.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Verely, that it may defend good manners, and that it may amend. correct or drive out. expell bad manners. the evill.

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: Truely I do admire this discipline, I am so far off from fearing it. it is so far off that I should feare it. And my Quercetane, I indeed doe love thee,kisse sweetly, or embrace, or am in love with. for this freedom. liberty ofspeaking.speech, whereby thou added more sharp spurs to me.hast given, or put to goades, or spurs, or prickes.set me on more cheerefully.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: but I doe humbly thanke our heavenly father. I also doe give immortall thankes to [our] heavenly father, who hath given thee a good mind, and a sincere judgement.

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: Therefore farewell, and looke for me. expect me (if the Lord shall permit) against the next week: farewell againe, and commend earnestly to Christ. commend our beginning. enterprise, to Christ in thy prayers, veryagaine and againe.earnestly.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: I pray againe. I wish to thee. God send thee a quiet night, and pleasant rest. sleepe.
What is it?WHat is the matter, that I see thee so sorrowfull, or heavie. sad?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: me wretch. woe is me wretch Wretch that I am! I am scarse able [or partaker] of my mind mine own man, I am smitten with fear.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: I say, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: Our master tooke us tardie, or found us faultie. taught us.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: In what, whether in theft. in theft?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Ah, not at all of nations. no, God forbid.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: In what then?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: In secret junketing, bozling, swilling, tipling. drinking together.

sp.speaker: T
sp.p:
A
unworthy. hainous fact!

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: me wretch, me wretch.Hoe, wretch, wretch that I am, what shall I do?

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: Alas, do not trouble or afflict thy selfe so greatly. Ah, afflict not.thou mayest not so greatly disquiet thy selfe; who were present with thee?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: Fluvian and Florensis, lost, naughty lived, past hope. O ungratious boyes, which inforced me. drew me thither!

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: Where was it done?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: in the chamber of Fluvian. In Fluvians chamber; that I wish. I would to God he had not risen out of the bed to day.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: how were ye caught at length.How I pray you were ye catched? was not your chamber locked?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: Yea, it was: but (as thou knowest) our Master keyes of all theroomes whereunto are sundry keyes, or such as whereunto there is onely one common key.chambers: moreover, we thought him to have tome to, &c. that to have met the brethren to day. he had gone to this dayes meeting of the brethrē, otherwise wehad set againe the bar to the doore. had made the doore fast bolted the doore.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: Howsoever the matterhath it selfe. is, it hath happened. fallen outGod willing, or pleasing so. by the will of God.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: I am perswaded so altogether. so fully perswaded: but we are wont thus for the most part, to ascribe. attribute all ourthings. matters, whatsoever falleth out whether good or evill, either to our foresight. wisdom or want of wisdome, or of forecast, or of forecast, or over sight. folly

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: By what, &c. Upon what occasionbegan you,had you begun this junketing.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: Those two, which as thou knowst well, are not dayly guests. companions at the table.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: delicates, or dainties, Junkets, I wot not what, were brought them from home, for theirfood, or provision.diet, which I would to God that they had perished by the way. been lost by the way.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: But God would not so: go on.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: And because I teach them sometimes by my leasure, or when I attend. at my leisure, yesterday after supper, they had biden. they had invited mee to this banket.these junkets against this daies breakfast.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: (It was) unhappy, &c.An unhappy breakfast to thee: but what? was therenot.no wine?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p:
Yea there waswine too muchwine more then enough: for they have se • kins or little barrels.rundlets
of wine in the cellar of (our master in our masters cellar.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: What [did your] master, when he saw youbanquetting or revelling so.feasting thus? did he not burne with anger most grievosly. wax exceeding angry?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: He was moved nothing at all, but smiling somewhat. smiling a little, I desire to be of this drinking together, or banquetting o • feast. I will (quoth he) be of this junketing, if it please [you]

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: O troublesome guest▪ what [did] yee?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: Wee all being amazed.astonishedwax dumbe.were speechlesse: for that being spokenhaving spoken that,he snatched himselfe away, or withdrew himselfe straightwayhe conveied himself away forthwith.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: I see all signes here to bethe worst.exceeding bad.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: who judgeth not so Who can judge otherwise?

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: behoveth It is very likeour master to, &c.that our master understood. smelled out the matter some other way.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: I suspect one There is a certain one whome I suspect, who hadshewed us. made us known told of us.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: Whom doest thou suspect? I will tell thee after all done. after the end of the matter.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: What helpe. remedy will you • inde for this mischiefe. evill?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: I know not, we are who feasted together. all greatly amazed, although those two my companions in banquetting, do seeme to be carefull nothing at all. nothing carefull, for they have a cause. an excuse ready. in readinesse.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: what can they shew. What at length.(pray thee) can they alledge?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: we went to breakfast (will they say) because. They will say, we went to break our fast, because in the morning whē the rest did break their fast, we were with [our] parents, who had brought vsnourishment provision.victuals yesterday.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: Indeed that is somwhat.something, yet they shall not escape so. escape punishments so.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: F
sp.p:
Because that ought to be doneto have been done openly in the triclinium was a chamber with a table and three beds to rest on after meatdining chamber: but not privily in the bedchamber. Also that wilmake 〈◊〉 more grievous or haynous,aggravate the cause that they have led away thee (sith thou art a, &c.being a tabler within) as it were, to surfeting:
which indeed our master cannot abide. is most odious to the master himselfe. to the master, yet thy cause is far the worst.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: Therforemy Florence.my good Florence tell me, what shall I doe?

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: Go to, let us conferre counsels. consult. bethinke our selves of some devices, wherby thou (if it be possible) maist beabsolved, or set free. acquit.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: There is nothing that thou canstmayest looke for.expect of me in that kinde: for neither have I a place of counsell. am I fit to give counsell,nor any store.nor have anyabilitie. meanes of remedy. But thou, (I pray thee) expresse the power or force of thy wit. shew all thy wit, to helpe me quickly: my minde doth hang to me. I am in feare that my punishment is at hand, thou seest sufficiently, that (unlesse somthing hinder) that punishment. it will be exacted after supper.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: that thing. That will not be done at all. be in any case. in any wise, for sith the fault. crime is not open publike, the punishment shall not be publike.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: Whether it shall be publikely or privatly, it will not be put off.deferred.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: Thou judgest rightly. aright.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: That is the cause, why. wherefore I have betaken my selfe. fled now to thy helpe.to thee for succour, if so be that thou forsake me, it is done. farewell all friendship.I am utterly undone;I shall be most grievously beaten. I shall abide most grievous punishment.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: Thou wast to betake thy selfe. flie rather to God,It hath beene to be fled. without whom no counsell dothavaile.prevaile; from whom also all helpe is both to be sought, & hoped for.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p:
The matter is manifest enough. very manyfest, and I forgot not to pray. I omitted not the duty of praying.prayer, before I came to thee: but nevertheles, that [our] most gratious. mercifull fatherwill that we use.will have us to use those helps, which he himselfe doth offer unto us, & give as it were into [our] hand: wherefore, I pray thee,by our most straight friendship. after all our neerest love, or neerenesse in love.according to our most faithfull friendship, that thou helpe
me now with thy, &c. by thy counsell. there is no time now to loyter, or slake. Here is not a place▪ no place of delaying, or of lingring, therefore bend thy strength, or power. forces hither, undertake this cause I pray thee.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: Sith that thou doest urge so earnestly art so instant that thou seemest after a certaine matter. a sort compell. to inforce [me,] I will speake from my heart, and trulyas I think.what I think.Art thou acquainted with.Knowest thou our masters wit, disposition, or qualities. nature?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: I know it (as I thinke) in some sort. part.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: Thou then remembrest none to be more gentle.that there is none more milde, then he; to them especially, whom he seeth to be humble, or lowly. submisse, and to confesse their fact freely.ingenuously; but hecan remit. will scarcely pardon any thing to proud andsturdy.stubborn [boyes.]

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: I my selfe have observed these things oft, or more then once not once.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: Therefore doest thou know what thou shalt do?what to doe?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: I pray thee tell me.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: Whilestthy matter is yet whole.all is as yet well, Icounsell. advisethat thou goe. thee to go aloneunto him.to the man into his study, and that thou use sentence.have speech to thisend.purpose; See, or behold. Loe most curteous master, I have offended grievosly, I confesse: but (as you know) it is the first fault that I have admitted. committed: for I never committed.did any thing before, which might seeme worthy correction. stripes: Wherefore most curteous. gentle master, you shall pardon this first fault (if it please you) to my accustomed, or ancient. for my former integrity. innocency: If so be that I shall doe the like. fall backe ever hereafter, I doe tell no cause. I will alledge no excuse, but will bee punished. beaten most severely. Thou shalt prevaile with him. over-intreat him (as I hope) by this or the like speech.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: O wise and good, seasonable. fit counsell!

sp.speaker: F
sp.p:
Use it if it seeme good unto thee: Surely it is such as I would wish. what one, as I would to be. have
given to me in an evill of such sort. such a like evill.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: But one thing is behinde. remaineth, concerning which I am carefull.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: Hoe, what remaineth?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: I can not speake so briefly and commodiously. fitly in the sight. presence of [my] master, as thou hast spoken now.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: Thou oughtest not. shouldest not be so carefull for my very words. concerning my words, so that thou holdest or keepest. knowest my sentence. meaning.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: hold it. I know it in a manner.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: It is well, write it now any away. in a grosse. plain manner, as thou shall be able. canst; and then we will conferre together: afterwards thou shalt learn it without book diligently word for word. to a word.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: There is nothing, neither more safe, nor more certaine then this; but what time doest thou thinke that he may to be gone to. be gone unto seasonably. fitly?

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: As soone as thou shalt see him after dinner, to goe into the a place where bookes lye, studie. library: for if peradventure, he shall go alone (as he is wont) to walke in the garden. orchard, then follow him straightway.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: What exordium or entrance. speech before. preface shall I use then?

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: There is no need of any other, then which (wee) all. all [of us] are wont to use at or unto him. with him.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: Master, may it be lawfull (to speake) a few words. may have a word, or two? may I speake a word or two unto you?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: God blesse. turne well. prosper well all thy counsell: now I goe to write [that] which thou hast said, and then I will visit. see thee againe.

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: be quicke. Make haste, for the houre of dinner. dinner time is at hand.
GRatian, thou seemest to me heavie, or sorrowfull. somwhat sad: what matter is it? what is the matter?

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: I thinke dayes and nights. day & night, concerning.of my father being absent, and I am consumed.spent with dumpishnesse with grief in the meane time, for that matter. cause.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: How long hath he been away?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: foure moneths hence. Now foure moneths.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Hath he written nothing to you in the meane while. time?

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: in truth. we have not heard▪ We have not heard indeed a word, since which time he went. since he departed.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: It may be that he hath written: but [his] letters either have fallen betweene. miscaried, or perished. been lost, or they have been taken by others in the way. intercepted.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: that is like to be true which. That which thou sayest is like to be true: for before he was wont to write unto us, whersoever he was.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: whether had he not gone to Lutece. Went he not to Paris this summer?

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: Surely he had given himselfe into the way, with that counsell. his purpose was to goe towards Paris. he then went forward with that purpose.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: I trust him to be safe. that he is safe.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: I also do not I am not out of hope. distrust: but my griefe is not lighted. eased therefore. thereby.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: What saith [thy] mother?

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: She doth lament. mourn almost alway. continually: thereupon it commeth to passe, that my griefe is increased much. double to me. doubled.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
But neverthelesse thou oughtest not to grieve trouble, or 〈◊〉 . torment thy selfe so very much: for thou oughtest it behoveth rather to hope well of him, then to afflict, or vexe. torment thy selfe so:
for what are foure moneths? How great a part is there of them? How many are there of them, who are away frō home so many yeares, being tossed in the meane time, by divers chances, by so many perils, [or difficulties] of things. dangers? But what do the hard haps, or casualities. chances and perils of other men comfort me?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Neverthelesse see that thou be not over nice, who canst not forbeare the indure the absence, or want of • ight. desire of [thy] father so little a time.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: I indeede could beare it with an equall mi • de. take it patiently, so that I could understand at least it to be well to him. of his heal • h. that he is well.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p:
to whom can it be evilly. Who can doe amisse who hath placed all his hope in God? for whether we live, [or whether we die,] we are
• ver. alwaies of God. the Lords, as S. Paul saith.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: Ido not doubt of the truth thereof. doubt nothing but that to be. that is most true: but such is the weaknesse. infirmitie of this flesh.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Therefore what should he doe who hath no hope in Christ?

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: I know not.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: But yet take heed lest thou offend God. God himselfe be offended by this thy impatience.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: I oftentimes. ever now and then acknowledge my fault and being humble do beg pardon. do humbly crave with teares. beg pardon.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Thou doest as thou oughtest. But heare, I pray thee, what hath come now into my minde.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: What if thy father have sayled into England. Brittaine for cause of trafiking. merchandize, or to trafik. trafick? for there is now the greatest libertie. freedome.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: What freedome doest thou meane?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Of the Gospel, which is heard there most freely.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: Saiest thou the Gospell to be. Sayest thou, that the Gospell is now in England. Britaine?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: The matter is sure.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: And [dost thou say.] And that idolatry to be driven away. is driven out?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: altogether. Yea verely.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: O happie newes. O glad tidings pleasant, or gladsome. joyfull to be heard of!

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Yea most joyfull.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p:
But
from whence knowest thou these things?thee to have been ignorant of that.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Doest thou aske from whence I know them? I marvell which is in the mouth to all people that thou knowest not that as yet, angle. which all men talk of.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: Thou wilt cease to marvel, if thou know'st where we dwell.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Where I pray thee?

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: In the uttermost. most remote you to have a dwelling or homestead house, habitation, mansion place. corner of all the citie. the whole citie.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: But I thought now before. that you had dwelt in the street at Molardus.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: We had flitted then. before had gone. that time that my father into a strange countrey. went far from home. out of his own country.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Therefore have now that most certaine. Know therefore now for a certaine, that that is most true, which thou wast ignorant of. knewest not before▪ and that thou mai • st beleeve it the rather, heare this besides. moreover. The greater part of the English. Britaines who had betaken themselves. fled into this city, as unto a sanctuary, for the Gospell, do flit back, or are returned. go backe now into their countrey fifteene dayes ago. before fifteene dayes.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: Oh my Ambrose, how much hast thou recreated, refreshed, or comforted. reviued me this day, with this n • wes. message concerning English matters, or newes. the state of Britain? what a medicine. remedy hast thou added. ministred to my griefe?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: So our God is wont to bee present to his in their greatest trials. extreamest straits.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: [It is] marvell except my father be. if [my] father be not in Britaine: for he complained very often long agoe, or of late, very lately. a good while agoe, that there was not a free accesse. passage thither, to trade, or trafick there. to go about merchandize.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p:
Moreover, a certaine English man. Britaine neither light, nor a trifler. no meane man, nor of small credit, shewed my father in these dayes. of late, that he had received undoubted. certaine letters from thence, in which this was amongst other things, all driven out, or who had escaped. All on every side. every where who had fled for the name of
Christ, to be intertained. received againe most courteously, in very Brittaine or Britanne it selfe. even in Britanne, and to be used most kindly.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: what is there. What [cause] is there then, that wee doubt any more?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: No doubting. there is no doubt. doubt remaineth (as thou hearest) concerning that matter.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: Onely it remaineth, that we extoll especially, the goodnesse of the best and greatest God. of God, the best and the greatest, with as great prayse and giving of thankes. thanksgiving as we can: and that we pray diligently. earnestly and continually, that he may not onely confirme his benefits, but also may encrease them more and more continually. dayly.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Therefore my Gratian, thou shalt remember. see that thou remember to commend very often. to commend the health of thy father to God himselfe to God thorow Christ very often, and that by mostfervent requests. ardent vowes and prayers.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: God grant he may so affect. frame, order, or inspire. incline my heart by his Spirit, that I may bee able to powre out from my very heart. from my lowest breast. the bottome of my heart such prayers. such like prayers, which he may vouchsafe to heare.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: [It is] a most holy prayer. vow, so that (which in truth I beleeve) [it proceed. be] come from the heart.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: O our God, the wonderfull. marvellous comforter! O how much doth the counsell and comfort of a true friend availe in adverse things. troubles. home the right way. in adversity!

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: But whither goest thou now?

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: I make hast * straight home, that I may shew these things to my mother the very first. very quickly, and may cause her to rejoyce exceedingly may fill her mind with all joy.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: God grant that she may be made merry in good earnest. thorowly cheared.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: I pray so. So I pray.
O Iona most wished for, be thou safe. O Jonah most wished for [of all men] God save thee.

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: And O most pleasant grape gathere • . vinteger Be thou safe. God saue thee.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: How the schoole h •• h it selfe. How is the schoole?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: the best of all. Passing well.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: are many returned? Haue many returned already?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: hardly. Scarsly a fourth part is away now.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: What is done? It is taught, it is read, &c.

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: they teach, read, write, repeate.they teach, they reade, theywrite, they repeate

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: These are general and dayly things, but what is done in our forme?

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: The same which is done in the rest, and which was done before the breaking up. vacation.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: doe they learne now? Are then the lessons had now in good earnest? in earnest?

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: (they are had, or begun) now, &c. Now eight daies ago: for what other thing should be done?

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: Wee were wont to be exercised by certaine, or some. for certain dayes, in repeating those things which we had l • arned before.

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: No other thing is done. was done for three whole dayes.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p:
what say you of the probation? What the
• osing. probation? is it now begun?

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: Alasse begun? It is ended almost: the sixt form shalbe examined, or asked questions. posed to morrow.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p:
O me. Me wretch, I am excluded from
•
praemium. a reward.

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: Yea indeed didst thou hope for a praemium. a reward?

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: why should I not hope? What if I did hope? it is lawfull for euery one to hope, &c. every one may hope, especially being studious.

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: I had rather hope for nothing.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: I
sp.p:
For if I shall get nothing. if there
shall nothing happen, there shall be no deceiving. frustrating [my hope] nor trouble. griefe: but if I shall get. obtain any thing I shall depute it in gaine. account it to be gained. gained.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: Hast thou never read, I have seene him who was about to die. [him] to live in hope, who was about to die?
Yea I have read it usually, commonly. oft, and I remember it. I do remember it: but this [is] nothing to the purpose.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: Because Ovid speakes there, of that hope, which is to be retained. kept in adversitie: which sence our Cato hath expressed in these two verses together of one matter. this distich.

lg.l: Doe not cast downe thy minde in adversity▪
keepe hope, or hope still. Retain hope: onely hope doth leave a man nei • her in death, or no not in death. doth not leave a man in death.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: Hopest thou then for nothing?

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: I hope for life eternall. everlasting.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: Thou saydest even now that we were to trust only in adverse things. in adversity: What are adverse things to thee. what doest thou account adversities. adversitie?

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: Those things which oppugne me, or trouble me. doe fight against me daily.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: What are those things. those at length. I pray thee?

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: [mine] owne flesh, Satan and wicked men, who affect me with iniuries. who do injure me.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: Since when. what time art thou made a young divine, or novice in divinity. smattering divine?

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: I am neither divine nor smatter in divinity, but I say that which I have learned. but what I say that I have learned out of the holy sermons.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: I indeed doe praise thee: but goe to, tell me in good earnest, is the examination, or posing. probation of our forme past. done?

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: think it now to be spoken to thee.Now thinke c that I speak to thee in good earnest.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: It grieveth me me not to haue been present. that I was not present.

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: Thou shouldest have come sooner: what didst thou?

sp.speaker: D
sp.p:
My mother compelled
me to expect.to tarry the end of the vintage.

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: I beleeve it, but thou was enforced. hast been compelled by thine owne will.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: That I may cō fesse frankly. ingenuously, I tarried willingly. But what meanest thou? we are men, as they say

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: Yea [we are] children or lads. boyes.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: But thou canst scarse beleeve how pleasant it is, to practice husbandrie, or to play the country man. to dwell in the countrey, especially where there is so great store. abundance of all fruits.

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: Is there to you, &c. Have you great increase, store. plenty of wine?

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: there i • . [we have] indeed so great store that I doe not remember me have seene. that I have seene greater.

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: What say the countrey men in this so great abundance. plenty?

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: Theyspeak, or talke of. crack of no other thing then. but drinking and drinkings, or eating unsatiably. surfeting: moreover they abuse wine now even so, in like manner. even as it were fountaine water, or well water. spring water

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: p That is the madnesse of the foolish such is. common sort. people, that it never knoweth. that they never know to use the gifts, or blessings. benefits of God rightly. aright.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: Verely that is it which is said: foolish men have never understanding. Fooles are never wise, except intrialls. straights.

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: Therfore they are punished worthily. deservedly.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: what may we say?What, that they doe also mock at admonitions?

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: There are [some] who can beare no [admonition] at all; but they are • ngry even at at [men] [others] admonishing [them] well and milde • ly. gently.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: But I will tell. [But] heare something [yet] more worse grievous: there have beene who would threaten stripes, or strokes to me. threaten to beat me, when I admonished them most kindly.curteously.

sp.speaker: I
sp.p:
This is not▪ newes. no newes to me: for also a certaine one some time, menaced his fist to me, or offered me his fist for one also of a time, offered me a blow with his fist. held vp his fist against me▪ that had he not feared but that he feared the authority of my father, truely I had been beaten most sharpely. most
grievously, or pitifully. soundly.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: But let us omit them. let them alone, because they are blind, neither yet do they understand themselves to be such. that they are such. They brag themselves to know, that they know very well what the Gospell is, when intruth they are against. adversaries to the Gospell.

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: If they heare not the ministers of the divine word. of the word of God and their owne pastours, how doest thou thinke it to be able to be. that it can bee that they will. can heare us?

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: Therefore let us follow that which Christ hath commanded; Doe not give [that which is] holy to dogs.

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: But there are some simple and well willers. well willing, who are delighted marvellously. in a marvellous manner, with the hearing of the divine word. of Gods word, these are they whom it is a most pleasant thing to teach.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: How doe I rejoyce as oft as I light vpon, or meet with. I fall upon such▪ How much doe I make of them. How doe I embrace them willingly. gladly▪

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: Nor without cause. undeservedly, for when thou hast taught them shalt teach them, then at length thou
doest enjoy.shalt enjoy the fruit of thy labour, not without the greatest. exceeding pleasure.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: But what do we think? doest thou not see how the night hath almost overtaken us. oppressed us.

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: Therefore let us depart, and we will talke. deale together to morrow (if GOD shall permit) in moe words concerning the repeating of our studies cheerefully. more largely, of going againe cheerfully to our studies.
Is thy father come▪ THy father (as I have heard) is returned out of France.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: he hath returned. He is returned indeede.

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: * When?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: Upon monday at night. at evening.

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: Was not his comming troublesome. grievous to thee?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: What grievous? yea truly, it was most gladsome, or welcome. pleasant: but why doest thou aske that?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: Because peradventure he being absent there is power to thee of living more freely. when he is absēt, thou hast power to live more at thy libertie.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: I know not what libertie thou shewest unto me, or meanest. tellest me of.

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: Of drinking, playing, running up and downe.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: therefore dost thou thinke me to do no other thing. Doest thou thinke then that I doe nothing else, when. whilst [my] father is away?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: All almost, or for most part. in a manner are wont [to do] so.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: Indeed dissolute [boyes] [are wont so] for what appertaines to me. as much as concernes me.But as for me, I live so when my father is away▪ as when he is present. my father being absent as he being present. in my fathers absence, as in his presence. I do not drinke unmeasureably, but I drink as much as is sufficient. I play when time doth require. I do not runne up and downe, but I goe into the publique. abroad with the good leave of my mother. my mothers good liking, when I haue any businesse.

sp.speaker: R
sp.p:
Yea, art thou
• o exceedingly, or so submisse. so subject to thy mother?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p:
I am subject alike. equally▪ Even as to my father: for what doest thou thinke? Is not the precept. commandement of the Lord alike. equall concerning
• ither. both?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p:
Honour (quoth
he) thy father and thy mother.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: What [saith] that Cato. heathen author of the morall distichs?

lg.l:
Love thy deare parents not with sicke, or fainting godlinesse. with n •
constrained, or grudging. repining piety.

and see thou doe not offend. Neither offend thy mother whilst thou wil • be obedient.
good. dutifull to thy father. father.

sp.p: What [saith] our Apostle. our Paul? Children (quoth he) obey your parents in the Lord. Are not the father and mother contained under the name of a parent?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: This is observed of Latine authors.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: Moreover, if there were to be had. were any difference of reverence, more might seeme to be due, or owing. there might see me more to be due by the best right, unto the mothers, as who have undergone. indured so great griefes and labours, paines. travels for us.

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: I have knowne. I know these things, and all things which thou hast said do please me.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: Therfore why didst thou gainsay me. resist me?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: That by that repugnance, contradictions. resistance (as it were) I might send for, or cause. procure to us matter of speech: for (as thou thy selfe knowest) our master doth exhort us oftentimes, that we bestow our vacation, or idle time. spare time in such like speeches.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: Truely it is a good leisure, which is consumed. spent in honest businesse.

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: Hither appertaines that Apotheg. grave and wise speech of Scipio. Africane, who said, himselfe never to be lesse idle. that he was never lesse idle, thē when he was at leasure. free from businesse idle, as we have learned out of Cicero. Tully.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: But now time doth put us in minde. admonish, that we make an end. put an end to this speech.

sp.speaker: R
sp.p:
Thou admonishest well, for peradventure
supper is stayed. lingered, or hindred for thee. stayeth at home for thee.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: I will adjoyne, or speake.adde more (if the Lord shall permit) in. at our next meeting. I pray to thee a prosperous night. God give thee a good night.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: And I pray to thee a pleasant rest thorow [all] thy And I wish thee most sweet rest, through [thy] members, or joynts. limmes.
I Cannot sufficiently marvell maruell enough. that thou art not more diligent.thee not to be more diligent.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: wherein. In what thing do I seeme to thee [to be] negligent?

sp.speaker: N
sp.p: That [thou] never almost art present. art almost never present in time in the morning, and therupon it commeth to passe, that thou artset in roule. noted almost. welneere daily in the catalogue. bill: why a • t thou so drowsie. sleepie?

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: My nature doth beare, or covet 〈◊〉 , or carry me so. doth so require.

sp.speaker: N
sp.p: Correct this nature; that is. I meane this vice fault of nature: what hath the saying of our Cato fault. done thee good?profited thee?

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: What [saying] I pray thee?

sp.speaker: N
sp.p: be more watchfull continually. Watch more alwayes continually, neither. and be not given to sleepe, &c.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: [Adde] no moe [words] Say no more, I remember it well.

sp.speaker: N
sp.p:
It profiteth nothing to remember it,Say no more. unles thou
• it it make use of it. apply it to thy use.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: God grant we may translate or transfer. apply▪ turn both this and other good & profitable. wholsome precept • so easily to the use of living well, as we lea • ne them without booke easily. we learne them easily. quickly without book.

sp.speaker: N
sp.p:
That I may conf • sse the truth, it is more easy by much. much more easie to give precepts. to command,
then to performe. But yet. But neverthelesse we ought to indeavour that wee may profit somewhat both by admonitions and by prayers or entreaties. either by admonitions, or by prayers, and may escape, grow, or prove. become better every day.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: The welfare, estate, or case. salvation of him. of that [man] who doth not that is to be despaired of: But nothing is corrected more hardly. more hardly amended then a naturall vice. a fault in nature.

sp.speaker: N
sp.p: All vices almost are naturall unto us, and unlesse the goodnesse of God did keepe us, all of us should be most wicked.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: Therefore what is to bee done?

sp.speaker: N
sp.p: It is to be fought. Wee must fight valiantly with our vices.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: who being Captaine. Under what captain?

sp.speaker: N
sp.p: God himselfe.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: With what weapons?

sp.speaker: N
sp.p: With divine and spirituall [weapons.]

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: where at length. And where are they found?

sp.speaker: N
sp.p: In the Epistle of Saint Paul to the Ephesians.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: In what chapter?

sp.speaker: N
sp.p: In the sixt [chapter.] sixt.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: What if I shall not understand the place of my selfe. by selfe?

sp.speaker: N
sp.p: Thou wilt not understand it altogether. at all, I know well: but our master shall be to be consulted with thou maiest aske of our master.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: What if thou shalt bee present with me?

sp.speaker: N
sp.p: I will bee present, it is determined. I am determined: but the opportunitie must be taken. is to be catched. is to be taken.

sp.speaker: N
sp.p: We will consult. take counsell therefore of this otherwise. at another time.

sp.speaker: N
sp.p: When shall that be?

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: The next wednesday, if it seeme so. seeme good so to thee.

sp.speaker: N
sp.p: At what hour • ? At what of the clocke?

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: At the first one after the noone time of the day. noone.

sp.speaker: N
sp.p: Thy sentence. determination pleaseth me.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: Therefore let us now depart. let us depart now.
IS it lawfull to repay. to requi • e evill for evill.with evill?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: Why askest thou, enquirest thou? doest thou aske that?

sp.speaker: T
sp.p: That I may answer them, who gainsay. contradict me in this matter.

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: Thou hast asked shortly in few words. briefly; I wil answer most briefly: it is not lawfull.

sp.speaker: T
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: Because Christ hath forbidden it, and the Apostles have forbidden it likewise. Apostles after him.

sp.speaker: T
sp.p: What is to be done then?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: Evill [is] to be recompenced with good.

sp.speaker: T
sp.p: Is it not enough to requite good with good?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: Truly [it is] not enough to a Christian.

sp.speaker: T
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: For it becommeth. behoveth a Christian to imitate Christ [his] master.

sp.speaker: T
sp.p: What did Christ in that kinde?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: He healed him who hadfastned a blow to him, or a buffet. given him a blowe, he prayed for them who lifted him upon the crosse. crucified him, and he did many such like things. many other things of the same sort

sp.speaker: T
sp.p: Doth he therefore nothing, who doth rewardrequite good will, or one good turne for another. favour for favour? He doth asmuch. so much as the Heathens do.

sp.speaker: T
sp.p: What do they those?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: They love their friends, and they requi • e good will, or kindnesse. render thankes [to them] of whom they have received good will, or favour. kindnesse.

sp.speaker: T
sp.p: whether nothing more. And [doe they] no more?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: Nothing: for what canst thou expect more from them, who have not knowne▪ know not the true God?

sp.speaker: T
sp.p:
What
doe they to [their] enemies?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: They vexe and molest them, pursuing them. persecute thē by what means soever they can.

sp.speaker: T
sp.p: Is it a sinne to a Christian to requite evill for evil. in a Christian?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: If it be not lawfull (as now I have proved to thee) conclude that it is a sinne. it to be a sinne.

sp.speaker: T
sp.p: But (as it is said commonly) it is lawfull to drive back, resist evill with evill. repell force by force: which sentence a certaine new Poet hath interpreted. expounded also more largely, in these words: Lawes doe suffer to put away, or turne away. drive away force by force, and a wound by a wound.
What dost thou answer to this?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: Truly the lawes of the Ethnicks. heathens do suffer. permit it, but the Gods law. divine law doth speak farre otherwise.

sp.speaker: T
sp.p: What is the divine law?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: [it is] the same. The same that the word of God.

sp.speaker: T
sp.p: is whatsoever is contrary to Gods word a sinne? Is it then a sin whatsoever is contrary to the word of God?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: Without all doubt it is a sinne.

sp.speaker: T
sp.p: Canst thou prove these things out of the divine letters. Gods word?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: what else can I? Why can I not? [I can doe] nothing more easily.

sp.speaker: T
sp.p: I pray thee bring me [some] places of scriptures. sentences.

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: Dost thou not beleeve that, which is In confession to all confessed of all?

sp.speaker: T
sp.p: Yea truly I beleeve it undoubtedly.

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: What need is there then of [any] proofes. testimonies?

sp.speaker: T
sp.p: That I may answere certainely to men gainsaying. to [all] gainesayers. to them that gainesay it.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p:
Thou understandest rightly. aright: but because thou canst not commit [them] to memory forth of hand, or presently, or of the the present time. forthwith, expect whilst I describe them. set them downe in a little paper: in which also may be a noting of the places, that thou mayest
likewise point them with the finger,demonstrate, or shew. to whom thou wilt.

sp.speaker: T
sp.p: [It is] the best, excellent, or passing good counsell. very good counsell without time of meditation. of a sudden: by how. how much shall that.this bemore profitable. more commodious to me? for so I shall learne perfectly. without book at my leasure that I may have it in readinesse. at hand, as oft as need shall be. require. But when wilt thou give [them] me?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: come againe. Returne hither to me to morrow if thou thinke good. if it please thee.

sp.speaker: T
sp.p: At what a clocke▪ At what houre?

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: At the first. At one, afternoone.

sp.speaker: T
sp.p: I have enough: farewell in the meane time.

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: The Lord God keepe thee. preserve thee.
WIlt thou buy this girdle?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: Why should I buy [it?] One sufficeth me. is enough to me. for me▪ but thou▪ but why wilt thou sell it?

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: Because there are two to me. I have two.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: neither yet is it lawfull for thee to sell it▪ or that thou sell it. yet maiest thou not sell it unlesse thou wilt run into punishment. incurre danger of punishment.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: What doth forbid, or let me. hinder me to sell my things?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: Thou hast nothing thine owne as yet.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: Hoe, [have I] nothing. nothing? how. from whence provest thou that?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: Because thou ar • not yet of thine owne right. thou art not yet at thine owne liberty, but under thy power belonging to thy father. fathers authority: to cōclude wilt thou heare briefly. in a word, that thou mayest not do it?

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: I will. I desire it greatly, or earnestly, or with all my heart. especially.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p:
Concerning this there is a a law of our schoole, or a scholasticall law. schoole law: wherof
this is the summe: boyes may neither sell, or let them not sell. Let boyes neither sell any thing, nor buy, nor change, nor passe from themselves to others. alienate by any other meanes, without the cō mandement of their parents. He that shall do contrarily shall be corrected, or beaten. shalbe punished with stripes

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: I was not ignorant of that: but I would make a danger, an experiment. a triall, whether thou wert constant in observing lawes.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: Therefore thou art a dissembler.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: I see no evill to be in this dissimulation. dissembling: whether dost thou interpret? Dost thou expound it evilly?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: not at all. No truly: for thou hast hurt me nothing. nothing hurt mee.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: What if I had hurt [thee?]

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: I would had. have borne it with an •• uall minde. patiently, as it becommeth a Christian.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: God grant we may beare all adversities so for Christ, who suffered every thing for the cause of our health. salvation.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: Certainly we shall beare them, if we set. propound alwaies to our selves the example of him to us. his example, before our eyes.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: Truely that is a difficult thing.

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: Yea [it is] impossible, unlesse we be helped alwayes. ever by his spirit: which indeed is to be obtained by dayly. continuall prayers.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: O in how sweet speech have we consumed. spent [this] so little leisure, or breathing time. respite!
HAst thou praied any thing. at all to day at home?

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: Why dost thou aske that?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: Because thou wast not present at morning prayer.

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: How thinkest thou?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: I have noted thee. I observed [thee]

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: But thou art not a an observer. monitour.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: I am not.

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: Therefore why▪ Why then did • t thou set me in the bill, or roule. note [me?]

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: Because thou art most deare unto me.

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: It will grieve me if thou shalt be beaten.

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: What? whether have I beene noted? was I noted?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: Yea, dost thou doubt?

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: hath no man excused. Did no man excuse me when the a catalogue or roule was recited. bill was called?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: No man that I know.

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: If thou love me so greatly, (as thou saist) why diddest not thou thy selfe? hast not thou thy selfe excused me?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: What cause should I had said? have alleadged?

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: Thou shouldest had. haue devised something.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: had told a lie. Therefore I, &c. I should then have lyed.

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: What thereupon. then?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: But it is forbidden to lye, by the word of God.

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: I confesse it: but it was a light lie.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: Nothing is to be judged light, whereby God is offended.

sp.speaker: O
sp.p:
I cannot deny that: but he doth easily remit unto us these light [faults] for Jesus Christ, who is our intercessour and advocate; forhow oft is there any, or who is there▪ who doth not offend daily most often. very
often?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: In truth no man. none: moreover, we do pray scarcely. scarcely pray, or doe worke. do any good thing, in which there is not some shew of sin.

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: Therfore what should be done to us. become of us, except Godwere ready to forgive. should pardon easily? whereupon also we praying do say daily. daily, do say: remit unto us our debts. Forgive us our trespasses.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: We ought not to doubt but that he will remit, or pardon. forgive us: if we acknowledge our faults earnestly and truely, if we desire pardon from our minde. heart, if we trust that we shall be pardoned.

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: What remaineth,therefore. then?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: That remaineth, that we neither be delighted in sinnes, neither persist in them; neither that we commit sin wickedly, naughtily, malitiously. peevishly,knowing. wittingly, and of industry. of a set purpose: for there are over-many things which we commit thorow infirmity of the flesh or also thorow ignorance.

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: I do not doubt. I do nothing doubt concerning those sinnes, which we commit thorow weaknes of the flesh, what a one was as was the deniall of Peter: but how is it done? commeth it to passe, that we sin by ignorance?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: Concerning this, thou hast. we have the example of Paul, who writing to Timothy, in his former epistle, doth confesse openly, that he. himselfe, although he persecuted the Church of God, yet obtained. yet to have obtained pardon, because he did it ignorantly.

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: Thou hast satisfied me a bundantly in this example: for I also do remember to reade it, or to have read that. that I have read it, but doest thou know in what chapter of the Epistle it is written?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p:
In truth I am not wont to trouble my memory, in holding, or keeping. retaining the numbers of the chapters: it seemeth to
be enough to me at this time, to note some sentences as it were snatching suddenly. hastily, which it may be lawfull.I may commit to memory, if in the meane time I can steale any leasure, from the daily occupation, or businesse. imployment of our present studies.

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: I would to God I also could do that.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: What doth hinder thee?

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: I can scarcely satisfie [my] master in my exercises in the schoole. scholasticall exercises, it is so far off. so far away, that I can have any time for other studies. occupied enough daily. that any time can be granted to be bestowed in other studies.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: Indeed we are daily * sufficiently imployed: but neverthelesse these things are to be borne, as long as God and our parents shall see it good. as it shall seeme to God himselfe and to our parents need to be to us. that we have need.

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: therefore I.I therefore beare willingly, and tolerate. indure all such labors.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: With what hope dost thou tollerate them. indure [them?]

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: Because I hope it to come to passe. it will come to passe, that they are▪ may be the first steps, by which I may come sometime, or in time. at length unto greater. But concerning these matters, in moe [words] at other times: now let us do that which is instant, or the time requireth. is at hand.

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: Doest thou heare the bell to tole. the signe to be given to supper?

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: Thou shewest. tellest me a good token. signe, now I did. I did already feele hunger. feele my selfe an hungry.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: Doubtlesse, because thou hast pretermitted. omittedst thy drinking.

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: I would to God I could abstaine alwaies so easily from my drinking. from it, as I wanted, or lacked it. was without it willingly to day.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: But I cannot want it willingly. be well without it, unlesse I shall be occupied in necessary bu • sinesse.
O Most wished walker God speed thee. God save thee!

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: And thou most busie slow back. loyterer, God save thee.

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: My Stephen art thou very well? art thou in good health?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: Yea most rightly. passing well, which thorow the goodnesse such is the bounty of the best [and] the greatest God▪

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: In truth I am glad. I doe rejoyce from my heart, I am exceedingly glad for thy cause. and I do vehemently.exceedingly congratulate vnto thee this [thy] safe returne: where hast thou been this whole yeare?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: In Italy.

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: for what cause hadst thou induced thy minde to go, &c.Why resolvedst thou to goe thither?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: For the fame of the region. country, concerning which so many things are talked of, reported, or praised. spoken every where, neither art thou ignorant how desirous we are of new things. of newes

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: So it is compared, provided, ordained, ordered by nature. Our nature is such: but what foundest thou there?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: Truly moe things by much. many moe things, then I had heard by the report. fame.

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: But I beleeve thou sawest many things which thou wouldest not.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: to wit, or verely. Yea indeed abhominations. wickednesse: but that which appertaineth to the region but as for the countrey, it is a land most fertile by far. exceeding fruitfull. fertile, exceedingly abounding. very aboundant with all sorts. every kinde of the best fruits; chiefly. especially with most notable. excellent wine.

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: Verely that did smile to thee. please thee principally. chiefly.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p:
That I may confesse as truth is. the truth, it did affect my palate, or the roofe of my mouth. it did please my taste marvellously: for what one. of what sort saiest thou this our wine to be that this our wine is?
thou mayest call it truely weak, or base wine such as is drunke in each village, or country house. small wine, if thou compare it with that.

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: Thereupon it did offer it selfe unto thee, as a notable argument. as a goodly argument of praising God.

sp.speaker: S▪
sp.p:
A most goodly. notable [argument▪] for I thought thus oftentimes, O Lord God how good art thou, who hast loved vs even unto dainties so as thou hast given us dainties! for thou hast not onely created those things for us, to foode, or to feede upon. for food, which the earth doth produce. bring forth of the own accord▪ but also so many kindes of most delicate things, which if we take moderately, and with giving of thankes, doe both feed. nourish the body most sweetly. pleasantly, and do make merry wonderfully. marvellously cheere up the mind it selfe. O O Lord i •
in what wordes, with what workes may we set forth the glo • y of▪ glorifie thy name worthily enough O Lord? To conclude,my minde was so carried, or set. I was so affected ravished in minde, that I did desire. covet nothing more, then to have divine prayses. the praises of God alwaies in my mouth: but (alasse!) other and other. one or other cogitations being conceived. by conceiving euer new thoughts. comming into my minde ever and anone, that fire was quenched by little and little.

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: That is no New thing. newes with me: for very oftoftētimes some such thing is wont to fall out. to happen unto me.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: That is. Such is the unconstancy of our nature.

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: We prove or finde. try this by experience almost at all houres. every houre: but, at length, at last. I pray thee, what hast thou done. didst thou in thy Italy?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: I have gone to see, or seene. visited for the cause of my minde. for my minde sake some of the more famous, or excellent. more famous cities: I studied also somewhere. here & there. in some places somtime. a little while.

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: What cities wentest thou to see. sawest thou especially?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p:
Truely I saw many in my iourney, as I passed by. passage: but I being at leisure, or at my leasure beheld but a few. I viewed [but]
a few, at leasure, to wit, Gennes in Liguria, by the sea side Genua, Florence, Venice, lastly that Rome, which was called in time past the sea side. the head of the world, but now is the fountaine and originall of all abhominations.

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: Sawest thou not that great beast?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: I saw him the Pope.[her]incidently or by chance. by the way, when she was carried thorow the streets (I thinke) for the cause of a spectacle. for shew-sake, or in triumph. to bee beholden of all.

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: But (that [wee may turne] to the matter) I pray thee in what towns or at least in. in what townes (I pray thee) didst thou abide. stayedst thou for thy study sake. for the cause of thy study?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: Returning from Rome, I passed thorow Bologna in Hetruria. Bononia, a city of the Venetians by Padus Padway, Myllane, I stayed or was conversant. I coversed in every one of those townes, about three moneths in diverse sorts of studie. in sundry kindes of learning: for I desired to taste, as it were, a few things. a little of every one.

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: But. And whatstrange things. new things newes sawest thou in so many most famous townes?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: Doest thou aske? all things in a manner. Almost all things seemed new. strange newes to me: but it would be long to tell, or make report of all. to shew thee all things, especially now whenit is to be hasted of me. I am to make haste some whither. to a certaine place.

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: Whitherat length. I pray thee?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: To [my] uncle whohath bidden. invited me to supper.

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: Therefore I will not stay thee any longer: but when shal it be lawfull for us. when may we talk more quietly. at leisure?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: To morrow from din • ner. after dinner, if thou wilt.

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: Verely I throughly desire it. earnestly desire it.

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: Expect me then in my chamber at the first houre. at one of the clocke.

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: I will do it. It shall be done. the houre is fit for the drinking it is an houre fit for bev • r. It is a fit time for our drinking.
WHat, have you thought sufficiently of that which we we had done. we did. had speech of betweene us in these dayes. of late?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I have thought [of it] againe and againe. seriously of it.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Doth the condition which I offered, like you at all. any thing please you?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: The gr • atliest of all, or ver • greatly, especially. Very well.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: my diet or fare like you. What, doth [my] table, or living together. diet please you?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I desire nothing. [more,] [or I lacke [nothing in that matter. requi • e n • more therein.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Therefore what remaineth?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: That (if it be not troublesome to you,) you prescribe mee what works. services you will have performed unto you from. of me. by mee.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
That indeed is most equall. Therefore receive. heare the chiefe heads of your office, of which this is the first [head.] first. In the morning daily to care diligently. see carefully that all my houshold schollars doe arise early from bedde, for the reason. according to the time both of sum-and winter. in regard both of the winter time, and also the summer: when they are have risen. risen, [that they care for. looke to those things, which appertaine to the dressing and cleanlinesse of [their] body: last of all, that they bee present to. at our private prayer. The the second head. second [is] to bring them. leade them thrice daily. every day into the hall, to wit in the morning and before the ele • venth houre. eleven of the clock, and the thing. at three after
noone. To expect there (except I my selfe shall be present) untill some of the teachers. governours▪ shall be present. doctors catalogues recited. shall come: in the meane time to see some bills called, and prayer to bee said. Al • r. In like manner to marke carefully. to observe diligently, whether any of the doctors themselves bee absent from his owne forme, charge, or place. auditory: if any of the doctours. if any one [of them] shall bee away: to to shew me straightway, signifie to mee presently, or doe his parts. or to doe his duty for him. A third head. The third is to tarry. to remaine with the scholars of the house, or boyes with the houshold children, as oft a • they are not taught in their schooles: in the meane to institute. instruct the younger. the lesse to learne to read and to write. in reading and writing, and to heare the repetitions of the rest, asmuch as time and opportunity will suffer: to conclude, to retaine, keepe all in doing their duty. in their duty, to admonish, reprove, chide, also to breech▪ to correct with rods where need shall be. The head of his duty. to goe before them fourth [is] to sermons. leade them forth in order, unto the holy them backe in like sort. assemblies, upon the holidayes, and to leade in like manner to bring them backe home. The fifth [is] as oft as it they shall have leave to play. shall be permitted [unto them] to play, to observe euer and anon. forthwith, that they do not admit. doe not any thing,contrary to duty. besides duty and good manners, either in deeds or sayings. words. The sixth [is] to minister, or give. lay forth. deliver unto them of the mony which I shall give. deliver to you to bestow. put into your hands, paper▪ for paper, pennes, inke, and certaine other necessary things. necessaries onely of small price; and to refer all those things into &c. to set them all downe in a book of accounts or reckonnings, or of things a booke of expences. And that is wont to be done chiefly, upon the dayes of me • curie, and of the Sabbath. upon wednesdayes and saturdayes. The seventh [is] to be carefull for not to neglect those things, which shall
appertaine to the bookes. their bookes, apparell and care of [their] body: that is, to to require strictly. to aske. to exact sometimes of them a reason. an account of [their] bookes, and garments, clothing, attire vesture. apparell, to have a regard of -[their] health, and dressing. ordering of [their] body,other lik things. and other things of such sort, to bee cared for. looked to, and obserued, especially amongst the least. in the lesse boyes. eighth head, or duty An eighth [is] to teach the boyes both in my order, or under me▪ forme, and also in the other formes. the rest, besides the three upper [formes] if at any time need shall be. shall require. A ninth [duty is] to helpe me sometime, (if there shall be need, if need shall be) both at home and without dores. abroad, in private businesses. Hitherto you have heard what duties I desire. will have to bee performed unto mee. from you, and which I am wont to exact also of other domesticall undermasters. ushers in my house: notwihstanding I shall not. yet I will not bee so severe an exactor of them all, but I my selfe will forbeare to require of you. remit some things unto you, as oft as it shall be lawfull by my leisure or I can attend. I may be at leisure; in which I will do performe, as it were the part of a vicar. viz. one that supplyeth the place of another. deputy. Have you understood. understand you all these things?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Truely [I have marked all. I understand] all things diligently. well: bu I intreat you one thing, that to my memory to be renewed. to the helping of my memory, you give me a litle copy, or a memoriall. a little note of them;comentary. and withall, space to think of them. of thinking and deliberating [of them.]

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: How much time doe you require?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: One natural of 24 houres whole day.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: verily. Indeed I will give you two whole [dayes.] In the meane time (as you h • ve begun) you shall hold on. proceed to live together. to eat and drinke together, to diet. to table and to tar • y with us. stay together with us, with none your cost, o • charge. without any cost of yours, so frankly or welcome, freely as if you were at your own house.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p:
You
do this not without curtesie, or humanity. very curteously: whence it is. whereby it commeth to passe that you doe make me more beholden. binde mee with a greater benefit. kindnesse.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: You shall have the note which you require, after dinner, so soone as I can compose, or write it together. write it you, with mine owne hand.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: What if you should speake it unto me word by word. dictate it to me?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I my selfe had rather to write it, lest peradventure any thing fall from me or passe mee. over • lip me betweene the dictating it. as I am uttering it.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: As it lusteth or liketh pleaseth you.
HOw am I sorry, mee not to have beene present. that I was not present to you.at your repeating!

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Why camest thou not sooner into the schoole, as thou a • t wont usually. almost. for most part?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: O me wretch. Wretch that I am, I rose not in time.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Because none, or no man. no body did call me. awaked mee.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Who is wont to awake thee. to raise thee up?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Our Host, or his maid-servant. girle: but he being away. when he is away, the maid. girle doth forget oftentimes, or certainely. at least regards it not. doth neglect [it.]

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Where was [your] host?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: He had. He went forth Hee was gone forth to his businesse under the morning, a little before day. early in the morning, as I knew afterwards.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What [doth your] hostesse? doth shee care for. looke to nothing?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p:
What doest thou think her to care for. that she should looke to▪
Every daily. day from what [time] she hath risen, or riseth. is up she is alwayes intent. busie partly her little ones to be cared for. in caring for her little children, partly in other houshold businesse. matters·

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Hast thou no scholars [thy] companions. chamber-fellowes?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: [I have] none at all. None at all.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Ah unfortunate child. unhappy boy! who hast none to confer no one with whom thou mayest conferre, concerning thy studies.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: For that cause, my condition is most miserable, as much as I do judge: for I cannot study as I would, for • o great a company of buyers and sellers, who doe use that. frequent that house, and doe trouble me with noise, the whole day.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Hast thou not a chamber to thy selfe?

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: what am I better. What doth it profit me to have [a chamber?] for it is so neere joyned to the staires. greeces and tothe greece going up round like a cockle shell. the winding staire,that not in that indeed not so much as a cat can eyther goe up and downe,deed a cat can ascend or descend.. but I am troubled with some noise.but some noise smiteth my eares.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Certainely [it is] a great trouble.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p:
• ut that is much worse. greater by much, that above my chamber there is a very large a roome of many chambers under one key, or warehouse. common chamber, where wares are kept? whereupon it is▪ it comes to passe, that some great
• ardels. packs are either carried in, or carried out, at all times. at all houres.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: O the immortall God! how canst thou live there?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What sayest thou, to live. live? I in truth doe not live, but rather I pine, or faint I • anguish: neither do I seeme ever to my selfe to be well free. to be a freeman,except.but when I am together with thee in the schoole,with the rest of our fellowes. and with other our schoolefellowes.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: How doe I grieve for▪ thy course, or estate. doe I lament thy case!

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: it might be lawfull for me to dwell.I would to God that I might dwell with thee in these houses for scholars. scholars houses!

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Nothing shovld be more pleasing. pleasant to mee. but what lets. what doth hinder?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: The anci • nt acquaintance. My fathers ancient acquaintance with that my host.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Thou shouldest Thou oughtest to admonish. put in mi • de, or acquaint. tell [thy] father, of the impediments. discommodities of thy studies.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: In deed I have admonished. acquainted him oftentimes, both being with him. in presence, and by letters.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What doth hee answer?a fable be shewed.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: He is admonished. told in vaine: [it is] a • if a tale were told to a deafe [man]

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: what so.Why so?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Because he hath neve • been conversant. brought up in a play, or exercise, schoole of learning, and therefore hee understandeth nothing in the reason of learning. way of studies.if my matter were done, or were in hand.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yet I, if it were my case, would try all meanes, or leave nothing untryed. would moove every stone, that I might have my desi • e.
