sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What if the Master himselfe should write unto thy father?that I might be made partaker of my vow.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Thou couldst never perswade that to him. him that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Because he will not labour any man. wooe any man, that he may get. to get himselfe a number of scholars: for hee doth abhor both from all. abhorre both all ambition,a great company. and also from covetousnesse. covetousnesse.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Therefore what doest thou perswade me to be done. to doe?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I have one onely advise. onead • vise onely, counsell alone.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I pray thee doe not keepe in secret, • r s • l • nt. conceale it from me.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That. The matter is As • aied. to be tryed by friends.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p:
the same had come to me also somtimes into thy mind.I sometimes have thought the same also▪ but I never dur ••
make experience of it, or attempt it. try it.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What dost thou doubt?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I am af • aid that this will not succe • d. that this may suceeed little. it will have small successe.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: The issue of the matter is in the hand of the Lor • : but what shall it hurt us to try?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: In truth let vs make triall: for (as I trust) no evill can come or happen. fall out thereof. But I know not what reason I must use here. what way I am to take here.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Tell mee, dost thou not expect,may come in a short [space?] him to come. that thy father should
come Tortly into this city? I hope * that he will come now within this day, or two. very shortly.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: When then therefore?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: At the calends of Iuly.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: It is the best of all. very well: dost thou know therefore what is need to be done?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I pray thee teach me. tell me.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: See that thou speake withall, or talke with. thou speake unto two or three of [thy] fathers chiefe friends, who are grave, and honourable men. of esteeme men of note, to wit, that their authority may more prevaile with thy father.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Thou advisest [me] well: what shall I say to them?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Thou shalt shew unto them diligently, or acquaint them carefully. tell them thorowly of all the hinderances. discommodi • ies of thy studies.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Whether nothing more? Nothing more?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Thou shalt teach. shew [them] moreover how. after what manner it may be provided for thee. thou mayest be provided for, that thou mayest redeeme the time, which thou hast lost so miserably hitherto, with that host:it to be. done, or an end to be. that except it bee consulted for thee. thou be quickely, timely, in due time. speedily provided for, by that remedie,leave off. cease. there is an utter end of thy studies, and the progresse of them. To conclude, thou shalt not give over before to admonish. advise, pray. intreat, beseech, untill thou shalt perswade them. thou hast perswaded [them] that they promise thee, to deale earnestly. themselves to manage [thy] businesse earnestly with thy father. that they will follow thy businesse earnestly with thy father.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What if they shall refuse.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: it can be done scarsely. It can scarsely be, that all refuse. should refuse?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: It is not like to be true. likely to be so: especially sith they are most loving of me. seeing they love me most tenderly, and doe gratifie me so gladly in the name of my father. will pleasure me most willingly for my fathers sake.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: unto these Moreover, the matter it selfe will urge them, to wit, so great a losse of thy studies.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: There is no need of moe words. I using the helpe of God. relying upon God. relying upon the helpe of God will set upon [them] presently.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
but in the meane
time bee thou mindefull,leane unto or relie upon. that thou apply diligently. give thy selfe earnestly to call upon God. to godly prayers day and night.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: God himselfe. God helping. God-willing I will care for. looke to that, for my steength. as much as I can: for I know sufficiently no counsell to profit me. that no counsel will do me good, except so far forth as he shall helpe. but as he shall helpe.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: But now it is time that thou receive, or betake thy selfe. get thee home, left peradventure [thy] host be offended: what dost thou linger, or loyte • . stay.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: thinke. I bethinke my selfe lest I have omitted any thing concerning which thou shouldest be admonished. put in minde.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: If any thing besides shall meet [or come to minde,] • o either of us. come to either of our mindes, we will handle it, or talke off it, discourse, or conferre of it. speake of it to morrow at leisure

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Therfore my Benigne farewell: and I pray thee goe on to helpe me with thy prayers, like as thou hast holpen mee by the best counsell. most excellent counsell

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: All [these] things are proceeded. come of the Lord God, who as he hath given the counsell, so hee will give the issue. effect.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I trust it will be so: farewell againe.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: most pleasant Questor farewell. Farewell, O most sweet Questor.
is thy fathe • gone away so, mee not knowing, that it might not be lawfull for me.WEnt thy father so away without my knowledge, that I could not speake with him?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Wherefore camest thou not unto his Inne after dinner?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Because I thought that him to be about to depart onely to morrow. he would not depart before
to morrow.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I also did deeme. thinke the same thing, but he would not omit. pretermit the occasion, which had offered it selfe of the time, or presently, unexpected. of a sudden.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: unto these. Moreover hee remembred tha double metre. disticke of Cata.

p.hi: The first occasion is to be
too late which thou haddest negl • cted

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Hee doth keep, or hold in memory that little worke. so remember that little worke, that hee may seeme to have let passe, or sl • pped. worne out [his] age in it.spent his time.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: See how great the power of memory is. how great force. power there is of memory,first yeares in those things which wee learned in our rude yeares.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That is the sentence, or opinion. judgement of Quintilian upon this matter; the words of. whom. whose words (as I judge. I thinke) thou remembrest.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I remember [them:] but (that [we may returne] to the matter) what occasion was to thy. had [thy] father, that hee departed before then. the time that he had determined. appointed?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Certaine Lions 〈◊〉 . of Lions with whom he had came. he came hither to the Mart.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Wast thou present when he went?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I tarried for. waited for him in the Inne.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: from whence. How hadst thou knowne. knewest thou him to had changed. that he had changed his purpose. counsell concerning his going forward. going?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I was in dinner, or dining at dinner, when it • ad beene agreed they agreed, that they having dispatched certaine other busine •• es. certaine other busines being dispatched in the citie, they would goe to, or take [their] horses. take horse a little before the secōd houre about two of the clocke.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: that which remaineth, furthermore. For other matters, hath he done his matters. businesse sufficiently. well according to the sentence of his mind. according to his mind?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: So prosperously. happily that he exhorted mee vehemently. earnestly, to • ivine praises. to praise God for that matter. cause.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Therefore thou [as] I thinke, doest returne now having good store of money. well
monied.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Doest thou deride me. laugh at me?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Why should I doe that. so?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: For thy lust. for the cause of my minde. pleasure.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: As if indeed I am wont to laugh at others missedst far, or erred much. for my pleasure.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: But I did think so.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thou to mock wast far deceived: for it is one thing to jest, another thing u to scoffe. The one wanteth. a frequent. is free from fault, and is vitious, or naught. usuall enough amongst friends; the other is come almost. faulty and worthy hatred, even as which doth not a great proceede commonly of contempt.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Therfore pardon me.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is [thy] father hath he given thee nothing of money. no great fault. But say, I pray thee, therefore. hath thy father given thee no money?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Truely I did not aske. I asked [him] not.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yet he gave thee unasked. of his owne accord.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: a little. Somewhat.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: How much then?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: A very little.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Tell [me] of all love, or I pray thee. of all good fellowship.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Why doest thou enquire so greedily. earnestly?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That I may rejoyce to, or for thee. with thee accoording to the custome of friends. after the manner of friends.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: There is nothing worthy congratulation. rejoycing.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: At length acknowledge at length. confesse how much. what it is.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Onely five pence alone. But onely five pence.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Alasse, so little! O foole, who askedst not two or three silver shillings, or ten pences. shillings!

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I durst not.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: What diddest thou feare?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That I should he world altogether deny me. bee denyed all altogether, and that he would take it ill, or grievously. be offended that I did aske.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He would never had done that, so that thou hadst ad • ed a cause of given him a reason of thy asking.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: In truth I doe believe it: but what cause should I had brought?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Doest thou aske? are there not six hundreth matters, which scholars necessity, [or occasion] doth need. scholars have need of? • . I confesse there are many.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: And hast thou such store. dost thou so abound with all things, nothing is wanting. that thou lackest nothing.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
yea very many things are wanting. Yea I lacke very
many things; but which I may want easily. I can be well without. Furthermore [my] father knoweth very well. sufficiently, what things are needfull for me, for the cause of. to further my stu • y. for my studies, both for to living, or for food, and the attiring of, or ordering▪ or decking, or apparelling of my body. diet and apparell.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Indeed he knoweth: he hath many other things to care for. but many other things are to bee cared for, and to be thought ofof him. by him.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I believe there to be to him a chiefe regard. that hee hath a speciall care of [his] children.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But thou art removed too far, or too remote. too far distant from him.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Suffer me to proceed. to come [with thee] whither I will.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Goe to, I suf • er, or permit thee. give thee leave·

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: My father also knoweth not yet to be fi • . that I am not yet fit to handle, lay out, or bestow. to use money well.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Why not? whether hast thou not. hast thou not age enough and wisedome I am away. for that matter?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: unto that. I am most far from thence. that: Therefore my father hath commanded, or in given ioyned my master. in command.in charge to my maister, that he let me have. minister. lay forth unto me all things, fo • the necessary uses of my life and of my studies, to which matter. unto which purpose hee giveth him how much money is▪ &c. as much money as is sufficient.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Be it so.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Therefore if I should aske any thing of my father, hee would send mee backe straight way to my maister: peradventure also he would be angry, and would chide me grievously.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is an easie thing to beare. suffer a chiding, so that blowes. stripes doe not follow.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
It is an easie thing I believe; but onely to those whom neither shame doth move, nor any reverence of [their] parents. But I had rather beare stripes themselves then the chiding of my angry father. my father being angry Whereupon it comes to passe, that I looke to it carefully. take heed diligently lest I give any c • use of danger. that I give him not any cause to be angry: for that is contained under
the precept of Gods law. fift commandement of the divine law of the law of God.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thou doest as it becommeth a godly young man.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: The praise of that thing. thereof is not to be given to me, but onely to God. to God alone.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: To wit, from whom whatsoever good thing is in us doth come. proceed.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: God grant▪ Hee grant, that what good things he doth inspire to us. into us, we may follow the same. those with a most cheerfull. ready minde. But that I may returne to the matter, didst thou reprehend, or find fault with me. reprove [me] in good earnest, for that I had asked no money of my father?that.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: whether would I induce thee. Would I perswade thee to deceive thy father?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Truely it is not a thing likely to me:it seemeth not to be likely. yet. neverthelesse thou hast deceived my selfe. me.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Because thou didst seeme to speake in earnest;in good earnest. thou didst accommodate, fit, or apply. framedst [thy] countenance so aptly. fitly to the words themselves.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But what doest thou thinke concerning this our spe • ch, or talking together. our conference?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Thou hast given us a very fit argument, or matter apt enough. subject to talk of in this our evening respite, recreation. or leisure. vocation.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: And what our speech hath had. hath our speech had, which the observer. Monitor could had re • rehended. blamed. have found fault with, if be chance (as he is wont) he had espied us lying in wait for us. watched us by deceits. out of wiles?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Nothing as I thinke.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Truely. Indeed that is true.ij is true, which our maister doth oft beat upon unto us.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That the store, or plenty. The copie and skill. facuty of the Latine tongue, to be gotten chiefly by these things, by much writing. writing oft, talking, reading authors, by turning English Latinely. into Latine, and Latine into English.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Therefore let us exercise our selves diligently in these things, the Lord God being [our] helper, in whose hand all our studies are sets or due consist. are
all our studies.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The same [God] grant, that wee may set forth, or extoll▪ celebrate perpetually his benefits towards us, with true worship, or reverence. honour and ample. worthy thy praises.

p.hi: This [is] the worke, this [is] the study:
p.note: [both] little and great let us has • en this worke, &c.
p.hi: let us make hast [both] little and great▪
I pray that this may bee

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But hearken to▪ heare the clocke.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: It doth admonish us in fit time. fitly: therefore let us defist. leav • off

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Otherwise the sun-setting will setting of the sunne. make us breake off here.oppresse us.

div.head: The 38. Dialogue.

sp.p: [THat] cannot hold out long. is not of long continuance. durable which wants rest by course. due rest.

div.p: This doth repaire the strength, and doth renew. refresh the weary ioynt. limbs. Ovid.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Neither play shall offend. shall play in boyes. in children offend me [for] even this. this also is a signe of cheerefulnesse, Quintilian.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Therefore is nothing which can indure continuall labour. Quntilian.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p:
I see whither these things do belong. tend, to wit, that I may have you • orth. I should leade you forth to walk: but yee doe sing againe almost alwayes the same note. song, as your little birds are wont to
doe▪

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Maister what will you then that we say?

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Say hereafter every one his owne sentence out of the new Testament.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Oh, nothing is shall be more easie to us, for wee have in readinesse much copie, or plenty of those sentences in readinesse. a great store of them. Master will you then that wee beginne even now. presently?

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Indeed I will, sith (as thou sayest) you have such store.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Who shall bebin?

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Thou Honoratus wilt thou. Wilt thou Honoratus exhibite, or shew give a triall, demonstration▪ or proofe. an example for the cause of the honour &c. for thy honours sake?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I will do it willingly, but for for the cause of the honour &c. the honour of God.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: I commend that saying of word. speech, for Gods honour and glory is to bee preferred in all things: goe to. well, begin, if thou have any thing▪

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: except. Vniesse your righteousnesse shall abound more then of the, &c. exceed the righteousnesse of the Scribes and Pharisces, you cannot enter into the kingdome of heaven. the fifth chapter of Matth. Matth. the fifth Chapter.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p:
lying being put away▪
Putting away lying, every one speake ye. speake every man truth to his. with his neig • bour. The fourth Chapter to the Ephesians.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Children obey [your] Parents in all things: for doth please. this * is well-pleasing to the Lord. The third [Chap.] to the Col.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: Oh good proofe or trialls example!proceeding. see that your progresse doe answer: that is, that you proceed. goe on diligently for your after time. hereafter.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: He who hath given us the beginning▪ the same will give prosperous successe.

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p: we are to hope so. It is to bee hoped so. Prepare your selves, that wee may make hast to goe forth.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: We will be present most prepar • d. very ready presently.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Take yee every one his owne▪ cloke. his cloke, that you may goe forth the more honestly. decently. But hoe laddes. boyes!

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Anon Master. Master, what will you?

sp.speaker: Pae.
sp.p:
See that ye bring the Psalmes. Psalme books also:
wee will sing some-where under the shadow in the shadow

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: So our walking shall be more pleasant.
wast thou Hast thou beene at the schoole to day?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Where therefore. else haue I been? but what didst thou?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: I was busie, or imployed occupied at home.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: That fell out besides thy manner. custome: for thou art wont to bee away more rarely. very seldome.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: As seldome as I can: but what was done. is done?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Nothing at all.the master of the schoole▪

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Have we then remission▪ or r • laxation. leave to play?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Surely, or without doubt we have. Yea verily.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Wherfore?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: For this dayes Mart. market.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Who granted it?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: leave. the head master;vacation, or liberty. yet by the permission of the governer. Rectour.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: What did hee grant?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: whether for a whole day. Freedome from every scholasticall •• nction.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: untill▪ the setting of the sun, or evening. What, for a whole day?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
•• om the morning even untill the sunne
•• tting: although hee admonished us diligently, and indeed in many words, that we should thinke of our businesse In our leisure. when we are at leisure. in our vacation we should think of [our] businesse, lest wee shall come unprepared to the schoole to morrow to morrow unprepared to the schoole.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Therfore what shall we doe? [doe] we? Shall we abuse this time. leisure?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Verily that doth not become our age.doth become nothing at all.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Therefore what doest thou prepare • o doe?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
To goe to. To betake my selfe into my little study, or closet. my study: except peradventure thou like better▪ it please the •
rather that wee goe forth some whithe • walke an houre and a halfe.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p:
Should I
••• fuse? yea there is nothing which I will rather now.
〈◊〉 more desire, for wee also in the meane ti ••
will have some • peech o • learning. will handle some speech belonging to lea •• ning, and d withall wee will exercise [our • bodies.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Therefore let us goe withou • the walls.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: our bodie together. even unto th • banke of the lake.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p:
unto▪ This doth I like this well. much please me: but thou (if it please thee) shal •
please me greatly. tarry for me.

sp.speaker: M▪
sp.p: How long?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: S. So long whilest I goe to change my expect me. pantofles wit • shooes▪

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Where wilt thou that I tarry fo • thee?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: At the Franciscan gate.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: But se • thou doe not deceiue me.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Should I deceiue my friend,whether should I sith I know that fidelity ought to be kept even to an enemy▪ fidelity, [or promise to be performed

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Go • thy way, make hast. I will reade something in the meane time, whilest I wayt or stay for. tarry for thee▪

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Marrell, God save [thee.]

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: who saluteth mee. Who is this saluter?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: See I am come againe. Behold I have. am returned.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Hoe so quickly! Thou seemest to me to have flowne.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Verily my affect • on it selfe. [my] uery affection hath added or given. put wings to my feet.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Le • us goe now, God leading. backe hi • . the Lord guiding us.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: It is God alone who doth leade forth his, and bring [them] backe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Let us make haste: the lake is fa • enough hence. a good way hence.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: We shall dine better by so much. so much the better: proceed, or goe on. goe forward▪
